episodes.title: The journey of rational wonder - Sasha Zouev
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with author Sasha Zouev, who grew up exposed to but never truly believing in Christianity as a worldview.  He now helps others to think through their truth claims to be sure they are considering the evidence.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Learning that belief is often inherited, not discovered, which helps us reframe religion as culture, not truth.
• Considering the afterlife as a gamble that includes the high emotional cost of faith-based living.
• Realizing most Christians grieve death as if they don’t really believe, which reveals the deep cracks in their theological confidence and actual worldview.
• Observing how morality thrives without gods and that divinity is not required for goodness.
• Studying mythological parallels to Jesus that unveil the man-made architecture of the Christian gospel.
• Reflecting on childhood indoctrination that allowed fear and fantasy to sabotage emotional development.
• Questioning faith and opening the door to lifelong critical thinking,
• Recognizing that "belonging" is weaponized in religious communities that easily replace actual connection with a fake one.
• Facing the finality of death without illusion and having a deeper reverence for the present moment.
• Accepting that meaning can be made, not given, and that we have the power to define and live a beautiful life.

Many thanks to Sasha for sharing his story!

_________________________________________

https://www.amazon.com/Tim-Giant-Teapot-Sasha-Zouev/dp/1916345174/

episodes.title: APOSTATE: Someone who refuses to be controlled - Riley
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Riley, who grew up as a Jehovah's Witness but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of the JWs and other forms of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Being deeply indoctrinated into the Jehovah's Witnesses, where he faced the nonstop pressure of religious conformity and intense academic-style study.
• Having his life consumed by multiple weekly meetings, preparation, and witnessing, effectively discouraging career ambitions in favor of total religious devotion.
• Despite his outward dedication, never feeling an emotional connection to Jehovah, in contrast to his mother's deep, visible commitment.
• Staying in a believer for many decades due to mental conviction rather than heartfelt belief, despite constantly feeling like he was never good enough.
• Experiencing his first serious misgivings about the religion's wisdom and teachings when he faced major life challenges and unhelpful counsel from JW elders.
• Facing a major turning point during the COVID-19 pandemic, when apocalyptic fears from his JW upbringing triggered intense nightmares and psychological distress.
• Finding the bravery to express his preference for love and humanity over religious salvation, which marked a pivotal emotional shift away from the JW worldview.
• Being exposed to ex-JW content online and which moved him toward deconstruction and eventually a full rejection of the JW belief system.
• After escaping the Jehovah's Witnesses, enduring homelessness, disfellowshipping, and estrangement from his mother due to the JW shunning policy.
• Promoting the message that life outside of high-control religion is expansive, fulfilling, and worth embracing.

Many thanks to Riley for sharing his story!

_________________________________________


Connect with Riley!

YouTube: @Jexit2020 

TikTok: @Jexit2020

episodes.title: Bravely speak truth to power - Rev. Mariann Budde
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Rev. Mariann Budde, who gave the homily at the national prayer service held on President Trump's Inauguration Day and spoke truth to power as she asked him to have mercy on those in the country who are now scared.

We touched on many topics, including:

• How communities of faith and of no faith can stand together in the fight to protect the marginalized and oppressed, despite those in power working aggressively to harm them.
• Seeing that racism is being cloaked in the language of patriotism, and that white supremacy is at the core of much of the Trump administration's policies.
• Naming racism for what it is and speaking boldly against it instead of being swept up in the rhetoric and propaganda or being guilty of complicity through silence.
• The importance of opposing Christian nationalism and authoritarianism as we come to grips with our human tendency toward extreme tribalism.
• Defending pluralism and democracy rather than letting religion be a weapon for cultural dominance.
• Galvanizing our anger toward speaking up against injustice while giving ourselves space to lament the cultural erosion that is being orchestrated by the Trump administration.
• What Jesus would do if he were here today -- and how the Trump administration would treat him.

Many thanks to Rev. Budde for her public voice in these matters and for sharing her insights with us today!


_________________________________________

Her website is: www.mariannbudde.com

https://edow.org/about/bishop-mariann/

episodes.title: Insight for living WITHOUT mythology - Chuck Swindoll Jr.
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Chuck Swindoll Jr., who grew up believing in Jesus and spent many years in church ministry, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Being deeply indoctrinated into Christianity from birth and never being exposed to alternative worldviews or critical thinking until adulthood.
• Growing up with childhood faith that was a kind of imaginative indoctrination, where his relationship with Jesus was a cultivated internal narrative, heavily reinforced by community, repetition, and emotional manipulation.
• Being terrified by the doctrine eternal hell, which instilled a deep, lifelong fear that failure to believe would result in eternal torment.
• Deconstructing slowly as a result of physical suffering and psychedelic use, both of which catalyzed introspection and a reevaluation of previously unquestioned beliefs.
• Finding that Christianity had replaced personal responsibility with spiritual dependence, where he had been led to hand off his morality, purpose, and self-image to the Christian god, stunting his psychological development and critical thought.
• Facing a major fight with cancer, which became a philosophical and psychological awakening, forcing him to rethink the entirety of his life—body, mind, and spirit—and recognize the mental and emotional toxicity of his religious conditioning.
• Realizing the psychological harm of believing you're a sinner and that internalizing that as part of your identity shapes your behavior in self-destructive ways.
• Acknowledging that Christianity is a cult where questioning is discouraged, authority is obeyed without critique, and any deviation is equated with spiritual failure and damnation.
• Despite the personal cost, leaving ministry and family expectations behind, choosing truth, self-awareness, and integrity over comfort and conformity.
• Becoming a vocal advocate for psychological liberation and personal authenticity.

Many thanks to Chuck for sharing his story!

_________________________________________


Connect with Chuck!

https://www.youtube.com/@UCE6j4FUmP_jd_cIWUGzvTGw 

https://www.amazon.com/Elucidating-Christianity-Heretics-Triangulating-Dysfunctional-ebook/dp/B09GX9WPD8/ref=sr_1_1

episodes.title: Christianity is a mind virus of deception and control - Jo-Ann
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Jo-Ann, who grew up Catholic and eventually placed her faith in Jesus as her Savior, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a French Canadian Catholic home where church was a tradition rather than a personal relationship with a god.
• As a child, praying with rosary beads and cherishing a crucifix keepsake.
• In her teens, attending a charismatic retreat led by a nun that sparked a profound spiritual experience.
• Attending a Pentecostal church that led her to an intense conversion and deep Bible study.
• Serving as a worship leader and cell group mentor as she grew in her faith.
• Embracing faith‑based politics by running for provincial office under the New Apostolic Reformation’s Seven Mountains strategy.
• Becoming disillusioned as she witnessed financial exploitation and leadership hypocrisy within the church.
• Starting to doubt end‑times prophecies and see through scriptural inconsistencies, which drove her to question fundamental Christian claims.
• Becoming exposed to comparative mythology and many other ideas that further eroded her faith.
• Finding her beliefs collapsing, leading to loneliness, alcohol use, and a deep identity crisis.
• Briefly exploring the Hebrew Roots and Sacred Name movements before finding them similarly false.
• Fully deconverting from Christianity and beginning to reclaim her identity.
• Coming to see religious teachings as “mind viruses” implanted without evidence and passed on from victim to victim.
• Recovering her sense of self by disentangling from constructs, roles, and rules that had defined her for decades, and identifying how people in society try to control each other.
• Starting to help guide others through doubt toward honest exploration.

Many thanks to Jo-Ann for sharing her story!

_________________________________________


Connect with Jo-Ann!

YouTube - @jo-jotalks

episodes.title: The faith that was meant to heal me was actually killing me - Aaron Tomlinson
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Aaron Tomlinson, who grew up believing in Jesus and became a pastor for many years, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Turning to Christianity not because of religious upbringing but as a way to cope with overwhelming loss and pain After a traumatic collapse of his family’s financial stability and community standing.
• Experiencing Christianity as an emotional and psychological bypass as it offered him an identity and purpose without ever allowing him to process the original wounds.
• Deconstructing major Christian doctrines like penal substitutionary atonement and the Rapture long before fully leaving the faith and subsequently shifting toward Christian mysticism and progressive Christianity even during his time as a pastor.
• Never feeling at home among other pastors or with the authority and spotlight that came with the title "pastor," and often feeling like a fraud trapped in a system he instinctively knew was wrong, despite leading a growing and successful church.
• Realizing that Christianity had stolen his ability to live authentically, pressuring him to constantly strive to please an invisible judge and suppress his true emotions and desires.
• During trauma counseling, understanding that the very thing that was supposed to heal him — Christianity — had deeply traumatized him, especially the doctrines of original sin, divine wrath, and hell.
• Identifying as neither a traditional theist nor an atheist tied to scientific materialism, but instead, staying open to metaphysical possibilities outside the framework of Abrahamic religions and physicalism.
• Moving beyond analysis-paralysis into embodied living and fully feeling emotions without judging them, instead of just intellectualizing life.
• Raising his kids to explore belief systems freely, emphasizing critical thinking over dogmatic faith, and supporting them without any coercion.
• Finding purpose in helping others heal through mental health counseling, raising his family authentically, and living openly without fear — not needing divine validation, but creating meaning through real human relationships.

Many thanks to Aaron for sharing his story and insights!

_________________________________________


Connect with Aaron:

@newdayglobal

episodes.title: It's time to break the generational ignorance that is Christianity - AmyPassion
episodes.description:
**My apologies for the poor audio quality on this video.
_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Amypassion, who grew up believing in Jesus as her Savior but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Reclaiming her identity and experiencing a personal awakening after she fully questioned the Biblical narrative, leading her to reject Yahweh, whom she saw as morally inferior.
• Deconstructing her inherited religious trauma and reflecting on how indoctrination can emotionally and physically devastate families.
• Challenging the commodification of religion, especially in Nigeria, where churches frequently exploit poverty by commercializing hope, requiring tithes for basic church access, and preying on desperation through manipulative prophecies.
• Recognizing the moral dissonance in Bible stories like Cain and Abel or Pharaoh’s hardened heart, which helped her see that the Yahweh character is presented as unjust, unkind, and deeply problematic.
• Exposing the psychological cost of indoctrination, such as the panic, fear, and insomnia caused by the constant threat of hell and demonic attacks, which was in strong contrast to the peace she felt only after she let go of Christian beliefs.
• Rejecting fear-based control systems that are used to keep believers compliant and to create a “mental slavery” that thrives on anxiety.
• Resisting systemic religious elitism and injustice that is embedded in many church structures.
• Rebuilding morality on humanist foundations of empathy, accountability, kindness, and the principle of ethical autonomy.
• Celebrating the joy of the mental freedom and inner peace she gained after shedding Christianity.
• Advocating for communal awakening and solidarity, including a united, decolonized, secular movement in Africa that empowers people to reclaim their minds and resist spiritual oppression.

Many thanks to Amypassion for sharing her story!

_________________________________________

episodes.title: Halfpipes and Hellfire: Skating out of evangelical fear - Daniel Beck
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Daniel Beck, who grew up believing in Jesus as his Savior but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Being indoctrinated before he could understand the stakes through Bible stories and constant warnings about Hell, demons, and an all-seeing god character that brought on fear and guilt.
• Experiencing terror, nightmares, and anxiety that persisted into adulthood due to religious conditioning, where even falling leaves and shadows became possible demonic manifestations.
• Despite wandering into "worldly" activities, never fully letting go of Jesus, often whispering secret prayers and remaining terrified of divine judgment.
• Seeing what he thought might be a miracle, which reinforced the idea that Jesus had intervened directly and solidified his faith.
• In Bible college, pursuing deeper truth and structure but beginning instead to see cracks in Christian theology, such as Jesus possibly sinning as a child and the arbitrary moral standards of scripture.
• Moving deeper into deconstruction when he saw a Korean Christian cult using deceptive tactics which he recognized in his own evangelical past, realizing the manipulation he once viewed as sincere ministry.
• Studying and reflecting on his religious trauma, especially the psychological manipulation that kept him afraid to even think critical thoughts, as if doubt alone might condemn him to Hell.
• Comparing his belief in god to a molested child clinging to an imaginary superhero, illustrating how the trauma-based attachment to a divine figure masks a deep-seated loss of autonomy.
• Finding freedom when he realized all the “miracles” and spiritual feelings were just him, not divine intervention, that he was the one who acted, who prayed, who felt, and who grew.
• Enjoying the beauty of a life liberated from fear of Hell, rejection, guilt, and spiritual gaslighting, and being finally able to trust his own judgment and enjoy being "enough" just as he is.

Many thanks to Daniel for sharing his story!

episodes.title: Reclaiming my identity after leaving Mormonism - Ashley Buckner
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Ashley Buckner, who grew up as a Mormon believer but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Mormonism and Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in an atypical Mormon family, which created an early awareness that her home life wasn’t quite aligned with the expected religious blueprint.
• Being inundated with the extreme patriarchal nature of Mormonism where women’s roles were limited and male authority defined her access to God.
• Taking her faith seriously from a young age but still feeling like she was always falling short of an impossible standard.
• Absorbing purity culture and modesty messaging that left her disconnected her from her body.
• Constantly fearing eternal consequences for thinking wrong thoughts as she believed that both god and Satan were watching her at all times.
• Being haunted by teachings about hell and eternal separation from her family, thinking that if she didn’t get everything just right, she might end up alone while her family was in heaven.
• Hearing that her feelings and instincts were dangerous and could not be trusted.
• Learning perfectionism as a survival mechanism for the constant internal pressure to measure up spiritually.
• Spending years wondering if she was not chosen and was instead predestined to fall away.
• Having experiences and friendships in college that exposed her to new perspectives and gave her the space to start becoming her own person.
• Deconstructing and deconverting from the Mormon / Christian worldview.
• Realizing that her nervous system had been shaped by fear, judgment, and divine surveillance which had created a chronic vigilance that had shaped her sense of self and safety.
• Understanding how harmful spiritual environments don't just affect belief systems, they also alter our nervous systems and keep people stuck in fight, flight, or freeze modes long after they've left their religion.
• Learning to gently unravel layers of shame stemming from belief systems and deeply tied to emotional memories and body-based experiences.
• Integrating her love for movement into her recovery process as she reframed her body as a space of joy, agency, and connection.
• Using both her professional training and her personal journey to hold space for others who are unpacking spiritual trauma, healing, and reclaiming their lives.

Many thanks to Ashley for sharing her story!


_________________________________________

episodes.title: When I understood the trauma that Christianity caused - Keisha Kiger
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Keisha Kiger, who grew up believing in Jesus but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Being raised in a strict Christian household where she came to believe that all non-Christians were inherently aligned with the devil and headed to hell.
• Discovering Santa Claus was a myth, which made her question whether Jesus was real, sparking a lifelong analytical approach to her epistemology.
• Developing obsessive-compulsive tendencies rooted in Christianity, from a young age, as she feared that stray thoughts could condemn her and believed that both god and Satan were constantly watching her.
• Being haunted by the doctrine of hell, leading to intense anxiety and a deep fear that she might be eternally separated from her family.
• Internalizing purity culture from a young age, ensuring she dressed modestly to avoid tempting men, which contributed to an unhealthy self-image and fear of her own body.
• Being disturbed by the idea that god placed believers in difficult situations as divine tests, making morality feel like an impossible guessing game between god and Satan.
• Seeing that religious leaders and parents pushed Christianity as unquestionable truth, often dismissing doubts as sinful, which fueled her growing skepticism.
• Recognizing that Yahweh’s behavior in the Bible mirrored that of toxic parents who manipulate and abuse their children.
• Doing research over many years that culminated in her fully escaping Christianity.
• Finding immense freedom as she let go of the concept of hell.
• Pursuing joy in simple pleasures and philosophical inquiry as she focuses on the power of curiosity and critical thinking in breaking free from religious trauma.

Many thanks to Keisha for sharing her story!

episodes.title: The Bible is the death knell of Christianity - Sharice Katcha
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Sharice Katcha, who grew up believing in Jesus but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Internalizing Christianity as both a source of hope and a looming threat, with early indoctrination into the fear of hell defining much of her belief system.
• Facing a Christianity that demanded absolute control over every aspect of life, with little room left for personal identity or autonomy.
• As a child diagnosed with autism, being particularly susceptible to the rigid structures of faith, which promised certainty but instead isolated her from reality and healthy development.
• Hearing the messages that her body was dangerous, that she was a "stumbling block" to men, and that sexuality was inherently sinful, which created a cycle of shame.
• Seeing religious authority figures wield power through fear, intimidation, and manipulation rather than through wisdom, reason, or compassion.
• Reading the Bible critically, especially the passages about slavery, genocide, and misogyny, which made it impossible to believe that it was divinely inspired and ultimately shattered her faith.
• Realizing that Christian fundamentalism thrives on controlling narratives, rewriting history, and oppressing others.
• Concluding that the silence of "god" in the face of atrocities and injustices demonstrated that humanity operates alone, and that we must create our own meaning, justice, and kindness.
• Leaving faith and reclaiming her personal sovereignty as she embraced her freedom to be fully herself without fearing divine judgment.
• Breaking generational cycles of trauma by rejecting corporal punishment, misogyny, and raising her children with respect, critical thinking, and personal autonomy.

Many thanks to Sharice for sharing her story!

_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Katrina Richard, who grew up believing in Jesus but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a conservative homeschooling Christian family that severely controlled, abused, shamed, and sheltered the children.
• Being overly sexualized as a child and being pushed to consider marriage early.
• Facing intense purity culture and gender role restrictions.
• Being driven to give her life to Jesus, forsake everything else for him, and be willing to die for him.
• Seeing her parents adopt a lifestyle of Messianic Judaism.
• Questioning why god was allowing so many horrifically traumatic things to happen in her life.
• Dealing with accusations of being demonically possessed due to her asking hard questions.
• Despite deconstructing, trying to save her faith by evolving toward a more progressive and charismatic perspective.
• Understanding the connection between the psychopathic nature of the Yahweh character and the hyper abusive nature of Christian parents.
• Becoming horrified at the genocide perpetrated by Israel against Gaza in recent years.
• Along with her husband, deconverting from Christianity and beginning the process of reclaiming her identity and healing from religious trauma.

Many thanks to Katrina for sharing her story!

episodes.title: Jesus among other myths - Dr. Aaron Adair
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Dr. Aaron Adair regarding his research paper, "Justin Martyr and the Epistemology of Mythology."  We discussed the fascinating perspectives of early church apologists and the surrounding mythology-filled culture.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Understanding how early Christian apologist and philosopher Justin Martyr viewed mythology, interpreting the Gospels allegorically rather than literally.
• Seeing Christianity’s many shared themes with older mythologies, despite early Christians justifying it by claiming that demons preemptively imitated Christ’s story.
• Appreciating that the Gospels were an evolving text rather than a fixed historical account.
• Seeing how early Christians tried to harmonize the contradictions in the Gospel stories, such as the Star of Bethlehem and Jesus’ triumphal entry, through a symbolic rather than historical approach.
• Reflecting on how early Christian perspectives aligned strongly with mystery cult traditions, where initiates progress through deeper symbolic interpretations rather than literal history.
• Recognizing the ancient cosmic myths that may have influenced early Christian theology.
• Suggesting that Christianity may have developed from myth to history rather than history to myth.

Thanks to Dr. Adair for his amazing research and insights!


_________________________________________

episodes.title: Letting go of certainty and finding spiritual freedom- Michela Giordano Castro
episodes.description:
C/W - brief discussion of suicidal ideation

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Michela Giordano Castro, who grew up in the Church of Christ and placed her faith in Jesus at an early age, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart, and reclaimed her spirituality outside of religion.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up facing the intense pressure of religious expectations, leading to being baptized as a child despite not feeling ready.
• Experiencing deep loneliness and depression as a result of being isolated within a strict faith community.
• Wrestling with doubts and the pain of praying desperately for signs of God’s presence but feeling unheard.
• Facing her fundamentalist Christian father’s sudden deconstruction and atheism, which shocked the family and created turmoil.
• Mourning the loss of her sense of a deeply personal connection to god.
• Feeling the overwhelming emotional weight of letting go of her faith.
• Enjoying the freedom to accept and love her LGBTQ+ friends after escaping Christianity.
• Exploring spirituality as a value rooted in connectedness rather than adherence to doctrine.
• Learning to release the need for certainty, embrace life’s uncertainties, and find peace in the unknown.
• Prioritizing emotional healing by processing her grief and embracing love in order to move forward in her life.

Many thanks to Michela for sharing her story and insights!

_________________________________________

episodes.title: If we don’t fight now, tomorrow will be far worse than we imagine - Leo Igwe
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Leo Igwe, who grew up in the Catholic faith, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.  He has become an activist for protecting victims of witch hunts and for promoting rationality, especially in schools.

We touched on many topics, including:

• How supernatural beliefs drain people's sense of compassion and care for fellow humans, and removes their logic and rationality.
• Realizing that ignorance is disease that ends up being toxic and deadly.
• Struggling against people who don't have the conscience to tell themselves that they are deceiving and exploiting people through religion.
• Seeing how religion encourages people to lie to themselves, and to not to say what they are really thinking when they are questioning the religion's claims.
• Having the bravery to change culture as we realize that progress is not handed down for free but instead has a high price.
• Understanding that many institutions incentivize magical thinking and leave no space for skepticism and reason.
• The need for us to reward people in our society for being skeptical, rational, and critical thinkers.
• Acknowledging the fearful reality that if we don’t fight against religion now, the situation will be far worse in the future.

Many thanks to Leo for sharing his story and insights!


_________________________________________

episodes.title: How to treat your body like a sacred text - Emily Hedrick
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Emily Hedrick, who grew up in the Mennonite Church and became a Mennonite pastor, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We discussed many topics based on her new book, including:

• Leaving the confines of religion to rediscover the profound joy of creativity and unleash a new sense of personal freedom through music and exploration.
• Rewriting her life’s narrative as she courageously confronted harmful theological beliefs and reclaimed her story as one of healing and empowerment.
• Processing her experiences of spiritual abuse and transforming them into a powerful testament of resilience and recovery through reflective storytelling.
• Understanding how fear-based teachings shape attachment patterns, especially the unhealthy relational dynamics fostered by religious contexts.
• Embracing the body as a sacred text so that we can honor its wisdom and reclaim our physical and emotional connections.
• Overcoming the crushing weight of childhood body shame and discovering the transformative power of self-worth and authenticity.
• Finding healing through practices of relaxation and pleasure as she worked to rewire the body’s trauma responses and foster inner safety.
• Reclaiming her autonomy and creativity as she broke free from high-control religion and began to lead a life of artistic and emotional liberation.
• Understanding the essential role of grief in healing and embracing it as a sacred part of growth.
• Building spaces of connection and creating opportunities for individuals to share their stories, rediscover their voices, and reclaim their lives with courage and hope.

Many thanks to Emily for sharing her story and insights!


_________________________________________

episodes.title: god, Sex, and Rich People - Mattie Jo Cowsert
episodes.description:
C/W - rape, sexual trauma
_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Mattie Jo Cowsert, an author and actress who grew up believing in and committed to Jesus, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Reflecting on how deeply entrenched evangelicalism was in her family history and identity.
• Thinking through the ways purity culture objectified women, often treating their bodies as commodities for male approval and determining their value based on their purity and marital status.
• Critiquing gender role expectations that ultimately suppress individuality and self-expression.
• Overcoming the fear of eternal damnation, which had been a primary reason she'd kept believing for so long.
• Understanding that sexual ignorance harms people by leaving them unprepared for healthy, empowered sexual experiences.
• Identifying the binary thinking of evangelicalism that presented the world in rigid absolutes, leaving little room for nuance or individuality.
• Experiencing cognitive dissonance as she met people from diverse backgrounds, shattering the homogeneous narratives she'd grown up with.
• Confronting the idea that an all-loving God would condemn people based on narrow and exclusionary criteria.
• How she empowered herself as she defined her own sexual ethics and reclaimed her body and desires.
• Unpacking how deeply her self-esteem was tied to evangelical doctrines that portrayed her as inherently sinful apart from a god.
• Appreciating the process of self-reflection and the gradual unlearning of harmful religious teachings.
• Learning to view casual relationships with care and respect, moving beyond reductive binaries like "just sex" vs. "making love."
• Advocating for a values-driven, autonomous approach to life.
• The importance of patience and self-compassion during the deconstruction process.

Many thanks to Mattie Jo for sharing her story!

_________________________________________

Connect with Mattie!

https://www.mattiejocowsert.com/

Blog: https://www.mattiejocowsert.com/godsexandrichpeople

IG: @mattiecowsert

Buy Mattie's book!
https://www.amazon.com/God-Rich-People-Mattie-Cowsert/dp/1964252059/

--- What happens when an Evangelical pastor's daughter moves from Branson, Missouri to New York City? A collapse ​of identity that begins a journey of figuring our faith, fucking, and the 1%. With humor and raw honesty, God, Sex, and Rich People follows Mattie Jo as she takes off her purity ring, navigates public transportation, and tries to have good sex without hating herself. From dating her doorman, to sex with a pop star, and living with millionaires, watch Mattie Jo hilariously fumble and find her footing as she redefines her sexuality and spirituality in the city that never sleeps (and never stops sleeping around). 

_________________________________________

episodes.title: Childhood religious trauma is the deepest hell - Troy Stoeber
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Troy Stoeber, who was a committed Catholic believer for decades, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Reflecting on the deeply ingrained Catholic upbringing that shaped his worldview and the courage it took to admit atheism after decades of belief.
• Exploring the profound psychological and physiological harm inflicted by early exposure to guilt, shame, and fear-based teachings in Catholicism.
• Examining how practices like confession fostered a relentless cycle of self-scrutiny and unrelenting guilt, shaping self-worth from a young age.
• Recalling how church experiences, from cold pews to relentless reminders of sin, instilled a deep sense of inadequacy and unworthiness.
• Reflecting on how the terror of hell and the conditional nature of divine love keep children in a constant state of anxiety and compliance.
• Unpacking the physiological consequences of stress, including low vagal tone, that stemmed from years of living in a state of fear and shame.
• Delving into the disturbing ways children internalize vivid imagery and messages of eternal punishment, creating a personal hell within their minds.
• Highlighting the power of stepping out of the echo chamber to critically examine long-held beliefs and embrace freedom of thought.
• Discussing the generational impact of religion’s toxic teachings, which can distort self-esteem and relationships for years, if not lifetimes.
• Contrasting the conditional love taught in religion with the empowering beauty of unconditional love and acceptance for children.
• Celebrating the newfound freedom to live authentically and the transformative journey of building self-esteem and self-regard.
• Advocating for a cultural shift to honor children’s curiosity and development, free from the trauma of indoctrination and fear.
• Exposing the ways religion exploits vulnerability, conflates fantasy with reality, and perpetuates a cycle of unquestioning obedience.
• Acknowledging the bittersweet process of letting go of beliefs that once brought comfort but ultimately led to liberation.
• Fighting for the cycle of religious harm to stop by committing ourselves to empower the next generation to live free of guilt and fear.

Many thanks to Troy for sharing his story!

_________________________________________

episodes.title: Religion exploits and consumes until kills its own host - Dr. Kara Cooney
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Dr. Kara Cooney, an Egyptologist and archaeologist who grew up exposed to Catholicism, but ultimately deconverted as she rejected dogmatic theology, patriarchy, and literalism.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up feeling excluded and demonized as a cultural minority Catholic in Evangelical-dominated Texas.
• Realizing that Catholicism is as a magical polytheistic religion rather than a monotheistic one.
• Rejecting both Heaven and Hell as simplistic and terrifying concepts and concluding that reincarnation made more sense as a model for human growth.
• Acknowledging the patriarchal roots of fear-based myths, like the devil story as a symbol of male control and the loss of female autonomy.
• Exploring the connection between Catholicism and animism through rituals and cause-and-effect dynamics.
• Experiencing deep shame in leaving religion, like ending a toxic relationship where there is a need to abandon everything from the old life to heal and rebuild.
• Understanding how patriarchy and toxic gender roles force men into oppressive roles and steal women's autonomy.
• Advocating for personal and community-based morality to replace oppressive corporate religious systems.
• Lamenting the loss of awe and connection caused by modernity and environmental destruction.
• Celebrating the potential for transformation after deconstruction of harmful systems.

Many thanks to Dr. Cooney for sharing her story!

_________________________________________

episodes.title: When faith collides with reality - Reggie Beloved
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Reggie Beloved, who gave his life to Jesus and was committed to living for him, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in Haiti with Catholic and Baptist influences that shaped his early religious experiences.
• Being taught to view god as an omnipresent and judgmental figure.
• Accepting the Gospel and committing his life to Jesus.
• Encountering contradictions in scripture that undermined the claims of divine authorship and consistency.
• Reading the Bible and Quran during his deployment in Iraq and grappling with their depictions of violence, slavery, and patriarchal practices, and concluding that both were human-created texts with significant flaws.
• Rejecting the concept of faith as a virtue after recognizing its role in suppressing critical thought.
• Choosing to prioritize morality and human connection over adherence to outdated religious doctrines.
• Letting go of Christianity after critically examining its contradictions and moral inconsistencies.
• Embracing atheism and finding freedom and intellectual fulfillment in a secular community.
• Rebuilding his worldview by critically analyzing religious beliefs and seeking evidence-based understanding.
• Realizing the societal harm caused by religious indoctrination and dedicating himself to promoting secular education.
• Reflecting on the cultural and psychological effects of growing up in a deeply religious environment.
• Advocating for open dialogue about religious trauma to help others heal and reclaim their autonomy.
• Founding the Haitian Freethinkers group to support secular individuals in the Haitian community.

Many thanks to Reggie for sharing his story!

episodes.title: Once an evangelical missionary, now an advocate for justice and inclusion - Marla Taviano
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Maria Taviano, who was an Evangelical Christian missionary and prolific author, but who ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:
• As a missionary, seeing that focusing on sharing the gospel often left people's physical needs completely unmet.
• Realizing that she could not truly love people while clinging to beliefs that harm them.
• Questioning the narrowness of the evangelical gospel.
• When she felt the need to choose between loving people and staying a Christian, choosing people.
• Seeing non-Christians show more love and compassion than Christians.
• Learning not to care what the Bible says about people’s identities and choices, and instead caring more about their humanity.
• Seeing that the Bible is not inerrant or a moral authority, but is just a product of its time, full of contradictions and harm.
• Being amazed at how many Christians are comfortable not asking hard questions and preferring to stay willfully ignorant.
• Losing relationships with people she loves, as a result of her deconversion, but gaining truth, freedom, authenticity, and peace.
• Acknowledging the fear of death and loss but choosing to focus on finding joy in the present.
• Becoming a strong advocate for justice and inclusion, and promoting love, justice, and community over dogma.
• Using her poetry and art as therapeutic tools to process her evolving beliefs and past religious trauma and to call out hypocrisy in evangelical stances on social issues.

Many thanks to Marla for sharing her story!

episodes.title: I moved from belief to reason - AJ Ruley
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with AJ Ruley, who grew up in a non-religious home at first but eventually got exposed to the Gospel and believed in Jesus for many years, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity kept falling apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Feeling the church speak of love and acceptance at first but then drift to a message of fear.
• Realizing that when people feel vulnerable and desperate, they are open to anything—especially the hope of a miracle.
• Feeling the heavy burden of guilt, especially in the context of purity culture.
• Questioning the idea of a loving God after seeing her child in pain after surgery, and wondering why a god would punish a human for something that another human, or even Adam and Eve, supposedly did?"
• Seeing religion teaching her to judge others but finding much more positivity and healthiness in her connection with the LGBTQ+ community.
• Slowly realizing that religion didn’t align with reality.
• Finding that the more she read the Bible critically, the more it unraveled for her.
• Wondering how there could be free will in heaven if heaven is all good.
• Experiencing immense peace when she realized that neither heaven nor hell were real and that she did not need to worry any more about the afterlife.
• Beginning to reclaim her own identity after she had spent many years trying not to offend Christians and being told by them who she should be.
• Feeling anger at the system of Christianity, especially how it shapes minds and restricts critical thinking.
• Acknowledging that her personal relationships had been deeply affected in negative ways by religious messages.
• Finding a new sense of belonging after connecting with the atheist community.

Many thanks to AJ for sharing her story!


_________________________________________


Connect with AJ!

@WaysToHuman

episodes.title: I broke Christianity's stronghold over me and got my power back - Herson Valdez
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Herson Valdez, who grew up in a religious Dominican household and got very serious about his faith, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a religious Dominican household with influences of Catholicism and voodoo.
• Observing his mom's spiritual transformation, which sparked his deep belief in god as a teenager.
• Deepening his faith after delving into apologetics to defend his beliefs against atheist friends.
• Immersing himself in charismatic Christianity, including learning to speak in tongues and practicing healing ministries.
• Noticing discrepancies between church teachings and Jesus’s words, particularly around prosperity and tithing.
• Feeling disillusioned by the focus on wealth and expansion within megachurches, despite seeing widespread poverty.
• Encountering contradictions and inconsistencies in the Bible that further shook his perspectives on Christianity.
• Studying Judaism after deeply questioning New Testament interpretations and teachings.
• Realizing that Jesus's lineage and the prophecies did not align, which led to doubts about his Messiahship.
• Struggling to reconcile the doctrine of the Trinity and seeing logical flaws in the concept.
• Exploring the historical roots of Christianity and learning about its evolution through political and religious influences.
• Connecting the mythologies and rituals of ancient religions to Christian traditions, such as communion and resurrection stories.
• Questioning the validity of church teachings after discovering historical inaccuracies and constructed narratives.
• Feeling lied to and betrayed by Christians.
• Experiencing a deep personal and relational impact, including strained communication with loved ones after leaving the faith.
• Facing accusations that life struggles were divine punishment, contributing to a sense of isolation.
• Embracing newfound freedom by relinquishing guilt and shame tied to Christian teachings on morality and life choices.
• Understanding that people’s belief in supernatural experiences often correlates with psychological and cultural influences, and that at their core, Christians are afraid of the truth.
• Finding strength in creating his own path, free from the constraints of religious dogma and embracing critical thinking.
• The importance of questioning our beliefs and seeking truth, even when it challenges our current worldview.

Many thanks to Herson for sharing his story!

_________________________________________

https://www.youtube.com/@Hersonalities

episodes.title: Lies Christian parents believe - Marissa Burt
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Marissa Burt, a Christian author who joined me to discuss the issue of corporal punishment among Christians.

We touched on many topics, including:

• How the Christian parenting empire shaped a generation of evangelical families and how false promises and myths about "good Christian parenting" betrayed them.
• The strong connection between blind adherence to religious principles and the neglect of critical self-reflection.
• Understanding that how we raise our children can reflect deeper beliefs, often without questioning if those beliefs are truly beneficial.
• The need for a more empathetic, psychologically informed approach to child rearing, especially in Christian homes.
• Realizing that a lot of what Christians assume is biblical child-rearing is rooted more in culture than in the Bible.
• Seeing that the intention behind the child rearing practices doesn't always align with their actual impact on children.
• Acknowledging that parents' attempts at control in parenting often stems from fear, not love or guidance.
• The importance of empathy being at the core of any teaching or correction.
• The fearful reality that while every parenting system has flaws, few are as intricately defended as religious ones.
• Observing families who once embraced strict religious parenting now grappling with the consequences in their adult children.
• How the act of breaking cycles of harmful beliefs and practices is an act of courage and love.
• The need to look at our motivations as parents to reveal biases we've disguised as 'truth.'
• Shifting from fear-based discipline to love-based guidance is a journey worth taking.
• The need to learn from the voices of those who were hurt by bad parenting ideas, not silence them.
• Being willing to give your child the example of owning up to mistakes.
• Acknowledging that harm that was done in abusive parenting doesn’t invalidate the good intentions behind it but invites admission of what was done, in order to start the process of forgiveness and healing.

Thanks to Marissa for sharing her insights!

episodes.title: I was a street evangelist ... until the truth claims of Christianity unraveled - Carmine D'Amore
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Carmine D'Amore, who grew up in the Catholic Church, became a "born again" Christian, and even became a street evangelist, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a strict Italian Catholic family where everything was shaped by their unwavering adherence to church traditions.
• Believing that they as Catholics held the ultimate truth and that everyone else, especially Protestants, was just following incorrect theology.
• Constantly fearing hell or purgatory, especially with the fear that he might sin and then not make it to confession in time before death.
• Being amazed by the invitation to become a born again Christian as he realized that a priest or confession booth was unnecessary.
• Becoming zealous to share his faith with his family and beyond.
• Trying to purify himself from the influences of secular culture.
• Preaching on the streets with a mission to save others.
• Starting to realize the many contradictions in the Bible, particularly the differing resurrection accounts, which planted the first seeds of doubt.
• Seeing how different translations and interpretations of the Bible muddied any sense of clarity.
• Realizing that the Bible’s inconsistencies meant it wasn’t divinely perfect.
• Wanting to know what was true even if it meant dismantling everything he had previously clung to.
• As he eventually questioned his entire faith, feeling like it was unraveling under scrutiny, raising questions he couldn’t ignore, and eventually collapsing.

Many thanks to Carmine for sharing his story!

_________________________________________

Connect with Carmine!

https://www.youtube.com/@UCDRDVdxIZLiIcOlheoaUl3g

episodes.title: The Fires that Built Me - Angela McLellan
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Angela McClellan, who grew up believing in Jesus as her savior, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in Christianity from a young age and navigating faith and moral expectations that framed her early worldview.
• Facing physical challenges with juvenile idiopathic arthritis from age two, which shaped her understanding of god, prayer, and healing.
• Struggling with questions about suffering and sin, especially in light of her physical condition.
• Experiencing trauma through church-based healing services, which intensified her anxiety and conflicted relationship with god.
• Struggling with purity culture and perfectionism, leading to self-doubt and shame.
• Experiencing marital struggles and abuse that were complicated by expectations and blame by church leadership and family.
• Feeling isolated and diminished by her church, which left her feeling betrayed during her marital and faith crises.
• Beginning her deconstruction journey, fueled by unanswered questions and painful realizations about the religious doctrines she'd been taught and the personal autonomy she'd lost as a Christian.
• Disentangling her beliefs in hell, shame, and judgment from her developing self-awareness.
• Reclaiming her personal agency and processing her journey out of Christianity through creative expression as a writer and poet.
• Creating new community with individuals who could relate to her experiences as a former Christian.
• Experiencing immense freedom as she let go of former fears built on Christian theology.
• Shedding the psychological weight of self-condemnation imposed by religious teachings.
• Rediscovering spirituality as her own personal, peaceful journey that no longer involves external validation or dogmatic control.

Thanks to Angela for sharing her story!

episodes.title: Going forward, I'm giving up god - Sarah Henn Hayward
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Sarah Henn Hayward, who grew up as an evangelical Christian who believed in Jesus as her Savior but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a devout Christian family where the Bible's messages shaped her identity from a young age.
• The influence of her parents' conversion and their decision to raise her in a highly committed Christian environment.
• Actively participating in Campus Crusade for Christ during college, which began to broaden her theological perspectives.
• Finding her theological views shifting further after being exposed to more progressive Christian teachings and interfaith experiences at college.
• Making gay friends and exploring the history of the Bible’s formation, which became pivotal in her shift toward a more inclusive and less literal interpretation of Scripture.
• During the COVID-19 pandemic, questioning the very existence of god, leading to an eventual departure from Christianity.
• Experiencing fear, anxiety, and, eventually, peace she felt when she embraced the idea that god might be a human concept.
• Working together amicably with her husband through their worldview differences with respect, couples therapy, and support from their community.
• Remaining connected to a progressive church that values open questioning and exploration rather than strict dogma.
• Calling herself a "Christian atheist," where she embraces her cultural Christian background but rejects traditional beliefs in a deity.
• Working to help others understand the psychological aspects of faith deconstruction by drawing from her own therapeutic experiences.
• The emotional complexities of leaving behind Christianity, and walking through stages of grief, anger, and freedom.
• Finding meaning in relationships, nature, and personal growth.
• The crucial importance of living authentically.

Many thanks to Sarah for sharing her story!


_________________________________________

episodes.title: The hidden roots of Christianity and other world religions - David Fitzgerald
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with David Fitzgerald, a renowned atheist activist, historical researcher, and novelist whose books have been pivotal for the deconstructing community as we work to understand the origins and evolution of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• The inspiration behind studying mythicism, which challenges the historical existence of Jesus and other religious figures.
• The various patterns seen across different religions.
• The inconsistencies between the Gospels and how they depict various versions of Jesus.
• Uncovering common mythological elements across religions, including parallels between figures like Jesus, Buddha, and Muhammad.
• The influence of Zoroastrianism on Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.
• Recent archaeological and scholarly discoveries challenge the conventional timelines of the Old Testament's origins.
• Understanding that religion is an evolutionary process shaped by historical and political factors.
• The influence of Egyptian, Babylonian, and Persian traditions on Jewish scriptures.
• How early Christian figures like Paul had differing visions for the religion, contributing to its diversity.
• How religious leaders manipulated Christianity to shape beliefs and control narratives.
• How understanding the origins and evolution of religion can aid in healing from religious trauma.

Many thanks to David for sharing his story and insights!


_________________________________________

https://www.amazon.com/stores/author/B004ASD9M4/allbooks

episodes.title: Everything changed when I chose LOVE over dogma - April Ajoy
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with April Ajoy, who grew up in a Pentecostal family with deep evangelical roots and gave her life to share the Gospel, but heavily deconstructed her faith as she examined toxic aspects of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Traveling with her family to do ministry through music and preaching, which exposed her to various global cultures.
• Along with her family, being intensely focused on converting others, which caused anxiety and guilt whenever she failed to witness effectively.
• Experiencing intense childhood anxiety caused by fear of being "left behind" during the Rapture.
• Believing in miracles and faith healing for many years but starting to experience significant doubts after her father passed away from cancer despite prayers and expectations of healing.
• Living by strict modesty rules and teachings about purity which made her feel responsible for male thoughts and behavior.
• Feeling unexpected joy for LGBTQ couples when gay marriage was legalized, which conflicted with her evangelical teachings.
• Shifting her theology further when her brother came out as gay, as she saw his suffering and realized that sexuality wasn't a choice.
• Being disillusioned by evangelical support for Donald Trump, despite his major character flaws which contradicted the "morality-first" ideals April grew up with.
• Becoming increasingly concerned as she saw how Christian nationalism seeks to create a theocracy, using scripture to oppress marginalized communities and legislate morality.
• While still embracing the teachings of Jesus, holding her beliefs more loosely, embracing uncertainty, and rejecting fear-based doctrines like hell.
• Aiming to raise awareness, through her book and her activism, about the dangers of Christian nationalism and promote a more inclusive society.

Many thanks to April for sharing her story with us today!

_________________________________________

episodes.title: My doubts kept growing until it was GAME OVER - Larenzo Reid
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Larenzo Reid, who grew up in a Baptist environment and tried for decades to understand and defend the faith, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Attending church regularly as a child, but sensing that even at a young age, he was already questioning his beliefs.
• Sensing his doubts increase when a pastor incorrectly interpreted the story of the "eye of the needle," saying that rich people go to hell, which led him to seek answers by studying the Bible and other sources independently.
• Noticing inconsistencies in the teachings and interpretations of pastors, who often lacked historical and cultural context.
• Finding his questions about were not welcomed by church leaders, who saw them as challenges to their authority.
• Being encouraged by his family to pursue his intellectual curiosity and to speak his mind, which helped him to continue exploring his doubts despite backlash from the church.
• Desiring not to leave Christianity but to understand it better and to be a more devout Christian by grasping the historical and cultural backgrounds of biblical stories.
• Traveling to Israel, Rome, and other places, where he saw firsthand the historical and archaeological contexts of biblical stories, further fueling his doubts.
• Finding that his firsthand experiences, combined with his independent studies, were leading him to see contradictions between what he was taught in church and what he observed in reality, particularly regarding the story of Jesus, the Old Testament, and the role of Christianity in history.
• Criticizing the Bible's morality, especially concerning issues like slavery, genocide, and child sacrifice, which he found inconsistent with the idea of a benevolent deity.
• Exploring other philosophies, such as Stoicism and Hermeticism, which provided alternative frameworks to understand life and the universe, and ultimately helping him overcome his fear of death and let go of the concept of heaven and hell.
• Fully deconverting from Christianity, and consequently facing pushback, criticism, and even death threats from Christians.
• Hearing pastors privately acknowledge the inaccuracies in their teachings but feeling trapped by financial obligations and fear of community backlash.
• Starting his YouTube channel, "Deconstructing Christianity," originally as a resource for his children, but now a platform to help others who are questioning their faith.
• Emphasizing the importance of understanding oneself and pursuing personal growth outside of religious structures and advocating for self-love and self-trust.

Many thanks to Larenzo for sharing his story!

episodes.title: From Quiverfull to freedom from religious oppression - Lesa Williams
episodes.description:
C/W - brief discussion of CSA, domestic violence, alcoholism
_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Lesa Williams, a mother of 12 who was heavily influenced by the Bill Gothard and Quiverfull movements, and who ultimately deconverted from Christianity as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a dysfunctional family with an alcoholic father and abusive stepmother created an unstable environment, driving her intense search for love and acceptance through Christianity.
• Getting involved in the Bill Gothard and Quiverfull movements, which advocate strict adherence to biblical teachings, patriarchal family structures, having many children as God's will, and homeschooling with strict biblical principles.
• Facing depression and feelings of inadequacy while striving to be a “Proverbs 31 woman.”
• Feeling overwhelmed by the expectations of her Christian walk and maintaining a large family, while dealing with the death of two of her sons.
• Questioning God’s plan and beliefs after personal losses, leading to a nervous breakdown and unraveling of her faith.
• Meeting people outside of Christianity through work and realizing love, compassion, and empathy exist beyond its confines.
• Moving away from her insular community and adopting a secular lifestyle, shocking her former peers.
• Escaping Christianity fully and acknowledging it's just mythology.
• Finding peace and freedom, but still grappling with the impact of her religious past on her children.
• Using creative expression to process trauma and helping women through childbirth to find purpose outside her former faith.

Many thanks to Lesa for sharing her story!

episodes.title: Why I left Christianity after 20 years of preaching - Trisjen Harris
episodes.description:
Trisjen HAS just started a YouTube channel!   Please check it out and subscribe:
@TrisjensChronicles1203 

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Trisjen Harris, who grew up in a Baptist environment and became an evangelical preacher for 20 years, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Being heavily influenced by his stepfather, a pastor, and adopting a strict, fear-based Christian worldview.
• Having profound experiences with god early in life, marked by a strong emphasis on sin, repentance, and salvation.
• By age 17, committing his life to Jesus and experiencing a deep, personal transformation.
• Becoming a youth pastor and pursuing formal theological training at Moody Bible Institute and Liberty University.
• Doing many years pastoral ministry characterized by strict adherence to doctrine and a strong emphasis on evangelism.
• Seeing his faith start to unravel after experiencing church politics, doctrinal discrepancies, and observing a lack of diversity and authenticity in congregations.
• Becoming disillusioned as he noticed the same people repeatedly praying for help without tangible results.
• After leaving his original church, joining a Vineyard church but continuing to wrestle with the lack of diversity in church and the contradictions in the Bible.
• Questioning the Bible's validity and the authenticity of its narratives, which kicked his deconstruction journey into high gear.
• Shifting from fundamentalist to more liberal Christian beliefs before eventually rejecting Christianity altogether.
• Sharing his change in beliefs to his loved ones, emphasizing everyone's right to choose their own spiritual path.
• Enjoying a life free from religious constraints, respecting others’ autonomy, and rejecting dogmatic beliefs and doctrines.
• Reflecting on how life as a Christian felt like being trapped in a mental prison, while life outside Christianity now offers a renewed sense of freedom and purpose.

Thanks to Trisjen for sharing his story!

episodes.title: How I deconstructed, brick by brick - Elbe Spurling
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Elbe Spurling, an accomplished artist and author, best known for The Brick Bible project, which illustrates the entire Bible in LEGO bricks from the Garden of Eden to the Book of Revelation.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Slowly getting rid of magical thinking throughout her childhood.
• Noticing that many Christians don't know what's actually in the Bible and would be horrified to read many of the stories and the characterizations of the Yahweh character.
• Gradually seeing prayer as an ineffective practice, often rationalized as god “working in mysterious ways” when prayers were not answered.
• Critically and skeptically examining her own beliefs, resulting in her separating what's real and what's make believe.
• Diving deeply into the best arguments for and against Christianity.
• Questioning the morality of a god who would punish people for doubting his existence, which solidified her decision to reject such a deity as unworthy of worship, even if he were real.
• Slowly deconverting from Christianity by age 13.
• Feeling isolated, lonely, and disconnected being the only atheist she knew, and being curious why others kept on believing in the claims of the Christian worldview.
• Channeling her artistic expression into projects like The Brick Bible as a way to explore and critique the Bible from a secular perspective.
• Seeing her family gradually accept her non-belief, and then watching many of them leave Christianity themselves over time.
• After escaping Christianity as a worldview, becoming increasingly fascinated with the study of philosophy and religion.
• Exploring the development of Christianity from ancient Judaism with a purely heavenly Jesus character at the core.

Many thanks to Elbe for sharing her story!

episodes.title: How I found my voice after religious abuse - Brigette Gildemaster
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Brigette Gildemaster, who believed in Jesus from a young age and was dedicated to living her life for him, but deconverted as her experience with religious abuse prompted her to examine the truth claims of Christianity, which ultimately fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a deeply Christian, legalistic household, with her parents embracing a Reformed Presbyterian belief system.
• Never doubting her faith in her early years but struggling with the concept of being inherently sinful.
• Feeling internal conflict between her desire to lead and the traditional gender roles imposed by her Christian community.
• Experiencing different Christian worship styles, which sparked curiosity about exploring the faith in different ways, but continuing to see overly emotional worship as wrong.
• Feeling immense pressure to marry and have children, which led her to push aside career aspirations.
• Healing from her first husband’s porn addiction and emotional distance.
• Experiencing multiple miscarriages and caring for a child with significant medical needs.
• Reflecting on her homeschooling experience, which discouraged higher education and personal growth outside of domestic roles.
• Slowly realizing that Christianity's teachings were abusive and confusing.
• Unpacking how her emotions had been suppressed within the Christian environment.
• The importance of reclaiming her personal autonomy after leaving behind toxic religious and marital structures.
• Advocating for people recovering from religious and romantic abuse.
• Helping others to reclaim their autonomy after leaving rigid belief systems and to find empowerment through storytelling and emotional healing.

Many thanks to Brigette for sharing her story!

_________________________________________

https://brigettegildemaster.com/

episodes.title: Deep Drinks, Deep Questions, and my Deconversion Story - David McDonald
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with David McDonald, who grew up as a Pentecostal Christian and served many years in youth ministry, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up deeply religious with an early sense of seriousness about his relationship with god.
• Having intense religious experiences including speaking in tongues.
• Leading Bible studies and working as a youth pastor, but eventually becoming disillusioned with church politics and leadership struggles.
• Starting his deconstruction journey by traveling, which opened his eyes to the diversity of religious beliefs and cultures and led him to question the exclusivity of Christianity.
• Experiencing a mental health struggle that prompted him to reflect deeply on religion and life choices.
• Starting to investigate scientific evidence that contradicted his previous young-earth creationist views.
• Questioning the Bible, particularly around issues like gender roles, Biblical inerrancy, and contradictions between faith and science.
• Feeling the emotional toll of deconstruction, such as being isolated from the Christian community.
• Finding freedom and relief as he let go of rigid beliefs.
• Missing some aspects of Christian community, but ultimately finding the search for truth to be more important.

Many thanks to David for sharing his story!


_________________________________________


Check out the Deep Drinks YouTube channel!
@DeepDrinks

episodes.title: I embraced my doubts and left Christian mythology behind - Kimberly Sprowl
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Kim Sprowl, who grew up believing in Jesus as her Savior, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Being raised in the Baptist denomination.
• Facing constant guilt over not praying and fasting enough.
• Noticing that many Christians had little knowledge of the Bible, relying instead on religious clichés and rituals.
• Learning about what other cults believed but becoming concerned as she saw strong parallels between the cultish beliefs and the beliefs of her church community.
• Observing prayers from herself and other faithful Christians going unanswered, which pushed her further into questioning the validity of her faith.
• Deciding to study the Bible deeply, including its origins, authors, and contexts, and discovering similarities with older mythologies, which sparked further doubts about its divine nature.
• Reaching a pivotal moment where she realized she no longer believed in Christianity.
• Overcoming the loss of the imaginary divine protection she used to have.
• Facing ostracization from Christian friends after deconverting.
• Seeing the need for more visibility of Black atheists to expose the harm of religious indoctrination in the Black community.
• Finding joy and purpose in living one day at a time, cherishing her relationships with her children and grandchildren, and embracing a life free from religious burdens.

Thanks to Kim for sharing her story!

_________________________________________

episodes.title: The questions that shook my beliefs to the core - Holy Koolaid
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Thomas Westbrook, aka "Holy Koolaid," who gave his life to Jesus at a young age and became zealous in his relationship with god, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Getting saved and becoming very serious about god at a young age.
• Feeling a lot of pressure to be holy and repent quickly of any sin.
• Battling shame and guilt as he went through puberty as a Christian teen.
• Seeing a lot of guys around him quietly struggling with homosexuality.
• Growing up thinking the Bible was divinely inspired, accurate, and consistent.
• After deconversion, reassessing the literature of the Bible, especially in light of comparative mythology.
• Being taught to believe that the earth was very young and that evolution was a ridiculous notion that could not be true.
• Realizing that creationists were cherry-picking data and using circular arguments.
• Seeing many Christians prove themselves to be fundamentally ignorant or deliberately dishonest.
• Looking deeply into the psychology of belief, logical fallacies, self-delusion.
• Through various situations, beginning to feel like prayer was futile.
• Studying about the origins and evolution of Christian teachings about hell.
• Fully deconverting from Christianity and developing a platform to help bring critical information to others.
• The importance of challenging harmful ideologies, exposing fraud, promoting reason, and raising awareness about skepticism.

Many thanks to Thomas for sharing his story!


_________________________________________


Check out the Holy Koolaid YT channel!
@HolyKoolaid

episodes.title: Sharing your journey out of Christianity brings healing and strength - Kathy Cotton
episodes.description:
C/W - Child sexual abuse, substance abuse

_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Kathy Cotton, who grew up heavily exposed to evangelical Christianity and became a pastor's wife, but ultimately deconverted as she examined the truth claims of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up with parents with mental health issues and addictions and having to grow up fast and help take care of siblings.
• Switching into a foster home due to the unhealthy home environment, including molestation.
• Getting exposed to the plan of salvation at church and placing her faith in Jesus.
• Being told by a fellow believer that she had a "prophetic gift," and shortly after that, speaking in tongues.
• Getting married at age 18 to avoid sexual temptation, but quickly finding that she was married to an abusive alcoholic.
• As she eventually got divorced, getting connected to an ultra-conservative fundamentalist church.
• Asking god why he had let a horrible marriage happen to her, in light of his love for her.
• Starting to work for Pat Robertson's 500 Club ministry, where she met her second husband, who was a pastor.
• Experiencing endless bizarre and painful experiences that slowly shook her faith and led her to seriously question god's presence and plan.
• Observing church leaders repeatedly committing horrific abuses.
• Realizing that in all her years as a Christian, she had never seen a miracle.
• Understanding that Paul created his own version of Christianity.
• Doing a deep dive into the origins of the Bible and the mythology woven through it, leading to her deconversion from Christianity.
• The beauty of helping others to heal from religious trauma.

Many thanks to Kathy for sharing her story!

episodes.title: I was a Pastor for 30 years ... until I realized that Christianity is mythology - Timmy Gibson
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Timmy Gibson, who grew up in a Pentecostal church, placed his faith in Jesus at a young age, and became a Pastor for 30 years before ultimately deconverting from Christianity.

We touched on many topics including:

• Being encouraged to "check his brain at the door," have blind faith, and to stop worrying about anything that didn't make sense, because god's ways were seen as far above ours.
• Feeling like his ministry and evangelism were directly and positively impacting people's eternal destinies.
• Starting to deconstruct as he read the book "Sapiens" and learned about evolution and Neanderthals.
• Moving from Fundamentalist Christianity to a more liberal perspective as he shifted his positions, especially regarding hell and homosexuality.
• Realizing the psychopathic nature of the Yahweh character in the Old Testament.
• Finding donations to his church drop exponentially as he publicly affirmed the LGBTQ community.
• Being told by other pastors that he needed to keep his changing perspectives to himself.
• Slowly concluding that people who subscribe to the Christian worldview are deluded.
• Realizing that we were both the victims and the perpetrators of the Christian belief system and therefore feeling compelled to try to undo some of the damage we had done during our time in Christian ministry.
• Experiencing much more peace after escaping Christianity.

Thanks to Timmy for sharing his story and insights!

episodes.title: My faith crumbled once I could no longer trust the Bible's accuracy - Steph Moser Smith
episodes.description:
C/W - Brief discussion of suicide

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Steph Moser Smith, who placed her faith in Jesus at an early age and lived her life for him, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Giving her life to the Lord at a young age, but still being afraid, as a child, that she would sin too much and still end up in hell.
• Feeling a euphoria in various events and being told that was evidence of god's presence.
• Fearing that one of her grandfathers might be in hell.
• Being convinced in childhood that she would end up a missionary, which got solidified when someone "gave a prophecy" over her that this was the case.
• Imagining people burning in hell and feeling responsible for people's eternal state if she didn't actively share the Gospel with them.
• Severely fearing missing the Rapture and having to face the Tribulation.
• Becoming very stressed about figuring out god's will for her life.
• Feeling like she'd become a "cultural Christian" for several years.
• Being discouraged as she tried in vain to save her non-Christian husband.
• Starting to see the damaging aspects of patriarchy.
• Seeing her teenage children walk away from Christianity.
• Having to face the reality that she had loved ones who had come out as gay and struggling with the Biblical stance against them.
• Observing emotional manipulation in worship services by her pastor.
• Starting to deconstruct the concept of heaven.
• Upon the death of her brother, becoming brutally honest about the big questions of life.
• Realizing that the Bible has errors in it, and finding that she'd lost her ability to trust the Bible as well as Christianity as a whole.
• Fully deconverting from Christianity and finding immense peace in the process.
• Re-establishing her moral compass after deconversion.
• The relief of finally being able to accept others unconditionally.
• Being proud of herself and giving herself credit, instead of god, when she achieves her goals.

Thanks to Steph for sharing her story and insights!


_________________________________________
