episodes.title: The Watchtower kept on crumbling until there was nothing left - Noel & Rick Ross
episodes.description:
C/W - Suicide ideation
_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Noel and Rick Ross, who placed their faith in Jehovah and got involved in church ministry, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Being told that loved ones who don't make it to Paradise will be erased from their memories.
• Doing extensive work as Pioneers who go door to door sharing the Jehovah's Witness message.
• Getting disfellowshipped (Noel) and losing her entire community since no one else in the church was allowed to interact with her.
• Growing up Baptist (Rick) but starting to deconstruct the identity of Jesus and question whether he was really god, and ultimately getting pulled into the Jehovah's Witnesses perspective.
• Being pushed to be a ministerial student, on the path to becoming an elder.
• Starting to have significant and growing doubts about what they believed as JWs.
• Hearing JW leaders give detailed prescriptions about what marital intimacy should and should not look like.
• Staying in the JW church for many years, despite their doubts, because of their fears of losing the afterlife and their marriage.
• Eventually admitting their doubts to each other and slowly deconstructing together.
• Asking their JW elders to answer some hard questions, which the elders were unable to answer.
• Realizing the horror of the rampant child abuse in the Jehovah's Witnesses.
• Escaping Christianity altogether and reclaiming their identities.

Thanks to Noel and Ross for sharing their story and insights!


_________________________________________

https://www.youtube.com/@RossFamily/videos

episodes.title: I realized Christianity was a bunch of lies, and I simply couldn't believe anymore - Khrista Nelson
episodes.description:
C/W - Suicide ideation, brief discussion of rape
_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Khrista Nelson, who placed her faith in Jesus and became radically committed to him, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Becoming radically committed to Jesus and to serving him.
• "Crucifying" her flesh to be pure and useful to god.
• Doing street evangelism and casting demons out of people.
• Becoming convinced that her same-sex attraction was an abomination.
• Engaging in a same-sex relationship but then getting exposed to "turn or burn" preaching and getting convicted that she needed to return to heterosexuality.
• Getting strongly plugged into the New Apostolic Reformation movement, which focused on signs and wonders, miracles, prophecies, angels and demons, speaking in tongues, etc.
• Feeling "sexually dead" as she tried in vain to return to heterosexuality and to program herself to give her body to her husband as part of Biblical submission.
• Experiencing multiple church abuses and cover-ups, to the point that she got into the home church movement.
• Leaning toward Preterism and the Israel-Only position.
• Deconverting from Christianity and reclaiming her identity.
• The importance of giving kids the choice of thought autonomy.
• The beauty of not seeing other people and relationships as Christian "projects" anymore.
• Experiencing much more peace after escaping Christianity.
• Realizing that her whole life as a Christian had been based on fear of a supposedly loving god.
• The importance of learning to trust yourself.

Thanks to Khrista for sharing her story and insights!

episodes.title: I found a better, more beautiful purpose in life when I left Christianity - Ve Marié
episodes.description:
*Apologies for the audio issues toward the beginning of the interview
_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Ve Marié, who grew up in a Baptist Christian environment and placed her faith in Jesus at an early age, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• As a child, looking up to her grandparents who were strongly dedicated to sharing the Gospel and helping the poor.
• Basing her worldview of god in part on how she viewed her perfectionistic mother.
• Having a very vivid imagination regarding Satan and demons wanting to attack her.
• Struggling with people-pleasing in her Christian life.
• Hearing altar calls where congregants were invited to make a decision for god.
• Getting involved in the music ministry on a major level in her church.
• Facing intense purity culture messages at church but, fortunately, hearing a balanced perspective on it at home.
• Getting shaken up when she was exposed to very authoritarian gender roles at church.
• Being very surprised as she learned about other mythologies and folklores in the world and starting to question why those other religious stories had to be seen as false while the Bible's stories had to be seen as correct and divinely inspired.
• Going through an intense season of prayer and angst as she faced overwhelming medical concerns.
• Beginning to question whether the Bible were really from god, and eventually concluding that it was just a man-made book.
• Giving herself the freedom to explore other religions and ask hard questions.
• After deconversion, being able to stop judging others and starting to study the psyche more than ever in an effort to understand how religion affects the human journey.
• The importance of crafting a new sense of purpose after deconversion.

Thanks to Ve for sharing her story and insights!

episodes.title: You don't need to go it alone as you recover from religion - Rachel Hunt
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Rachel Hunt, who grew up in the Christian Science denomination and later explored other religious options, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in the Christian Science church where there was less dogmatism than most other Protestant denominations.
• Hearing the core Christian Science beliefs that the world is an illusion, that everything is perfect in the mind of god, and that if you can align your mind with the mind of god, all pain and illness will disappear.
• Getting briefly involved with Scientology.
• Understanding the dynamics of confirmation bias in religious groups.
• Connecting the dots that the Yahweh character is an abusive psychopath.
• Getting involved with "Recovering From Religion" and helping people who were thinking through their worldviews.
• The seductive nature of religion's false promises.
• The importance of building a new support system and community after deconversion from Christianity.

Thanks to Rachel for sharing her story and insights!


_________________________________________


Recovering From Religion
https://www.recoveringfromreligion.org/

The Secular Therapy Project
https://www.seculartherapy.org/

The Clergy Project
https://clergyproject.org/

episodes.title: It all fell apart when I realized the Jesus of history was NOT the Christ of faith - Laura Alcala
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Laura Alcala, who grew up into a devout Catholic believer but fully deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in the Catholic church on both cultural and personal levels.
• Being traumatized as she attended a poorly lit church with gory statues that scared her as a child to the point that she had nightmares.
• Hearing nonstop messages of being very bad and so guilty that she needed salvation from god to be forgiven and go to heaven.
• Feeling the love of Mother Mary more than of Yahweh and Jesus.
• Going through the sacraments, such as Baptism, Confirmation, Eucharist, Penance, etc.
• Having a strong faith in god and feeling his presence everywhere.
• Thinking that the holy Catholic church was the one true church.
• Being shocked when she learned about the many varieties of Protestant beliefs.
• Not having Bible reading ever emphasized to her.
• Being astonished at the purity culture issues in Evangelical Christianity.
• Getting married with the strong expectation of raising their kids as Catholics.
• Realizing that the historical Jesus was completely different from the Christ of faith.
• Raising her children without the constraints and traumas of Christianity.

Thanks to Laura for sharing her story and insights!

episodes.title: Christianity's claims fell apart when I questioned the unquestionable - Laurentia Wells
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Laurentia Wells, who grew up in Christian home and gave her life to the Lord at an early age, but eventually deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Feeling like she had to continually say the sinner's prayer to be sure she was saved.
• Becoming convinced that she would be Raptured before the age of 20.
• Having it drilled into her heart from a young age that she was worthless apart from god.
• Being in church whenever its doors were open.
• Hearing in school the ideas that Adam and Eve might be mythology and that evolution might be true but doubling down in her faith and rebutting those ideas.
• For a time, feeling like god was her protector and her friend.
• Beginning to question god after her church abandoned her family when her mom died.
• Realizing the long-term damage that had been done to her by Christianity.
• Understanding that the only reason she'd ever really believed in Jesus was because that was what her parents taught her.
• Being angry over the lies that the church pushed on her for so many years.

Many thanks to Laurentia for sharing her story and for her YouTube channel!


_________________________________________

episodes.title: Even though I kept showing up for god, he never made himself present in my life - Andre Forbes
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Andre Forbes, who grew up in a Christian environment and was pushed from an early age to use his musical talents for church worship.  Andre ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart, and he now uses his musical talents for secular messages.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a religious bubble where people made up a lot of legalistic rules for the group to follow.
• Despite being very committed and devout in his faith, never feeling a closeness to god, yet still firmly believing the Bible's teachings were true.
• Admitting that the Bible and Christianity don't make sense anymore as an explanation of reality.
• Realizing that Christianity is a form of the "thought police."
• Concluding that Christianity is ultimately all about fear and punishment, and that when we escape Christianity, we can live without fear for the first time.
• Embracing the likelihood that we have one single life and no afterlife.
• Regretting the arrogance, ignorance, and stances against various kind of "sins" and "sinners" that he had while he was a Christian.
• Being slowly traumatized by the experience of strongly wanting for decades to feel god's presence and a strong a connection with him, and yet never seeing god make himself present in his life.
• Focusing heavily on being gracious and connecting with people who disagree with us and trying to avoid writing people off.
• Making sure he can clearly articulate his perspective clearly without insisting that others adopt his beliefs and worldview.
• Re-reading the Bible after deconversion and being appalled at the stories we used to think were okay and the ways we used to think of the Yahweh character as a good god.
• Understanding that while he was a Christian, there was a form of outward peace, but not a true inward peace of mind.
• The importance of not indoctrinating kids, but instead giving them information, respect, and the freedom to make their own decisions -- and for parents to respect whatever their kids decide.

Many thanks to Andre for sharing his story and insights!

episodes.title: While divorcing an abusive spouse, I also divorced an abusive and toxic religion - Dawne Anthony
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Dawne Anthony, who placed her faith in Jesus at a young age and got involved in ministry, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Being in church multiple times each week during childhood.
• Seeing her parents have problems with each church they attended and consequently church hopping frequently and no longer talking to the people at the previous church.
• Giving her life to Jesus as a young child, but repeatedly rededicating her life to god to be sure her salvation was secure.
• From an early age, having questions about theological concepts that didn't make sense, but being very careful about who she spoke to about them.
• Feeling like she would sometimes sense god's presence and voice, but other times she couldn't.
• Attending a Christian Missionary Alliance Bible college to prepare for missions and ministry.
• Seeing overwhelming hypocrisy at Bible college that drove her to even more concerns about the Christian worldview but fearing hell if she focused on her doubts too strongly.
• Being told by her church to never use birth control and to see having lots of babies as a blessing from god, but realizing over the years that she was overwhelmed and depressed by the situation.
• Becoming disillusioned by her worsening marriage and very difficult home life.
• Realizing that while she was divorcing an abusive spouse, she was concurrently divorcing an abusive and toxic religion.
• As she slowly escaped Christianity, realizing that her identity as a Christian had been based on mythology, but still fearing what other Christians would think.
• Being able to talk through her deconversion with her father, who had deconverted a few years before she did.
• Realizing that there is no power in the Gospel and what appears as power is just humans doing good things in their own power.
• Perceiving that Christianity does not transcend the human experience.
• The importance of giving ourselves time to heal as we go through the lifelong journey of recovering from religious trauma.

Thanks to Dawne for sharing her story!


_________________________________________

episodes.title: Christians may be SINCERE, but they are SINCERELY WRONG - Anna McBride
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Anna McBride, who got drawn into conservative fundamentalist Christianity as a young adult, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Slowly getting pulled into conspiracy theories, the New Age movement, and various forms of spirituality.
• As a non-believer, joining a Christian group that lived the "Acts 2" life to the extreme where Christians were required to live in poverty and do ministry for free.
• Starting to study the Bible for herself and becoming convinced that it was true and from god.
• Giving her life wholeheartedly to Jesus as her Savior and getting convicted that she needed to be sold out to and live wholeheartedly for him.
• Becoming increasingly exposed to fundamentalist Christian preachers.
• Getting married with Jesus as the cornerstone of their marriage and home.
• Noticing major discrepancies between what her pastor was preaching vs. what she was reading in the Bible.
• Starting to feel disillusioned in her Christian journey as she began to see severe hypocrisy and division in their church family and Bible study groups.
• Being severely jolted as they went on a missions trip that caused overwhelming anxiety and upheaval.
• Starting to deconstruct Christian culture, starting with the Christian tendency toward extreme sheltering from and escaping the world, as well as fearmongering and manipulation.
• Rejecting the teaching of hell and embracing universal salvation.
• Admitting to herself that there's simply no way that Christianity could be true.
• Enjoying the experience of no longer sensing that god was looking at her and judging her.
• Losing dear Christian friends due to her leaving Christianity.
• Going through the journey of healing from religious trauma.
• Finding more freedom and happiness after leaving Christianity.

Thanks to Anna for sharing her story!

episodes.title: HOW TO KILL gOD the easy way - Alan Bondar
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Alan Bondar, who grew up in a Christian environment, gave his life to Jesus at a young age, and became a pastor of his own church plant, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• As a child, developing a strong passion for the Bible and theology.
• Preaching at youth services and even a funeral at age 11.
• Getting intense Biblical education but noticing that many others at Bible college were not seriously committed to Jesus and to purity.
• Starting to question certain aspects of his faith but turning to Pastors and Christian counselors for help.
• Healing from a severe depression and then realizing that god was not really there one day while praying.
• After breaking the addiction of smoking, realizing that there were many parallels to escaping the addiction of a pretend god, as a void that you can never fill but feel compelled to try, wrapped in the context of the nonstop shame of repeatedly failing.
• Leaving any hopes of returning to ministry and the pastorate as he fully deconverted.
• Realizing that Christianity had stolen his identity but that humanism helped him recover it.
• Healing from the false worldview, lost time, and shame that the Christian worldview had inflicted on him.

Many thanks to Alan for sharing his story and insights!

episodes.title: Sometimes you've just got to laugh at the crazy things you used to believe - Karen Alea
episodes.description:
*Apologies for the issue with the background changing a few times toward the beginning of the video.  It's a very small percentage of the video, fortunately.  I'll make sure it doesn't happen again.  --Tim

_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Karen Alea, who grew up in the Southern Baptist Church and gave her life to Jesus at an early age, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a very protective and sheltering patriarchal home.
• Answering an altar call at church and giving her life to Jesus.
• Realizing the strangeness of a "revival service" being "scheduled" by church leadership.
• Hearing purity culture messages pushing her to be ultra modest to the point of making her extremely self-conscious about her body.
• Finding, upon getting baptized, that she became extremely aware of her inherent shame and how much her body was tempting the men in the church.
• Being in church many times each week and attending the church's school.
• Finding that she got her purpose and meaning from serving Jesus as she felt that she owed her life to Jesus, yet still feeling that she was never doing enough and that she was disappointing him often.
• Being taught, by age 12, to pray for her future husband.
• Feeling compelled to do full time ministry and to be willing to sacrifice everything for Jesus.
• Focusing heavily on internal purity so god could use her for ministry.
• Recognizing the benefit of the Christian habit of being vulnerable but also realizing that it put her into a fight or flight mode multiple times every week.
• At YWAM's DTS, being guided by non-professional Christians to dig up and even make up personal stories and emotions during regular times of "openness and brokenness" and being urged to find something wrong in her relationship with her earthly father to contrast to her heavenly father.
• On missions trips, realizing that people in foreign countries with very different worldviews were truly joyful and at peace.
• Slowly being shaken up as she began to dig into the Bible more, such as when she realized the two sets of "10 Commandments" in the Bible were different.
• Studying the mythology tropes that are woven into the Bible.
• After deconversion, using humor as part of the healing process.

Thanks to Karen for sharing her story and insights!


_________________________________________

episodes.title: Shame belongs to the Oppressors - Jenny McGrath
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Jenny McGrath, who grew up exposed to Christianity, placed her faith in Jesus at a young age, and became very active in overseas missions, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up being homeschooled and spending a lot of time in church.
• At a young age, asking Jesus to come into her heart, and then repeating that process to ensure she was really saved.
• From a young age, being concerned about the eternal state of her friends.
• Focusing obsessively on being honest, good, and pure so that she could be right with god at all times, but still feeling dirty and wrong all the time anyway.
• Getting a purity ring at age 13, leading her to focus even more on honoring god through chastity, but also feeling more shame than ever.
• Becoming disembodied as her nervous system reached critical stages of "fight or flight" and led her to disassociate from the perceived spiritual threats.
• Being taught that she could not trust herself or her body, but finding a safe place to feel more embodied as she did competitive dancing.
• After an experience with a sexual predator, doubling down into how much she needed to work to be good and overcome her shame of feeling like "soiled goods."
• Sensing that god was crushing her as a way to punish her for her sins and refine her.
• Doing missions in Uganda and South Africa to take her spiritual sacrifices and outreach to the next level.
• At a secular school, being free for the first time to truly question her white, heteronormative theology and worldview.
• Learning to see people's humanity and individual journeys instead of seeing them as a project and someone to "save."
• Realizing that she had not been taught about autonomy and consent in relationships, especially in the context of patriarchy-based courtships.
• Deconstructing her faith as she learned more about the evolution of the Jesus character and the way the early church used power and violence to force people to adopt Christianity.
• The importance of health sex therapy to heal from purity culture.
• The importance of teaching body and thought autonomy to the next generation, without threats or coercion, and with the necessary resources to make informed decisions.
• Moving past the good spirit / bad body duality that was prevalent from her Christian background.

Many thanks to Jenny for sharing her story and insights!


_________________________________________

IG: @indwell_movement

episodes.title: We've lost our parents to a DOOMSDAY CULT - Apostate Sisters
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Patti and Nancy, who grew up in the Worldwide Church of god but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• How cult founder Herbert Armstrong tried to find and create the "true church" as he created the Worldwide Church of god.
• How the cult created high, holy days based in large part on the Old Testament calendar and instituted endless rules and regulations for congregants.
• Seeing Herbert Armstrong's pattern of exploiting the vulnerable.
• Being taught to hate and fear the world, its systems, and the cultures in it.
• Feeling safety and pride over being secure as one of god's "elect."
• Watching their parents lose their connection to the real world as the cult sucked them in deeper and deeper, to the point that their parents have barely spoken to them in 20 years.
• Growing up thinking the world was probably going to end soon so it wasn't important to be very connected to the world, but to instead remain focused on the world to come.
• Being insulated from other cultures and ideas in the context of a strong "us vs. them" mentality.
• Noticing that the church was hyper focused on describing the chaos and dangers of the world while describing themselves as the "safe place" for believers.
• Seeing marriage to a Christian man as a healthy choice in order to remain equally yoked and under the authority and protection of a man, with the background goals of feeling valued and secure.
• Being shamed, as a child, for exploring her own body, and being told that her body and its ability to give and receive pleasure was "for her future husband," which ultimately led to a cycle of disembodiment and shame.
• Realizing that Christians often poison the well against important information and ideas, leading people to eventually deconstruct as they see Christians as no longer honest and safe.
• Working hard to improve the world for future generations through a perspective of "optimistic nihilism."

Many thanks to Patti and Nancy for sharing their stories and insights!

episodes.title: I'm DONE with being CATFISHED by your pretend god - Tai Goodwin
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Tai Goodwin, who grew up in a Baptist church and placed her faith in Jesus at a young age, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Placing her faith in Jesus at an early age in large part due to the mostly positive example of strong Christian women in her life.
• Being afraid of being "left behind" when Jesus came back to Rapture his church.
• Starting to doubt her salvation as she wrestled with whether she was rejecting sin and pursuing god enough.
• Moving away from the church and Christianity as she saw the powerlessness of prayer.
• Realizing that people who had been exposed to the Gospel and Biblical teaching for decades were often unkind and unhappy.
• Feeling like god was refusing to show up to help her and others in need.
• Admitting that she could not connect to the god of her mother anymore but asking god, if he were real, to find a way to connect with her.
• Admitting that the Yahweh character is a hyper-abusive psychopath and that he would be entirely undeserving of worship if he were real.
• The beauty of being able to ask hard questions and to glean from various worldviews without including dogmatism.
• The importance of not raising kids based on the motivation of fear and punishment and instead helping them to gain their autonomy and becoming fully themselves.

Thanks to Tai for sharing her story and insights!

episodes.title: LOVE and HELL are INCOMPATIBLE - Eady Jay
episodes.description:
T/W - Childhood sexual abuse
C/W - Interviewee has deconstructed but not deconverted

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Eady Jay, who grew up in fundamentalist Christianity but ultimately deconstructed her faith substantially as she examined key tenets of the faith.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Trusting Jesus as her savior early in life.
• Voraciously reading her Bible and memorizing lots of verses.
• Growing up with immense guilt to the point that as a pre-teen, she faced profound self-hatred.
• Seeing Jesus as her best friend as a way to assuage the pain of loneliness and depression.
• Feeling the need to be fake in church as her peers were full of joy and fervor for worship, but she was facing emptiness and anger inside.
• Questioning at times whether she might lose her salvation if her sins got bad enough, and consequently never being able to "rest" in her salvation.
• Realizing, through counseling, that a lot of her shame may have stemmed from childhood sexual abuse.
• Being taught that she needed to focus on forgiving abusers instead of her own self-care and healing.
• Starting to deconstruct the message of hell and eternal conscious torment and becoming a hopeful universalist after she moved away from messages of legalism and guilt and instead embraced the message of "no condemnation" as she learned more about god's radical grace and love.
• Being taught in church that being gay was a sin but starting to be conflicted and think through her perspectives on it as she realized that some of the family members whom she cared about were gay.
• Seeing that the Bible is just people giving their personal opinion as they tried to grapple with who they thought god was to them.
• Starting to move away from the Bible as a rulebook for life today as she realized how the Bible was put together and that it was a very human book, and nothing more.
• The importance, as we examine religious texts, of understanding the original text, language, and cultural meaning, and how it has been influenced and re-interpreted since the books were canonized.
• Deconstructing but not fully deconverting, in part due to feeling like letting go of the "god" concept entirely would negatively affect her mental health.
• Holding on to the hope of an afterlife and universal reconciliation.
• The beauty of raising kids without the concepts of "sin" and "salvation."
• The importance of healing from purity culture, especially when there was childhood sexual trauma as well.

Thanks to Eady for sharing her story and insights with us today!

episodes.title: My heart cannot ACCEPT what my mind REJECTS - Dan Barker
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Dan Barker, who grew up in a Christian home, got very involved in missions, and became a pastor for many years, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up feeling meaning and purpose through god and the Gospel.
• Feeling comfort and pride as he thought he was growing up growing up in the "right" religion and denomination with the "right interpretation" of the Bible.
• At age 15, accepting a call to ministry, leading to him focus on evangelism, missions, itinerant preaching and singing, and being a pastor.
• Realizing that there are many kinds of Christians with many divergent interpretations of the Bible, including the idea that some characters may have been allegorical.
• Needing to make the active choice to reject the path of fear and to choose the path of open inquiry and integrity.
• Realizing, as part of the deconversion process, that we are grieving the loss of things that we never actually had, like an afterlife and a heavenly father.
• Learning to radically change our perspective through the process of "contraduction."
• The importance of being involved in political and social change to help our country and world move past mythology-based worldviews and to support the separation of church and state.

Many thanks to Dan for sharing his story and for all he has been doing for the community for many years!

episodes.title: I DON'T BELIEVE in SALVATION ~ and ~ I DON'T BELIEVE in SIN - Shelley Segal
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Shelley Segal, who grew up in a tight-knit Jewish community and was a very serious believer, but ultimately deconverted as she examined her worldview in depth.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Praying every day to god and writing songs to him.
• Growing up feeling very connected to god but in some ways very separate from the world.
• Learning about evolution as she started to study biology and consequently finding her Biblical worldview seriously challenged for the first time.
• Feeling degraded as a woman when she experienced gender segregation in her synagogue and being told that women could not lead the services, sing unaccompanied by men, be a rabbi, or touch the (male) rabbi.
• Hearing men being taught to pray, "Dear god, thank you for not making me a woman," and being trained to respond with the other women, "Dear god, thank you for making me what I am."
• Starting to face many aspects of cognitive dissonance as she experienced more aspects of her synagogue's teachings and culture.
• Attending Jewish school during the day and a Zionist group on the weekends.
• Facing pushback from her family when she dated a non-Jewish man but still ultimately feeling unconditional love from them.
• Trying to put together the extreme suffering in the world with her vision of the supremely good god she believed in.
• Embracing her autonomy and choosing to be free from patriarchy.

Thanks to Shelley for sharing her story and for all she does for the community!

episodes.title: Christianity is about power, control, abuse, and covering for the abusers - Sarah Caton
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Sarah Caton, who grew up as a pastor's daughter and placed her faith in Jesus at an early age, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up the daughter of parents who were focused on pastoring and missions who were focused on planting Baptist churches in Mormon areas.
• Becoming a very devout Christian from a very young age.
• Living in constant fear of the Rapture occurring and Jesus taking everyone in her family except her to heaven.
• Feeling intense pressure to be a "model Christian" in a "model Christian family."
• Starting in childhood, leading others to the Gospel message of salvation through Jesus.
• Constantly talking and praying to god, but never feeling any response from him.
• Being steeped and groomed in patriarchy to the point that she regretted being a woman due the need to submit and relinquish her power and rights.
• Within purity culture, having her body and normal desires demonized, and effectively being asked to deny her humanness.
• Seeing hypocrisy in the pulpit as she heard pastors preach about loving everyone but then later on telling racist and sexist jokes.
• Facing inconsistencies and issues in the Bible but finding ways to temporarily push aside the cognitive dissonance.
• Realizing, as Christians, that our faith was being sustained in large part by mental gymnastics and the overarching fear of death.
• Seeing the ways that Christianity turns people into moral monsters as they would be willing to sacrifice or kill their own children for the sake and commands of Yahweh.
• Being cut off from her parents and "turned over to her sin" when she deconverted from Christianity.
• Needing to stay away from most of her family due to the severe trauma and further indoctrination they were intent on inflicting on her.
• Reclaiming her identity and self-worth and starting to heal from severe religious trauma after deconverting from Christianity.

Many thanks to Sarah for writing her book and sharing her story with us today!


_________________________________________

episodes.title: The Christian worldview is based on lies, and I can't believe it anymore - Michelle Brown
episodes.description:
C/W - drug usage, molestation, suicide ideation, infant death

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Michelle Brown, who gave her life to Jesus in her teen years and fervently worshipped and served god for decades, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Being drawn to Christianity as a child based on its positive effect on her mom and family.
• Attending a very strict and legalistic Pentecostal church but still enjoying the church community.
• Seeing her childhood pastor, whom she deeply admired, steal a large amount of money from her mother.
• Asking Jesus to heal a physical issue with her fingers, but facing the reality that Jesus never did.
• As a Christian, delighting in the worship and church life.
• Seeing her Christian family turn their backs on her repeatedly over the years.
• Hearing a preacher tell the deacons to lock the church doors until a certain amount of donations was collected from the congregation.
• Seeing a pastor refuse to help a homeless mother and child in distress, due to not being able to "verify her story."
• Being asked by Pastors to do counseling work for the church without pay, and when she declined, being released by the Pastors from that church position.
• When her infant grandson died in a pool accident, being told by Christians that the angels took him to heaven and that god took him because they loved the baby too much.
• Starting to connect the dots between the Bible and the earlier mythologies from which it was plagiarized.
• Realizing that her Christian worldview had been based on lies, and that she could no longer believe.
• Being surprised and hurt by Christians not being open to honest discussions about the origins of Christianity.
• Understanding that Christianity and the Bible are in many ways about racism, white supremacy, slavery, and colonialism.
• Facing intense patriarchy and misogyny in the church.
Seeing 
• The importance of loving yourself through the deconversion and healing process.
• Admitting that the Yahweh character is a psychopath and that the Bible's messages are nonsensical.

Many thanks to Michelle for sharing her story!

episodes.title: I can no longer have blind faith in creeds, because I am no longer blind - Julia Scheeres
episodes.description:
C/W - racism, physical torture, mental health, sexual assault, molestation
 
_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Julia Scheeres, author of "Jesus Land: A Memoir."  She grew up in the Dutch Reformed Calvinist church and believed in Jesus from a young age, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Growing up in a conservative, racist community in Indiana that severely abused her black adopted siblings.
• Attending strict and morose churches that preached harsh messages of god's wrath.
• Seeing her parents adopt two black children as a way of proving their obedience to god, even though they were not really prepared.
• Being sent, along with her brother, to a Christian therapeutic disciplinary reform school in the Dominican Republic.
• Being taught to have intense shame and fear regarding her body and sexuality.
• Due to intense stress in her home and the messaging of never being good enough, having vivid nightmares in her childhood that sometimes even caused her to throw up.
• Having her curiosity and questions squashed, but eventually learning more about science and evolution, which broadened her perspectives and allowed her to explore new information and ideas.
• The importance and beauty of raising children without the concept of sin and with a heavy emphasis on their autonomy.
• Intentionally choosing to permanently move past the negativity and disapproval of her Christian parents.

Many thanks to Julia for sharing her story!

episodes.title: When I escaped Christianity, I was finally able to be my authentic self - Lori Nelson
episodes.description:
C/W - domestic abuse, verbal abuse, psychological abuse, rape, self-harm, cutting, alcoholism.

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Lori Nelson, who grew up in the Lutheran church and placed her faith in Jesus at a young age, but ultimately deconverted as she examined the truth claims of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Not hearing much about the Gospels or salvation as she attended a Lutheran church in her early childhood.
• After her mom got saved, learning more about Jesus and heaven, and eventually placing her faith in Jesus as she heard more about him and heaven after her mom.
• Attending charismatic churches where she heard preachers talk about casting out demons.
• Marrying a youth pastor and facing a very abusive marriage right away, including constant put-downs and marital rape.
• Learning to embrace her sexual desires for women.
Seeing her mom claim a physical healing, and then lose it and get very sick.
• Being shocked and disillusioned at Christians labeling Donald Trump as a good and moral person.
• Begging god to show up and reveal himself but hearing only silence.
• Deconverting fully and going through the grieving process as she realized that her "heavenly father" never existed.
• The importance of getting a thorough education on the origins of the Bible and Christianity as part of the healing process and fully letting go of Christianity.
• Realizing that if the Yahweh character had been real, he would be a psychopathic narcissist.
• Seeing her love outgrowing the toxic belief system of Christianity.
• As she deconverted, finally being able to authentically be herself.

Many thanks to Lori for sharing her story!

episodes.title: I have just one creed: EVERYONE is related and EVERYTHING is connected - Larry Jordan
episodes.description:
Around 1:13:00, there is a 30-second issue with the audio going silent.  I added CC/Subtitles for that section.  Please turn on CC for a moment at that point to read the text of the conversation.  Apologies for this mistake! --Tim

_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Larry Jordan, who grew up Catholic but began to question his beliefs and worldview in adulthood, and ultimately deconverted but embraced a spiritual perspective focused on how we are interconnected to others and to the world around us.

We touched on many topics, including:

• As an adult, diving deep into learning about Christianity, Catholicism, and the other world religions.
• Selling most of his possessions in order to fully serve the poor and needy.
• Rethinking his position on the LGBTQ community.
• Realizing there were endless variations of Christianity and that each of their beliefs and traditions had evolved over time, yet each branch of Christianity sees their version as the traditional and correct one.
• Going through an angry phase as he exited Christianity. 
• Studying and appreciating the difference between Eastern and Western worldviews and philosophy.
• Diving deep into science with its focus on evidence and mysticism with its focus on experience. 
• Reshaping his perspective toward a oneness, an interconnection with the universe. 
• Addressing the fact that many people have had what they consider to be mystical, transcendent experiences.
• The importance of having enough humility to reach out of our worldview comfort zone and admit that others with divergent beliefs might be right -- or at least have helpful insights.
• Unpacking the implications of the idea that everyone's related and everything's connected, including the idea that what hurts others also hurts us and the need to provide the greatest benefit to the most amount of people.
• Dropping the need to have a label for ourselves and our belief system.
• Admitting we believe things because they're comfortable, not because they're sensible.
• Realizing that as part of the total indoctrination process, many people have been trained to think that if their belief system were incorrect, reality would be chaos, there would be no morality, and life might not even feel like it was worthy living anymore -- and that in such a mentality, believers would rather not know if they were wrong.
• The importance of remaining humble and admitting that others might be right as we learn more about the universe and our existence.

Many thanks to Larry for sharing his story and insights!



_________________________________________

episodes.title: Extremist beliefs are like intoxicating drugs - Lisa Kohn
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Lisa Kohn, who grew up in the cult known as the "Moonies."  She slowly escaped the cult, and Christianity as a whole, as the truth claims fell apart and she reclaimed her autonomy.

We touched on many topics, including:

• At age ten, watching her mom get loved-bombed by the Moonie church.
• Hearing that Rev. Sun Myung Moon was the Messiah and that his writings were the "completed testament."
• Seeing her mom agree to leave her family to do full-time ministry for the church.
• Being instilled with the importance of never being mad or sad, or having any wants.
• Learning that it was virtuous to make severe sacrifices and be willing to suffer for god.
• Being taught that humans were constantly breaking god's heart and cause him to suffer, and that it needed to stop.
• Being taught that any doubts she might have were from Satan.
• Hearing that the sin in the Garden of Eden was Eve having sex with Satan as well as with Adam before they were married, that Jesus was supposed to have restored the right view of sexuality, but that he failed in his mission, and that Moon was the final Messiah who would show the correct away to live and restore humanity to god.
• Expecting, per the cult norm, to get married someday where her future husband would be directly chosen and her marriage be blessed by Moon.
• Hearing misogynistic messages, such as the idea that Eve was the cause of all human suffering.
• Being taught that the church members were heavenly warriors to create the kingdom of heaven on earth.
• Never feeling good enough, but instead being taught to think of herself as evil, sinful, and tainted.
• Struggling with overwhelming self-revulsion and consequently punishing herself for failing.
• Being told by Moon that she was bad and could no longer associate with his children.
• Facing intense cognitive dissonance as she was told to reject her gay friends.
• Starting to experience life "on the outside" of the cult, so she could make a solid decision if it was or was not right for her.
• Understanding that shame-based worldviews are built around lies.
• Starting the long journey toward healing, starting with the messaging, at her core, that she needed to fully love herself, show herself compassion, and see herself as "enough" and "worthy."
• Reclaiming her autonomy and voice during the deconversion process.

Many thanks to Lisa for sharing her story and for all the does for the community!


_________________________________________

episodes.title: The more I studied the Bible, the more cognitive dissonance set in - Jennifer Graham
episodes.description:
T/W - child abuse, child neglect, sexual molestation

_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Jennifer Graham, who grew up in South Africa under the oppressive apartheid government and gave her life to the Lord early in life, but eventually deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Being taught that white people were the superior race and non-whites were the cursed "descendants of Ham."
• Being fully indoctrinated into Christianity with a strict message that while god loves you, he will also pay you back terribly for your sins and mistakes.
• Growing up in a strict Pentecostal church that focused intensely on messages of obedience and blind faith.
• Never feeling like she could "rest" in her salvation due to the constant messaging of how bad she was and 
• Seeing her father plant a church and become the head pastor.
• Attending Pentecostal revival and healing meetings.
• Growing up with strict modesty rules.
• Being traumatized by men in church who would grope and molest the young girls, while also being taught that when a man did assault a girl, it was probably her fault for wearing something inappropriate.
• Placing her faith in Jesus at age 12 and rededicating her life to the Lord at age 16.
• As she went through a mass baptism in a river, being told that her old self had died and she was a new creation.
• Knowing intellectually about the love of god but feeling unloved and having low self-esteem due to having a very dysfunctional family life and having to maintain a façade of being a healthy family.
• Being raised in a family where the physical and emotional abuse was woven into the parenting style, combined with strong messages of her never being good enough and needing to constantly repent.
• Being discouraged from higher education and urged instead to focus on marriage and motherhood.
• Needing to get married in England due to the criminalization of mixed-race relationships in South Africa.
• Being told that her immense depression was her fault and a result of her sin and being therefore driven to double her efforts to surrender to god, obey, and passionately pursue him.
• Starting to work through the idea that her worth was found only in god, and eventually deeply questioning the validity of the Bible and of Christianity.
• Getting increasingly troubled by the "worm theology" she kept hearing across multiple churches and denominations.
• Slowly realizing she was worthy and good in her own right, and that she did not need a savior.
• Understanding that, opposed to what she had been taught, faith is not actually a virtue and is instead a poor substitute for not having answers.
• Fully deconverting from Christianity.
• Seeing her depression, fear, and anxiety drop dramatically after deconversion.

Many thanks to Jennifer for sharing her story!


_________________________________________

episodes.description:
C/W - brief discussion of marital abuse, rape

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Laurel Ebert, who grew up in nominally Christian environment and eventually got very serious about her faith in Jesus, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Growing up believing in god but deeply wanting him to prove his existence.
• Fearing immense guilt from not living up to god's expectations.
• When her human father passed away when she was 5, seeing god as somewhat of a father substitute.
• Going to AA for a season and hearing the undercurrent of god as the "higher power."
• Starting to attend an Assemblies of god church.
• As she began to go through the entire Bible verse by verse, finding problematic, contradictory, bizarre, horrific, and misogynistic stories and teachings.
• Realizing that the Yahweh character resembles an abusive spouse and that the Bible is a bad moral compass.
• Finding that she had to bury her concerns to still remain in Christianity.
• Being disgusted by the behavior of Christians during Covid and the Trump presidency.
• Finding that after deconversion she was experiencing more peace and doing more for those in need than she'd ever done while a Christian.
• Enjoying the freedom after deconversion, for the first time, to think and talk honestly about crucial questions.

Many thanks to Laurel for sharing her story and insights!

episodes.title: I'll be listening to my own voice and trusting my own understanding from now on - Ursula Schneider
episodes.description:
C/W - domestic abuse, suicide ideation, suicide

_________________________________________

** Background art by Ursula Schneider

_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Ursula Schneider, who grew up believing in Jesus but ultimately deconverted as she examined the truth claims of Christianity, especially regarding the Biblical teachings of patriarchy and misogyny.

We discussed many topics, including:

• As a young child, seeing her parents get saved and switch from a Catholic church to an evangelical charismatic one.
• Seeing her mom get diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia and her family split up, and begging god in vain to heal her mom's mental health issues.
• Watching her mom try to cast out demons.
• Frequently rededicating her life to Jesus to be sure she was truly saved.
• Hearing lots of preaching about the end times and the Rapture/Tribulation.
• Being disturbed by the Biblical stories of people drowning outside Noah's ark during the flood, and of Abraham being willing to slaughter Isaac to obey Yahweh.
• Actively sharing the Gospel with the lost.
• Facing increasing patriarchy and misogyny as she entered adulthood.
• After her sister died of suicide, dealing with the concern that her sister might have gone to hell.
• Beginning to use her leadership skills on the worship team at her church and getting more fervent in her relationship with Jesus in both her private and public life.
• Realizing that the people in the church, who had been heavily exposed to the Word of god and the Gospel, were not showing any evidence of being transformed by the Gospel.
• Experiencing tremendous patriarchy and misogyny from several churches, which caused her to do more research and investigation than ever before.
• Learning to listen to her own voice and trust her own understanding for the first time and she became free to think and make choices for herself, apart from the claims of Christianity.
• Realizing that the kindness she had shown to others stemmed from her own heart, not from Jesus.
• Fully deconverting from Christianity and going through a process of being angry and grieving the loss of Christian friends.
• Healing from internalized misogyny.
• Seeing the trend of deconverted Christians losing their Christian friends and their former support system and facing intense loneliness as Christians punish them for leaving.
• Discovering that almost no Christians were willing to talk with her about why she left.

Many thanks to Ursula for sharing her story and insights!

episodes.title: The choice to examine our beliefs & question our assumptions changes everything - Anthony Dominello
episodes.description:
C/W - brief discussion of suicide ideation
_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Anthony Dominello, who grew up grew up in a Catholic home and trusted Jesus as his savior at a young age, but ultimately deconverted as he examined the truth claims of the Bible and Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• "Accepting Jesus into his heart" in his teenage years while switching from a Catholic to an evangelical church.
• Facing a great deal of anxiety over science-related topics and stories.
• Getting exposed to Jehovah's Witnesses, Quakers, and even Wiccans/Neo Pagans.
• The importance of being skeptical and carefully examining our beliefs and assumptions, even long after deconverting from Christianity.
• Realizing our tendency to lean toward established narratives -- regardless of whether they are true -- and admitting we all have blind spots in our thinking and research.
• Seeing that we tend not to question the beliefs we were taught as children and thus need to develop critical faculties as adults.
• The importance of practicing radical candor.
• How being on the autism spectrum can affect the way autistic people interpret the Biblical stories and their Christian experience.
• Understanding that the competing narratives of the books in the Bible were written by people who were interpreting the Yahweh character in wildly different ways.
• How the Recovering From Religion organization can support those who are deconstructing their faith.

Many thanks to Anthony for sharing his story and insights!

episodes.title: You don't need to believe it if it doesn't have evidence and doesn't make sense - Becca
episodes.description:
C/W - brief discussion of domestic violence and suicide ideation

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Becca, who grew up in the Assemblies of God church and placed her faith in Jesus as her savior as a young child, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Facing a traumatic home life due to her dad being an elder in the church while her mom dealt with depression, schizophrenia, and suicidal ideation.
• Being told at church that the Bible is the answer to everything, so higher education was not emphasized.
• Having elders blame her mom's mental health issues on demons and try in vain to perform exorcisms on her.
• Facing intensely dramatic and chaotic worship services at church, including dancing, speaking in tongues, and crying.
• Constantly confessing her sins in order to not backslide and lose her salvation.
• Not being allowed to focus on her own thoughts and feelings but being urged to instead always focus on god and on what would make him happy.
• Facing Rapture anxiety as she expected the Lord's return at any moment.
• Doing street evangelism with her father.
• Thinking early on that the unbelievers around her did not deserve hell.
• Being groomed, as a woman, to be ultra submissive, to not be assertive or pursue any leadership roles, and to not trust herself.
• Struggling with the conundrum of bringing children into the world with the knowledge that there was a chance they could go to hell.
• Concluding that the evidence in the New Testament portraying Jesus as fulfilling Old Testament prophecies was weak and uncompelling.
• Realizing that the Gospel accounts are fictional stories crafted from earlier mythological stories.
• Losing her first marriage due to worldview differences.
• Raising the next generation with an emphasis on their autonomy, education, and science.
• The importance of telling ourselves that we don't have to believe what doesn't have any evidence and doesn't make sense to us.

Many thanks to Becca for sharing her story and insights!

episodes.title: I escaped Christianity and reclaimed my personal sovereignty - Matt Martz
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Matt Martz, a video producer and a musician who worked for Ravi Zacharias as well as an Atlanta megachurch, but ultimately deconverted as he examined the truth claims of Christianity and the Bible.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Being fearful about hell very early in life.
• Realizing the connection between the spectrum of personality types and each person's unique way of pursuing their relationship with god.
• Experiencing life with very deep feelings and strong curiosity.
• Finding endless "plot holes" in the story of the Bible and the Christian worldview.
• Discerning early the mixed messages of the loving "Sunday school" Jesus character contrasted with the psychotic personality and anger of the Yahweh character in the Old Testament.
• Understanding that trauma does semi-permanent damage to the brain, and how that plays into recovering from religious harm.
• Feeling for a long time like god and Jesus were mostly there to induce guilt.
• During his teenage years, facing immense depression mixed with desperation to be grounded and to find peace.
• Feeling god's presence during devotional worship experiences.
• Beginning to struggle with the theology of worship music, such as why we have to keep telling god how great he is.
• Realizing that Christianity took away his personal sovereignty and that the whole paradigm of Christianity should be questioned instead of approached with assent and submission.
• Understanding that the Christian worldview leads to neuroses.
• Working closely with Ravi Zacharias for several years but picking up on his façade and fakeness.
• After he lost a dear friend, feeling drawn to god through what seemed like a supernatural experience.
• During grad school, learning a great deal about the Bible that helped him realize that there was a lot more he did not know, and struggling with the topic of theodicy.
• Deconverting from Christianity, but not necessarily landing in atheism.
• Realizing the naïveté that he once had and that Christians still have in order to hold on to the Christian worldview.
• Rethinking heaven, especially in light of the Bible's description of people having to first have their memory partially erased and their personalities highly edited in order to be happy and sinless in heaven.
• Admitting how truly monstrous it is to be okay with your loved ones being tortured forever in hell while you are blissfully happy in heaven.

Many thanks to Matt for sharing his story and insights!

episodes.title: Wounds run deep from the manipulation and shame used by high-control religions - Megan Von Fricken
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Megan Von Fricken, a religious harm recovery coach who grew up believing in Jesus but ultimately deconverted as she examined the truth claims of Christianity and the Bible.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a very structured version of Christianity where there were extensive rules to keep everyone thinking and doing the "right" things.
• Seeing her parents get strongly connected to a small fundamentalist church for a few years and then switching to another small fundamentalist church, repeatedly.
• Being taught that there is just one "black and white" way to think and live, and everything that went against that was unacceptable and seen as sinful or worldly.
• Facing lots of modest rules to ensure she stayed pure and was not a stumbling block to men.
• Being told that the only reason for any relationships with a man was to see if he was "marriage material."
• Placing her faith in Jesus at a young age, with a special focus on escaping hell.
• Rededicating her life to Christ in her teen years as she got exposed to the Left Behind / Rapture concept.
• Going through salvation anxiety as she wondered over the years, many times, if she were truly saved.
• Seeing missionaries being elevated to celebrity status in church and being urged to share the Gospel with others herself, yet not feeling comfortable pushing her faith on others.
• Feeling extreme guilt over pursuing love and affection in her teenage years.
• Having her faith significantly shaken up when she heard Christian professors indicate that there were several legitimate interpretations of Genesis 1, especially in light of evolution and the science around the age of the earth and the universe.
• Realizing over the years that many other Christians have a vastly different perspective on the Bible 
• Starting to physically and emotionally separate from the church community.
• Understanding the generational trauma and attachment issues that had been woven into her family dynamics.
• Fully deconverting as the truth claims of Biblical inerrancy and Christianity fell apart.
• Doing the hard work of recovering from religious trauma and making peace with the harm that Christianity caused us and our families.

Many thanks to Megan for sharing her story and insights!

episodes.title: My faith died the death of a thousand unanswered prayers - Bart Campolo
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Bart Campolo, who grew up as the son of a famous but controversial preacher.  Bart got involved in ministry himself, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims and practical experience of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• As a child, admitting that the fantastical Gospel stories didn't make sense to him, but eventually, in his teen years, placing his faith in Jesus as his Savior.
• Having transcendent worship experiences at youth retreats that led him to think that he was sensing the Holy Spirit moving in him.
• Being groomed for leadership by his youth group leaders.
• Feeling driven to help those in great need so that he could truly care about them and give them a life purpose and a loving community.
• As a growing Christian, focusing his theology on god being the ultimate rescuer, hero, and healer.
• Facing a theological crisis as he became exposed to extreme urban poverty and violent crimes, while wondering why god did not intervene.
• Realizing the bizarreness and cruelty of the Gospel story and salvation message, and that because he was far more loving than the god of the Bible, he could no longer worship that god.
• As he deconverted, focusing on humanism where his meaning and purpose is wrapped around connecting with other people and helping them to thrive.

Many thanks to Bart for sharing his story and insights!

episodes.title: People believe in Christianity and conspiracy theories for the same reasons - Cynane Shay
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Cynane Shay, who grew up believing in Jesus but ultimately deconverted as she began to understand how conspiracy theories work and as she examined the truth claims of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a non-denominational church and attending a Christian school that strongly pushed propaganda for white Christian Nationalism and American exceptionalism.
• Feeling an indirect but strong influence from the teachings of the IBLP / Bill Gothard, especially focused on patriarchy and purity culture.
• Being taught that women are mentally, physically, and spiritually inferior to men, and that higher education for women was discouraged in light of gender role expectations.
• Getting saved early in life but frequently wondering if she were really saved or if she missed the Rapture.
• Being taught strict Biblical inerrancy and that the Scriptures should never be questioned.
• Compulsively trying to hear god's leading and will for her life.
• Recognizing early on that she was sometimes being emotionally manipulated in church.
• Interpreting emotional experiences as a divine experience.
• Being harassed by her mother and told that she would be judged by god in the afterlife for marrying a Catholic man.
• Being told by her family that she's been brainwashed by "higher education" even though college was not part of her deconversion.
• The crucial importance of experiencing a new social environment outside of Christianity, where she felt like she belonged.
• Starting to see evangelical Christians around her falling very hard for severe conspiracy theories.
• Seeing her family and loved ones create an arsenal of weapons in preparation for Armageddon and getting ready to "take America back for god" as part of the white Christian nationalist movement and as part of their overall perception that Christians are being persecuted.
• Discerning that Christianity has very well developed social and psychological control programs.
• Realizing that her entire knowledge base, as an evangelical Christian, had been built on a lie.
• Seeing that Christianity is, at its core, a conspiracy theory.

Many thanks to Cynane for sharing her story!

episodes.title: As you deconvert from Christianity, you need a sanctuary in the desert - Karl and Laura Forehand
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Karl and Laura Forehand, who grew up exposed to Christianity and eventually became a Pastor and Pastor's wife, but ultimately both deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

(KARL)
• Growing up exposed to Christianity and getting very serious about the Lord and ministry in his early adulthood.
• Becoming a Southern Baptist Pastor of a small church.
• Never fully buying into penal substitutionary atonement theory based on it being unreasonable.
• Wrestling with how to interact with the queer community.
• Diving deep into the questions of whether we are really sinners and really need to be "saved."
• Grappling with why god frequently doesn't show up at the darkest and most traumatic times of our lives.
• Deconverting from Christianity and starting to turn his focus on helping others dealing with religious trauma.
• Facing his childhood traumas head-on during the healing process.

(LAURA)
• Growing up in the Lutheran church where she was exposed to Christianity but not hearing an intense Gospel message and invitation.
• Feeling like she was "going through the motions" for some aspects of her time in Christianity and as a Pastor's wife.
• Carefully starting to talk with their kids about their deconstruction, only to find that their kids had already deconstructed beforehand.
• Finding immense respect and freedom to openly discuss hard topics after deconversion.
• The importance of getting professional help in dealing with religious trauma.
• Providing a safe place for others to share their stories without judgment.

Many thanks to Karl and Laura for sharing their stories, and for all they do for the community!

episodes.title: Sexism in Christianity: My experience as a Woman - Melanie Trecek-King
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Melanie Trecek-King, who grew up in a conservative Christian environment but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Growing up in a conservative fundamentalist church that preached young earth creationism.
• Hearing messages early on about women being created to serve men and that women's roles were very restricted to ensure men kept all the power.
• Being traumatized by the extreme misogyny, patriarchy, and hyper control of women that she was exposed to in church.
• Being told that being female was bad and the cause of the fall and all bad things in the world.
• Receiving messages in church about a woman's value being directly connected to her virginity.
• Hearing Christians "poison the well" about science, evolution, and atheism.
• Learning about cultural anthropology and connecting the dots about how gods were invented.
• Realizing that religion is used in almost every culture to justify sexist power structures.
• Realizing that the Yahweh character is psychopathic and that the Old Testament is full of toxic messages.
• Deconverting from Christianity and focusing her life on rationality and critical thinking.
• Seeing strong sexism in atheist communities.
• Creating a system for her students where she helps teach skills not facts by walking them through critical thinking, information literacy, and science literacy.
• Understanding why facts don't change our minds.
• Being aware that we often fall for misinformation when we are not skeptical enough and do not recognize our biases.
• The importance of having boundaries with conspiracy theorists and people who have fallen prey to misinformation.

Thanks to Melanie for sharing her story, insights, and work!

episodes.title: I kept noticing that the Gospel was powerless to actually change lives - Daranté Lamar
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Daranté LaMar, who grew up in the Word of Faith denomination and became a pastor for 10 years before ultimately deconverting as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• In his youth, observing his mom have a very moving spiritual experience at church.
• Accepting the invitation to accept god as his loving father, which was especially meaningful as he grew up feeling like an orphan.
• Being forced by his mother to either prioritize her or god and the church ... and proudly choosing god and the church.
• Hearing preachers encourage their congregations to purposely not focus on learning and knowledge, but to simply have blind faith.
• Believing that anything in his mind that was not aligned with the Bible was probably from the Devil.
• Growing in his leadership roles in ministry as well as his perceived spiritual power and influence, which he saw as evidence of god's blessing.
• Getting married before entering the pastorate to ensure he would not be sexually tempted in ministry.
• Constantly praying to god to ask him for clarity and direction.
• Seeing people in the church heavily exposed to the Bible and the church who were nonetheless not showing any evidence of the power of the Gospel to transform their lives.
• Observing his fellow pastors not caring about where the Bible really came from.
• Deconverting but not strongly feeling like the loss of "heaven" and the afterlife was a really big deal to him.
• Experiencing much more peace after deconversion than he ever had as a Christian.
• Realizing that Christianity had deprived his of his personal capacity, and being driven more than ever to achieve the most he is capable of and to keep asking hard questions.

Many thanks to Daranté for sharing his story and insights!

episodes.title: As I pastored for 20 years, the truth claims of Christianity kept on crumbling - Ed Raby
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Ed Raby, who grew up in the Pentecostal Assemblies of god denomination and worked an ordained minister for many years, but ultimately deconverted as he examined the truth claims of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Spending most of his life repeatedly confessing sin and rededicating his heart to the Lord due to hearing the constant message preached to him that he was never good or holy enough.
• Constantly pursuing more power, grace, and holiness in his relationship with god.
• Going down to the church alter frequently and "waiting" for the Holy Spirit to sanctify him and empower him for service.
• Slowing realizing that the charismatic/Pentecostal culture is a learned behavior, not a work of a supernatural being.
• Hearing many miracle stories but never actually seeing one that could be confirmed.
• Being taught that demons were trying to attack Christians, that spiritual warfare was real, and that its remedies were critical.
• Having a strong desire to do something great for god, which lead him into pastoral ministry.
• Observing other ministers being able to "work the crowd" to get the desired atmosphere and emotional hype.
• Despite having significant questions about the claims of Christianity and the Bible, staying entrenched in Christianity due to the sudden death of his father and his desire to see him again.
• Seeing his faith slowly dissipate as he investigated the evidence for the life of Jesus.
• Seeing how Christians attribute cultural and political dynamics to the supernatural realm, which ultimately makes them very susceptible to conspiracy theories.
• Struggling to be open with others about his doubts and eventual deconversion and worldview shift.
• Navigating relationships with Christian loved ones after deconversion.

Thanks to Ed for sharing his story and insights!

episodes.title: The Church of God tried to crush me, but I found my strength and fought my way out - Gloria Froese
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Gloria Froese, who grew up in the Church of God Restoration cult, a group that tried to crush and cripple her with its extremist ideologies and practices.  Gloria ultimately escaped as she examined the claims of the group and of Christianity as a whole.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Seeing her parents pursue homeschooling so they could keep the kids separate from the "world" and ensure a pure and sheltered educational experience for their children.
• Being loved-bombed by an ultra-conservative Church of God group that had emotionally charged worship service experiences.
• Being repeatedly and increasingly pressured by her mother to "get saved" by going to the front of the church when the invitation was given, even though she had already made a profession of faith earlier in her childhood.
• Seeing other children in the church being physically abused and psychologically coerced into "getting saved."
• Being mocked by other girls at church because she was wearing a short-sleeved dress.
• Being preached at by her pastor, as a child, about how Christ's sufferings were on her behalf, because of her wickedness.
• Hearing church leaders claim to have the authority and power to take away someone's salvation.
• How the push for extreme purity in the church leads to facades that allows believers to temporarily hide their deviant behavior.
• Hearing the church legislate and repress sexuality within marriage, insisting on hyper modesty even in the bedroom.
• Being told that she could not marry anyone she was physically attracted to, and instead had to marry whomever the church told her to marry.
• Hearing messages of intense hatred toward homosexuals.
• Facing pervasive purity culture where blouses had to go up to the neck, sleeves to the wrists, dresses to the ankle, and they had to wear stockings at all times.
• Enduring the myriad ways the church purposely fostered ignorance, especially about biology and sexuality.
• As a young person, having almost no idea how sexuality worked, and learning to completely turn off the aspects of sexuality she was aware of.
• Facing agony through her teenage years based on the intense legalism, restrictions, lack of information, and her prescribed role and future within the community.
• Seeing her church go through an intense, angry split that led many to leave.
• Being harassed by church members to get her to remain in the church even as her parents were moving on from it, but ultimately choosing to escape.
• Attending a liberal arts Christian college where the professors provided various interpretations of different topics but didn't dogmatically say which one was the sole correct version.
• Beginning to question her faith and worldview, slowly at first, but eventually realizing that Christianity is mythology and that she had been lied to her whole life.
• Understanding how the ultra-conservative arrogant Christian mindset acts like a drug.
• Experiencing much more peace after deconverting than she ever had as a Christian.

Many thanks to Gloria for sharing her story and insights!


_________________________________________
