episodes.title: A Christ Church elder molested me, and then the church blamed me for it - Emilie Paige Dye
episodes.description:
T/W - extensive discussion of severe child grooming, sexual exploitation, abuse.  Brief mention of suicide ideation, self-harm, and anorexia.

_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Emilie Paige Dye, who grew up in an evangelical household and placed her faith in Jesus at a young age, but ultimately deconverted after experiencing years of mistreatment by the church and examining the truth claims of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Getting saved early in life and then repeatedly rededicating her life to Jesus and repenting of sin to be sure she was truly saved.
• Being terrified of the Rapture and of being "left behind."
• Growing closer to the Lord, reading through the entire Bible many times, deepening her love for Jesus and the Gospel, and pursuing experiences of closeness to god.
• Seeing her parents hyper focused on getting their theology correct to the point that they had to switch churches frequently.
• Attending Logos School, which is part of the ministry of Doug Wilson and Christ Church in Moscow, Idaho.
• Due to purity culture, being scared of male-female relationships and knowing very little about her own body, while seeing virginity culture portrayed as the romantic ideal, especially in the context where the fathers are responsible to keep their daughters pure until marriage.
• Being intentionally groomed over time by an older male theology teacher at Logos School, who was also an Elder at Christ Church and one of her spiritual authorities, in the larger context of male leaders publicly touching and giving back rubs to some of the teenage girls on a regular basis.
• Being so overwhelmed with shame that she felt like she could not talk to anyone about the ongoing molestation.
• Hearing her abuser try to keep her in a cycle of shame by telling her she was culpable for being impure, that she had betrayed her parents, and that she had ruined herself for her future husband, even right after he had assaulted her, and then insisting she beg his forgiveness, which he would follow up by comforting her in her shame, starting the cycle of molestation all over again.
• Seeing the church community rally around her abuser as he confessed to a small portion of his severe abuses.
• Feeling ostracized by the Christ Church community as her story came to light.
• Being repeatedly blamed for the situation, despite being underage and despite the power dynamics at play in school and church.
• Realizing that Christians are hyper-sexualizing children through purity culture.
• Thinking through the ways that the Christian worldview is inherently abusive to women as calls them seductresses and labels them as inferior, and then blames, shames, and silences them.
• Understanding that she did not need the church to be healthy or thrive, and subsequently realizing that god was not real.
• Experiencing much more joy and peace after escaping Christianity than she ever had as a Christian.

Many thanks to Emilie for sharing her story, as well as for the many ways that her bravery and resilience have empowered others to tell their stories and heal from the Christ Church cult.

• Understanding that the "eternal life" that Jesus was offering was Ionic, and part of the message of existing Pythagorean mystery cults.

• Grasping the background of what Jesus was doing with a naked boy at 4am in a public park, why a child prostitute recognized the apostle Peter, why Jesus was naked in the upper room with the young boy disciples, and the real meaning behind the Mary Magdalene character.

episodes.title: Christianity stole my autonomy, voice, and joy ... but I fought hard to get them back - Jesse
episodes.description:
T/W - brief discussion of domestic violence, child abuse, and suicide ideation

_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Jesse, who grew up in a Christian environment and placed her faith in Jesus early in life, but fully deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a home where access to information was strictly controlled and any questions were seen as a challenge to authority and their ideological purity.
• Seeing punishments and physical abuse being widely advocated in Christian homeschool circles, in addition to the goals of indoctrinating, sheltering, demanding instant obedience, breaking a child's will, and seeing a child as depraved and sinful in their every impulse -- instead of understanding normal child development.
• Being forced to take on the role of a mother and parent for the younger siblings due to parental neglect and irresponsibility.
• Hearing lots of indoctrination messages in childhood through Christian radio.
• Feeling like she had no choice but to accept Jesus as her Savior, due to the family pressure and the threat of hell.
• Observing, even as a child, the difference between the harsh Jesus portrayed in the Bible versus the loving "Sunday school" Jesus.
• Feeling like her relationship with the Yahweh character was a rollercoaster, where some days she felt close to him, and some days she didn't, and there didn't seem to be a path forward to fix that dynamic.
• Becoming a perfectionist because the punishment for disobedience and mistakes was extensive violent physical abuse.
• Going numb as a teenager due to years of walking on eggshells and facing long-term emotional neglect.
• Feeling selfish and worthless the first time she made decisions that were truly focused on what she wanted.
• Finding more safety in a 12-step program than she'd ever found in church.
• Beginning to move past co-dependency with her parents and regaining her autonomy, and ultimately being able to do the same thing with the character of god.
• Learning to "adopt" and "reparent" herself as she began to heal from her childhood trauma and anxiety.
• The importance of creating a safe place for us to think through our worldview changes, reclaim our identities, and begin to heal.

Many thanks to Jesse for sharing her story!

episodes.title: I realized I was more loving than the god I was supposed to worship - Michael Lecy
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Michael Lecy, who grew up in an evangelical Christian environment and became a pastor for 13 years before ultimately deconverting as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:
• Placing his faith in Jesus as his savior at a young age.
• Growing up in a charismatic church with emotional extremes and intense experiences.
• Realizing that the teachings of the church weren't working to actually help people in their real lives.
• Realizing that Christianity is a very self-centered worldview, often leaving believers callous to the needs of others because they, the Christians, are ultimately in a safe and glorious condition regarding their ultimate and eternal home.
• Starting to think through critical questions such as eternal conscious torment, how adverse childhood experiences affect people's ability to believe, the inerrancy of Scripture, genocide, sex slavery, 
• Admitting that if god had been real, we would have to admit that he is a failure on the grand scale as well as our individual lives.
• Seeing that his Christian environment had kept critical information about the mythology that Christian is based on and poisoned the well about opposing viewpoints.
• Raising his kids without telling them they are wicked and deserve hell apart from god.
• Concluding that Christianity is a form of colonialism.
• Experiencing much more peace after deconversion than during his time as a Christian.
• Understanding that Christians are inherently nihilistic as they state or imply that this present world is relatively unimportant compared to the mythological life they are waiting for.
• How purity culture has created anxiety and shame as we consider our bodies, sexual desires, and relationships.
• The importance of trusting ourselves, advocating for our own agency, and letting go of our need for approval in what we believe.
• Seeing Christians shun and ostracize those who deconvert, but understanding that they are still in a mental prison themselves.

Thanks to Michael for sharing his story and insights!

episodes.title: We grow out of Christianity and begin to heal as love touches us deeply - Wiesje Verpeut
episodes.description:
T/W - brief discussion of childhood sexual abuse, self-harm/cutting, suicide ideation, domestic violence

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Wiesje Verpeut, who grew up in Belgium in a very evangelical family and dedicated her life to serving the Lord, but ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up with frequent and intense nightmares that bordered on being "demonic."
• Being oversexualized as a young girl, while being blamed for it by the adult men around her, and thus feeling like she was impure even though she had not done anything wrong.
• Being unable to cope with the situation when her first husband deconverted from Christianity.
• Getting involved in Pentecostalism, where she focused on spiritual warfare and spiritual/geographical mapping.
• Focusing on meditating, being in the presence of god, and pursuing spiritual experiences that promoted healing from her wounds and fears and pushed her toward the concept of the love of god.
• Getting so intense in her faith, at times, that family saw her version of Christianity as extreme.
• Slowly realizing that the Bible's message, especially the Gospel, was no longer important and necessary.
• Realizing that what we used to call "god" is simply our maturing inner awareness.
• Understanding that "facts" about history, politics, and religion have been heavily manipulated over time and that our minds have a strong tendency to accept what we've been taught, whether it's true or not.
• Moving past the concept of hell, sin, and judgment.
• Realizing that she was growing above Christianity in a peaceful way that allowed her to not be bitter at the lies of the religion but to simply focus on love.

Thanks to Wiesje for sharing her story and insights!

episodes.title: Dear Evangelicals: I can't pretend that your worldview makes sense anymore - Jamin Coller
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Jamin Coller, who grew up as a pastor's kid and became a worship pastor himself for 25 years before ultimately deconverting as he examined the truth claims of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Getting "saved" but repeatedly recommitting his life to Jesus to be confident that his salvation was absolutely certain.
• Experiencing cycles of "spiritual OCD" revolving around guilt, repentance, renewal, sinning again, and falling back into guilt.
• Seeing that Christian testimonies are extremely biased and do not prove that the Christian worldview is correct.
• Being strongly urged to not associate much with non-Christians or listen to their perspectives, and to instead stayed extremely sheltered and ignorant of other views.
• How using the "outsider test for faith" on other versions of Christianity, and religion in general, leads to the conclusion that people are often clinging to a worldview based on how they were indoctrinated, community pressure, and their feelings, instead of whether the claims are actually true.
• Being intensely shamed and demeaned by loved ones for asking hard questions about the Christian worldview, and ultimately facing extreme passive-aggressive shunning for deconverting.
• Being shocked at rampant anti-intellectualism in Christianity.
• Understanding that there have been many divergent understandings of the Yahweh and Jesus characters, and Christians are often referring to only one of those understandings and simply ignoring the rest.
• Watching the endless versions of Christianity continually try, over time, to adapt and evolve their messages to cultural sensitivities and politics, while consistently disparaging and fighting each other.
• The importance of helping kids get all the information possible to make worldview decisions, and to ensure they feel empowered in their autonomy to make the best decisions for themselves as they grow up, without threats of shunning or hell.

Many thanks to Jamin for sharing his story and insights!

episodes.title: Christianity trains people to believe in glaring falsehoods - Shane Almgren
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Shane Almgren, who grew in a fundamentalist evangelical charismatic Christian environment as a missionary kid and eventually became a worship leader himself, but ultimately deconverted as he examined the truth claims of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Admitting that the Christian worldview is not just erroneous but also truly horrifying.
• Facing early in life the discrepancy between the teaching that if you ask for something in Jesus' name that he will do it, versus the experience that he doesn't actually do things that you ask for in his name.
• Being told by his parents that he could always come to them with his questions and doubts yet being afraid to do so due to the heavy disciplinarian context at home.
• Moving to China with his family to become full-time missionaries.
• Badly wanting to have an increasing relationship with god but never being able to make it progress to deeper levels like the Christians around him claimed to be experiencing.
• Not seeing Christians clearly differentiate between the power of things that are perceived as magic or absurd claims versus the scientific explanation for what actually happened and the psychological dynamics for why were deceived -- especially in the realm of supernatural claims and conspiracy theories.
• Realizing that when we were Christians, what we called "knowledge" about the Christian belief system and worldview was actually just blind faith and the uncritical acceptance of our indoctrination and groupthink.
• How the church trains your thinking to interpret blind faith as a virtue and a show of piety.
• Understanding that Christianity systematically removes kids' thought autonomy.
• Going to Christians for help to understand the contradictions in the Bible and finding only that they felt unequipped and intimidated by the task, and ultimately wouldn't get involved in the discussions.
• The importance of breaking society from the supposed importance of making firm conclusions on topics for which there is no strong evidence either way.
• Seeing the connection between believing in the Christian worldview and being gullible regarding conspiracy theories, and ultimately realizing that Christianity is a bogus system that trains people to believe in glaring falsehoods.

Many thanks to Shane for sharing his story and insights!

episodes.title: Childhood indoctrination into Christianity is a core development trauma - Wren Story
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Wren Story, who grew up in the Independent Fundamental Baptist denomination and attended a Christian college but ultimately deconverted as she examined the truth claims of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Being adopted early in life and being separated from her siblings.
• As a young child, having her inner dialogue turn to perfectionism in the context of her blaming herself for her parents' divorce and the subsequent adoption that occurred and fearing that she needed to always be on her best behavior, or she could lose her adoptive family.
• Making a public profession of faith at an early age to win the approval of the adults in her life.
• Facing "salvation anxiety" as a young person as she felt the need to reaffirm her faith and rededicate her life to the Lord to be doubly sure that she was truly saved.
• Hearing messages of security being "grace based" and yet facing a church and home life context of works-based acceptance.
• Seeing the constantly reinforced messaging in Christianity that "you are the problem" and "you're never good enough."
• Observing church scandals where abusers are often protected, and subsequently connecting the dots that the church is already inherently committed to protecting the abusive character of god in order to avoid an identity crisis and the collapse of their worldview.
• Facing the conflicting doctrines of god being all good but also creating evil.
• Struggling with the concept that if Yahweh had been real, he would effectively be placing small children into harm's way every day on purpose.
• Intensely fearing a literal hell as she grew up.
• Realizing that many Christians do not truly believe in hell, even when they claim to, because if they really believed it was real, they could not enjoy a moment of this life while knowing people are actively being tortured there and would spend every waking moment sharing the Gospel to try to rescue people from hell.
• Being heartbroken over Christians gloating over people going through torture both in this life and in the mythological construct of hell.
• Realizing that while Christians claim to be "pro life," their worldview is inherently "pro death."
• Experiencing struggles and challenges during her early parenting phase of life that caused her to continue to ask hard questions about her worldview.
• Seeing the Christian worldview as a horrible magic spell that needs to be broken.
• Being overwhelmed with joy to realize that hell, and the entire Christian worldview, are not real.
• Using her skills and passions to help move humanity through our existential crisis with the hopes of a better future, especially the future generations. 

Many thanks to Wren for sharing her story and insights!

• Seeing the cultural dynamics of Christian nationalism in the US and Hindu nationalism in India.
• Understanding the ways that misogyny is woven into the fabric of Hinduism, regardless of caste.

episodes.title: I left Christianity and discovered true peace and freedom - Ginger
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Ginger, who grew up as a Southern Baptist and gave her life to Jesus early in life, but eventually deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up fairly sheltered in a small Southern Baptist Church.
• Hearing the message that if you are obedient to god, he will help you, but if you are disobedient, he will not.
• Focusing strongly on small group Bible studies, personal worship, and evangelism conferences, especially as a way to have emotional experiences with god and to hear from him.
• Having her faith strengthened as a child when she would pray for simple things and they would happen (e.g., to have a day where nothing terrible happened).
• Feeling a burden and pressure to save people from hell but struggling to verbally share the gospel due to shyness.
• Being taught the men are the head of the household and that women needed to submit and be the homemaker.
• Struggling with depression as a young adult and finding herself slowly drifting away from her faith.
• Fasting and praying for healing for her marriage, but not seeing any answers to prayer.
• Thinking that she should not have been born because she was born from her dad's second marriage, and she saw that second marriage as illegitimate.
• Realizing that there are "logic hoops" to jump through when trying to explain what god's will is and what doors he does and does not open.
• Seeing that sex is put on a pedestal as some kind of "holy grail" in life that's a transcendent experience as soon as you get to enjoy it.
• Feeling scared that god was going to "get her" for pursuing a divorce.
• Dealing with the constant fear of disappointing god.
• Hearing that god would work miracles only if you had enough faith.
• Experiencing immense freedom, after deconversion, from the fear of god's punishment and from the need to judge others for their sin or lack of faith in Jesus.
• Admitting that, as a Christian, prayer felt encouraging and calming because it gave the impression that help was coming in difficult situations.
• Embracing the freedom that you don't need any transcendent power that you're at the mercy of, and that all you need is already within you.

Thanks to Ginger for sharing her story and insights!

episodes.title: What if the Apostle Paul was the Qumran community's "Spouter of Lies"? - David Oliver Smith
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with David Oliver Smith, who grew up in a liberal Episcopalian denomination and interpreted the Bible metaphorically for most of his life and then became a Buddhist in his early adulthood.  His research on Christian origins led him to write several books about the mythological origins of the Jesus character and of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Realizing that the Synoptic gospels used Paul's teachings to craft their stories, and that the authors of Matthew and Luke then edited and altered the Gospel of Mark in their versions of the Jesus story.
• Piecing together that specific events which occurred in first century Palestine are described in both the Dead Sea Scrolls and in Paul’s letters, from different points of view.
• Piecing together Paul's backstory, that he was probably sent out by the Qumran community to share their message, but he altered it as he invented Christianity, broke his oath, became a traitor to the Qumran community rules, and became known as "the Spouter of Lies."
• The idea that Jesus was a mythological being crucified in the levels of heaven by demons.
• How Paul and Qumran community used Pesher as a way to glean a fresh meaning from the Old Testament.
• How the Jerusalem church leaders were opposed to Paul and believed in a different Jesus who had not been crucified.
• Seeing that Paul's letters are his trying to keep his churches in his group, versus siding with the Qumran group.
• Noticing the stark contrast between Paul's message of grace versus his repeatedly graceless and rude personality and interactions with others.
• Understanding that the Gospel of Mark is a Midrash on Old Testament passages, as Mark rewrites the Old Testament stories to create the many "new" stories about the Jesus character.
• Understanding that canonical Mark has been redacted and the stories re-ordered.
• The possibility that the Jerusalem apostles murdered Paul and then covered it up.

Many thanks to David for sharing his story, research, and insights!

episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Amedu Oriazele, who grew up in a Christian home in Nigeria, attended Bible College, and became a pastor, but ultimately deconverted as he examined the truth claims of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up with a strong fervor for the Lord, the Bible, and ministry.
• Struggling intensely with the question of god electing and predestinating certain people and nations but not others.
• Starting to feel like humans were being set up like pawns in a game.
• Being told, as he was deconstructing, that the devil was using his hard questions to try to get his soul.
• Facing strong pushback from his family for deconstructing, as they feared shame and disgrace for his walking away from the Lord.
• Deconstructing about the same time as his wife, and consequently finding an openness in his marriage to discuss his ideas.
• Grappling with the question of whether Christianity is just a big lie that evolved through culture in order to control people.
• Being told by loved ones that "the Bible is enough" for all of his questions.
• Slowly but fully deconverting over the space of ten years, and consequently exiting his pastorate.
• Being shunned by family due to his deconversion.
• Parenting differently after deconversion, with a focus on freedom as well as being open to learning from his children.
• Starting the Lovewise Initiative to help those with medical and food needs in Nigeria.

episodes.title: Our capacity to be cruel is outweighed by our capacity to be altruistic - Daniel Dacombe
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Daniel Dacombe, who grew up in a Christian home, gave his life to Jesus as a young person, and eventually attended Bible College and entered ministry, but ultimately deconverted as he examined the truth claims of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a Christian environment that was free of many of the heavily toxic ideas often taught in Evangelicalism.
• Noticing strong differences between the harsh Yahweh character of the Old Testament and the more gracious character of Jesus in the New Testament, despite the apologetics industry trying to pretend that those differences aren't there.
• The relationship between how our parents treated us and how we viewed the god character as we grew up.
• Attending a Mennonite Brethren Church and becoming serious about his faith and walk with the Lord.
• Trying in vain for many years to experiencing god and feel his presence.
• Hearing many Christians strongly disparage other forms of Christianity.
• Unpacking how our belief systems are created and maintained.
• Seeing that we tend to form our beliefs backwards, intuiting our beliefs based on what seems true at first glance, and then proceeding to try to rationalize those beliefs.
• Observing that our brains react to perceived threats to our strongly held beliefs and values in the same way we could react to a perceived physical threat.
• Going to seminary and starting ministry in order to be involved in sharing the Gospel, while at the same time realizing that he was facing increasing cognitive dissonance about the claims of Christianity, especially as he realized that the answers from Christian apologists were extremely poor.
• Moving into progressive Christianity for a season as he worked through his persistent suspicions about the claims of Christianity.
• Seeing the need to not subscribe to supernatural explanations with bad evidence and weak arguments when natural explanations with good evidence are available.
• Starting to see that the god construct had just been a "useful fiction."
• Fully deconverting and feeling immense pain and loss, as well as anger at what he had gone through.
• Realizing that he would never again see people who had already died.
• Embracing intellectual humility in order to leave room for growth, change, and new ideas.
• The importance of starting new secular traditions.

Thanks to Daniel for sharing his story and insights!

episodes.title: You can embrace eroticism and sexually thrive after purity culture - Faith Blanchard
episodes.description:
T/W - brief discussion of suicide ideation, domestic abuse

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Faith Blanchard, who grew up in a Pentecostal environment while also facing bizarre religious beliefs and oppression at home.  Faith fully deconverted as an adult as she examined the truth claims of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Having a father who dealt strongly with sexual fear and self-loathing that led him to see most women as temptresses and to blame women for many of the problems in his life.
• Internalizing shame over her own body from a young age, especially when she hit puberty.
• Watching her dad overpower gaslight her mom for her entire life.
• Hearing her dad threaten to reject and abandon her if she did not totally comply with his beliefs and rules.
• Feeling immense pressure to be perfect at all times in order to earn her dad's love.
• Being involved with a therapist who helped her to think more rationally and critically, helping sow the seeds of deconversion.
• As she moved through therapy, realizing she was dealing with PTSD.
• Giving herself permission to sexually explore, and choosing to define her sexuality as pure and beautiful and innocent as she began to pursue a healthy sex life.
• Experiencing nightmares for years as a result of the trauma from her co-dependent relationship with her Christian dad.
• Undoing the sexism and internalized hatred as part of deconversion and rediscovering her identity, but still struggling with shame and guilt as she worked through the damage that purity culture had done to her.
• Having panic attacks during sex and overwhelming shame and trauma at having an orgasm.
• Admitting that lustful thoughts are natural, beautiful, and good.
• Acknowledging that each of our bodies don't belong to anyone else, even in marriage.
• The importance of helping people heal from purity culture so that they feel safe in their own skin and safe to be sexually active.
• The beauty of embracing eroticism and moving past our fears to be able to fully inhabit our body.

Many thanks to Faith for sharing her story and insights today!

episodes.title: What would happen to religion if aliens showed up? - Jonathan Pearce & Dr. Aaron Adair
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Dr. Aaron Adair and Jonathan MS Pearce, co-authors of the book "Aliens and Religion: Where Two Worlds Collide: Assessing the Impact of Discovering Extraterrestrial Intelligence on Religion and Theology."  

We discussed many topics, including:

• The vastness of space, the expansion of the universe, and the likelihood and difficulties of space civilizations finding each other.
• The importance of the sci-fi genre.
• Implications of the Fermi Paradox (it looks like the universe has plenty of space for life to easily exist, yet we see no evidence of it).
• The fine tuning / Goldilocks argument.
• The dilemma that there may be many lifeforms out in the universe, but we are so far from each other that we are effectively permanently isolated.
• The dark forest hypothesis and the ultimate resulting concern of whether there is something nefarious and fearful about the universe.
• The Drake Equation and the question of the expected lifespan of an advanced civilization.
Clarke's Third Law, the idea that sufficiently advanced technology would be indistinguishable from magic.
• Imagining how world religions, especially Christianity and the other Abrahamic religions, would be threatened if we ever confirm that alien life exists -- yet many would likely find a way to double down on their faith in such a scenario.
• The issue of Divine Deception (the idea that there are many other civilizations, but Yahweh has simply withheld that information from us).
• The Copernican Principle (the idea that the earth is just one of many planets around one of many stars, and we are thus average, and not in a privileged position.
• The idea of trans-universe depravity, atonement, and salvation across all the civilizations that need their own version of redemption and to which we would be responsible to share the Gospel message even though they are too far away to reach, or else Jesus might need to have become incarnated in billions of civilizations.
• The difference between inductive, deductive, and abductive hypotheses.
• Thinking through the ramifications of the problem of evil, especially on a universal scale.

Many thanks to Dr. Aaron Adair and Jonathan MS Pearce for their book, humor, and thought-provoking insights!

episodes.title: I escaped a cult of pedophilia and preparing for the apocalypse - Daniella Mestyanek Young
episodes.description:
T/W - discussion of child abuse, childhood sexual assault, pedophilia kidnapping, torture, suicide ideation, extreme brainwashing.

_________________________________________


Today my co-host Summer Biby and I spoke with Daniella Mestyanek Young, a third-generation survivor of an apocalyptic sex cult called the "Children of God," which she wrote about extensively in the book "Uncultured."

We discussed many topics, including:

• How David Berg began the apocalyptic cult called "Children of God" with a strong focus on "sexually liberating children."
• Growing up in a context where the cult actively broke up families, kidnapped children, taught them that "rape is love," took away all personal rights, and put everyone under David Berg's total control.
• How the "sacred transcendent assumption" that David Berg was God's Prophet created the deprogramming atmosphere where adults, who should have easily known better, ended up allowing and supporting extreme abuse and criminal behavior.
• Having the messaging of "self sacrifice" drilled into her in the cult.
• She and the other children being severely disciplined almost nonstop and consequently never having spontaneous moments of joy out of fear that something they said or did would earn punishment -- including severe corporal punishment, sexual assault and solitary confinement.
• Observing that cults start to die when the cult leaders fail to successfully indoctrinate the next generation.
• Being almost entirely cut off from private time with her own birth mom in a context where all the children had to treat all adults equally as their collective parents most of the time.
• Being blamed for accidents from clumsiness and being told that they were part of God's punishment.
• Being driven to disassociate and shut down her emotions to an extreme level, as a survival mechanism.
• Being taught that she was lovable only when she was perfect and that she was "nothing without Jesus."
• Intentionally choosing to raise the next generation without fear, pain, and violence.
• Being told that David Berg was "the" end times prophet from God and they needed to be ready for Jesus' imminent return.
• Reading stories of Christian martyrs and fantasizing about being killed for Jesus by the Antichrist.
• Going through training drills for how to survive and deal with the end times and Tribulation as they prepared to be "God's insurgency."
• Realizing that, in the context of apocalyptic cults, that cult leaders precipitate their own apocalypse because they want the world to burn, to find a way to prove themselves right.

Many thanks to Daniella for sharing her story and for her amazing voice and strength through all she does for the community!

episodes.title: Imagine losing everyone you've ever known ... by their choice - Scott Homan / Witness Underground
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Scott Homan, a former Jehovah's Witness (JW) and the Director of the new documentary "Witness Underground," which tells the story of several ex-JW's as they share the pain of questioning their worldview and use music as a way to express the amazing journey of deconversion.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Being told that Jesus was going to come back soon and personally kill everyone who was not a JW.
• Hearing that Jesus is in Jehovah's throne room doing the work of Jehovah but that the main relationship and the direction of prayer was to Jehovah, not Jesus.
• Being told to not be formulaic with his prayers, but still being given ritual prayers to say.
• Hearing the preaching of physical immortality promised to those who remained consistently faithful to Jehovah.
• Never feeling secure in his "salvation" because there was always the threat that he was not doing enough and would fall away.
• Seeing people shamed in public for failure to follow all the rules or for having a questionable witness.
• Hearing fellow JWs talk joyfully about non-believers soon being "blasted" by Jesus and how they, the witnesses, would help clear the land of the carcasses.
• Being told from some family that his deceased grandfather was in heaven, and from other family that his grandfather had been annihilated.
• Being told that he could lose eternal life both during his life here and during the future kingdom.
• Starting to study evolution even though it had been described as a satanic belief.
• Finally admitting that Bible stories are fantasy lore and make believe.
• Being completely shunned by his family after he deconverted.
• Realizing that most Christians are exceptionally fragile in both their faith and their emotions.
• The importance of Christians needing to have a "unified" faith where dissent is strongly discouraged.
• How the freedom to create lyrics and music led to freethought for many JWs.
• Seeing those who escaped slowly influencing those still stuck in the cult, even from a distance.
• Realizing that getting out of the JW cult is like leaving an extremely abusive relationship.
• The background and goals of the Witness Underground documentary where JWs share their stories, face intense shunning, reclaim their identities, and rebuild their identities post-deconversion, all centered around their music.

Many thanks to Scott for sharing his story and for his amazing work in the Witness Underground documentary!

episodes.title: Despite my best efforts, I ran out of reasons to believe - Clay Arnall
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Clay Arnall, who grew up in the Christian Alliance denomination but ultimately deconverted as he investigated the truth claims of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Being taught that there were angels and demons all around him.
• Declaring his faith in Jesus multiple times to be sure that he was saved and not going to end up in hell.
• Seeing the hardcore Christian indoctrination dynamic of Christians not having a true option, without threat, to disbelieve or really investigate other worldviews.
• Observing the Christian assumption that "we're right and everyone else is wrong."
• Questioning the strong emphasis in many churches on everyone needing to "feel good."
• Thinking through whether the dopamine euphoria is actually evidence of a god's presence, realizing that people can artificially create and induce those feelings, and how that has "become Christianity" to many people.
• Being afraid that god might call him to be a full-time missionary, even though he didn't want to do it.
• Facing the mental gymnastics of god causing bad things to happen vs. bad things simply being the result of sin.
• Seeing that within Calvinism, people who are not elect have no chance to believe, but they are still condemned by god.
• The cognitive bias that leads Christians to think that god can do no wrong and that anything that happens in life is part of his trustworthy "plan."
• Realizing that much of Christianity boils down to carrot-and-stick dynamics.
• Learning that Christians have always had various interpretations of hell.
• Being told that god would reward him in life if he stayed away from alcohol and remained a virgin till marriage.
• Seeing most Christians ignore him after he deconverted.
• Realizing that many of his struggles with depression dissipated once he deconverted.
• Understanding that Christian theology amounts to psychological child abuse.
• The importance of trying to avoid unnecessary antagonism in discussions with loved ones who are still stuck in Christianity.

Many thanks to Clay for sharing his story and for all he does for the community!

episodes.title: The more I learned to love and accept myself, the less I could remain a Christian - Myndee Mack
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Myndee Mack, who placed her faith in Christ as a young child and pursued her relationship with Yahweh for decades, but fully deconverted as an adult as she examined the truth claims of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Strongly relying on her friendship with Jesus to get through hard times as a child.
• Observing poverty being demonized by the church she attended.
• Feeling that her family was not seeing god's blessings, and being heartbroken that she could not sense god helping her and her family.
• Taking the feeling of rejection from god very personally and responding with disassociation and depression.
• Never being able to truly rest in her "salvation" for fear of backsliding.
• Not having any freedom to ask critical questions or express concerns about theology without facing condescending responses and people questioning her faith.
• Admitting to herself that the Yahweh character as a loving father did not make sense anymore.
• Being told that you will be completely happy in heaven even as your unbelieving loved ones are burning in hell.
• Admitting that when people believe monstrous things long enough, they turn themselves into a monster.
• Starting to develop much more self-awareness and self-love and acknowledging that those dynamics make it ultimately impossible to remain in the Christian worldview.
• Finally experiencing true peace for the first time, after escaping Christianity, and realizing that peace begins inside, with each of us.
• Finding that community and connections post-deconversion are much more authentic.

Thanks to Myndee for sharing her story and insights!

episodes.title: I realized that the foundation of my faith had been false - Kelly Pearsall (Godless Granny)
episodes.description:
T/W - brief discussion of suicide ideation, having a stillborn baby.

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Kelly Pearsall, a fellow YouTuber who runs the channel "Godless Granny."  We talked through her story of coming to faith in Christ but fully deconverting later in life as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a family environment that was a mixture of Catholic and agnostic.
• As a teen, struggling with the purpose of life to the extent that she contemplated suicide.
• Trusting Jesus as her Savior and starting to get plugged into a church.
• Reading the Bible cover-to-cover for the first time and starting to attend Bible studies.
• Facing the loss and trauma of a stillborn baby and poor medical treatment.
• Being told by a pastor that feeling distant from god was her own fault.
• Experiencing a "close call" with a bad car accident that almost happened but sensing angelic protection.
• Finding a way to get through seasons of doubt by setting up the Bible as the bedrock foundation of her worldview.
• Observing extreme patriarchy and misogyny in church leaders.
• Being told that childless women are worthless.
• Being very impressed with the pseudo-intellectualism of Calvinism.
• Deconstructing her perspectives on LGBTQ issues.
• Learning more about science and history to the point of becoming skeptical about the stories in Genesis.
• Wrestling with the issues of divine hiddenness and eternal conscious torment.
• Realizing that since the Bible had been her foundation, and it was flawed, that her faith and worldview foundation was false.
• Fully deconverting from Christianity and realizing that everything she had believed about god had only ever been in her head.
• Developing her "Godless granny" platform to speak up about the cracks in the foundation of the Christian worldview.

Many thanks to Kelly for sharing her story and for her awesome YouTube platform!

episodes.title: Our journey through deconversion gave us freedom - Susurra band
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Paul Vinsonhaler and Brian Kruzan of the atmospheric pop band "Susurra."  They both grew up strongly exposed to evangelical Christianity and gave their lives to Jesus as they grew up, but they both ultimately deconverted as the truth claims of Christianity fell apart.

We discussed many topics, including:

(Paul)
• Trusting Jesus as his Savior at a very young age and rededicating his life to Jesus several times as his faith and theology deepened.
• Frequently praying and dialoguing with the Lord throughout each day.
• Struggling with the knowledge that some friends and family were not Christians.
• Deepening his theology and diving into apologetics during his college years.
• Getting involved in mission trips and other ministries, but sensing dynamics of colonialism woven into some of the mission
• Facing philosophical concerns and a strong "fear of doubting" but hoping that other more mature Christians had good answers.
• Opening himself up to hearing from secular scientists and historians.
• Starting to be open to the possibility of complex answers outside 
• Experiencing much more peace after deconversion than while a Christian.
• Finding himself being even more loving to other people post-Christianity.
• Healing from religious trauma.
• Observing most Christians not making any attempt whatsoever to "save" him again post-deconversion.
• Providing kids with the autonomy and freedom to investigate make their own path in life, while also instilling in them messages of self-love.
• Losing fear and coming to a strong place of peace about death and the loss of the afterlife.
• Being able to respect and appreciate other people's worldviews more than ever before.

(Bryan)
• Trusting Jesus as his Savior at a very young age and growing up with an Assemblies of God pastor.
• Being heavily focused on teachings about the Holy Spirit, speaking in tongues, revival, prayer, worship, and the power of music.
• Hearing messages and skits about hell and eternal damnation.
• As his theology grew, feeling the pull to focus his gifts and ministry on music and worship.
• Starting to lose his ability to adhere to and defend the inerrancy of Scripture.
• Moving toward Progressive Christianity for a while before fully deconverting.

Many thanks to Paul and Bryan for sharing their stories, for their music, and for their drive to use their musical talents to help the deconstructing community!

episodes.title: Christianity kept falling apart and eventually it was "game over" - David Ames
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with David Ames, the host of The Graceful Atheist podcast.  He placed his faith in Jesus in his early adulthood, but ultimately deconverted as he examined the truth claims of Christianity.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Seeing his mom get clean and sober from addiction through turning to Jesus.
• Being encouraged by his youth pastor to get a strong Bible education and to consider going into ministry.
• Feeling the excitement of being connected with god and sensing the presence of the Holy Spirit.
• Understanding the teachings of sin and of god's grace.
• Enjoying his time at Bible college but also being taught strong critical thinking skills which ultimately led him to deconvert.
• Feeling that "Jesus won his heart and Paul won his mind" as he dove into the New Testament and systematic theology.
• Experiencing angst over pressure to sign a statement of faith where he agreed with some things but not with others.
• Successfully starting ministry but, as an introvert, simultaneously burning out quickly.
• Getting married to a Christian, having a Christian home, and being focused on actively witnessing to the lost.
• Realizing that he had been ignoring cognitive dissonance, discrepancies, and doubts.
• Becoming increasingly concerned about how the church was treating people in the LGBTQ+ community.
• Turning to apologetics to reinforce his faith, but seeing that their arguments were extremely poor, especially regarding "intelligent design."
• Starting to listen to atheist authors and speakers
• Starting to lose the idea that he had a soul.
• Rethinking the story about Jesus' resurrection in light of whether he would accept other belief systems' miracle claims.
• Facing the outcome of an "unequally yoked" marriage.
• Realizing that Christianity is predicated on the principle of faith.
• Giving himself the permission to doubt and to no longer accept bad Christian explanations for the psychotic behavior and bizarreness of the Yahweh character.
• The process of creating meaning in our lives after the religious meaning and context are gone.
• Learning to grieve death properly after deconversion.
• Working through the best way to fight the psychological abuse of religious childhood indoctrination in our culture.
• Experiencing much more peace after deconversion than while he was a Christian.
• The importance of developing a mindset of "secular grace."

Many thanks to David for sharing his story and for his amazing platform!

episodes.description:
T/W - brief discussion of the Children of God sex cult, multiple miscarriages, child abuse, child sexual abuse, severe depression, suicidal ideation

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Sarah Louise Gross, who grew up on the overseas mission field and gave her life to Jesus at an early age, but ultimately deconverted as the Christian worldview fell apart.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Going on deputation with her parents to raise support for missions.
• Seeing her parents have a very bad marriage, despite being full-time missionaries.
• Experiencing culture shock when she came back to the US and went to Bob Jones, where the many freedoms she had experienced on the mission field.
• Being taught that self-care or doing things for yourself was selfish, and that your focus should be rewards in heaven, not here on earth.
• Having a very short courtship and engagement period due to not knowing how to live in the US and to avoid burning in lust.
• As a homeschooling mom, facing endless plates to juggle, and seeing mothers around her crumble and fall.
• Being pregnant and seeing her dad dying of cancer at the same time.
• In the Quiverful setting, facing intense pressure to have as many kids as possible.
• Hearing that preventing pregnancy was like a slap in god's face because it was trying to take his authority over our lives and bodies.
• Feeling very frustrated at church and moving to a "home church" model to see if it would work better for them.
• Getting involved briefly with Catholicism and realizing that Protestants had severely misrepresented what Catholics believe.
• Becoming increasingly frustrated at the dynamic of the Bible interpretation being very unclear and open to endless different interpretations.
• Seeing that the Yahweh character was portrayed as punishing people for things that were beyond their control.
• Seeing how spiritually and emotionally oppressed she had been by the patriarchal mindset, and how important it was to escape and reclaim her identity.
• How the church, and eventually Scripture, lost their façade of authority over her mind and life.
• Starting to embrace her own spiritual autonomy and confidence.
• Realizing how much she had been groomed and sheltered earlier in life.
• Experiencing more peace after deconversion than she ever had as a Christian.

Thanks to Sarah for sharing her story!

• Seeing his parents focus on helping people in addiction recovery.
• Experiencing social pressure to speak in tongues.
• Watching his dad claim to audibly hear god's voice telling him to get much more publicly involved in the anti-abortion movement by walking across America.

• Seeing his parents engaging in "spiritual warfare" by "claiming for the Lord" every place where they walked.

• Focusing her life on serving god passionately.
• Being told to expect the Rapture and to fear being "left behind."
• Facing intense pressure to be "on fire for the Lord."
• Seeing people at church falling on the floor and foaming at the mouth in their fervor for the Lord.
• Having the church leaders put "blessed" anointing oil on her forehead when she made a profession of faith.
• Feeling like she was one of god's "chosen ones."
• Facing pressure to speak in tongues and to get baptized.
• Attending emotionally intense tent revival services that emphasized "saving souls."
• Continually repenting of her sins and thanking Jesus for everything that happened in life.
• Fully believing that her mom was getting messages and confirmations directly from god, but observing that whenever her mom got the message wrong, the discrepancy was explained away as a deception of the devil.
• Experiencing extreme homophobia from her mother, especially once she (Rachael) came out as a lesbian, while concurrently hearing her dad describe Christianity as an abusive worldview.
• Seeing loved ones refuse to go to a doctor, but instead claiming a healing from god, yet not being healed.
• Believing that her being raped was deserved because she was not living for Christ.
• Feeling constant pressure to rededicate her life to the Lord.
• Seeing her mom try to preach in church but hearing male church leaders shut her down.
• Knowing that the act of ever questioning the "word of god" would send someone to hell.
• Being given the consistent picture in her black church of Jesus being a white man.
• As part of her deconversion, shifting to a worldview where rationality and the need for evidence becomes central.

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Katherine and her son Micah.  Katherine grew up believing strongly in Jesus and in the power of god to do miracles in her life, but after decades of waiting on god but finding him nothing but silent, she ultimately realized that Christianity is mythology, and she deconverted.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Believing god and Jesus were very real to her as a young child.
• Going to lots of "tent meetings" as a kid.
• Experiencing the love of god through church friends as a relief from an abusive home environment.
• Focusing on Bible verses that described Jesus as a loving, empathetic character.
• Struggling with anger at god for not saving her from a very abuse and a lack of love as a child.
• How Christians are intensely focused on getting kids' minds completely indoctrinated while they are still young.
• Trying to claim physical healing from god but failing to ever experience it.
• Staying in an abusive marriage for decades waiting for god to intervene.
• Rebuking the devil and confessing sins, expecting things to get better as a result.
• Making excuses for god putting her through intense suffering, as if god was preparing her for great things later by hurting her today.
• Starting to read secular self-help books and starting to reclaim her autonomy and power.
• Beginning to take a more "forensic" perspective about the Christian worldview.
• Realizing that she was a better parent than the Yahweh character is.
• Going through various stages of grief as she deconverted and realized she'd been deceived and self-deceived for decades.
• Being glad that Yahweh and Jesus don't actually.
• Losing the Christian agenda and the need to save everyone from hell or to try to convince everyone that the Bible is divine truth.

episodes.title: I was willing to lose everyone and everything to live an authentic life - Andrew Pledger
episodes.description:
T/W - brief discussion of depression, suicidal ideation

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Andrew Pledger, who grew up as a Christian in the Independent Fundamental Baptist (IFB) cult and attended Bob Jones University, but ultimately denounced fundamentalism.

We discussed many topics, including:

• How the IFB maintains strict control through fear-based teachings, a strict authority and control structure, and strong isolation from all other influences.
• Being taught that the King James Version of the Bible was the only legitimate version, and all other versions were false and Satanic.
• Hearing that if he obeyed his parents, he would have a long life.
• Being taught that god hated people and was sick of their sin, but yet still loved them.
• Hearing that a lack of wholehearted obedience or conformity was evidence of not being saved and being in danger of damnation.
• Growing up in an environment where strict gender roles were strongly preached.
• Being taught to be judgmental of and disgusted by everyone who wasn't a staunch fundamentalist Christian.
• Learning that acceptance and praise was only available to him through conformity.
• Facing intense shame for not being perfect or for having any struggles in life.
• Going "soul-winning" and being told that not sharing the Gospel with people meant he was partly guilty for their damnation.
• Living by a daily checklist of things to do to be holy, but at the cost of being judgmental toward those who didn't live that way and being obsessively driven to be an over-achiever.
• Fearing the possibility of "missing out" on the will of god.
• Feeling like he was being groomed to be a "soldier for Christ" from a very young age.
• Being told to always put others first and himself last.
• Facing mental health trauma and a severe depression from being told he was an awful and sinful person in general, but even more so when he struggled with homosexuality and wondered if he was an abomination to god.
• Feeling so sheltered that there was no way to express his concerns and doubts or to distance himself from his community and from fundamentalism.
• Starting to question authority and realize he'd been in a very harmful environment.
• Realizing that Christianity creates a problem (sin/hell) and then sells you the solution (salvation/heaven).
• Never feeling secure in his salvation, even though he was told that eternal security was a key piece of his Christian experience.
• The subtle ways that cults indoctrinate you and slowly shift your mindset so that they can control you, including keeping people extremely busy and tired.
• Starting to claim his own autonomy and recognize his own needs for the first time in his life.
• Reaching out to the "world" for community and experiencing much more love and peace than in fundamentalist Christianity.
• Starting to move past the "Us vs. Them" / "Ingroup vs. Outgroup" mentality.
• Realizing that there are truly good and loving people outside of the cult, even though "phobia indoctrination" had taught otherwise.
• Critically examining the Bible for the first time.
• Making the intentional choice to escape Christianity.
• Learning to be okay with uncertainty and with not having answers to "ultimate" questions.
• The importance of learning to enjoy life here and now.

Many thanks to Andrew for sharing his story!

Today I spoke with Kristyn Whitaker Hood, who grew up in the Assemblies of God denomination and gave her life to Jesus at a young age, but ultimately deconverted as she examined the truth claims of Christianity and realized that it IS mythology.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Being frequently invited to give her heart to Jesus and rededicate her life to Christ.
• Constantly trying to sense and judge who in the room is a Christian and on fire for the Lord vs. who needs to get saved or get more serious about the Lord.
• Seeing Christian Nationalism creep into church events.
• Getting exposed to many variations of Christians and of Bible interpretations, which broadened her perspective.
• Learning the various ways that the Gospels wove together aspects of various mythologies, mystery cults, Gnosticism, astrotheology, and some history, and realizing that the Gospels are truly a product of their time.
• Realizing that Christians by and large "read Paul" through the Gospels, but if you reverse that, you realize the mythical nature of the stories.
• Realizing that early Christianity evolved to serve a political purpose for ancient Rome.
• How Christianity makes people subservient by enabling them to put up with bad treatment now with the promise of a much better afterlife.
• The importance of understanding that you can be good without a god.
• Learning to enjoy the beauty and moments of life more, after you "lose" the afterlife during deconversion.

Thanks to Kristyn for sharing her story and for all she does for the community!

episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Carol, who grew up in a Baptist environment but in adulthood became a Jehovah's Witness, before ultimately fully deconverting as she examined the worldview claims of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Attending a Baptist church that was considered extreme even by other Baptist Churches in the area.
• Growing up traumatized over fear of missing the Rapture.
• Being very concerned about what the unforgiveable sin was and whether she had ever committed it.
• Feeling bothered by the idea of the unsaved who never heard the Gospel going to hell.
• Learning that other religions have parallel and very similar themes to Christianity.
• Being so jaded from evangelical Christianity that Jehovah's Witnesses (JW) became appealing to her.
• Realizing, afterward, that JW's work you till you systematically give away your power and autonomy.
• Seeing JW's praise converts extensively for anything they do right in order to manipulate them.
• Feeling like god hated her.
• How depression from her son being disfellowshipped and her adoptive father passing away ended up being an early crack in her deconversion.
• Seeing up close the very effective control tactics of the JW organization, primarily through fear.
• Waiting on Armageddon so god can fix the world but fearing that she might still get annihilated if she displeased Jehovah.
• Not letting herself get counseling for fear of bringing reproach to Jehovah's name.
• Being angry and regretful at the ways that the JW organization stole years of her life and years of close contact with non-JW family members that she could have had.
• Grieving the loss of time with her family, especially birthdays and holidays.
• Setting up higher standards, going forward, of reason, logic, and evidence for any worldview claims.

Many thanks to Carol for sharing her story!

episodes.title: I found my voice away from the church (a poet’s path to deconversion) - Kaitlin Shetler
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Kaitlin Shetler, who grew up in the Church of Christ denomination, gave her life to Jesus early, and was focused on serving in the church until she began to unpack the toxicity of the Christian worldview and think through the topic of human suffering, ultimately leading her to fully deconvert.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up with church as her primary and almost exclusive social influence.
• Being instilled with a strong love for the Bible.
• As a young child, feeling completely ready to go to heaven and praying that Jesus would return soon.
• Correlating the experience of having a strong and loving human father with her concept of the heavenly father.
• Realizing as a teenager that because she was a female, she would not be permitted to take on most leadership roles, and even those that she could do would need to be under the direct supervision and authority of a man.
• Getting exposed to other denominations where women had more chances to speak up and take leadership roles.
• Using poetry to raise her voice about the patriarchy and other toxic and abusive messages coming from the church and the Bible.
• Realizing, as a parent, that she was willing to do much more for her daughter than the Yahweh character does for his children.
• No longer being able to see massive human suffering and natural disasters and still praying for god to make something good out of the situation.                                                      
• Concluding that she was a better person in every way without Christianity.
• Feeling "safer in her own skin" after deconversion because she is no longer performing for anyone and no longer needs to silence herself.
• The importance of validating yourself and creating a safe place for yourself during the deconstruction process.

Many thanks to Kaitlin for sharing her story and for her amazing poetry!

episodes.title: There are more bullet holes in the Bible than you ever imagined - Justin Best
episodes.description:
T/W - brief description of Iraq war fighting and death, PTSD, suicide

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Justin Best, who grew up in the Southern Baptist and Presbyterian denominations, moved into the Torah Observant / Hebrew Roots movement, but ultimately deconverted as he investigated the truth claims and origins of Christianity.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Growing up in the Southern Baptist denomination and then moving to a more Presbyterian and Calvinistic perspective.
• Feeling the intense pressure of his actions having the ability to directly affect other people's eternal condition.
• Getting saved early in life but rededicating his life many times to be sure he was truly saved, especially in light of the contrasting messages of Paul's message of "faith alone" and James' message of "faith plus works."
• Becoming extremely passionate and zealous, even to an "OCD" level, about pursuing god, the Bible, the Gospel, and things that would further the kingdom.
• Going through an existential crisis as a result of what he experienced as a Marine in the Iraq War.
• Moving into the Hebrew Roots movement as he became convinced that Jesus and his disciples followed the Torah during Jesus' life and after he ascended.
• Realizing that the apostle Paul taught against the Torah, repeatedly and consistently, and seeing Paul as a false teacher who is frequently fighting with and mocking the very men who had supposedly walked with Jesus.
• Realizing that the text of the Bible had been extensively corrupted.
• Understanding that the "chain of custody" of the actual "Word of god" has been entirely non-existent for much of history.
• The bizarre dynamic of Christians accepting that the text and the canon have been heavily altered and edited for millennia, but in their minds, no such changes are allowed anymore.
• Realizing that the Old Testament "prophecies" about Jesus are not about Jesus at all.
• Learning about the mythological origins of the Jesus and Yahweh characters.
• Receiving very hateful messages from Christians upon deconverting.
• Post deconversion, getting professional counseling and focusing on self care, self love, healing from narcissistic abuse, mindfulness, and meditation.

Unending thanks to Justin for sharing his story and for his platform!

• Hearing "prophets" in the church on a regular basis.
• Seeing people slain in the spirit and "purged."
• Getting "saved" in a youth revival service and then living in a way that was "sold out to Jesus."
• Being given Apostolic Succession by his denomination during his time as a pastor.

episodes.title: Loving kids is greater than theology - Esther Goetz & Sarah Meassick
episodes.description:
T/W - today's guests are deconstructing their former beliefs but they are not atheists.

_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Esther Goetz and her daughter Sarah Meassick.  Esther grew up in an evangelical missionary family and later began raising her own family in a conservative evangelical church context, but ultimately heavily deconstructed as she critically examined the toxicity and harm her worldview was having on her and her family.

We discussed many topics, including:

Esther:
• Believing that the highest calling and the best way to show love to others was to keep people out of hell.
• Being told that she had the gift of evangelism and that her main role was to be a light to her neighborhood and world.
• Coming to realize the harm that her Christian worldview was causing to her and her children.
• Making the conscious choice to prioritize her children's wellbeing over her theology.
• Deconstructing the idea of eternal conscious torment in hell.
• Realizing that as an evangelical, she was ruled by manipulative fear and a desire to control her children.
• Seeing Jesus as an "archetype."
• Moving past the need to put compartmentalizing labels on ourselves and our beliefs.
• Understanding that religious texts describe the worldviews and culture of the people who wrote them, but that we are not restricted by those beliefs.
• The importance of asking, "How is this hurting me?" about our beliefs.

Sarah:
• Growing up with a spiritual OCD where she was constantly trying to jump through hoops to please god and be a good Christian.
• Giving herself permission to believe differently from her parents.
• Starting to move past a dualistic "black and white" mentality.
• Move away from a patriarchal background where women could be taught only by men.
• Seeing that many religious characters, including Yahweh, are pictured as extremely oppressive and narcissistic.
• Pursuing the mentality of the universe being full of healing, love, and growth.
• Seeing Christian theology as a form of manipulation and psychological abuse to children.

Many thanks to Esther and Sarah for sharing their stories and insights!

episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Apostate Anne and Mark Peralta, who grew up believing in Jesus and going into pastoral ministry, but ultimately deconverting as they examined the truth claims of Christianity.

We discussed many topics, including:
• Growing up hearing messages in church of women's subservient role to men.
• Experiencing church elders ask them to lie to the entire church.
• Apply critical skills to their worldview and beliefs.
• Doing intense research about different Biblical topics and slowly realizing that apologetics perspectives consistently fell short.
• Learning that for many Biblical figures, there is no evidence that they ever existed.
• Watching a good friend die who had faith that god was going to heal him.
• Explaining to their kids, whom they'd already indoctrinated into Christianity, that they had changed their beliefs and worldview.
• Seeing how churches emotionally manipulate their congregations and prey on the weak.
• The freedom, as a deconverted couple, to enjoy married life without patriarchy, as equals, and to delight in sexuality with more freedom and less guilt than ever.
• How deconversion saves us from bad ideas as well as false expectations in life.
• Raising children free from the concepts of original sin and admitting that kids naturally want to do good.
• Seeing Christian loved ones become distant and disinterested after their deconversion, often either patronizing or ignoring those of us who have escaped Christianity.

episodes.title: Thinking through Science, Mythology, Misogyny, and Trump led me to fully deconvert - Elvine
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Elvine, who grew up in a Roman Catholic environment, moved to Protestant Evangelicalism, but then began to investigate in depth the truth claims of Christianity, and ultimately fully deconverted.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Growing up exposed to Catholicism with a focus on mass, good works, and prayers to saints.
• Eventually becoming jaded in the Catholic environment and converting to evangelical Protestant Christianity.
• Being exposed to purity culture for the first time, when she spent time with evangelicals.
• Hearing in church that god loved her and had a plan for her life.
• Feeling like evangelical Christianity was fulfilling what she was missing in the Catholic church.
• Hearing evangelicals treat all other faiths and denominations with disdain and even describing them as heretical and demonic.
• Concluding that Catholicism was wrong and evangelical Christianity was Biblical.
• Being told by Catholics that she was in a cult and was becoming extremist when she moved into Protestantism.
• Believing that people in her life who knew witchcraft were able to keep good things from happening to her.
• Seeing her and other evangelical Christians developing a strong persecution complex.
• Praying for a long time to speak in tongues, and eventually developing the skill herself.
• Realizing the strength of the placebo effect.
• Being told that strong-willed and opinionated women have a "Jezebel spirit" that reflects a lack of being quiet and submissive, and that if she became more compliant, the right man would see her good qualities and want her as a wife.
• Dealing with internalized misogyny and self-hatred, feeling terrible for not conforming, and being told that extended singleness was a punishment for not being a "Proverbs 31" woman.
• Seeing that Jesus supposedly freed humanity from the curses from the Fall, but that those curses still remain on humanity.
• Doing constant mental gymnastics to maintain the idea that god is in control and that he will make everything okay in the end, despite the cognitive dissonance showing otherwise.
• Facing nonstop confusion about the will of god in the context of god sometimes closing doors but wanting us to just wait longer, or to work harder, or realizing that we were self-deceived in thinking it was god's will, but it really wasn't, or that Satan was thwarting god's will, or that god would find a creative way to make it still work out in the end, but is temporarily testing us.
• Realizing the interconnectedness of Christianity with racism and sexism.
• Seeing that the Yahweh character's actions in the Garden of Eden story show him to be a narcissistic, gaslighting psychopath.
• Learning that King David was very wicked, just like Jezebel, but he is strangely seen in a good light and his songs are still sung today, yet Jezebel is villainized.
• Learning about how Christianity spread to sub-Saharan Africa through colonialism, and that Africans were taught to identify with Jesus' suffering as a means to endure the colonialism and the loss of their culture.
• Realizing that the "fruit of the Spirit," such as gentleness, is absent in Christian culture.
• After deconversion, feeling immense freedom from the nonsense and bizarre mindset of the Christian worldview.
• Understanding that it affects people of color to pray to a savior god figure that they are groomed to see as white and male.
• Deconstructing the concept of fallen angels, and realizing that if heaven were real, it wouldn't be perfect, as we imagined, and that god could have created them genderless if they didn't want them to ever have the option of copulating with human women and creating the Nephilim.
• The importance of giving yourself the authority to question the Yahweh character.

Many thanks to Elvine for sharing her story!

episodes.title: The truth caused a mind shift that led me straight out of Christianity - Brandon
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Brandon, who grew up in a Christian environment, believed in and loved Jesus, memorized large portions of the Bible, and wanted to make his life count for eternity ... until his search for the truth caused a mind shift that ultimately led to his deconversion from Christianity.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Seeing the cognitive dissonance of Christians who were compelled to share the Gospel but the majority actually lived as if the mundane details of their lives here were the main focus.
• Memorizing thousands of verses for Bible quizzing and passionately reading the Bible to know the Yahweh character better.
• Realizing the depths of the indoctrination that occurred during his childhood.
• Experiencing his parents' mixed-faith marriage, and then later facing his own mixed-faith marriage.
• Admitting, as a Christian, that it seemed like god was hiding, but how that drove him to pursue god even more.
• Hearing a leader in church prophesy that he, Brandon, would do signs and wonders for the Lord.
• How Christian guilt and shame puts people into a mindset of constantly second guessing themselves.
• Facing the purity culture message that sexual sin is the worst possible sin, in the context of the preachments that the body is beautiful, that god designed sex, that it is better to marry than to burn in lust, and yet that a godly person does not focus on sex and eroticism.
• Feeling like you're never doing enough for the Lord, especially in the area of evangelism.
• The emotional process of preparing to respectfully share our reasons for deconversion with our Christian spouses yet knowing that they may respond with fear and anger and perhaps start to punish us as retribution.
• Dealing with the existential dread of losing the afterlife but realizing that living for eternity, even in heaven, would actually be torture.
• Working through how to protect children from a mythological worldview and the psychological abuses of Christianity in the context of an "unequally yoked" marriage.
• The importance of pursuing the truth, no matter where it leads, even if it strongly challenges our current worldview.

Thanks to Brandon for sharing his story!

episodes.title: Christianity groomed me to be submissive, silenced, and shamed - Stephanie Logan
episodes.description:
T/W - child abuse, marital abuse, church abuse and scandals, discussion of suicide ideation

_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Stephanie Logan, a former evangelical homeschool mom, one-time missionary, and pastor’s wife who ultimately deconverted as she examined the claims of Christianity.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Growing up in the Christian Missionary Alliance denomination, which was focused on the Gospel and holiness.
• Being told her righteousness was like a filthy rag and that Jesus could buy us out of our slavery to sin.
• Placing her faith in the Jesus character around age 8 and becoming very serious about the faith.
• Hearing the message that if you really honor the Lord, you will serve him and stop sinning.
• Hearing alter calls in church on a regular basis and frequently going up in response as a way of being sure that she was really saved.
• Constantly second guessing herself and her motives as she was taught to examine and "police" herself.
• Seeing church leaders anoint people with oil as part of their central focus on healing.
• Never feeling "good enough" and "right enough" in her relationship with god, and consequently not feeling confident that her eternal salvation was truly secure.
• Feeling constant anxiety and fear in her personal relationship with god.
• Fearing the being "left behind" when the Rapture occurred and possibly facing the Tribulation, especially in the larger context of being told that the End Times and Armageddon were about to begin.
• Attending Mission Conferences and youth events where she was urged to sacrifice everything to become a missionary and share the Gospel full time.
• How a strong mixture of her fear of not being good enough, her strong desire to truly please the Lord, peer pressure, and overwhelming manipulation by preachers led her to become a missionary.
• Feeling increasingly concerned about social justice but realizing that she had to keep it quiet in the church environment.
• Coming under the leadership of a youth pastor who was grooming girls to be in inappropriate situations.
• Facing significant pushback, rebuke, and shunning from church leaders and congregants who refused to admit that a church leader had been grooming young girls and lying about it.
• How church leaders are often given immunity to be investigated and exposed for their abuses.
• How church leaders use the preachment that you must forgive others and pursue the peace and unity of the church as a way to ignore or minimize abuse and let abusers continue grooming and abusing people.
• Hearing from a man at college that god had told him that she was supposed to be his wife and serve the Lord with him.
• How teachings by Elisabeth Elliot and Focus on the Family led her to think that wifely submission would lead to god's blessing and protection.
• Strongly believing that despite the abuse and suffering, god would eventually makes things right.
• Catching her husband in affairs multiple times but feeling the need to forgive him and focus on serving the Lord as missionaries.
• Believing that so long as someone apologizes and repents, you should keep on forgiving and restoring them.
• Studying her Bible several hours a day in order to stay grounded and closer than ever to god despite the chaos and abuse she was facing.
• Ideating about suicide as the situation got desperate.
• Realizing that she'd repeatedly been silenced and shamed by church leaders, all due to her being a woman.
• Concluding that the Christian worldview did not work, that it was based on circular reasoning, and that she no longer believed.
• Having exponentially more peace after deconversion than while she was a Christian.

Many thanks to Stephanie for sharing her story!
