episodes.title: Disturbing questions led me to one simple answer: Goodbye, Jesus - Tim Sledge
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Tim Sledge, who was a Southern Baptist preacher for 35 years before fully examining the worldview claims of Christianity and ultimately deconverting.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Facing a childhood with an alcoholic father, and consequently, from an early age, seeking something stable and safe in his life, which Christianity provided.
• Being exhorted at a young age to choose heaven or hell.
• As a teenager, going to "Revival" services that called people to get saved, repent of sin, and consider full-time ministry.
• Seeing many "exceptions to faith" such as fellow Christians displaying severe racism toward black people and people having a radical salvation story but then quickly "falling away."
• Starting to think and talk more about depression, anxiety, recovery, vulnerability, and healing from the past -- and realizing that it was much more impactful than prayer and discipleship.
• Experiencing a Pastor tell him that he was "permanently broken."
• Starting to turn off the "confirmation bias" he had lived with as a Christian.
• Affirming that people he knew who were gay had not chosen to be gay, that being gay was not a sin, and that the Yahweh character could not be a loving father if he would torture people forever in hell.
• Crossing the deconstruction threshold into admitting that the Bible was not inerrant and was therefore untrustworthy.
• Concluding that he no longer believed in Jesus or the god of any religion.
• Observing Christians express revulsion and fear over his deconversion.
• Entering a 10-year phase of being a "quiet atheist."
• Sharing his journey through his books and social media, with a special focus on helping others not feel alone, correcting the Biblical messages he used to preach, and making it clear that truth matters.
• Experiencing Christians shunning, snarking, discarding those of us who deconvert.
• Dealing with the grief and amazement at how we let ourselves believe the Bible and cling to the Christian worldview for so long.
• Remembering how, when we were Christians, other fellow Christians would advise us to see "doubt" as the enemy and to simply "keep running the race."
• Realizing that the "spell of belief" makes it nearly impossible for many Christians to seriously consider challenges to what they believe.  In addition, the possibility that what they believe is not true is so daunting for many believers that they cannot bring themselves to seriously address even the most obvious problems with their belief system.
• The importance of not giving in to toxic shame.
• Acknowledging that childhood indoctrination is psychological child abuse.

Thanks to Tim for sharing his story, for his many books, and for all he does for the community!

episodes.title: Evaluating my epistemology led me to discard faith - LeighAnn Miller
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with LeighAnn Miller, who grew up in Pentecostal and Southern Baptist churches and placed her faith in Jesus as a child, but ultimately deconverted as she reconsidered her epistemology and the claims of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Placing her faith in Christ and getting baptized at age 8.
• Observing emotional manipulation during church services, even at a young age.
• Having to physically nail paper "sins" to a makeshift cross of Jesus.
• Having "mountaintop" experiences at various church events but having to go back to the "real world" when that experience ended.
• Feeling awkward about telling people of non-Christian faiths that everyone in their faith group was headed to hell.
• Being taught how to wield power over Satan.
• Feeling the pressure to marry the first person she had sex with.
• Healing from purity/modesty/virginity/shame culture but admitting it still affects her deeply, even long after deconversion.
• Acknowledging that she never experienced peace as a Christian.
• Realizing that many of the stories in the Bible, especially in the Gospels, are based on astrotheological "star stories."
• Admitting that the Bible is not infallible and that it is copied in large part from earlier mythologies.
• Upon sharing her deconversion, she received concerns from Christian loved ones and attempted to share her reasoning for discarding faith.
• Realizing that people who have a mythological worldview have completely disconnected from rationality, and that when they try to pass that indoctrination on to children, they are committing psychological child abuse.
• Realizing that Christianity is driven by fear.
• Being able to process death and loss better after deconversion.

Many thanks to LeighAnn for sharing her story!

episodes.title: Fundamentalist Indoctrination Stifles Critical Thinking and Causes Harm - Ricky + Austin Johnson
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Ricky Johnson and his son, Austin Johnson.  Ricky grew up in Laestadian Lutheranism, but ultimately deconverted as he investigated the truth claims of Christianity.  Austin grew up exposed to Christianity but saw through its claims early in life and was able to easily escape it.

We discussed many topics, including:

For Ricky:
• Not being allowed to play or watch sports much, as a young man, in order to avoid having sports become an idol.
• Being warned to not associate with worldly people, practices, and ideas.
• Being taught that true Christians can forgive the sins of other Christians.
• Feeling like he was not breaking down and crying hard enough, like other Christians in his church, as part of repentance for their sins.
• Having to adhere to whatever advice the preachers give and whatever the church elders decide is a sin.
• Trying to balance the overwhelming threat of hell with the injunction to experience the joy of the Lord.
• Never feeling, as a Christian, that he could "rest" in the security and peace of his salvation.
• Realizing that he had been conditioned his whole life to be afraid of evidence and information, for fear of losing his Christianity.
• Learning for the first time that many stories in the Bible were copied from earlier mythologies.
• Concluding that Christianity is just a man-made construct.
• Facing the need to be honest and authentic in the context of Christians who will ostracize and hate you for leaving.
• Understanding that vulnerable people can be primed for indoctrination by churches that "offer a solution." 
• Experiencing some church members questioning his wife about her love for him and advising her to not talk with him about religion, which appeared like they were trying to drive a wedge between them.
• Realizing the even greater love and empathy that develops after escaping Christianity.
• Dealing with the embarrassment of ever having believed in Christianity and for trying so hard to keep believing it, but understanding that psychological conditioning can profoundly overpower our minds.
• How Christians set up the paradigm of "us vs. them" and "Christian vs. other," but how wonderful it is to lose that dynamic and perspective upon deconversion.
• The bizarre experience of grieving the loss of your worldview, during deconversion, while also starting to receive rudeness and animosity from Christians.

For Austin:
• Feeling like the Christian stories, theology, and worldview never added up.
• How Christians "poison the well" against non-Christian ideas and information.
• Admitting that the Yahweh character appears to be purposefully trying to trick people and sow confusion, and ultimately that the Yahweh character does not live out the attributes that Christian theology ascribes to him.
• Dealing with the loss of the afterlife concept.
• After deconversion, the importance of studying moral philosophy to rebuild your moral underpinning and to ultimately lead by example without a theological underpinning.

Many thanks to Ricky and Austin for sharing their stories!

episodes.title: My relationship with god was like being with an abusive partner - Denise Powell
episodes.description:
T/W - brief discussion about suicide

Today I spoke with Denise Powell, who placed her faith in Jesus as a young child and grew up in a Baptist environment, but ultimately deconverted from Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Asking god into her heart as a young child so that she could be a "good girl," please her parents, and not go to hell.
• Asking good questions but getting shut down because her questions about the afterlife, same sex relationships, etc., were too difficult for adults to answer.
• Being groomed to believe that men are in charge and that women are there to support and submit to them.
• Growing up hearing that atheists are bad people who just want to reject god and sin.
• Realizing that she struggled less in life before becoming a Christian and focusing on honoring god.
• As a child, going through a lot of anxiety about going to sleep because she wasn't sure where people went when they slept and wondering if demonic powers could impact her while she slept.
• Feeling like she was in a vicious cycle of trying to be perfect, failing to be perfect, and then giving up on herself.
• Feeling the constant need of a Savior for herself and the world.
• Loving to sing hymns and acapella music and the magical feelings that Christian songs evoked.
• Growing up with strong pressure to save and impact others for god, as a way of being a light in the dark world.
• Seeing people who are part of the overseas "mission field" as the "others" who desperately need Jesus.
• Being traumatized by a relationship with a Christian man who was strongly patriarchal, misogynistic, and controlling.
• Wondering, after a very serious accident, why god did not prevent the accident and why she was spared while others were not.
• Finding that atheists are often kinder and more selfless than Christians.
• How learning about things like evolution, the history and details of the formation of the New Testament canon began to create cracks in the foundation of her Christian worldview.
• Realizing that as a Christian, she had not been taught to think critically.
• Concluding that since Christians have withheld huge amounts of information about the origins and evolution of Christianity, that their worldview and beliefs are extremely suspect.
• Seeing the importance of understanding the author viewpoint, culture, and time period when reading an apologist, the Bible, or any other book.
• Admitting that it looked like god was hiding, if he were real at all.
• Feeling like her deconversion was like a traumatic breakup from the Yahweh character.
• The beauty of just "being" now that she has escaped Christianity.
• How purity culture, combined with an abusive boyfriend, created trauma in the arena of 
• Realizing that "the still small voice" is ourselves.
• Acknowledging that we have wasted a lot of time while stuck in religion.
• Understanding that what we were taught was "typology" was actually just earlier stories that were re-written into the Jesus mythology.
• The bizarre mentality of Christians who would disqualify a pastor over sexual innuendos but will sing the songs of David who was a rapist and murderer.
• Realizing that Christianity is an inherited system.

Thanks to Denise for sharing her story!

episodes.title: One of life’s greatest freedoms is freedom from religion - Kenneth Marion
episodes.description:
T/W - brief discussion of self-harm

Today I spoke with Kenneth Marion, who grew up in an Apostolic UPC (United Pentecostal Church) environment, but ultimately deconverted as his experience with Christianity got more bizarre and as he examined the truth claims he had been raised to believe.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Growing up hearing that we are "in the Lord's Army."
• Hearing that people in church leadership had to pray at least 1 hour/day as a prerequisite to be active in ministry.
• Facing an endless list of legalistic rules for what would prove how committed and holy a church member is.
• Observing the church culture of people constantly looking for a new revelation after they had studied the Bible a lot.
• Hearing constant fearmongering messages in church.
• Being urged to "lay down his life for the Lord" and be willing to be a martyr for Jesus.
• Being treated like a spiritual prodigy in church, ministry, and Bible quizzing.
• Dealing with the contrast of pursuing god vs. pursuing sin, lust, etc.
• Feeling deeply ashamed when he felt like he wasn't fully honoring god.
• Being told that organized sports and other activities could become "idols."
• Seeing ushers in church writing down notes of people who were not dressing in a modest way, so they could report to the pastor, who could ultimately control everyone's behavior.
• Hearing the message that he was not allowed to switch churches unless the pastor approved the change.
• Facing major contradictions between the Bible's teachings and his church leadership's proclamations.
• Hearing his pastor threaten to ask god to kill him if he did not fully submit to church authority.
• Seeing sexual text messages from the Pastor to his girlfriend.
• Being publicly harassed by his Pastor, from the pulpit.
• Starting to think through the horror of the doctrines of election and predestination, from the side of those who were chosen by Yahweh to be cursed and punished.
• Facing the contrast between Yahweh claiming to not be a respecter of persons but at the same time having a "chosen people."
• Experiencing much more happiness and peace after deconversion.
• The importance of using your life to create your own mission and build something significant.


Many thanks to Kenneth for sharing his story with us today!

episodes.title: Who's Afraid of the Judgment Day?  It Ain't Me - Rebecca Jade
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Rebecca Jade, who kicked off her interview with a song, and then shared her story of being raised in a strong evangelical Christian environment but ultimately deconverting as she examined the claims of Christianity.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Growing up being threatened with hell.
• Placing her faith in Jesus as her Savior but also rededicating her life several times, to be sure she was really saved and living for god.
• Hearing Christians commiserate over how badly they had failed god.
• Feeling pressure, as a worship leader, to sound both super humble but also as filled with the Spirit as possible.
• Wanting badly to speak in tongues but never being able to.
• Ultra-spiritualizing everything in life, such as fearing that burning incense in her home might be inviting demons.
• Observing exorcisms at church. 
• Learning that it was extremely important to use the phrase "in Jesus' name" when praying, as if that phrase had power.
• Believing that it was crucial to be ready for Jesus' imminent return, which could happen at any moment.
• Observing her child traumatized by fear over the end times.
• Feeling immense shame and guilt, and resenting her husband, for not remaining virgins until marriage -- and ultimately struggling to forgive herself and her husband.
• The importance of not connecting your self worth to your virginity.
• Starting to slowly question her faith, starting with questioning the idea of an overarching "divine plan" being orchestrated by the Yahweh character.
• Being disturbed by seeing Christians constantly fighting harshly over Bible passages and the right way to see different doctrines and realizing that the messaging of the god character is very confusing and unclear.
• How meeting "real life" people, not connected to church, helped broaden her perspectives and to wonder if god would really send many of them to hell.
• Getting to a place of "being done with" judging other people and their eternal state.
• Realizing that the human sacrifice atonement of Jesus goes against Torah rules.
• Moving into the "Torah observant" movement as a way of handling the contradictions of Christianity.
• Seeing the Torah Observant perspective unraveling as she found contradictions, extreme violence, and mythology in the Torah.
• Processing the history of Yahweh's wife Asherah, and how she was written out of the Bible to support patriarchy.
• Realizing that she is happier and a better person, after her deconversion.
• Experiencing shunning from Christians due to her deconversion.
• The importance of developing boundaries with Christians post-deconversion.
• Hearing Christians tell her own children that she is being deceived by the devil.
• The critical importance of giving thought autonomy to the next generation.
• Using her musical skills to help share deconstruction messages.
• Hearing it preached in church that "women should be silent in church" yet being allowed to publicly pray during worship.
• How Christians want deconverted people to fail at life so they can argue that you "reaped what you sowed."
• How Christianity gives preemptive abandonment trauma as people are told that Yahweh is their loving father but that he will abandon them if they do not believe in Jesus as their Savior.

Many thanks to Rebecca for sharing her music, story, and insights with us!

episodes.title: Christ Church Rampant: How the church creates a culture of conformity & reduces freedom - Eric Runge
episodes.description:
T/W - Today's guest is a Christian.

_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Eric Runge, who attended Christ Church (in Moscow, Idaho) for 4 years and taught at their school, but was ultimately harassed and threatened by leadership, enabling him to see through their mind control tactics and escape.

We discussed many topics, including:

• How Doug Wilson (DW) and the Christ Church (CC) community give a vibe that they have "all the answers."
• Going through unaccredited marital counseling with DW that proved to be very shallow.
• Realizing that he had been a victim of spiritual abuse by DW and CC.
• Observing the CC culture that mocked other evangelical Christians and saw them as "stupid idiots" over theological and cultural differences.
• How individual "Christian" freedoms are not respected at CC.
Observing CC push a narrative that men in general are ravenous sexual wolves that will hurt innocent girls but that sex in marriage resolves the temptations.
• Observing DW's puritan, holier-than thou, elitist mentality.
• The implication at CC that if you don't conform to their ways of thinking and living, you will be cast out and socially shamed.
• Being harassed, pressured, and threatened by Elder Mike Lawyer.
• How CC effectively covers up abusers, and the abused end up getting attacked as a result.
• The authoritarian and bullying mindset practiced by DW and CC leadership.
• How Nouthetic counseling, which is practiced at CC, shallowly teaches people to "just believe and obey the Bible."
• The dynamic that people are fearful of DW, even when they move to other states and other countries.
• The strong element of control, including mind control, as well as threats, at CC.
• How the CC culture leads to people feeling very pressured to hand over their consent, stop being an individual agent, and simply conform -- or risk oppression and scorn.
• The importance of acknowledging and healing from religious trauma, especially from a secular humanist perspective.
• The crucial need to have and protect a strong sense of individuality and self, in order to protect ourselves from the damage done by groups like CC.

Many thanks to Eric for sharing his story and insights!

episodes.title: My pursuit of truth led me out of Christianity - Kelsey Gallert
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Kelsey Gallert, who grew up in a mainstream Evangelical and Pentecostal environment, but as an adult moved through Independent Fundamental Baptist and Torah Observance / Hebrew roots perspectives before ultimately deconverting as she investigated the mythological origins of Christianity.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Watching people in church being "slain in the spirit."
• Intensely hungering for the Spirit and being concerned about people around her who didn't share that hunger.
• Feeling the struggle to maintain a strong "mountaintop experience" in daily life.
• Sensing that the Yahweh character was sending her personal messages and life direction through her private devotions and prayer life.
• "Pleading the blood" for protection and victory in various life situations.
• Hearing strong preaching about her being profoundly wicked, to the point that she questioned her previous professions of faith in Jesus.
• Realizing that other religions were acting out the same way as Pentecostals do.
• Fearing the Rapture / Tribulation and being left behind.
• Being drawn into the Hebrew Roots movement.
• Feeling like the truth was too hard to find, as if the god character was intentionally making it difficult to find the truth, despite her sincere devotion to him.
• Realizing that Jesus is a copy of demigods like Dionysius and Paul's conversion on the road to Damascus is based on Euripides' Bacchae.
• Concluding that human sacrifice blood magic atonement is not reality.
• Realizing that instead of trusting god this whole time, we've actually just been trusting a bunch of unknown dead men who concocted and evolved Judaism and Christianity.
• Admitting that the Yahweh character was portrayed as psychopathic and at the same time that we were trained to love him and gladly obey him.
• Understanding that for many years the most important person in our lives was imaginary, leaving us free to connect with and love the real people in our lives.
• Realizing that she had felt that she used to have an imaginary friend near her, but that after deconversion, the imaginary friend was no longer there.
• Experiencing much more peace after deconversion.
• The importance of imparting a secular morality to the next generation.
• The struggle to not give into the existential OCD that can occur when we lose the Christian worldview and seek to give our lives meaning and purpose.
• Dealing with the post-deconversion anger of how the proponents of Christianity broke our hearts, stole time from our lives, and lied to us about its origins.

Many thanks to Kelsey for sharing her story!

episodes.title: There are too many glitches in the matrix of Christianity - Paolo Gordon
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Paolo Gordon, who grew up in an evangelical Christian environment focused on missions and dedicated his life to Jesus, but ultimately deconverted as the "glitches in the matrix" of Christianity kept adding up. 

We discussed many topics, including:

• Being told that Catholicism was a toxic system that was damning souls.
• Seeing his family move toward Calvinism and a more legalistic perspective.
• Noticing that racism, bigotry, and even capitalistic mentalities were "baked into" the Christian worldview and culture.
• Seeing hypocrisy and contradictory messages in other religions and other versions of Christianity but being blind to it in our own denomination and version of Christianity.
• Being invited as a young child to believe in Jesus as his Savior, and later understanding the human sacrifice and blood magic atonement aspects of the Gospel.
• Mocking Catholics for their transubstantiation view of the Eucharist, but seeing nothing bizarre in pretending to symbolically eat the body and drink the blood of the Jesus character.
• Placing his faith in the Jesus as his savior as a young child and rededicating his life to Jesus in his teenage years, in order to be sure he had been truly rescued from his sin.
• Noticing that his belief system did not truly allow for full certainty of salvation.
• Investigating the myriad Old Testament prophecies that failed.
• Reading passages that talk about god intentionally sending a deceiving spirit to people (2 Thess 2:11, 1 Kings 22:22), and thus wondering how god could be truly good and trustworthy.
• Being told by Christians that doubts were temptations from Satan.
• Moving into apologetics to try to find answers to Bible contradictions and to resolve his doubts.
• Wondering if his doubts were just evidence of spiritual immaturity.
• Dealing with the many contradictions, red flags, bizarre stories and horrific teachings in the Bible that started to cause him to deconstruct his worldview.
• Realizing that mythology is woven into the whole Bible, especially the Gospels.
• How religion allows people to justify abusive and toxic attitudes and behaviors if they believe they are driven by a divine purpose.
• How his deconversion has created an insatiable thirst for knowledge.
• Realizing, through comparative mythology, that the Bible and its claims are not unique.
• Studying how the Bible canon was put together, including the debates among church fathers, as well as later church leaders with very questionable character, about which books should have gone into or been kept out of the canon.
• Realizing that most of the Christians around us don't actually care to investigate many significant topics regarding the origins of the New Testament books and the stories in them, and they see our questions as an existential threat.
• Observing Christians encourage and even celebrate intentional ignorance.
• Realizing that Christianity is a plagiarized human sacrifice blood and death cult based on pagan mythology.
• Realizing that Christian apologists are in an echo chamber.

Many thanks to Paolo for sharing his story and his awesome insights!

episodes.title: The claims of Christianity kept unraveling until there was nothing left - Dee Murphy & Stacie Grahn
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Dee Murphy and her daughter, Stacie Grahn.  Dee grew up in Pentecostal Christianity, but ultimately deconverted as she examined the truth claims of Christianity.  Her daughter also separately deconverted, and they now work together to help others escape Christianity.

We discussed many aspects of her story, including:

• Attending tent meeting revivals as a young child.
• Observing how people were considered "backslidden" if they didn't appear to be on a constant spiritual high.
• Hearing people give her a "message from god."
• Feeling the constant contrasting messages that the Yahweh character will never leave you, but if you backslide, you are in danger of demons now and a literal lake of fire in hell after death.
• Believing that any doubts were evidence of the devil trying to tempt her away from god.
• Believing that angels and demons were part of an invisible world all around her, fighting all the time, and that any sin or lack of faith would empower the demons.
• Thinking that demons could attach themselves to objects, so buying things was problematic, especially if you had no way of knowing where the object had been you bought it.
• Anointing the house with oil to ward off demons.
• Being afraid of the dark, due to feeling like demons could be present.
• Praying for salvation many times to be sure she was truly saved.
• Moving away from charismatic Christianity toward Calvinism.
• Feeling like she could "breathe" for the first time as she deconstructed the truth claims of Christianity.
• The feeling of "finally being truthful with herself" when she admitted that the Christian worldview does not reflect reality.
• Being physically in but mentally out of Christianity for several years.
• Realizing, after deconverting, the fragility, briefness, and preciousness of our lives.
• How Christians severely disrespect and abuse people who deconvert from Christianity.
• The peace and beauty of life after deconversion.
• The importance of empowering children to have a strong voice and to question the narratives given to them by adults.


Many thanks to Dee and Stacie for sharing their story!

episodes.title: I could never worship a god who would separate people for eternity in hell - Lizz Enns Petters
episodes.description:
T/W - today's guest is a theist.

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Lizz Enns Petters, who grew up in a conservative Christian environment but has strongly deconstructed her faith and is helping others to think through critical issues related to the claims and implications of the Christian worldview.

We touched on many topics, including:

• How conservative Christian theology can cause immense anxiety in believers and can even cause issues like OCD and eating disorders.
• Never being "safe" in the Christian worldview and feeling like you are constantly walking on eggshells as you wonder whether you are pleasing the Yahweh and Jesus characters.
• Constantly praying for salvation to be sure your profession was real and that you are not in danger of going to hell.
• How Christianity teaches us to deny our bodies and our bodily desires.
• The choice many Christians make to not go down the route of deconstructing their faith because the process and outcome can feel messy and uncertain.
• Deciding that it cannot be an option to love and worship a god who would separate people for eternity in hell.
• The importance of not raising kids with the message that they are sinners who deserve condemnation and are on the way to eternal torment without Jesus.
• Learning to trust ourselves through the deconstruction process.
• The importance of not holding our beliefs too tightly, so that we can grow and evolve.
• Losing the need to "be right" about our beliefs and worldview.
• Admitting that the Jesus character is heavily mythologized.
• The importance of deepening our understanding of our connection to the planet.
• Pursuing a balance between philosophically accepting nihilism and yet not dwelling on it due to its possibly depressing conclusions.
• How Christianity can cause us to gloss over pain and grief, especially death, because we are taught to see such a loss as merely temporary, even though it's permanent.
• The importance of healing from religious trauma, especially focused on embodiment, on meeting your own needs, and on being willing to strongly speak up when something sounds wrong.
• Mourning the loss of what we no longer believe in and of people who no longer respect or even care about us because our belief systems and worldviews no longer align.
• Admitting that the beliefs of many Christians, including our own past beliefs when we were stuck in fundamentalism, are now disgusting to us.

Thanks to Lizz for sharing her story and insights!

episodes.title: Give yourself permission to trust yourself as you deconstruct - Emily Hedrick
episodes.description:
Trigger warning: brief mention of suicide, homophobia

_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Emily Hedrick, who grew up in the Mennonite Church and became a Mennonite pastor, before ultimately deconverting as she examined the truth claims of Christianity, and then becoming a religious trauma coach.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Being able to see theological red flags early in life due to there being a wide spectrum of perspectives in the Mennonite church as a whole.
• The importance of celebrating--and not stifling--analytical questions about our beliefs and worldview.
• Feeling called and conditioned to be a pastor at the age of 9.
• Dealing with the idea that "Your being who you are hurts people" regarding being a woman and moving toward church leadership.
• Going through anxiety over the Rapture due to the "Left Behind" books and over angels and demons due to Frank Peretti's books (This Present Darkness, etc.)
• Realizing that what felt like supernatural leading or oppression was actually just her own thoughts in her own mind.
• Acknowledging that we gaslight ourselves because our communities have taught us to interpret our experiences in light of the group theology and worldview.
• How Christian leaders trick people by getting them to believe things about themselves that aren't true and by manipulating their love for god.
• Dealing with the religious trauma of being told you're inherently bad, that you offend the Creator, and that your sin was the reason that the Jesus character had to be tortured.
• How rituals help us create meaning in our lives.
• How compassion fatigue can happen when you directly assist others in crisis as you experience burn out and secondary traumatic stress, especially as you witness people believing violent things about the Yahweh character, as you realize there are not enough resources to meet the demands of those you are trying to help, and as you feel the pressure to fit into the mold that the community puts on you.
• Admitting that the Yahweh character is portrayed as an abusive psychopathic tyrant, but people in church dance around that by just focusing on the message of his "love."
• The importance of being willing to investigate how others in the faith community can have a very different emotional experience, even with similar theology as what you experienced, based on what messages they did or did not subscribe to.
• The importance of condemning fundamentalist Christianity in order to create safety.
• How deconstructing requires that we carve out a safe space to examine and explore our beliefs by trying to find good people who will not condemn us for your questions and still accept us even if our beliefs end up shifting.
• Giving ourselves permission to trust ourselves and to pay attention to our bodies.


Many thanks to Emily for sharing her story!

episodes.title: I Escaped from the "Children of God" Christian Sex Cult and Reclaimed my Identity - Angel DeSantis
episodes.description:
*** Trigger warning: sexual assault, child abuse and exploitation, childhood rape, pedophilia, suicide.

____________________________________

Today I spoke with Angel DeSantis, who grew up in the "Children of God" Christian sex cult, but ultimately escaped as she examined the truth claims of the group, and of Christianity in general, and reclaimed her identity.

We discussed many topics, including: 

• Being indoctrinated to believe that the Antichrist and the End Times were coming very soon and that she was part of the Lord's End Time army.
• Being told to prepare for rape by the Antichrist's soldiers, but to use that as a means to seduce them to believe in Jesus.
• Seeing older women being sent out to do "Flirty Fishing" to seduce men sexually and then invite them to become involved in the cult.
• Being taught that your body belongs to the collective cult community, and consent was assumed.
• Receiving punishment for being kind toward her own sister, as a means to push the narrative that the entire community was as important as her immediate family.
• Hearing the Christian message of the Gospel of forgiveness of sin through Jesus altered into a works salvation message, focused primarily on whether the cult leaders where pleased with you.
• Seeing the cult leaders portray the known Christian characters (such as Yahweh, Jesus, the Holy Spirit, the Angel Gabriel, the Virgin Mary) in hyper-sexual terms.
• How the cult grooming process led to parents failing to see the danger or to protect their own children.
• How their worldview about god was highly authoritarian, where he was easily displeased with people, based on the cult leaders' perspectives.
• How the Yahweh character is shown as promising unconditional love yet with overwhelming conditions.
• How Christianity keeps people deeply stuck in cognitive dissonance because confused people are easier to control.
• How "purity culture" in the cult was reversed, encouraging women to show as much skin as possible and encouraging young men to "claw at" a woman's body.
• Hearing women being encouraged to not fight rape, but to see it as part of the will and plan of god.
• How the ultra-patriarchal and misogynistic mentalities of the cult saw women primarily as sex objects and childbearing objects.
• The extreme sheltering the cult imposed on members, so much that people who chose to leave would find their quality of life so poor that they would be compelled to return.
• Seeing all other Christians as foolish and unliberated.
• Being taught that heaven was basically an orgy scene.
• The importance of being self-aware enough to see red flags in our lives, worldviews, and relationships so that we can be mentally healthy and pass on healthiness to the next generation.
• The importance of autonomy and logical thinking in escaping fundamentalist religions.
• The importance of "setting a bar" that thoughts need to be 1) true and 2) useful, in order to be thoughts we are willing to entertain ... and rejecting any which don't meet that criteria.
• Slowly walking toward things that lead you to peace and health, and away from toxic ideas.
• How the Christian narrative actively degrades your sense of self.
• After deconversion, the importance of building yourself from ground zero as you discover and create your identity apart from the cult worldview.

Many thanks to Angel for sharing her story!


____________________________________

episodes.title: I'd Rather Have Questions I Can't Answer Than Answers I Can't Question - Fifth
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Fifth, a rapper who grew up as a Jehovah's Witness and was active as a Pioneer, Ministerial Student, and Bethelite, but ultimately deconverted as he examined the truth claims of the religion.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Seeing the men at the top of JW leadership believe they are being given direction directly from god.
• The ways that JW leadership claims that the Jehovah character keeps giving them "new light" as he clarifies his instructions for his people, even though all they are doing is "changing with the times."
• Actively doing door-to-door "witnessing" to unbelievers.
• Being invited to Bethel, the JW headquarters, to become more involved in ministry and leadership.
• The push to constantly do and sacrifice more for Jehovah in order to constantly fight for his salvation.
• Being excommunicated for sinning and opening questioning his belief in the Jehovah character and the JW worldview.
• The JW history of repeatedly telling congregants that within a weeks or months the world would end and paradise would begin.
• The pressure to not get married, have children, or pursue higher education due to the imminent end of the world.
• How there is no ultimate security or intimacy with the Jehovah character, compared to evangelical Protestant Christianity, where the theology lends to more of a secure and intimate relationship with the Yahweh character.
• Experiencing extreme brainwashing and manipulation in the JW community.
• The requirement on JWs that they see apostates as dangerous, even if they are family or a close friend, leading to apostates being demonized and shunned.
• The joy of using music to share his story and help others escape and heal.

Many thanks to Fifth for sharing his story!

episodes.title: Couples with different beliefs and values can still stay connected - Suzette Halterman
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Suzette Halterman, who grew up as a Latter Day Saint (Mormon), but ultimately shifted her beliefs and worldview as she examined the truth claims of Christianity, and subsequently began to also help other couples who hold different beliefs.

We talked about many topics, including:

• Learning about how the Mormon church's horrible history regarding the LBGTQ community, racism, and sexism.
• Experiencing sexual harassment from a church leader in high school.
• Unpacking the ways that the ultra-patriarchal dynamics of the LDS church deeply affected her psyche.
• Becoming "allergic" to the Christian worldview.
• Deconstructing the all-male leadership of the LDS church, starting with Joseph Smith.
• How our brains create "emotional knowings" and categories that make it easier for us to remain in an easy "black and white" mentality that can cause anxiety when we are faced with different opinions.
• The LDS belief that you stay married forever, even into eternity, and how that affects LDS marriages where one person no longer believes in the afterlife.
• The importance of the deconverted spouse being understanding and gracious to the still-believing spouse.
• How a believing spouse is driven toward their need to make meaning out of the situation of their spouse deconverting and possibly driving them to anxiety, depression, and control tactics.
• The experience of the believing spouse feeling threatened as they face the many uncertainties that are happening when their spouse deconverts.
• The need for professional counseling help in order for mixed-faith marriages to survive and thrive.
• The importance of knowing how your spouse's family of origin dealt with stress and change, in order to predict how they might respond to your worldview shift.
How to slowly create emotional safety and security for each other when one person starts questioning their beliefs.
• Dealing healthily with being rejected and despised by the believing spouse.
• The disconnect that occurs when people in a mix-faith marriage each try to convince each other of being smarter or wiser in their specific beliefs and values, and the need to instead "meet in the middle" as much as possible.
• Dealing honestly with non-negotiables in beliefs and worldviews, while still trying to find common ground where possible.
• The importance of moving away from the need for both people in a relationship to be the same in order to connect emotionally and physically.
• The importance of learning the tools of conflict resolution.

Thanks to Suzette for sharing her story and insights!

______________________________

episodes.title: It's Time to Escape and Heal from Mythological Worldviews - Cindy Wang Brandt
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Cindy Wang Brandt, who came to faith in Jesus as a young child, went to Bible college and seminary, and became a missionary, but eventually deconverted from Christianity as she examined the claims of Christianity.

We discussed many topics, including: 

• Growing up terrified of death and hell.
• Experiencing her Christian school set up a coffin with a mirror so that the students would be forced to get more serious about their own inevitable deaths.
• Being threatened with torture in hell if she did not believe in the Jesus character as her Savior.
• Being steeped in missionary culture, which was seen as the best possible life.
• Hearing stories of people who were compelled to profess Jesus as Lord at gunpoint or die, and the beautification of the martyr complex.
• How religious trauma can affect our memories of past experiences.
• Experiencing the watershed moment of standing up for gay and trans rights, even when Christians oppose you for it.
• Feeling easily triggered, even to the point of a panic attack, by just being invited to church.
• Unpacking the complex post-traumatic stress that occurred during years of Christian indoctrination.
• How religious trauma and stress "live" in the physical body for many years after the original experiences.
• Parenting after religious trauma, with a focus on children's autonomy and without religious fundamentalism.
• Seeing how religious systems control humans by taking aware their autonomy, teaching them that they are inherently and willfully wicked, and thus that they cannot be trusted.
• Experiencing hypervigilism, perfectionism, and anxiety as a result of trying to stop sinning and be entirely focused on honoring the Lord.
• How evangelical Christianity disassociates believers from their bodies, often provides very little information about sex to young people, shames people for their thoughts and desires, and ends up taking away their agency.
• The importance of developing a sex-positive worldview after deconstruction and imparting that to the next generation.
• Being a good example to our kids of rationality and critical thinking as we work to move our culture past mythological worldviews.
• Feeling angry at being lied to and deceived by Christians, and then grieving both the harm that was done to us as well as ways that we passed on the Christian worldview to others.
• The importance of giving our kids an education and vocabulary for hard topics like racism and homophobia, so that they see our example and we work together cross-generationally to advocate for marginalized identities -- starting with children.

Many thanks to Cindy for sharing her story and insights!

_________________________________________

episodes.title: I Was Silenced in Eden, but I Will be Silent No More - Jo Lloyd Johnson
episodes.description:
T/W: sexual assault / childhood rape

_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Jo Lloyd Johnson, who was born into a church commune, placed her faith in Jesus at a young age, and wanted to be a pastor's wife, but ultimately deconverted as the claims of Christianity fell apart.

We discussed many topics, including: 

• Being taught that angels and demons were all around us and were interacting with people and places.
• Due to purity culture, feeling like her womanhood was possibly bringing out evil thoughts in men.
• Being told that any sins that she committed were the equivalent of her trampling on the blood of Jesus.
• Growing seeing her primary gender role as becoming a wife in order to be her husband's helper and to support his dreams and vision.
• Seeing feelings as evil, deceptive, and untrustworthy, and seeing female emotions as part of why Eve was deceived.
• How women are portrayed in the Bible as a subservient afterthought.
• Wearing a purity ring as a pledge to her future husband to stay pure until they married.
• Feeling guilty whenever she showed "too much skin" and garnered male attention toward her body.
• Being taught that sexual urges were a man's battle, not a woman's, and that her role was to protect men's purity by having strict physical boundaries against his strong sexual urges toward her.
• Being given almost no education about sex, consent, the menstrual period, etc. -- and being told that menstrual cramps and childbirth pains were part of inherited punishment from Eve in the garden of Eden.
• Realizing that church culture and rape culture go hand-in-hand and that Christianity often grooms women for abuse.
• Learning that speaking in tongues can put you in a trance and cause trauma flashbacks.
• Dealing with PTSD from the repressed memory of childhood rape and the accompanying nightmares as it came to the surface.
• Being told that counseling and therapy was not Biblical, and that she should just pray for miraculous healing instead, which was just a coping mechanism.
• Dealing with the contextual messaging that she was less valuable and was "damaged goods" because her virginity was already taken before marriage.
• Anticipating sex as a duty in marriage, with no thought toward her own sexual pleasure.
• Dealing with intense shame and guilt over sexual activity with her boyfriend while concurrently enjoying the beauty and healing of a boyfriend who accepted her and delighted in her.
• Acknowledging that waiting until marriage to be sexually active would have actually been very damaging to her.
• Being shunned by her church for having premarital sex.
• Realizing that Bible stories of demon possession actually sound like mental illness.
• Seeing how women are described in the Bible and treated in church as second-class citizens.
• Studying the topic of hell and concluding that hell was never seen as a literal place, and thus it has always ever just been a fear tactic.
• Realizing that Christians who think the Bible is history are often the least educated on the history of the Bible and the stories behind it.
• Realizing that original sin was an evolved concept.
• Realizing that the Jesus stories originally painted him as just a man, and that his deity was an evolved concept.
• Admitting that there is no reason to think that the god of the Bible exists.
• Facing the experience of severely disappointing family and loved ones who are still Christians.
• Seeing the harm that Christianity does by trying to break a child's will.
• How deconversion is like mourning a death, but Christians act like you were the cause of that death.
• Having the preferred experienced of deconstructing at the same time as her spouse, so they could understand and support each other.
• Confronting and healing from sexual and religious trauma and reclaiming her voice.
• How the deconversion and healing process allows you to honor your inner self and to be yourself for the first time in your life.

Many thanks to Jo for sharing her story in this interview and through her book!

episodes.title: Christianity is mythology and you don't need a savior -  Janine Harris
episodes.description:
Trigger warning: sexual assault, depression

_________________________________________


Today I spoke with Janine Harris, who grew up in an evangelical Christian environment and believed in Jesus, but ultimately deconverted as she evaluated the truth claims of Christianity, especially in light of comparative mythology.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Believing that she was a sinner in need of a Savior, and that if she did not believe, the outcome in the afterlife would be eternal conscious torment in a literal hell.
• Acknowledging that parts of the Gospels are extremely antisemitic.
• Realizing that there were many red flags about the toxicity of the Christian worldview that we are now surprised we didn't see earlier.
• Hearing Christians describe yoga as a demonic religion.
• Taking seriously the command to "pray without ceasing."
• Wanting the Yahweh character to speak audibly to her.
• Feeling pressure to not dance during worship, even though she wanted to.
• As a Christian, doing missions trips focused on sharing the Gospel.
• Being told by a very non-empathetic Christian leader to simply forgive a sexual assault she had endured earlier in life.
• Seeing virginity elevated to such a high level that an unmarried woman who was not a virgin, whether by her voluntary choice or not, was seen as dirty, not as valuable of a potential marriage partner, and worth significantly less than a virgin.
• Being pushed away by Christian young men because her very presence was a temptation, and they wanted to keep themselves ultra-pure for their future wives.
• How purity culture can end up causing some people to be so closed off to eroticism that they are never able to achieve a sexual climax.
• The importance of being able to see the opposite sex, both clothed and nude, in a non-sexual way.
• Having concerns with different theological issues, while also beginning to fear -- in the context of Calvinism -- that the Yahweh character hadn't predestined/elected her to be saved.
• Starting to look at early church history and canonicity in great detail and being shocked at the level of corruption and evolution of the narratives that she found.
• Learning that many early Christians saw Yahweh as an evil god, and that Yahweh was originally part of a pantheon.
• Realizing that a lot of the Bible is symbolic, and that it is difficult for people today to be aware of or understand.
• Learning about how Buddhist, Mithraic, and Greco-Roman mystery cult mythology and astrotheology motifs were copied and woven into the New Testament.
• Looking honestly at atrocities done in the name of Yahweh and Jesus, from Old Testament stories through the Crusades and up to current times.
• Seeing that the real nature of Christian missions is colonialism.
• Realizing that we were the ones who created the gods, and in our image as humans.
• How Christian theology leads people to not really be "present" because they are so focused on heaven and the afterlife and consequently seeing this life as just a taste of the true and "real" life that begins after death.
• Figuring out what we want to consider "sacred" as we reclaim our identities after deconversion.

Many thanks to Janine for sharing her story!

episodes.title: Let's Talk About Sex: Purity Culture and Morality with Lars & Christie Cade
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Lars and Christie Cade, who shared in a previous interview their journey of deconversion from Christianity.  They returned today to talk about the myriad ways that purity culture caused damage and what their journey to recovery looked like.

We discussed many topics, including:

• How human "flesh" is repeatedly described in the Bible as bad and wicked.
• Growing up with Christian parents who provided almost no education about sexuality.
• How preaching against immorality and homosexuality reinforced the concept that sex is bad.
• Hearing strong messages that "true love waits" and that if you don't wait, you are tarnished and less valuable.
• Feeling ashamed of having genitals.
• Seeing the ways that religions often denigrate pleasure and set it up as something suspicious and to be ignored or repressed.
• Seeing how virginity culture leads some people to feel like dying once they get married.
• Realizing, after deconversion, that it is completely healthy to pursue sexual experiences based not on what the Bible dictates, but on what you people mutually agree to experience.
• The beauty of "being free to be yourself" sexually and to feel the total freedom to discuss your needs, desires, and fantasies.
• The importance of being sexually uninhibited and without any shame.
• How shame culture leads people to feel like they can never really share their true thoughts with others, even and especially their own spouse.
• The importance of facing head-on the healing process as you recover from purity culture.
• The importance of developing transparency and trust in our relationships.
• How long-term sexual deprivation in marriage is a breach of trust.

We barely scratched the surface on these topics, and there are many other similar and relevant issues that we could tackle, so we will probably do some follow ups down the line ... stay tuned.

Many thanks to Lars and Christie for sharing their story!

episodes.title: I Lost Religion and Found Myself - Scott Okamoto
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Scott Okamoto, the author of "Asian American Apostate: Losing Religion and Finding Myself at an Evangelical University."  He was a Christian, a worship leader, a Bible study guide, and a Christian university teacher until he deconstructed his beliefs and ultimately deconverted.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a church dominated by male leadership.
• Repeatedly accepting Jesus as his Savior to be sure it was real.
• As a kid, proselyting to other kids out of concern for them going to hell.
• Being raised to believe that homosexuals were evil and that the Yahweh character hated them.
• Realizing, throughout the long deconstruction period, that his view of god was changing dramatically and repeatedly.
• Seeing bias, racism, and white-centeredness woven into the fabric of the church and Christian university culture.
• Going to Christian academics for solid answers to difficult questions, but finding they had the same trite answers as other Christians.
• Hearing speakers at Azusa Pacific chapel services telling the student body that being gay was a sickness that could be cured and that gay people would likely rape children.
• The importance of fighting Christian nationalism.
• Feeling much more empathetic and connected to humanity outside of faith.
• How Christians consistently show hatred to those who bring light.
• Dealing with the Stockholm Syndrome effect of the Yahweh character and of Christianity as a whole.
• Dealing directly with academic issues, such as comparative mythology, but also acknowledging that for most people, the deconversion process has a very emotional component, especially as people realize that the Christians around them will despise and even shun them for escaping Christianity.

Thanks to Scott for sharing his story ... and congrats on publishing a book!

episodes.title: Christ Church Rampant: How the Doug Wilson cult destroys lives - Bekka Poznik
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Bekka Poznick in a profound and emotional interview about the overwhelming trauma caused by Doug Wilson and Toby Sumpter, leaders in the Christ Church cult in Moscow, Idaho.

Bekka and I touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in Christ Church as it got established and as Doug Wilson expanded his power.
• Seeing the church embrace child baptism (paedobaptism).
• Placing her faith in Christ as her Savior as a young child.
• Slowly but increasingly distrusting Pastor Doug Wilson.
• Experiencing her deep questions and concerns being shut down as quickly as possible.
• Facing the male-ruled culture at Christ Church and Trinity Reformed Church.
• Seeing young men taught to be more powerful, and women to be submissive.
• Being taught that masturbation is sin.
• Observing the strongly anti-gay mentality of the Christ Church community and how they mocked and hurt many people.
• Thinking that she was in danger of burning in hell because she was exploring various normal life experiences.
• Fearing that the reason she seemed "worldly" would not "repent" was because she was probably not one of the "Elect," and facing immense depression as a result.
• Being told by Pastor Toby Sumpter that she was selfish and had "the moral standing of a rapist" and was selfish because she chose to move away from Moscow and move in with her boyfriend.
• Being excommunicated by Trinity Reformed Church in 2018.
• Having panic attacks for many years after the abuse that she received in Moscow, Idaho.
• The importance of escaping toxic and controlling communities.
• The dynamics of healing, forgiveness, and moving on from severe religious trauma and abuse, especially in the context of aggressive and unrepentant cult leaders.
•  Realizing both that Christ Church is truly a highly controlling cult, but also eventually realizing that Christianity itself is mythology.

Many thanks to Bekka for her bravery in sharing her story about leaving the Christ Church cult and escaping Christianity as a whole.

episodes.title: We can undo the poison that religion has brought to our lives - James Valliant
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with James Valliant, a former prosecutor, author of "The Passion of Ayn Rand's Critics," and co-author of the book "Creating Christ."

We discussed many topics, including:

• How the confirmation bias leads Christians to believe first, before they have reasons to believe and proof for the truth of their worldview.
• The importance of admitting and diving into the ways that childhood indoctrination affected our ability to logically analyze alternative ideas.
• The importance of being more committed to the truth than to our current worldview.
• How we were taught that Yahweh and Jesus are the standard of good and that they care for their people, so bowing the knee to the Bible becomes not just something to obey because god was seen as the King, but as the loving King who could be trusted.
• To make progress, being able to change your perspective as new facts and knowledge present themselves.
• How Christians fail to flip Pascal's Wager on themselves and realize that they really are to be most pitied if the resurrection is not true.
• The very poisonous aspects of religion on our lives.
• The importance of embracing selfish pleasures.
• The importance of rejecting religion on the methodological, ethical, and psychological levels.
• How Christianity has typically been the enemy of human progress.
• The need to stop blaming ourselves for what we didn't know before we knew it.
• Why beliefs should never be based on bribes, threats, or a lack of information.
• How indoctrination and religious manipulation of children is a form of psychological child abuse.
• The importance of admitting to children that we, as adults, don't know everything.
• How asserting a god as a prior assumption is just another form of psychological manipulation.
• Admitting that the Yahweh character is portrayed as both bizarre and psychopathic.
• Dealing with the Christian contention that we all have a "god-shaped void" in our heart.

Many thanks to James for his invaluable insights!


_________________________________________

episodes.title: I am no longer a Phanatik for Christian mythology - Brady Goodwin
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Brady "Phanatik" Goodwin, a formerly Christian rapper with The Cross Movement who deconverted after deeply investigating the Bible and the claims of Christianity.

As we talked through his story, we touched on many topics, including:

• Being raised in a prosperity-gospel church context.
• Watching his mom consistently pray for him.
• Growing up not so much fearing hell itself but instead fearing going through life without the protection of the Yahweh character from bad forces and experiences in life.
• Repeatedly "getting saved" in church by renouncing sin and turning to Jesus.
• At age 15, getting very serious about the Lord and about sharing the Gospel with others.
• Believing and preaching that we all were unrighteous in the sight of Yahweh and deserving of hell.
• Feeling like it was an honor to investigate the mysteries and tensions of the messages of the Bible.
• Realizing that Paul's message about the Gospel contradicts both Jesus as well as the Old Testament.
• Seeing the theology and message of the Bible increasingly falling apart despite his best efforts to keep it together and keep believing.
• Acknowledging that critical information about the origins of the Bible were withheld from us and that and any ideas that diverged from traditional Christian interpretations of the Bible were made to look bad, foolish, and irrelevant.
• In the midst of his faith dissipating, asking the Yahweh character to supernaturally reveal himself if he is real.
• How the questions asked by progressive Christians, especially in light of understanding evolution, led him to not just deconstruct, but to fully deconvert.
• Admitting that Christianity is mythology and is based on earlier mythologies.
• Having close friends label him an enemy of the cross and begin to attack him.
• Focusing on the goal of spending the rest of his life actualizing all of his potential and removing false ideas.
• The importance of giving others a much better morality than the morality of the psychopathic Yahweh character and of giving the next generation the crucial gift of thought autonomy.

Many thanks to Brady for sharing his story!

episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Emma Thorne, a fellow YouTuber who helps reveal dangerous and harmful teachings of Christians.

We had a fun dialogue, starting with her story and moving on to various topics, including:

• Growing up in England, a country that is secular but ironically has no separation of church and state.
• Being exposed to Christianity but even from a young age not truly buying into and believing the Christian message.
• Feeling angry at the legality of psychological abuse and indoctrination of children that occurs in church and in Christian homes.
• The importance of not forcing kids to believe certain things, especially under the threat of eternal conscious torment.
• Realizing that her internal morals were much better than the morality of the Yahweh character.
• Realizing the implications of their probably being no afterlife.
• The dangers of purity and shame culture.
• Embracing and exploring bisexuality in the context of a conservative Christian culture.
• How and when to deal with people who are neck-deep in cognitive dissonance with their religious beliefs.
• How we as atheists get and evolve our morality.
• How the god of the Bible, Yahweh, is a brutally psychopathic character, yet believers look to him and the Bible as a source for their morality.
• Ways to support feminism and fight patriarchy and misogyny.

episodes.title: Christianity is mythology ... and I no longer believe - Patrick Jones
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Patrick Jones, who grew up as a Southern Baptist and focused on missions, but ultimately deconverted as he seriously examined the claims and origins of Christianity.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Being told that the Bible was completely inerrant and that the Earth was young.
• Being taught that Catholics were bad, but then attending a Catholic school and realizing they were good people.
• Realizing that the Bible had been interpreted very differently in other Christian traditions, and that some of those other traditions had encouraged their congregations to analyze all sides of a topic, think deeply, and possibly come to different conclusions.
• Being set up with an "Us versus Them" mentality regarding both non-Christians as well as other Christians who had a different theology.
• Enjoying leadership roles in the church, especially in light of his passion for educating others.
• Growing up feeling crushed by sin and completely guilty.
• How music has evolved in the evangelical church to bring about strong emotional responses, especially in light of the contrast of the intense personal guilt versus the invitation to connect with and be forgiven by the Yahweh character.
• Slowly dismantling Christianity over 20 years, so that the admission of full deconversion at the very end was not as painful as it is for others.
• Sensing that most Christians were not really concerned about those around them regarding the Gospel or about social issues like poverty and racism.
• Moving toward a progressive Christianity perspective that included the possibility of universal salvation.
• Learning about how the church and its dogmatic theology suppressed sexuality over the centuries.
• How purity culture was woven into Christian culture, including a body vs. spirit dualistic mentality, the critical need to preserve virginity until marriage, being in discipleship for accountability, confessing sinful thoughts, fighting masturbation and pornography, and seeing any sexual thought as wicked.
• Hearing women refer to Yahweh as their "Daddy" and Jesus as their "Husband."
• The season of deconversion when it truly hits you that "this is all made up."
• How a serious study of comparative mythology and folklore helps us see where Christian mythology evolved from, including how similar it is to other stories and practices from other ancient cults.
• Admitting that there are massive gaps in our understanding of how the various streams of Judaism and Christianity started and evolved.
• Realizing that through various flukes of history, we could easily have seen Pythagoreanism or Mithraism taking over the world instead of Christianity.

Thanks to Patrick for sharing his story!

episodes.title: Break the Chains of Transgenerational Trauma and Break Free from Christianity - Dorothy Husen
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Dorothy Husen, a Licensed Marriage & Family Therapist and the author of "Breaking the Chains of Transgenerational Trauma."  Dorothy grew up in an Evangelical church and believed in Jesus most of her life, but deconverted in adulthood as she dug deeply into the toxic messages and traumatic implications of the Christian worldview.

We discussed many topics, including:

• How a sexual assault during her childhood affected her view of god and of sexuality.
• Seeing her family convert to Christianity through Calvary Chapel.
• The effect of childhood sexual assault on her as a teenager, where she would feel like there was a part of her that was bad and lustful.
• The confusing message of not focusing on external beauty, and yet being surrounded by married women in church who were focused very heavily on external beauty.
• Being in a state of chronic stress, wondering what Yahweh's will was.
• The conundrum of fearing Yahweh and yet wanting to think of him as a loving heavenly father figure, where it is both "a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living god" and yet "perfect love casts out fear."
• How the contradictory messages about Yahweh's nature forces people to cherry pick which verses they wanted to focus on.
• Experiencing help from the church with family issues to be basically useless.
• The pressure on Christian parents to have good, Christian kids who are making the parents proud and demonstrating that the parents did a good job instilling Christian beliefs and character into their children.
• How Christianity leads people to punish themselves if they are not thriving in life.
• The reality that the Gospel is powerless to change lives.
• The fact that Christians of any kind are unequipped for counseling and psychology, and are going to cause more harm, as they push their mythological worldviews on counselees.
• Realizing that there are natural explanations for experiences that appear to be spiritual in nature.
• How Christianity creates a mental "circuit breaker" of cognitive dissonance that cuts people off from deep thinking and investigation and pushes them instead to trust in the Yahweh character and believe that he will make everything right someday.
• How Christianity creates a group delusion and a "hive" mentality.
• How Christianity leads adults to traumatize their kids on purpose.
• The importance of changing parenting habits caused by religious trauma, in order to give the next generation a better chance at being better people and better parents themselves.
• Seeing deconversion create a true context for self-love, self-confidence, and inner security to flourish.
• How nihilism frees us to create our own purpose and meaning in life.
• The freedom from sexual shame that happens when people leave religious worldviews.
• Realizing that so many of the aspects of Christianity that seemed positive were actually always liabilities as they kept us in self-deception.
• The importance of teaching parents how to meet their children's emotional needs and how to apply those principles to themselves, especially in the larger context of breaking transgenerational trauma.

Many thanks to Dorothy for sharing her story and insights!

_________________________________________

episodes.title: Ex-Pastor, now Atheist: Christianity stole the best years of my life - Apostate Ashley
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Apostate Ashley, who grew up as a Christian in the Assemblies of God denomination, pastored in Open Bible Churches, and was a Master's Commission Director until she examined the claims of Christianity in depth, and ultimately deconverted.

We discussed many topics, including:

• How church became a helpful escape from a difficult home situation.
• Trusting the Jesus character as her Savior at age 5, during a revival service, by saying the "Sinner's Prayer."
• Being urged to be "hot or cold" for Jesus, and not lukewarm.
• Feeling the urgency of the Great Commission to preach the Gospel and save the lost.
• Successfully evangelizing, and consequently leading many people "to Christ," but feeling ashamed and apologetic, after deconversion, for being involved in sharing the Christian worldview with other people.
• As a young person, thinking that miracles were happening all around her, but realizing now that it was just adrenaline rushes and self-deception.
• Truly believing that Yahweh was directly answering her prayers.
• Struggling with anxiety as a young person but seeing god and the church as her safe haven.
• Surrendering herself to Yahweh, especially when the music was playing during worship services, and experiencing a broad range of emotional responses, from tears to uncontrollable laughter.
• How church leaders prime the atmosphere during worship services in order to set believers up for the "high" of the experience.
• Seeing medication as a lack of faith in Yahweh, since he had the power to directly heal.
• Being empowered as a female associate pastor, yet still working within a patriarchal system.
• Being pushed to have a short engagement period and rush into marriage for the sake of purity, and how that dynamics leads people to not really know the person they are marrying.
• Starting to examine church teachings about topics such as hell, homosexuality, and the infallibility of the Bible.
• Deconverting quietly as she investigated the claims and origins of Christianity, but still being involved in church publicly for a while.
• Being heartbroken as she realized she didn't actually have a Savior, that prayer didn't actually work, that there was no heaven, and that there were so many missed opportunities earlier in life due to her focusing so heavily on church ministry.
• Feeling, upon deconversion, like she was "starting from scratch."
• Sensing the strong need to rescue her daughter from the Christian worldview.
• The bizarre, aggressive, and creepy ways that Christian leadership tried to pull her back to Christianity, and then publicly writing her off when she did not return, 
• Seeing that many Christians are vindictive against other Christians who deconvert, treating them like traitors, claiming they are evil and demon-possessed, and often cutting off all contact.
• The dynamic of Christians not really wanting to know why other Christians "left," due to the fear that those who have left might actually have a good reason, leaving Christians feeling safer by not inquiring about deconverted Christians' rationales for leaving.
• How Christians convince themselves that they've actually experienced the Yahweh and Jesus characters, and how that conviction cuts them off from even considering the possibility that those characters are mythological.
• The experience of deconstructing the preachment about a literal hell.
• The importance of being involved with theists without being so aggressive that they feel disinterested in engaging in serious discussion.
• The need to put up boundaries with Christians who personally attack her, such as Christians telling her that Yahweh cursed her with MS due to her deconversion.
• Reprogramming our worldview and healing from religious trauma by knowing, loving, and being proud of ourselves without a god.
• Seeing that she is mentally and emotionally much stronger after deconversion, compared to her time as a Christian.

Many thanks to Ashley for sharing her story and insights!

episodes.title: We're better in every way now than we ever could have been as Christians - Lars & Christie Cade
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Lars and Christie Cade, who believed in Jesus early in life, grew up in an evangelical Christian environment, and married as committed Christians, but ultimately both deconverted as they realized that the claims of the Bible and Christianity were false.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Growing up with parents who were full-time missionaries (Lars).
• Being taught about Dispensationalism, the rapture, and the end times.
• Seeing Catholics and other Christian denominations as not being "true Christians" or "the right kind of Christians."
• Being taught about women needing to be silent in church and wear head coverings "because of the angels" and the Watchers in the Enoch story.
• Believing that they were sinners, that Jesus was god's son and had lived a perfect life, that he died and rose again in our place, and that faith in Jesus as our substitute would give us peace with god.
• Believing in the literal fires and torture of hell.
• How the eternal nature of heaven was unappealing due to the expectation of boredom.
• How fundamentalism suppresses empathy, as we are taught to agree with the Yahweh character that people deserve unending torture in hell for their sin.
• Eventually seeing the repeated injustices done by the Yahweh character.
• Being deeply involved in the AWANA program.
• Struggling to figure out the will of god.
• Feeling like she was disappointing to god (Christie)
• Seeing god as capricious, unjust, and boastful through the book of Job.
• Feeling like god was always "out to get" him (Lars).
• The arrogance and even colonialism that comes out in certain aspects of Christianity, especially in the context of overseas missionary work.
• How science and evolution were like a "bomb" against their Christian worldview.
• Seeing that the more they did things for themselves, instead of acting "in faith," the more things turned out better.
• How people who are deconverting realize that they hadn't been taught a huge amount of information about topics they should already understand but were sheltered from in the church, and how that realization leads to "rage learning."
• Trying to make themselves believe even when as they were starting to deconvert.
• Admitting severe disappointment in seeing that "the best" that Christian apologists have to offer is still very unconvincing and is often mixed with huge amounts of arrogance.
• Realizing the bizarreness of the concept of blood atonement.
• How Young Earth Creationism is hopelessly naive about both the Bible and science.
• Learning to grieve a loved one's death properly, knowing we will not see them again.
• Feeling free to truly be themselves after deconversion.
• Partaking of pleasure without feeling guilt.
• Facing the stigma of calling themselves "atheists."
• Realizing that Christians have not been taught well how to critically evaluate ideas and claims.
• How knowledge beats faith every time.
• Being better in every way as atheists than they ever could have been as Christians.
• Acknowledging that life lived in reality is so much better.
• Seeing that Christianity promises "the way, the truth and the life" but delivers none of those things.

Many thanks to Lars and Christie for sharing their story!

episodes.title: Christ Church Rampant: Where Patriarchy, Grooming, Gaslighting, and Shunning Thrive - Abra Miller
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Abra Miller, who spent many years in the Christ Church cult in Moscow, Idaho, under Doug Wilson, but ultimately escaped.

As we talked through her story, we touched on topics such as:

• The arrogance and pride of the Christ Church leadership and culture, especially with the backdrop of ultra-Calvinism and extreme Patriarchy.
• How women are treated like property and are often expected to vote the way their husband does.
• How women are tested by their husbands in order to check their level of happy submission.
• As a woman, being infantilized and deprived of autonomy on almost all levels.
• How women who are being abused in the Christ Church cult are encouraged to never say "No" to their husbands regarding sex.
• How the Christ Church leadership takes on counseling situations that they are extremely unqualified to address.
• How marital rape is normalized and acceptable in that culture.
• How consent is not really taught in the Christ church culture, and how it adds up to grooming for those who grow up in it.
• How the Christ Church leadership gaslights their own congregation and shares private information publicly without consent.
• How complementarian marriages end up empowering men over women and gives a much stronger voice to men over women.
• How the Christ Church culture leads to sexual assaults, and how victims are urged to quickly forgive instead of holding the perpetrator accountable.
• The extreme lack of boundaries in the Christ Church culture.
• How church members who don't fall in line with the authority of Christ Church leadership end up being either attacked or severely shunned by church leaders and members.
• The importance of thinking critically, and for yourself, instead of being committed only to what your current community teaches.

Many thanks to Abra for sharing her story and helping others escape and heal from the abuse of the Christ Church cult.
