episodes.title: After 25 years as an evangelical pastor, I realized that Christianity is fiction - Bruce Gerencser
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Bruce Gerencser, who pastored mostly Baptist churches for 25 years until he realized that Christianity is mythology and fiction, and deconverted.

We discussed many topics including:

• Attending Independent Fundamental Baptist (IFB) Churches, starting with Tim LaHaye's church (of the "Left Behind" book series).
• Feeling close to god as he grew up.
• Saying the sinner's prayer at age 5 but rededicating his life as a teenager during a revival service and sharing with his church that he felt called to be a preacher.
• Attending an IFB College to prepare for the ministry.
• Hearing endless sermons about the need to fight against worldliness and sinfulness.
• Thinking that god was leading and directing personally in his life.
• Eventually realizing that the Bible is not inerrant or infallible, and that the Bible is full of errors and contradictions.
• Realizing that Christianity is just mythology, and deconverting.
• Sensing overwhelming peace upon deconversion.
• Observing Christians frequently ostracize and act hateful toward deconverted Christians.

Thanks to Bruce for sharing his story and for his many contributions to the community!

episodes.title: The still, small voice ... was MINE - Belle Clark
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Belle Clark, who placed her faith in Jesus as a teenager, but eventually deconverted as she realized that the Christian worldview no longer made sense.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Being drawn to the motif of Yahweh being a caring Father figure who cared about and loved her.
• Being taught by the church that she was sinful, wicked, and in desperate need of saving, but that Jesus could wash away her sins and forgive her.
• Being exposed to Baptist theology, including King James Only-ism.
• As a woman, being told in church that she needed to submit and be subservient to men.
• Believing that it was her primary mission to save others from the horrors of hell and feeling guilty for "not doing enough" to save those who died without Christ.
• Telling others that being a Christian is not about a religion, but about a personal and loving relationship with Jesus.
• Being taught that doing good works was not to earn favor with the Yahweh character, but to express gratitude to him for salvation.
• Delighting to study and memorize large chunks of the Bible.
• Being told, upon deconverting, that she never had a real relationship with Jesus.
• How deconversion was full of guilt and sadness as she went through the process of reclaiming her identity while at the same time getting extensive backlash from Christians.
• Seeing Christians patronize and gaslight her after her deconversion, insisting she was mistaken and predicting that she would come back to Jesus someday.
• The feeling of slowly losing her faith, despite trying to hold on to it.
• How moving into her own home, away from dysfunction, created a place of emotional and mental safety where she could re-evaluate her worldview, without any external factors pushing her in certain directions, and leaving her with the freedom to figure how who she really wanted to be and what she really believed.
• Hearing her own voice and intuition instead of trying to hear supposed voice or leading of the Yahweh and Jesus characters.
• How the increase in information, combined with the removal of fear, provided a context for an increase in rethinking her worldview and being a more critical thinking.
• Learning to get comfortable with contradicting the Bible and admitting its problems.
Starting to question the Yahweh/god character, including his supposed goodness.
• Being strongly encouraged in Christian purity culture, including ultra-modest clothing in order to not be a stumbling block or cause men to be tempted.
• How losing her virginity, in the context of purity culture, was traumatizing, and led to feelings of shame and guilt.
• The danger of suppressing your sexuality and the desire for pleasure and connection.
• How professional therapy has helped toward healing the religious trauma she endured.
• The critical importance of empowering ourselves and reclaiming and owning our thought autonomy.
• Acknowledging how hard it is, after deconversion, to shake off the guilt and shame that was so deeply ingrained in us as Christians.
Celebrating her "apostate anniversary" when she escaped Christianity.
• How Christianity sets up the paradigm that Yahweh will crush you, if necessary, to bring you back to him, and how painful and terrifying situations life led her to wonder if that situation was his way of trying to hurt her as a way of pursuing her.
• Being free to craft her own identity and to have the ultimate say over what your beliefs should be and who you need to be.
• The importance of being kind to yourself and those around you instead of violent and cruel like the Yahweh character is portrayed to be.
• The freedom of losing the afterlife, with the removal of the pressure to think like religious institutions dictate, and instead to live in a way that genuinely reflects our identity and values.
• Seeing life become much more precious.
The tragic perspective Christians have of wishing for the end of their lives so they can see Jesus.
• How learning more about evolution helped her deconversion move forward and pushed her to get more information and credible research.
• The importance of allowing yourself to experience emotions, like anger, that we were taught to suppress during our time in Christianity.

Many thanks to Belle for sharing her story!

_______________________________

https://pulpitpiece.blog/

episodes.title: I recognized Christian beliefs are toxic, then I realized it's just mythology - Christa
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Christa, who grew up in a non-denominational Christian church, but eventually deconverted as she saw the toxic beliefs and the mythology that it's based on.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Placing her faith in Jesus as a young child and then rededicating her life to Christ repeatedly to be sure it was genuine.
• How children who grow up in a Christian home are effectively taught to think that "god is speaking to you," when it's actually just their own thoughts and emotions.
• Being taught that Catholics weren't really Christians or saved, due to the religious differences, and effectively being taught to see Catholics as having a stigma.
• How religious superstition and magic thinking come out in the way Christians talk about symbolism, healings, prophecy.
• Being effectively taught that if something good happened in life, it was from Yahweh, and if something bad happened in life, it was from Satan.
• Believing that if you wanted something that wasn't happening, you needed to keep praying more and harder.
• Being instilled with a white nationalist perspective on history, during homeschooling.
• Being overly sheltered from anything "worldly."
• Being heavily indoctrinated into Christian fundamentalism.
• How Christians feel under attack all the time because they cannot handle their kids being exposed to the truth.
• Being raised to believe that there were angels and demons all around her at all times, so much that her mind tricked her into thinking she could see demons on the walls and ceiling of her home, but eventually realizing that it was just her imagination.
• How the mythology of Christianity instills messages of sin and shame in people and sets them up for lifelong guilt and sadness.
• How Christianity labels many childlike behaviors as "sins."
• Being labelled as "rebellious" for simply questioning the narrative, especially as a woman.
• How neurobehavioral disorders, such as ADHD, were not really considered acceptable diagnoses for Christians to consider.
• Being taught that you don't need medicine or counseling -- you just need Jesus and a better understanding the Gospel and your identity in Christ, or to "give it to god" in some way.
• The message to young girls to stay away from boys because "they only want one thing."
• Being taught to not "lust after your brothers in Christ" and to "protect their eyes and minds" by dressing modestly.
• Seeing homosexual people being shunned by the church.
• How Christianity conditions people to see their sexuality as bad, dirty, and deviant, and the ways that this dynamic even affects causes immense issues and suffering for married people.
• Never being encouraged to pursue a career or outside job because it was assumed that Christian women should only want to be a stay-at-home-mom.
• How fundamentalist Christianity indoctrinates women into patriarchy so intensely that women will actually fight for patriarchy and will tear down women who espouse feminism.
• The toxic mix of young people being told that they are sinful, that their bodily desires are sinful, to not do anything sexual, and at the same time teaching women that they are inherently stumbling blocks to the men.
• How Christianity encourages you to distance yourself from people who are not "godly."
• How cults use insidious tactics to invite, manipulate, isolate, and control their congregations, starting with love bombing.
• Realizing, through comparative mythology, that the Jesus character is not unique among the many dying and rising gods that have been invented throughout history.
• Realizing that the Yahweh character was once the husband of the goddess Asherah, and earlier, was the son of Elyon, but that the story has evolved repeatedly, in large part to counter the women's spiritual and cultural power.
• Understanding that our minds can "make" things seem true to us, even if they are not, especially if we are preconditioned and indoctrinated in that direction.
• Realizing, after deconversion, that every time you were praying, you were actually just conferring with yourself.
• How deconversion frees you to be the most authentic and best version of yourself possible, once you are free from a mythological worldview.

Thanks to Christa for sharing her story!

episodes.title: Christ Church Rampant: How I survived the grooming & abuse of Doug Wilson's cult - Lorena Hieronymus
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Lorena Hieronymus, who grew up in the Christ Church cult in Moscow, Idaho, under Doug Wilson, but ultimately escaped from that group, as well as the broader cult of Christianity.

We touched on many topics including:

• How the Christ Church cult aims to take over Moscow, Idaho, and beyond, for their particular brand of Christianity.
• Seeing racism woven into the Christ Church culture through being taught that blackness is the "mark of Cain," that slavery was a good thing for many slaves, and that white men are in charge.
• The dynamic that once you join Christ Church, it's almost impossible to get out of the cult.
• The stigma against anyone who is not part of the Christ Church, even if you are a Christian.
• How women in this ultra-misogynistic patriarchal cult are groomed to believe that they should be silent, disempowered domestic servants who are subservient to male leadership.
• How Christ Church, and especially Doug Wilson, uses fear as a tactic to brainwash the congregation, especially women.
• Being taught as a woman that you should never turn down your husband sexually and that there is no such thing as marital rape because your body belongs to him.
• How the Christ Church cult takes away autonomy of body and thought.
• How people in Christ Church don't seem to seriously question Doug Wilson, despite endless red flags.
• The danger of having structures of leadership and submission that protect the power of men at the expense of women, especially in cases of abuse.
• Being taught that a woman's body is inherently a stumbling block that causes men to sin.
• Being brainwashed to believe that you are worthless and worthy of shame.
• How women are treated as property in the Christ Church community, and how a woman gets passed from her father to her husband when she gets married, always remaining under the authority of the head of the household.
• Being taught that what matters is not your happiness, but your obedience -- to the Yahweh and Jesus characters, to the church elders, and to your father or husband.
• How Doug Wilson intentionally uses nasty, hateful language to trigger those who disagree with him, in order to instill shame and fear in people, especially liberal Christians, feminists, and the LGBTQ community.
• How people in Christ Church are shunned and excommunicated if they go against the church authority or culture.
• How men strongly benefit from the ultra-patriarchal system of a cult like Christ Church.
• Dealing with trauma from growing up in the Christ Church cult, and Christianity in general, but eventually reclaiming her identity, healing, and becoming an advocate for abuse victims.
• After deconversion, getting over the fear of hell, moving past the feelings of worthlessness, learning to be truly happy, and choosing the path that she wanted, not one that was dictated to her.
• Realizing, during deconstruction, that the New Testament heavily copies from the book of Enoch, many other intertestamental books, and the works of Homer.
• Admitting that the Yahweh character is portrayed in the Bible as a severely abusive narcissist.
• Choosing the path of courageously speaking up against abuse.
• Giving the next generation the gift of autonomy, of both their body and of their thought life and worldview.
• Forgiving Christians for the trauma they have inflicted on us, and thriving despite how much they and their mythology have hurt and continue to hurt us and our society.

Thanks to Lorena for sharing her story and helping others escape and heal from the abuse of the Christ Church cult and from Christianity.

episodes.title: I’m a better and happier person because of my departure from Christianity - Kyle Butler
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Kyle Butler, who grew up in a Christian home and became a pastor for 16 years before critically examining the claims of Christianity, and ultimately deconverting.

As we talked through his story, we touched on topics like:

• Feeling the sense of urgency as he reached the age of 13, the age of accountability, to get right with god.
• Repeatedly questioning his salvation because he struggled with sin and wondered if he was just temporarily struggling or not actually saved.
• How Lordship Salvation teachings ruined his life.
• Why the church is so afraid to scrutinize its narratives and to admit they are wrong and don't work.
• Admitting that the Gospel is powerless to change lives.
• Hearing people give him prophecies from god about his life and about god's will for him.
• The sense that he had to obey god's will, or god would force him to obey through humbling hardships -- and the consequences could be very painful.
• The bizarre cognitive dissonance in Christianity of a god who hurts and tortures his children and is yet called a loving and good father.
• The Christian dynamic of having people become teachers even when they don't understand the background of the Bible they are teaching.
• How the endless versions and varieties of Christianity and the resulting confusion and lack of consensus lead to wondering why that deity would be so confusing, if he were real.
• Believing that god was the head of our lives, that our lives were in his hands, that he was in control, and that we need to follow his plan and fully trust him, and that he cannot fail.
• How Christianity demands an obsessive, consuming love for Yahweh, Jesus, and the Biblical worldview.
• How Christianity is debilitating and punishing to believers, on many levels.
• How Christianity is ultimately revealed to be merely another tool to scare, control, and manipulate people.
• The message that the divine presence is constantly watching and judging you and can even see your thoughts and intentions.
• Realizing that the concept of a loving god cannot be reconciled with the teaching about eternal conscious torment.
• How we, when we were Christians, would gaslight ourselves constantly into thinking everything was our fault -- not the fault of god or the Christian machine.
• The bizarre Judeo-Christian narrative that the shedding of blood is required for forgiveness to occur, that it pleased god the father to torture his son Jesus, and that he ultimately needs to torture and kill someone -- either Jesus or sinners -- to be appeased.
• How the Lord's Table / Communion is a form of cannibalism, where we symbolically eat the flesh and drink the blood of a dead man.
• The importance of not indoctrinating the next generation into religion.
• Realizing that every religion has a god or gods, and every religion has a book, and that religion thus nothing more than a man-made structure where everyone is claiming to have the truth.
• How religion steals the precious time we have in life.
• Finding that you are a better, much happier person after we move on from Christianity.
• Being able, after our deconversion, to respect people and treat them with much more dignity than ever could when we were Christians.

Many thanks to Kyle for sharing his story!

_________________________________________

episodes.title: Seeking the truth is what led me out of Christianity - Stacie Grahn
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Stacie Grahn, who grew up in a charismatic Christian environment, shifted toward a more Reformed/Calvinistic version of Christianity in adulthood, but eventually deconverted after taking a hard look at the bizarreness of the claims of Christianity.

As we walked through her story, we touched on topics such as:

• Re-dedicating her life to Jesus several times to be sure that she was really saved.
• The pressure to continually see greater and greater things from the Lord.
• Experiencing prophetic dreams where she felt god was speaking to her.
• Letting emotions drive your thinking as a Christian.
• How it was considered sinful to even entertain the idea of god not being real.
• Believing that angels and demons were fighting all around her in the unseen realm and that there were territorial spirits inhabiting certain locations that Christians should avoid or pray against.
• The ways that church worship is designed to manipulate the congregation by evoking intense emotions and appealing to people's hurts and disappointments.
• Being terrified as a child thinking about hell and the Devil.
• Believing in the Rapture, where Jesus comes to take believers to heaven before the Tribulation, but also recognizing, even as a Christian, that it all sounded really weird.
• Constantly trying to figure out what spiritual door she opened to let demonic activity occur in her life.
• The dynamic that the people who were more deeply committed to Jesus, the Gospel, and the Kingdom are more "fully done" with religion when they escape Christianity.
• The ways that Christianity suppresses sexual pleasure and eroticism for unmarried people to such an extent that once they finally get married, it's often very difficult to flip the switch and start enjoying it.
• Getting pulled into Calvinism as a theological foundation and worldview and seeing the arrogance it evokes in its followers.
• Feeling like the rug has been pulled from under your feet when you start deconstructing.
• Making the decision to always let yourself ask the hard questions going forward.
• How the ludicrous Christian behavior and attitudes toward Covid, Trump, and Church abuses help us escape and realize the intense "cringe factor" of Christianity.
• Upon deconverting, feeling like you have seen life for the first time -- like you were truly born again (again).
• Finding that you are happier than you've ever been, after deconversion.
• The freedom that comes from realizing that sin is not a thing, and that it's instead just a made-up construct and fear tactic to keep people mentally enslaved to institutionalized mythology.
• Begin told by Christians, after we deconvert, that we have turned to evil and are mocking god.

Many thanks to Stacie for sharing her story and insights!

episodes.title: The closer you look at Christianity, the less it makes sense - Scott Staples
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Scott Staples, who grew up as a pastor's kid, went to Bible college and seminary, and worked extensively in missions, but eventually deconverted as the claims of Christianity made less and less sense.

As we walked through his story, we touched on topics such as:

• Recommitting his life to Jesus to ensure that he was acknowledging that Jesus is both Savior and Lord (Master).
• Doing missions via YWAM (Youth With a Mission) through their Discipleship Training School (DTS).
• Sharing the Gospel and "bringing others to Christ."
• Being taught that we are all born sinners, separated from god from birth, damaged, and on our way to hell if we don't "get saved."
• Hearing the Christian message that Jesus died on the cross to take our punishment and to cover our sins in order to make a way for us to go to heaven.
• Feeling called by god to be a pastor and seeing family respond by saying that they already knew he would have that calling.
• Thinking that the reason he was not hearing from god was because of a problem with himself.
• Observing people pick and choose which verses they did and did not want to take seriously and apply to their own lives.
• Seeing life events that didn't add up to the idea that god was in control.
• Feeling like the closer he got to the god character, the more that god appeared to be hurting him.
• Grappling with the immense suffering in the world in light of his understanding of the goodness, love, omnipotence, and omniscience of the god character in the Bible.
• How Christians develop theological constructs to try to pretend that Christianity makes sense, but the closer you look at its claims and details, the less it makes any coherent sense at all.
• Healing from religious trauma, especially from the idea that our extreme wickedness was the direct reason Jesus had to be tortured and killed.
• Learning how to grieve death healthily and fully after realizing that there is no afterlife and that we will not see our loved ones again who have already died.

Thanks to Scott for sharing his amazing story!

episodes.title: There's no power in the Gospel - Samantha Cadieux
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Samantha Cadieux, who grew up exposed to Catholicism and converted to Evangelical Christianity as an adult before ultimately deconverting entirely from all forms of Christianity.

As we talked through her story, we discussed topics such as:

• Going to Catholic school, doing the sacraments, going through the "stations of the cross," experiencing first communion, and being confirmed.
• Feeling traumatized as a child by images of Jesus and the saints suffering.
• Feeling that she needed something to fill life's emptiness, and thinking she'd found the answer in Jesus and the Gospel.
• Wanting to have a sense of belonging, and then thinking she had found it via the church community.
• Committing her life to Christ repeatedly.
• Slowly admitting that the Gospel doesn't make any sense and that blood sacrifice doesn't have any power.
• Facing the reality of the Bible's teachings about the fate of those who have never heard the Gospel, and the bizarreness and insanity of the doctrine of eternal conscious torment.
• Understanding that original sin is not real and is an exceptionally harmful teaching.
• The experience of being "born again, again" when she deconverted.
• The importance of getting professional help when dealing with childhood traumas.

Many thanks to Samantha to sharing her story with us!

episodes.title: It's okay to ask the really hard questions - Phil Drysdale
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Phil Drysdale, who grew up as a pastor's kid and was focused on ministry before he began deconstructing his faith and ultimately started The Deconstruction Network to help others going through the same thing.

As we talked through his story, we discussed:

• Hearing altar calls as a teenager and repeatedly giving our lives to the Jesus character as a way to prove our faith.
• Taking to an extreme the injunction to "give everything to the poor."
• Being passionately consumed with the Jesus character and the Bible.
• Realizing as Christians that we're part of a huge system that does widespread and lasting harm on a very serious level.
• Defending everything the Yahweh character decreed, including eternal conscious torment, because we saw Yahweh as the King and Judge, and believed that everything he did was right.
• How people who deconstruct often hold their new stance with more humility and less certainty.
• How people who deconstruct lose much of their community quickly when they lose and leave their faith.
• Seeing from recent polls that over a million people each year are leaving Christianity in America and understanding that many of them will be facing a lonely road as a result of losing their prior worldview and community.
• The huge need for deconstructing people, who are extremely vulnerable at that point, to have a safe place to talk and explore their questions.
• The importance of empowering deconstructing people to discover their own autonomy and path, versus trying to just give them our answers.
• The dynamic that many who leave their faith often later embrace some kind of spirituality.

Many thanks to Phil for sharing his amazing story and for all that he does the community every day!

episodes.title: I feel free for the first time in my life - Layne Yancey
episodes.description:
T/W: Sexual assault content
______________________________________
Today I spoke with Layne Yancey, who grew up in an extremely legalistic, fundamentalist Baptist church, but eventually deconverted as she did a deep dive into both current Christianity as well as its origins.

We touched on many topics, including:

• The influence of the IBLP (Institute for Basic Life Principles) on her family.
• How Christianity preys on parents' fears for their children's welfare and sexual purity.
• How the church controls congregants' lives.
• Being overwhelmed nonstop with messages of the Gospel and purity culture, in the larger context of being extremely sheltered.
• How "I Kissed Dating Goodbye" by Joshua Harris negatively affected her mentality toward herself and her sexuality.
• How purity culture teaches you to suppress all of your sexual thoughts and desires, and to feel shame if you think or do anything sexual.
• How the church often ignores social justice issues.
• Being told that everyone who was not a Christian was a sinner bound for hell.
• Sensing that the Devil was constantly trying to influence and tempt her away from the Yahweh character.
• How people's identities get wrapped up in their purity, and once they lose it or have it taken from them, they feel like they have lost their identity.
• Being traumatized from the "AWANA" children's church group.
• Being taught that she was born wicked, and how that idea implanted in her worldview.
• Being taught to not trust oneself, but to instead only trust the Yahweh character.
• Realizing, after deconversion, that she had been living in a mental prison her whole life.
• Dealing with the anger of how the Christian worldview "stole" our younger years.
• Healing from spiritual abuse, especially how we were taught to hate ourselves, during our time in Christianity.
• Seeing the dark side of church and realizing how cultish it is, and ultimately concluding that Christianity as a whole is a cult.

Many thanks to Layne for sharing her story and heart with us today!

episodes.title: When god had a wife - Ed Dodge
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Ed Dodge, author of "A History of the Goddess from the Ice Age to the Bible."

As we talked through his story and his book, we discussed many topics, including:

• Growing up in a liberal Christian context where rationality was strongly emphasized.
• Realizing that the picture of the divine godhead of Judaism and Christianity is missing a mother figure, and that she was originally there but was later removed from the narratives and traditions.
• How cannabis was sacred to the ancient goddess traditions, and how goddess theology in Judaism died out as religious cannabis use died out.
• How comparative mythology helps us see that Judaism and Christianity are nothing more than mythologies, and how that knowledge helps us escape our religious indoctrination.
• The bizarreness of the Yahweh character preferring to kill his own Son than to kill the Devil.
• How the Yahweh character, if he were real, would have been setting up humanity to fail by making sex so pleasurable and then putting major restrictions on how we pursue it.
• That all the gods we have invented, including Yahweh and Jesus, are projections of the human mind.
• How early religions connected the idea of heaven with the Father figure and the earth with the Mother figure.
• Realizing that the ancient Jewish people were polytheists in the Bronze Age, with a father god El, a mother goddess Asherah, and "children" demigods such as Ba'al, long before they eventually became monotheists as they invented Yahweh and claimed he had become the high god, and eventually, the only god.
• The origins of patriarchal religion and the start of the demise of goddess worship in Israel.
• The importance of admitting that we only have the patriarchal versions and redactions of many historical events, which frequently do not reflect historical reality.
• How religions pursue and require conformity and centralized authority.

Thanks to Ed for his amazing work and for sharing his story with us today!

episodes.title: The Church has a huge problem with abuse, and this needs to change - Julie Anne Smith
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Julie Anne Smith, an investigative blogger covering high-profile clergy sexual misconduct cases.

As we walked through her story and her investigative reporting journey, we touched on many topics, including:

• The negative impact of the Christian homeschool movement, where ideologies of patriarchy, courtship, purity culture, and "quiverfull" (having as many kids as possible) were pervasive and pushed hard among leaders and families.
• Being told by Protestants, while she was a Catholic earlier in life, that she was going to hell because she was not truly saved.
• Feeling guilty, in light of the Quiverfull movement, at carefully planning the timing each pregnancy, as it's viewed as not fully trusting god for the timing of pregnancies and large quantity of kids that he wants to bestow.
• How the reconstructionist Christian perspective aims to take over the US and the world, in order to establish a theocracy.
• How the Reconstructionist, Theonomic, and Patriarchal movements critically depend on daughters being raised to believe in and agree to its fundamentalist philosophies, in order to "outbreed the pagans" so they can "outvote the pagans" and take over the culture.
• How the cult of Christchurch in Moscow, Idaho, run by Doug Wilson, is trying to take over their town and the nation with their version of Christianity.
• How churches have failed women on multiple fronts.
• How the worldview of Calvinism creates harshness, rudeness, and pride in its adherents, leading to many Calvinists embracing an extremely hateful and snarky tone, and leading them to act like they think they are right about everything.
• How pastors in fundamentalist churches tend to end up on power trips, where their opinion is "the final word."
• The experience of church members shunning you when you leave the church.
• How purity culture leads to extreme legalism where you tend to constantly judge others for what they are wearing or how much skin they are showing.
• How Bill Gothard and the IBLP group shamed and blamed women, treated them as inherently temptresses, and taught that women are the "deceived" gender (1 Timothy 2:14).
• How ancient Judaism was steeped in the theology that women were bad and seductive because in the mythology of creation Eve invited Adam to sin.
• How women in patriarchal churches are required to quietly submit to their husband's leadership and not challenge his authority.
• How patriarchal pastors demonstrate hatred and contempt for women.
• How churches, and even journalists, focus their attention and stories on abusers and perpetrators instead of the victims and on how to protect them.
• How church leadership typically assumes that people who claim to have been abused by church leaders are probably not telling the truth, in order to protect church leadership and "maintain the peace" of the church, and how the church then often switches the narrative to blame the victims.
• Learning to see red flags and patterns in relationships and spiritual environments in order to have healthy boundaries.
• The importance of getting re-grounded in a new community and experiencing the full range of emotions as you grieve and make healthy choices after escaping from abusive situations.
• How pastors often prioritize the institution of marriage over the individuals in the marriage, and end up advising people to not divorce, even when marriages are extremely toxic and people are in harm's way.

Many thanks for Julie Anne for sharing her story and insights!

episodes.title: What if the real reason god seems so silent is that he's simply not there? - Untestimony
episodes.description:
**Apologies for the audio issues at the beginning; they die down pretty quickly.

Today I spoke with Untestimony, who grew up as a pastor's kid in a non-denominational evangelical church, but eventually deconverted after she dug deep into the claims and origins of Christianity.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Seeing life as a "rescue operation" where we are first rescued by Jesus and then we, in turn, help rescue others through the Gospel of Jesus' death and resurrection on our behalf.
• Being taught that non-Christian scientists were not correct purely because of their bias and blinders, and then during deconversion realizing that it's Christianity that is pushing the bias and blinders.
• Growing up believing that babies were born with a sin nature and that they deserved death.
• The importance of asking hard questions about your beliefs and worldview.
• Feeling like a wolf in sheep's clothing during the early stages of deconversion, because Christianity teaches that those who walk away are willfully "walking away from god," even though all you're doing is seeking truth more than ever.
• Feeling abandoned by god when you are asking for answers and consequently trying to seek him more than ever during the initial stages of deconversion.
• How Christians ask for a high standard of evidence for other religions, but then accept an absurdly low standard of evidence for their own.
• Begin horrified, on this side of deconversion, at what we used to believe and that we accepted crazy ideas simply because our authority figure at that time told us to.
• Growing up thinking that you cannot question the Yahweh character because his ways are far above ours and that we do not understand the true horrors of sin or the splendors of his holiness.
• Realizing that when we were reading the Bible, we weren't reading a book from a god, but a collection of horrific ideas by fallible men describing the literary and cultural evolution of the psychopathic Yahweh demigod character.
• Realizing that Judaism and Christianity are based on and heavily borrowing from what we, as Christians, would have called "pagan religions" and mythology.
• The Christian cultural impression that "women want love, and men want respect and sex," and the corollary ideas that women are less sexually interested than men and that men are sexually out of control, so a Christian wife's responsibility is to keep her man satisfied to keep him from being tempted, and if he strays, it's her fault.
• After deconversion, regretting not exploring our own sexuality earlier due to purity culture.
• How shame culture leads people to hate themselves and even to harm their own bodies as a result of feeling like a failure due to thinking about sexuality too much and not being focused on Jesus enough.
• The ironic ways that modesty culture will sexually charges Christians as they try to balance a pious façade with repressed sexual pressure.
• How church worship music manipulates congregants by making people feel emotionally connected to the Yahweh character.
• Acknowledging that Christian missionary work is a form of Western colonization.
• How the Christian worldview exudes extreme arrogance as it effectively tells all other worldviews and cultural perspectives to "shut up and listen to us, since we have the truth and you don't."
• Begin horrified at the Old Testament atrocities, such as genocide, child brides, slavery, stoning, etc.
• Feeling like when you are most needing god to show up, there is complete radio silence, and realizing that there is ultimately no difference between a god who does not communicate and a god who does not exist.
• Going through the stages of grief after deconversion.
• Dealing with the shock of the nastiness and snark of Christians after you deconvert and as you see them treating you like a traitor for leaving Christianity.
• Experiencing much more peace after deconversion than we ever had as Christians.

Many thanks to Untestimony for sharing her story today!

episodes.title: I didn't leave the faith ... the faith left me - Kamron Bennett
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Kamron Bennett, who grew up in the Seventh Day Adventist Church, but eventually deconverted after he realized that the claims of the Bible don't add up, that the Yahweh character is psychotic, and that Christianity is mythology.

As we talked through his story, we discussed many topics, including:

• Dealing with tragedy early in life when his older sister died suddenly at age 14 and wrestling with theological issues as people told him that it was God's will that she died.
• Going through a bad depression and preferring to die and be annihilated because he was upset at god.
• Attending a secular university and seeing one of his best friends die during his freshman year.
• Getting serious again about god and wanting to become a Bible scholar.
• The uniquenesses of the Seventh Day Adventist Church, especially regarding the Sabbath, Annihilation, and the teachings of Prophetess Ellen G. White.
• Analyzing Christianity using the outsider test for faith, and realizing that Christianity, just like other religions, evolved out of other earlier religious beliefs and how Christian apologists try in vain to explain away its truly horrific teachings.
• Being surprised that there weren't better answers to his questions than he could find from pastors and theologians.
• Seeing that the morality of the Yahweh character vacillates wildly throughout the Bible.
• Feeling like he didn't leave the faith, but, instead, that the faith left him.
• Going through the experience of "sinking in the quicksand of disbelief."
• Realizing that childhood indoctrination into Christianity is a form of psychological child abuse.
• Seeing the Adam and Eve characters in Genesis as being "framed" by the Yahweh character.
• Concluding that Christianity is just institutionalized bronze-age mythology.
• The beauty and joy of living without a mythological worldview.

Many thanks to Kamron for sharing his amazing story and insights!

episodes.title: When you realize the Gospels are mythology based on Greek epics - Dr. Dennis MacDonald
episodes.description:
**Apologies for the video/audio being slightly out of sync in places.

Today I spoke with Dr. Dennis MacDonald, who has done groundbreaking work demonstrating that the Gospels and Acts are imitating and rewriting Greek and Roman epics such as Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, Euripides' Bacchae, and Virgil's Aeneid, among others.

We discussed many topics, including:
• How people in the ancient world would often write stories that compared their superheroes using extraordinary tales, like having supernatural births, walking on water, flying, turning water into wine, clearing bad men out of their house, keeping their identity secret at times, visiting the land of the dead, possessing incredible powers of healing, has feasts for thousands, dying because their god has abandoned them, rising from the dead, and living forever, etc.
• Acknowledging that Christianity is an elaborate and toxic "con".
• How Christianity is psychologically abusive to children.
• Seeing Christianity is about separating the in-group versus the out-group, and then pushing the polarization and demonizing the outsider.
• How Christians refuse to admit many inconvenient truths that undermine the claims of their worldview.
• How to talk -- or not talk -- to Christians who refuse to acknowledge the origins of their religion.
• And many more topics.


Many thanks for Dr. MacDonald for sharing his story today.  I look forward to diving into more of his work and talking with him again.

_________________________________________

episodes.title: I deconstructed my indoctrination - Kendal Brenneman
episodes.description:
Note: we did a long intro/bio; the actual interview starts at minute 15.  Also, apologies for the audio issues on my side.

_________________________________________

Today I spoke with actress Kendal Brenneman, who grew up in a non-denominational church and eventually would have described herself as a Christian "Jesus freak," but eventually thought deeply about the claims of Christianity, and eventually deconverted.

We discussed many topics, including:

• Being heavily influenced by purity and virginity culture.
• How Christianity is much more "pagan" than we were ever told when we were in the church.
• Realizing that there many other books that could have been in the canon -- and in some cases, were in the canon but got removed later.
• How people who deconvert are often just trying to learn more about Christianity, in order to strengthen their faith, but in the process they start to learn information that causes their Christian worldview to unravel.
• Being more committed to the truth than to our religion, tradition, or preference.
• Wrestling with the disturbing reality that Christian indoctrination is psychological child abuse.
• Finding better, more honest answers outside the Church and the Bible than we ever found inside them.
• Realizing that Christianity is mythology.


Many thanks to Kendal for sharing her story!

episodes.title: At the intersection of science and religion, I take a skeptical view - Aaron Adair
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Dr. Aaron Adair, a physics professor, data scientist, and author of the book "The Star of Bethlehem: A Skeptical View."

We discussed his religious background and several other topics, including:

• Growing up exposed to cultural Catholicism but having a Deist outlook early in life.
• Realizing that the scientific and skeptical approach to life is much better than a mythological worldview.
• The ways that humans are good at seeing patterns, even to the point of making up patterns even when the pattern isn't really there.
• How the Yahweh character is not presented in the Bible as pro-life regarding babies, but very much pro-death.
• Options for where the story of the Bethlehem star, at Jesus' birth, might have originated.
• How Matthew takes stories from Mark and makes them even more implausible.
• How astromythology was woven into the Bible.

Thanks to Dr. Adair for his great insights!

episodes.title: Christianity is nothing more than propaganda, marketing, and gaslighting - Brady Hardin
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Brady Hardin, the host of The Life After podcast.  We touched on his story, and then had a lively discussion on several topics, including:

• Committing as a teenager to full-time ministry while simultaneously repressing homosexuality and trying to "pray the gay away."
• Selling a lot of his possessions to be sold-out to Jesus.
• Realizing the powerlessness of the gospel story and the lack of evidence of some kind of "Holy Spirit" at work to unify Christians.
• Observing how the church frequently "shoots its wounded."
• Wanting to believe but not seeing evidence to confirm that belief.
• Realizing that any version of Christianity is a cult.
• Seeing that Christianity is, in large part, about propaganda, marketing, and gaslighting.
• Realizing that the Yahweh character is a psychopathic narcissist.
• How religion is a form of patriotism, and a tribalistic way of saying, "I'm better than you."
• Sharing the Gospel and doing street preaching and missions trips to get others saved.
• Towing the line, as atheists, between being as graceful as possible, but still firm about how bad the Christian worldview is, and how it is psychologically damaging to children.
• Dealing with the bizarre mental gymnastics Christians try to use to justify believing that their god is loving and yet a god of genocide, land theft, slavery, stoning, etc.
• How the Christian shame culture psychologically buries people alive and creates a double life for many people.
• Understanding spiritual abuse and learning to heal from the overwhelming damage that the Christian worldview creates.

Thanks to Brady for sharing his story and insights with us today, and for all the ways he helps the deconstructing and deconverting communities.

episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Helen Greene, a support group leader at Recovering From Religion, as well as an atheist activist.

As we talked through her story as well as her current work, we discussed topics like:

• Growing up exposed to cultural Catholicism.
• How Recovering From Religion helps support people as they go through seasons of doubt and deconversion.
• The strange time period of deconversion, where you don't know what's true anymore, and when those around you often ostracize you for questioning your religion.
• How deconstruction about religion opens your mind to ask the question, "What else have I been wrong about?"
• Healing from religious trauma after deconversion.
• The importance of fighting against religious worldviews and helping to stop psychological child abuse.
• How the damage done to kids during the indoctrination phase can last a lifetime.
• And much more.

Thanks to Helen for sharing her story, for her work at Recovering From Religion, and for everyone there working around the clock to serve the deconverting community worldwide.

episodes.title: I escaped the mind control and indoctrination of Jehovah's Witnesses - Wendi Renay
episodes.description:
**My apologies for the audio issues on my side.

_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Wendi Renay, who grew up as one of Jehovah's Witnesses, but eventually deconverted and began to help others to escape and heal.

As we talked through her story, we discussed many topics, including:

• Being told to not worry much about your suffering today, because someday in heaven everything will be made right.
• The belief that anyone who is not a JW is considered worldly, and thus any relationship outside the organization is highly frowned upon.
• How higher education is discouraged because the new world is about to start any day.
• How the 8 men of the governing body in New York create rules and interpretations for all JWs.
• The repeated message to believers to not trust their own understanding, but to listen to the governing body's publications.
• Realizing that spirituality and religiosity are completely different things.
• How the JW church, among other Christian denominations, publicly shames people who have committed certain "sins."
• How women are taught that they are responsible for men's sexual thoughts, so modest dress is critical to avoid enticing men.
• Being told by the church that masturbation makes you a selfish person and can lead to health problems.
• How Christians who "messed up" sexually feel like they are cursed, and like they can never truly thrive again as they live with a permanent scarlet letter.
• How JWs, and many other Christian denominations, create fear-based systems of control for believers.
• The ways the JW church disfellowships and shuns those who don't believe or fall in line with church leadership.
• The common Christian teaching to not trust government authorities.
• The idea that demons might be attached to certain objects and people, or that Satanic influence could occur through certain television shows or movies.
• How Christians treat many mental health issues as a lack of faith, instead of a medical issue.
• The importance of listening to your own intuition.
• The beauty of giving yourself permission to explore new ideas and to look at your current worldview with a critical mind.

Thanks to Wendi for her story and for the amazing work she's doing on her channel!

_________________________________________

episodes.title: Mythological worldviews are a DANGER to our world - Scott Burdick
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with artist, novelist, and documentarian Scott Burdick, who created the film "In God We Trust?" and has also reported on events such as the Family Radio "end of the world" events in May 2011 and the Reason Rally in 2012.

As we talked through his story, we discussed many topics, including:

• The extreme cognitive dissonance evidenced in faith communities.
• How Christian apocalypticism leads people to expect the end of the world at any moment and even to set specific dates for the expected return of Jesus and the final judgment.
• The twisted dynamic of Christians disapproving of Isis in the Middle East today, but approving of the same bizarre morality of the Yahweh character and the ancient Israelites as portrayed in the Old Testament.
• The idea that to get otherwise good people to do or approve of horrible actions, you usually need religion.
• How Christians use the rationale of "it was different back then" to excuse things like slavery and child brides, which Yahweh commanded and never abolished.
• The importance of skepticism and the ability to do thorough research that looks at issues from all sides.
• The fascinating irony of fundamentalist believers being skeptical about a great many things in life, but almost not at all about their own religion.
• How religion preys on people who are facing hardships and feeling hopeless.

Many thanks to Scott for his amazing story, documentaries, and other ways he helps people escape mythological worldviews.

episodes.title: Escaping the MIND JOB of Christianity is a very painful journey - Rachel Aschliman
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Rachel Aschliman, who grew up in the Apostolic Christian Church and in Pentecostal denominations, but ultimately deconverted as Christian truth claims progressively fell apart.

As we talked through her story, we discussed many topics, including:

• The ripple effects of the ultra-legalistic Apostolic Christian Church, where men and women sit on separate sides of the church and elders have immense power over the congregation.
• Seeing some Christians advise against doctors and medicine, and instead encourage believers to wait on the Yahweh character for healing.
• As an 11 year old, dealing with earlier sexual abuse and wanting to die, but accepting the Jesus character as her Savior to take away her sin and the mental anguish of loathing herself.
• Growing up "pleading the blood of Jesus" for protection.
• Feeling the pressure to "fulfill the calling" from the Yahweh character to be a wife and mother, and to have a large family.
• The scary dynamic of recognizing that the world was full of demonic activity, and that demons could be overwhelmingly deceptive.
• The experience, as a Christian, of having no joy for decades, and how that experience betrays the reality that the Gospel has no power.
• Dealing with thoughts like "Why won't god take away these homosexual desires?" while trying to repress a same-sex attraction.
• Trying to deny one's sexuality for a season due to believing that being a Christian and being gay were not compatible.
• Understanding the psychological and emotional manipulation that churches use to control people -- especially those who are desperate -- and to prime the pump to get them to respond in blind faith and allegiance.
• Realizing the Gospels have discrepancies that cannot be harmonized, as well as mythology woven throughout.
• The experience of realizing Christianity is just a human-made and human-sustained religion -- not divine at all.
• Seeing the culture shift within Christianity to care much less about winning people to the Jesus character and saving them from hell, but instead fighting and attacking unbelievers, and writing them off when they disagree.
• Understanding the worldview many Christians have where they think they will be in paradise while non-Christians are tortured forever ... and realizing that most Christians agree with the Yahweh character on that fate of torment for unbelievers.
• After deconversion, dealing with the loss of the afterlife, but also appreciating our finite lives much more as a result.
• Realizing that the Christian worldview, which previously seemed so solid, had been extremely fragile the whole time and easily crumbles when people understand the origins of Christianity and its philosophical absurdities.
• Learning to accept yourself and your desires as you celebrate your sexuality and embrace eroticism.
• Realizing that in the Garden of Eden story, it appears that the Yahweh character was actually the liar, and the Serpent character was telling the truth.
• The need to protect children from the psychological child abuse that is inherent in all forms of Christianity.

Many thanks to Rachel for sharing her story and insights with us!

episodes.title: How to be gracious and patient with loved ones still stuck in Christianity - Sacha D'Souza
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Sacha D'Souza, who grew up as a Jehovah's Witness, but eventually deconverted as he unraveled its origins and the discrepancies and fallacies of the Biblical worldview.

As we walked through his story, we touched on many topics, such as:

• How the "Christ-like" love of Christians is often very conditional on your agreeing with their beliefs and worldview, and how their façade of love quickly turns to hate when you ask too many questions or dissent.
• The experience of having one very religious parent, while the other parent just goes along with it.
• Seeing Jehovah's Witnesses pray for the imminent destruction of all unbelievers, even their own of loved ones.
• The all-compassing commitment to Jehovah and to living for him that is expected of Witnesses, even from a very young age.
• The oppressive outcome of total shunning and ostracization that occurs after someone is baptized as a Witness but then stops believing or leaves the church.
• The dark message that the Tribulation and Armageddon will start very soon, when Jehovah will destroy all disbelievers.
• The intense pressure on Jehovah's Witnesses to not displease Jehovah or to ever fall away.
• The dynamic that the more educated you get, the more holes appear in religion, so religions shelter their people from the truth and discourage higher education because they might be encouraged to analytically examine their faith claims.
• Thinking there is a cosmic dualistic fight of good vs. evil constantly going on in the universe, the culture, and in our minds.
• How religions, especially high-control cults, prey on the young and malleable and abuse their vulnerability, blind trust, and lack of critical opposing information.
• The intense, regulated ministry preparation that occurs at Bethel.
• How many Jehovah's Witnesses fail to plan much for the future because they are confident Jesus will return "any day now."
• The importance in religion to never truly question "god," but to instead always trust and obey, even when the deity's character or commands don't make sense or appear inappropriate or cruel.
• Realizing that the pressure to conform leads people to "live the part" even if they don't truly believe or care to investigate whether the religious claims are true.
• Admitting that the Yahweh character would not be "good" if he were real.
• The importance of treading carefully through deconversion when you are in a marriage and you are deconverting, but your spouse has not yet even started deconstructing or asking critical questions about the religion.
• Being sensitive to those who are still in the "Bible prison," and to how they might find out about our deconversions after we've had lots of time to process our questions and journey, while it's all brand new to them.
• How that the Jehovah's Witnesses organization has whitewashed its own history, including the ways their teachings have changed over the decades.
• The horrific crime coverups in the Jehovah's Witnesses church, and other church denominations, which betray the utter lack of power in the Gospel, and of our need to work to free children from the psychological child abuse of mythological worldviews and of telling them they are wicked in Jehovah's sight and in need of blood magic to be at peace with him.
• How the organization "Recovering From Religion" helps those who are deconstructing and deconverting, meeting people right where they are.

Many thanks to Sacha for sharing his amazing journey out of religion and into freedom!

_________________________

episodes.title: The Christian god is a sadistic psychopath - Nancy O'Brien Simpson
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Nancy O'Brien Simpson, who grew up believing in Jesus, became the women's columnist for Jerry Falwell's Moral Majority, and was a co-founder of the Jericho Project, a pro-life group in Cincinnati.  Nancy was a fervent evangelical Christian until the idea of a loving god eternally tormenting his children began to invade her faith and trouble her worldview, and she eventually deconverted.

As we talked through her story, we touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up with an extreme fear of hell.
• The experience of being "born again" and being "on fire for Jesus."
• Realizing the horrors of external conscious torment.
• How Christians are indoctrinated to not ultimately question the Yahweh character, and whether the narrative is actually real.
• Seeing much more love from unbelievers, and hatred from Christians.
• How the Yahweh character is portrayed in the Bible as being on a constant ego-trip, demanding total and unending worship to address his insecurity, including psychopathic requests 
• How the Yahweh character is a brutal god of infanticide, genocide, and human sacrifice, stoning your children to death, etc.
• The fact that Passover is a celebration of killing children.
• Realizing, from a Trinitarian perspective, that Jesus commanded the same brutal violence as Yahweh, because he is equated to Yahweh.
• Realizing that if Yahweh were real, he would have foreseen every single brutality, abuse, and slaughter that would ever occur, and he could have stopped it, but chose not to, and arguably is ultimately behind it (“I form the light, and create darkness: I make peace, and create evil: I the LORD do all these things.”)
• How basic human love and forgiveness far exceeds the hatefulness and sadistic nature of the Yahweh character.
• The ways that Christianity darkens the human mind into a psychopathic worldview.
• Realizing that many Christians truly believe that even their own children deserve eternal conscious torment if they reject the Gospel.
• If you believe monstrous ideas long enough, you become a monster.
• The bizarre description of the Yahweh character delighting in the aroma of burning flesh.
• The joy and delight of escaping Christianity.

Many thanks to Nancy for sharing her story and insights!

episodes.title: Understanding how CHRONOLOGICAL DISLOCATION conceals HISTORICAL TRUTH - Ralph Ellis
episodes.description:
Today I was honored to speak again with Ralph Ellis, who shared many critical insights regarding the origins of Judaism and Christianity. 

As we moved through our discussion, we touched on:

• How the Bible, to some extent, describes legitimate history, but changes names and merges different stories to protect certain people at that time, to sell the persecution narrative, to unify the people through foundation stories, to shape the details to fit their evolving theology, and as propaganda.
• How history gets written by the victors.
• The Hyksos / Shepherd Kings (Israelite) exodus from Egypt (c. 1580 BC)
• The small exodus of the Amana kings (Akhenaten/Nefertiti (c. 1320 BC)
• How the characteristics, names, city nickname, temple name, family, and companions of Paseba-kha-en-nuit sound just like those of King David.
• The hidden history of Solomon (Sheshonq) and the United Monarchy (c. 900 BC).
• The fascinating way that the Bible rewrites the true story of what happened between David, Bathsheba, Solomon, and the Queen of Sheba (who was viewed as an incarnation of Isis).
• How the "United Monarchy" of Israel as described in the Old Testament appears to have been actually been located not in Jerusalem (Zion), but in Tanis (Zoan), Northern Egypt.
• The connection between the Aramaic and Egyptian language.
• How Yahweh was originally a moon god ("Yah" in Egyptian means "moon"), and Elohim was originally a sun god, showing early Egyptian / Jewish dualism.  Other names of the Jewish god were of Egyptian origin as well, with connections such as Adon/Aten, Shaddai (the storm god) / Seth -- who became Satan, the god of storms.
• How this understanding helps us see that the ancient Israelites were actually still Egyptians, even as late as the 900s BC.
• How the Jewish religious leaders crafted their stories during the Babylonian exile and crafted their new monotheistic religion, and 
• The overwhelming evidence that the Great Pyramid of Egypt is Mount Sinai of the Old Testament stories.
• How people and events have been repeatedly hidden from history and then reshaped to tell a different version of history than actually happened.
• The esoteric and astrotheological background to the story of the feeding of the 5,000 by the Jesus character.
• The background behind Mithraism and how it relates to the Jesus story.
• Understanding that Christianity began in Edessa, not Jerusalem.
• How scholars are often viewing these topics from a perspective of ignorance, as they show that they are unwilling to actually engage with the historical facts, in order to maintain the status quo.
• And many other topics and insights.

Thanks again to Ralph for the many ways he continues to share crucial historical connections and insights.

_____________________________

episodes.title: I left Christianity and religion for good - Kelita Sahliah
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Kelita Sahliah, who grew up in the Seventh Day Adventist Church, but ultimately deconverted after carefully examining the Biblical worldview.

As we talked through her story, we touched on topics such as:

• The importance, in the Seventh Day Adventist Church, of Saturday being kept completely for rest and for focusing on the Yahweh character.
• How the church often preys on vulnerable people.
• The contrast between the message of being "permanently saved and secure in Jesus," but feeling like you're constantly disappointing him and in some kind of danger of losing your close relationship with him.
• How shame culture overshadows life as a Christian.
• How the Seventh Day Adventist Church sees itself as the one true church, just like other denominations do, as well.
• The struggle to figure out the "perfect will" of the Yahweh character.
• The heavy emphasis of preparing for the End Times / Apocalypse.
• "The Great Disappointment" event when prophetess Ellen G. White set dates for the Lord's return, and it did not happen.
• How the Seventh Day Adventist church elevates Ellen White's writings to an almost canonical status.
• Dealing with the extreme legalism of church, where rules and minutiae are critical to being a "godly" person.
• The ways the Christian worldview teaches people to repress their sexual and erotic desires, so that many people never see their desires as truly good and normal and something to accept, pursue, and celebrate.
• The Christian teaching that the more you deny yourself now, the greater your rewards will be in heaven.
• Realizing that in the earliest days of Christianity, there were multiple different kinds of Christianity, including very divergent stories about what Jesus said and did.
• How the Christian patriarchal worldview leaves women feeling like a shadow, and that their main function is just to help the men.
• Thinking through the issue of why the Yahweh character wanted to be praised and worshipped so much, and realizing that he is repeatedly portrayed in the Old Testament as a nitpicky, narcissistic psychopath.
• How Christianity tricks people into putting up with unnecessary suffering as a way to please the Lord and stay focused on eternity.
• The freedom that comes from being released from the tyranny of the mythological master of the Yahweh character.

Thanks to Kelita for sharing her story and for the passion she brings to many important topics through her YT channel.

episodes.title: The Rise and Fall of Faith: A God-to-Godless story - Drew Bekius
episodes.description:
**Apologies for the audio issues at the beginning.  We fully resolved them about 30 minutes into the video.

______________________________

Today I spoke with Drew Bekius, who was an Evangelical Christian and a pastor of several churches, before ultimately deconverting.  He has also been heavily involved with The Clergy Project and is the author of "The Rise and Fall of Faith."

As we walked through his story, we touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a conservative Baptist Church.
• Coming to believe in the Jesus character and committing his life to serving Jesus at a very young age.
• Struggling with depression and suicide, starting in early childhood.
• How the Christian understanding of original sin and self-will / living independently of god shapes the way we see ourselves.
• Being truly zealous for the Lord, especially out of the desire to save people from the eternal fires of hell.
• How the passion to bring the unsaved to know, follow, and trust the Yahweh character overshadows everything the Christian thinks and does.
• Slowing finding more and larger holes in the Christian worldview and the Bible, to the point that faith falls like sand through our hands, until it's obvious that the Christian worldview is not an accurate reflection of reality.
• Rediscovering and rebuilding your identity after escaping from the prison of the Bible.
• The importance of passionately working toward the betterment of humanity.
• Grappling with the question of how to influence our culture away from mythological worldviews.
• The importance of opening dialogue between Christians and atheists, focusing on the common goal to make the world a better place.
• The importance of finding a good community that can help as you heal and get grounded after deconversion.
• The interesting dynamic that the more "fundamentalist" and zealous a person is while a Christian, the more deconversion hurts.

Thanks to Drew for sharing his amazing journey, and for his work with the Clergy Project and the deconstructing/deconverting community as a whole.

episodes.title: There is so much freedom outside of Christianity - Anna Schroeder
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Anna Schroeder, who grew up in New Zealand in a strict cult called The Evangelistic Church of Christ, before she dug deep into the claims of the Bible, and ultimately deconverted.

As we walked through her story, we talked about:

• Growing up with extremely strict rules that were used by the cult to control every area of the lives of the congregation, even down to the color and pattern of their clothing.
• How the church put extreme restrictions on what people could read and with whom they could associate, and harshly reprimanded those who did not fully comply.
• The gender roles that included the rule that women could not work outside the home and could not been seen outside during pregnancy.
• How the cult focused on various parts of the Bible at various times, then moved later on to another focus, forcing the congregation to shift in order to stay on track with whatever the men in leadership felt convicted of at that time.
• How the elders dictated who could get married, when they could get married, and even what clothes they had to wear during the wedding.
• The practice of Excommunication, where the church completely shuns people, even close family members.
• How the church leaders acted like the "voice of god" and demanded total obedience.
• Believing that the Bible was inspired by god and therefore had no errors.
• How fear of the end times and of the supernatural world dominates the Christian worldview.
• As a Christian, dealing with the reality that others would someday burn forever in hell, and how that leads to evangelism, to help people escape the coming torment--and how critical it became to ignore or try to forget that our loved ones would be tortured forever once they died.
• How the church's position against homosexuality helps open our eyes to the dark side of the church.
• How time away from the church can help people to lose their blinders and start to use their critical thinking for the first time.
• The significant effects of religious trauma on our minds.
• Realizing that when we were Christians, we had set ourselves up as judges over everyone else, and how freeing it is to just enjoy getting to know people, without constantly trying to access whether they are "right with god" and whether we need to "share the gospel" with them.
• The joy of leaving religion, and feeling the overwhelming sense of peace.
• Realizing how precious our short time on life is, especially once we realize there's probably no afterlife.
• Struggling with the motives of Christians, who often befriend people not because they actually want to be their friends, but to share the Gospel and have non-believers observe their lives so that they can "shine" the love of Jesus to them, and ultimately be able to list them, like a trophy, as someone they converted and "saved."
• The beauty of being able to learn from people with a different worldview and different life experiences, and of giving up the mentality that we are the teachers, and that non-Christians just need to listen to us.
• The daunting task of reshaping our worldviews and dealing with the trauma that the Christian worldview inflicted on us.
• How Christianity is a prison for the mind.

Thanks to Anna for sharing her story, and for demonstrating the bravery,  strength, and intellectual honesty needed to deconvert from the Christian worldview.

_________________________________________

episodes.title: The Jehovah's Witnesses cult is tearing families apart and ruining lives - Shayne Mechen
episodes.description:
C/W: Discussion of church cover-ups of child abuse; brief discussion regarding suicide.

_________________________________________

Today I spoke with Shayne Mechen, who grew up in New Zealand as a Jehovah's Witness, and was even an elder in the church, before later deconverting and helping others who have escaped.

As we talked through his story, we touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up deeply indoctrinated into Jehovah's Witnesses (JW) doctrines.
• Expecting the imminent return of Jehovah, so much so that going to school was not worth it, because it was expected that the world would end very soon.
• How life revolves nonstop around the church via endless time doing training and witnessing.
• The dynamic of the church having all Witnesses read the same thing at the same time, across the whole world, to maintain control.
• Being taught that JWs would be persecuted for sharing the Gospel, and how that should be seen as a badge of honor and an evidence of faithfulness to Jehovah.
• The relative lack of eternal security as a JW.
• The Patriarchal hierarchy of the JW church, and the message to women that they need to be submissive.
• The "Elders' Book" a.k.a., "Shepherd the Flock of God," and how women are forbidden from viewing it.
• How JWs are required to have 2 witnesses to any crime to take it seriously, and if there are not 2 witnesses, everyone has to "let it go" and stop slandering the abuser in order to promote the peace of the church.
• How the church dynamics regarding reporting abuse are very dangerous for young women who can be abused but have very little recourse.
• How the JW leadership strongly discourages people from doing any kind of research that criticizes the JW church/organization on the internet.
• The unfortunate likelihood that in a marriage, if one person but not the other leaves the church they will probably split up.
• How JW church leadership sets people in the same family against each other, often using the weapon of shunning, based on whether you are have fellowship with the church or not.
• The ways that questions about Noah's Ark, and the broader topic of evolution, can help people realize that they were not taught critical thinking skills when they were Christians.
• The tragic dynamic of high suicide rates in JW circles.
• How Christianity tries to act like the puppet-master of people's lives.
• The importance of healing from religious trauma, after you escape from Christianity and realize that the Jehovah/Yahweh character is part of ancient mythology.
• The overwhelming joy of escaping from Christianity and of helping others who are going through the same journey.

Thanks to Shayne for sharing his story and his passion for supporting those who are escaping from the mythology of Christianity.

episodes.title: I am SO GLAD that I left Christianity! - Lydie Bousch
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Lydie Bousch, who grew up in France in an Evangelical Christian home, in the midst of cultural Catholicism, but who eventually deconverted as she investigated the mythology behind the claims of the Bible.

As we talked through her story, we touched on many topics, including:

• The experience of sensing the Yahweh (god) character speaking to her as a small child.
• Growing up believing that we are wretched sinners, doomed to hell, apart from the blood of the Jesus character.
• Believing that the Bible was the inerrant, inspired message from Yahweh.
• Believing that Yahweh is in control, and that anything that seemed confusing to us about his character or plan was just part of the mystery of life, that he would provide the answers someday, and that we were called to trust him.
• Fantasizing about what happens after we die, when we see Yahweh face to face and understand "ultimate reality" better than ever before.
• Being terrified of unsaved family and friends going to hell because they did not believe in Jesus.
• Being indoctrinated into the thought habit of completely justifying the Yahweh character, no matter how bizarre or nasty he is described in the Bible.
• Believing that the Jesus character was coming back at any moment.
• How the Bible portrays god as being extremely unforgiving after each person's life is over.
• How the church clearly defines women's roles, in line with a patriarchal mindset.
• The ways that purity culture negatively affects people, including how it creates extensive shame and induces body images issues.
• How the American political scene of the last few years prompted serious questions about what Christianity means and what Christians stand for in our culture.
• The horrific notion of Christian parents worshipping Yahweh in heaven while their unbelieving children are being tortured in hell forever.
• The effect of realizing the origin and evolution of the Yahweh character, as originally a son of Elyon and Asherah, and then merging with Elyon--and thus having Asherah as his wife--and later having the Asherah character entirely removed from the pantheon, to ensure male dominance.
• Dealing with the finality of life after you deconvert and realize there is likely no afterlife.
• How the deconversion process feels like becoming an orphan.
• Realizing that human society has been duping itself for thousands of years.
• Dealing with the cognitive dissonance and intentional ignorance of Christians.
• The beauty of leaving Christianity and beginning the human journey free from the shackles of mythology.

Many thanks to Lydie for sharing her story and her infectious joy and passion for the beauty of life.
