episodes.title: Discerning what is FAKE and what is REAL in the borderlands of faith - Philip Yancey
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Philip Yancey, bestselling Christian author, regarding his faith journey.  We also dug into some of the reasons that so many Christians are deconverting.

Throughout our discussion, we touched on many topics, including:

• His newly released memoir, Where the Light Fell, and some of the highlights of his life.
• The story of his father passing away from polio when Philip was just 13 months old, in the context of Christians insisting that he would be healed.
• Growing up in a fundamentalist Christian environment in the South, where racism and the "curse of Ham" was preached.
• Thinking through the perspective of the Yahweh (god) character being portrayed as a "killjoy."
• The mechanisms that the church has often used to manipulate, control, and instill fear in believers.
• Realizing that the church had told him massive lies about crucial topics.
• How Philip starts with his conception of god from what he learns from jesus. 

[Note: I, Tim, see this as Philip's way of dealing with the Yahweh character's psychotic and brutal words and actions in the Old Testament, which I had just mentioned in detail and which Philip was directly responding to.  Philip had agreed that he was concerned about these actions by Yahweh, and went on to say that "there are only two ways I can live with that."  He first talks about how we humans are like ants to Yahweh, and then talks about seeing "especially the Old Testament as a very slanted human version of what took place, kind of like the propaganda that follows every war."

The Yahweh character's actions and commands in the Old Testament explicitly and repeatedly include: genocide, ethnic cleansing, land theft, slavery, kidnapping and child brides, beating of slaves, genital mutilation, priest-administered abortions via magic dust water, virginity checks, forced marriages, paying off rape with a few shekels, misogyny and sexism, tribalism, stoning gay people, stoning non-virgins, stoning people who worked on the Sabbath, etc., while encouraging people to not eat shellfish and to not mix two kinds of fabric, and telling his people that if they loved and obeyed him, he would bless them, but if they chose not to, he would curse and destroy them.]

• How the Greek epics and Greek mythology are intricately woven throughout the the Gospels, as well as the hundreds of quotes and references in the New Testament that are taken from non-canonical books, Greek philosophers, and Greco-Roman mystery cults that most Christians are completely unaware of.
• The bizarreness of the Biblical teachings on hell, where the Yahweh character insists that people have forgiving hearts, but who then refuses to ever forgive again after people die, and instead tortures those who did not love him.

*** AFTER our interview in the first hour, I took the second hour to do a response video.

Thanks to Philip for sharing part of his story as well as his insights with us today!   I hope to touch base again and take the conversation to a much deeper level.

_________________________________________

episodes.title: The Christian worldview is insane - Chip Diggins
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Chip Diggins, my cousin, who grew up with a secular worldview.  We chatted about what it was like growing up without religion, and why he's become passionate about helping others to escape the prison of mythology.

As we talked through his story, we talked about:

• The bizarre Gospel message that the Yahweh character is basically saying to the world, "I'm going to kill myself to appease myself because I created you flawed in the first place."
• Acknowledging that there is zero evidence for the Bible's message being true.
• How the Yahweh character is almost always speaking to men, and almost always speaking to men in the middle east.
• The major difference it makes to have a science-based education, free from superstition.
• The origins of the New Testament, and how most Christians have no idea where their Bible and its stories come from.
• How the historical truth of Jesus' life, activities, or teaching is entirely obscured by the legends and mythologies added to his story.
• The ways that the Christian worldview, when put through a rigorous test, falls apart -- across the board.
• The importance of not taking someone else's "word for it" that the Bible is from a god named Yahweh.
• How Christianity is an amalgamation of various dying and rising god stories, mystery cult teachings, mythologies, and philosophies.
• The sad and horrifying dynamics of childhood indoctrination into religion.
• How religion acts like an addiction, and how hard it is for people to escape.
• The idea that there is no ultimate purpose in life, because there is no designer and no design -- leaving us free to define our own purpose.
• The importance of doing our part to end the mystery cult called Christianity.
• The wonderful privilege of having a secular family, free of religion and superstition.
• Dealing with the fear of death as we acknowledge that there is probably no afterlife.
• The beauty of using your imagination to make the world a better place, instead of using your mental energy for mythology.

Thanks to Chip for sharing his story and insights!

episodes.title: It's OK to question what you've been taught - Jade Spoonemore
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Jade Spoonemore, who grew up in a Fundamentalist Baptist environment and believed in Jesus her whole life until she began to more seriously investigate the claims of the Bible and Christianity, and ultimately deconverted.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Growing up in a home with parents who were struggling with alcoholism and drug addiction, and seeing her mom feel like she "owed her life to god" after she got clean.
• Being scared of hell because of fear about being separated from her body in the afterlife.
• Constantly questioning why we don't have "the joy of the lord," and feeling like we are sinning or that that there's something wrong with us as a result.
• How the sheltering of Christianity leaves people who deconvert feeling like they have been deprived of basic information  and life experiences.
• The way that Christian worldview pits us against the world, with the "us vs. them,"  "light vs. darkness" motifs.
• Making Doomsday preparations due to the belief that the Rapture and End Times were coming very soon.
• Being told that if you're struggling with mental health, that it's a lack of faith in god, an expression of sin, and ultimately your own fault.
• Being told as a woman that you are a major temptation and stumbling block to men, and that your responsibility is to therefore be super careful at all times around men, and being reprimanded for ever not being modest enough or for being alone with a man.
• How the church by and large instructs women that they should never teach men, due to biblical gender roles.
• How women in the church are usually not allowed to have a strong voice, and how that affects their lack of options regarding what happens to them in life, especially regarding the focus on getting married and having lots of kids--and homeschooling them in order to shelter them from unbiblical and worldly ideas.
• Being told in church, as a woman, that you cannot ever teach a man.
• How men in the church have set a strong pattern of covering up and downplaying abuse.
• How the "blood" of the unsaved was "on your hands" if you failed to preach the gospel to them.
• Being taught that certain activities, items, and even people could invite or bring demons into your home.
• How Christians set themselves up as the source of truth, even while they are absurdly deceived and actively trying to deceive their congregations.
• The ways Christians often and patronizingly perceive questioning their narrative as "having a bad attitude."
• The experience of realizing that you're not the only one in your community who is questioning the Christian worldview.
• The strange experience of watching the Christian narrative unravel right before your eyes.
• Realizing that Christianity is complete nonsense and that we need to fight the culture war to end mythology as a worldview.
• How Christians treat deconverted people as traitors, and directly or effectively shun them.
• Healing from religious trauma and "getting your voice back" after deconversion.
• The need to share with others the critical information we were deprived of regarding the origins of the Bible, which can help them make an informed decision about whether Christianity is truth or mythology.

Thanks to Jade for sharing her amazing story and for being such an inspiration!

_________________________________________

episodes.title: Christianity is Mythology: Reflections on my 2-year anniversary of escaping the Bible prison
episodes.description:
Around the beginning of October 2019, after an intense, 18-month deep dive into the origins of Christianity and the Bible, I realized it was all mythology, that Jesus and Yahweh are not real, and that the Christian worldview is therefore not reflective of reality--at all.

In this video I share a short version of why I left (a VERY long, detailed version is in the works), and what the last 2 years have been like, since leaving the cult of Christianity and what I call "the Bible prison."

Thanks for going on this journey with me.

episodes.title: Church is just people getting together and playing make believe - Bill Guthrie
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Bill Guthrie, who grew up believing in Jesus, committed his life to sharing the gospel, and went to school to be a minister, but eventually deconverted as he dug into the details of the Bible and its claims.

As we talked through his story, we discussed many topics, including:

• Going to Bible camp and recommitting himself to the Yahweh character.
• Becoming deeply concerned that he did not have a real relationship with Jesus, and finally getting born again and on fire for "the Lord."
• Getting rid of worldly music to honor Yahweh.
• Being compelled to preach the gospel to those who had never heard it.
• Dealing with the KJV-only controversy.
• The tendency of some Christians to be judgmental of any Christians who weren't passionate about telling others how to "get saved."
• The idea that if you didn't share the gospel enough, the blood of those who went to hell without Jesus was "on your hands."
• Realizing that Paul wrote other epistles that were not include in the NT canon, and that many good scholars believe that many of the canonical letters attributed to Paul were not actually written by Paul, but by someone else claiming to be him.
• Realizing that the god who you thought was going to provide for your needs is not actually providing for your needs.
• Watching Christians fight over which preachers are not conservative enough due to various doctrinal stances that they feel the need to fight for.
• How the Church uses teachings on hell to keep people in fear and under their control.
• Watching small cracks in the Christian worldview become huge cracks.
• Facing the judgmentalism that is rampant among Christians, especially if you don't fully agree with the party line of your particular denomination,  and even more so if you appear to be questioning the basic claims of the Bible.
• How every aspect of the Christian's supposed experience with god can be easily explained through understanding human psychology.
• Knowing, as a Christian, that if you walk away from the faith your fellow Christians will ostracize and mistreat you, and ultimately deal with you as a traitor.
• The moment of realizing that we don't believe anymore, and the bizarre experience of admitting to ourselves that the Jesus character is made up and is thus entirely irrelevant to our lives and worldview.
• Starting to re-think what's really going on in the world -- apart from the perspectives of the mythology of Christianity.
• The importance of empowering kids to have "thought autonomy."
• How the cult of Christianity uses brainwashing tactics.

Many thanks to Bill for sharing his journey with us today!

episodes.title: I'm NOT going to let stories of a mythological deity hurt me ANYMORE - Amy Rath
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Amy Rath, who grew up Catholic and attended an Opus Dei school.  As she investigated the claims of Christianity, she realized it was mythology, and deconverted.

As we walked through her story, we touched on topics such as:

• Growing up exposed to Catholic doctrine and culture, including the excitement over seeing a new Pope selected.
• How Judaism and Christianity originally had a very strong "feminine divine" aspect.
• Being sheltered and insulated from other belief systems.
• Grieving, as a Christian, over the loss of people who went to hell due to not believing in Jesus.
• Being told to believe that the torture of hell was part of the Yahweh character's goodness, and that if we could understand sin and holiness the way he does, we would agree with him that eternal conscious torment was the appropriate punishment for unbelievers and sinners.
• How the Pope is seen as "the voice of god" on earth.
• The ways that the Catholic Church tries to explain away the bad and scientifically unsound stories in the Bible by claiming those parts are just allegories.
• Realizing the ways that Mother Teresa mistreated and helped oppress the poor.
• Thinking through teachings related to the end of life and the afterlife, such as: limbo, purgatory, confession, and last rites.
• Never feeling personally close to the Yahweh character, despite praying and going to church a lot.
• How the church is not a place of grace, despite its claims, but a bastion of hate and self-protection that we need to warn other people about.
• How learning details about the history of religion helps us to deconvert.
• The experience of asking ourselves for the first time, "What if Christianity is simply not true?"
• Choosing to not let stories of a mythological deity hurt us ever again.
• The beauty and importance of raising kids without religion and mythology.
• The process of reclaiming your identity as you recover from religion.
• Learning to forgive yourself for doing the best you could with the limited information you used to have while you were stuck in Christianity.
• Making your life the best you can, in light of each of us having only one life and limited years, and doing our best to leave this world better than we found it.

Thanks to Amy for sharing her story and insights with us!

episodes.title: Christianity is an irrational system of conformity, wishful thinking, and self-deception - Zach Doty
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Zach Doty, who grew up in Pentecostal and Foursquare churches, and later moved toward a Calvinistic perspective, before deconstructing his faith and realizing the irrationality of the Christianity worldview, and ultimately deconverting.

As we went through his story, we touched on topics such as:

• Understanding that truth is worth having, and therefore worth the pursuit, even if the journey is difficult.
• Admitting the conflicting motivations that override our search for truth.
• The experience of memorizing the Bible and passing out gospel tracts door to door.
• Moving from an Arminian perspective into a Calvinistic one, to more seriously honor the New Testament theology of election and sovereignty.
• Believing, as Christians, that people were inherently and completely wicked, at enmity with the Yahweh character, incapable of reaching out to him, spiritually dead, and having nothing good to offer him.
• Reveling in how the Yahweh character, in his mercy, chose to redeem his elect, of his own will and for his glory.
• Looking for "fruit" in our own lives and others, to have assurance that the Jesus character is living in us.
• Believing, as a Christian, that the world was 6,000 years old and even that the universe was geocentric.
• Being unwilling, as a Christian, to accept any scientific evidence that contradicted the Bible.
• Realizing, during deconstruction, that we had been severely duped by Christian apologist con-artists.
• Starting over as an adult, learning real science for the first time, after growing up in Christianity and its pseudo-science.
• The harrowing experience of seeing your epistemology crumble in front of you during deconstruction.
• Realizing that religion is the epitome of a selfish and anthropomorphic worldview, where the Yahweh character is orchestrating the gospel and all of history for you, so you can be part of his bride.
• Realizing we were callous to and even supporting the eternal conscious torment and suffering of the reprobate, in hell, because their torture was deserved and brought glory to Yahweh.
• Taking pride, as Christians, in ignorance and closed-mindedness, because we were part of the "base" things of the world, the clay that Yahweh chose to make into vessels of glory.
• How we go through life with an assumption that we are mostly rational in our worldview, even if we have a few ideas to tweak, rather than admit that we may be profoundly wrong about the most critical parts of our beliefs.
• The overwhelming power that our need for conformity has over us, especially in the areas of worldview and beliefs.
• The importance of being willing to update our worldview based on new information.
• Realizing that our intuitions are usually wrong, and that we need to question our assumptions and begin to apply the scientific method to our worldview, in our efforts to remove bad ideas and to search for the truth.
• The crucial importance of doubting claims, especially extraordinary ones that have no evidence, instead of blindly believing them.
• Admitting the role of wishful thinking and self-deception in our belief systems, especially when most of our loved ones and teachers all believe the same thing.
• How Christianity is like an evolved virus of parasitic ideas that infects our minds, in order to exploit our agency and biases, and that it is focused on its own self-interests and survival, not on truth or on our best interest.
• Understanding that the Bible is not monolithic, but that it was written by many men over many centuries, with competing, evolving, and incompatible ideas.
• The beauty of having truth as your North Star, versus conformity to an ancient, primitive text, which just leads to unending cognitive dissonance.
• The path to developing and using tools of truth.

Thanks to Zach for sharing his amazing journey out of the mythology of Christianity and into rationality and freedom!

episodes.title: CHRISTIANITY IS A dangerous, poisonous LIE - Esther the African Humanist
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Esther the African Humanist, who grew up in the Deeper Life Church in Nigeria and later joined the Anglican Church, but ultimately deconverted from Christianity.

As we walked through her story, we talked about:

• The Deeper Life Church teaching that holiness is the way to be "right with god."
• Being deeply afraid of backsliding away from god.
• Being shown movies that vividly depicted people burning in hell, and then hearing an altar call to repent and turn to the Jesus character
• Being told by their church to get rid of their TV because it was a venue for demonic activity.
• How she "gave her life to Christ" over and over to be sure it was legitimate and that she would not go to hell.
• Being told to spend the bulk of her time in church in order to avoid demonic activity and worldly influences.
• How church leadership controlled the information they let the congregation have access to.
• How the story of the garden of Eden, taken at face value, looks like god purposefully set up his own children to fail.
• How Christianity incorporates animism on many levels, such as using, "I plead the blood" as a mantra to ward off bad things or to have a prayer heard.
• Being told to aim for god's perfect will, while knowing sometimes you'll only hit the "permissible" or "acceptable" will of god, and yet trying to understand all that in the context of god's sovereignty.
• The ways that the Bible weaves magic into the narratives repeatedly to make god's will difficult to figure out, through the Urim and Thummin, and through casting lots, etc.
• Being told by the church that babies are born sinful
• Unpacking how the Jesus character is used as the ultimate scapegoat, and how we were told that there is power in his blood, and seeing all that in the greater context that the Yahweh character refuses to "simply forgive."
• Realizing that the Yahweh character in the Old Testament was portrayed as a jealous, vindictive monster.
• The bizarreness of the idea that the Yahweh character needs the blood of his own child to satisfy himself.
• Being urged to proselytize, because "the more souls you get, the more mansions and crowns you get" in heaven.
• The effectiveness of childhood indoctrination and brainwashing.
 
Thanks to Esther for sharing her story, and for all the great things she shares on her YT platform!

_________________________________________

episodes.title: I DECONSTRUCTED MY RELIGION ... and found FREEDOM instead of FLAMES - Erika Sams
episodes.description:
* Apologies for the audio/noise issues on my side.

Today I spoke with Erika Sams, who grew up in a very strict religious environment before unraveling the claims of Christianity and ultimately deconverting.

We touched on various topics, including:

• A woman being under a man's authority her whole life: under her father until she is transferred to her husband's authority, in order to obey the Biblical authority / obedience structure of god / Jesus / men / women / children.
• Being told entire life what your identity and purpose was -- to love and serve Jesus and bring people into the kingdom.
• The fear of the possibility of not being one of the elect, and thus being in danger of hell.
• Being taught that sexual attraction was wrong and "lust," so that even a basic interest in someone else feels like you're offending god and sinning against your future spouse.
• How Christianity teaches women to be responsible for safeguarding men's purity by being ultra modest.
• How modesty culture leads women with curves to want to hide their curves.
• The importance of saving yourself for one person in marriage, including in your thought life.
• Using a promise ring as a vow to god and your father that you will keep yourself pure until you swap it for the wedding ring.
• How human value -- especially for women -- gets tied up entirely in virginity and purity, and the danger of being shamefully labeled "used goods" if you've gone "too far."
• How Christianity leads people to have a double life as they try to maintain their sexual thoughts and their outward façade of Christian purity.
• For those who have done anything of a sexual nature, trying to determine how worthless and stained they should feel as they work through repentance.
• Being told sex outside of marriage invites demons into our lives.
• The ways that the Yahweh character ends up being like a psycho as he proclaims "You are worthless but I love you, but if you don't do things my way, I'll blast you!"
• The Christian dynamic of keeping you perpetually "broken and needy."
• How purity culture tells you to not even pleasure your own body.
• How the message of a literal hell terrifies Christians who are afraid for their loved ones who they believe will be tortured forever.
• Repeatedly asking Jesus to save us, to be sure it was real, since hell is at stake.
• How Christians hurt so many communities by writing people off as "lost causes" according to their theology.
• The nonstop fear of being "left behind."
• The unending damage that can be done by extremist parents to their children.
• The overwhelming arrogance that the Christian worldview creates in its adherents.
• The constant Christian personal experience conundrum of wondering if "the voice of god" is actually god, our own self-consciousness/wishful thinking, or the devil.
• The nonstop endeavor to figure out god's elusive will, and working through the resulting instability when his will seemed crystal clear, and then the door closes.
• Realizing the extreme manipulation of church worship, where they repeatedly get you to sing about being worthless and broken without the Jesus character.
• How the church commits psychological child abuse by preying on young people and brainwashing them into thinking they are wicked and that the Jesus character's torture was necessary because of how bad they are.
• The importance of having a psychological "funeral" to grieve your time in Christianity.
• The dynamic of "leaving the door open a little bit" at the end of your time in Christianity, out of fear that you might be wrong about Yahweh being real and over fear of death.
• Extreme fear of hell.
• The idea that Yahweh is so mad at his own creation that he's going to torture it, instead of just not create it in the first place or just forgive.
• The importance of wanting the truth more than your tradition.
• The way Christianity wraps your worldview entirely in the Yahweh character, and how hard it is to start over and reclaim your identity after deconversion.• How comparative mythology and religion helps us to see through Christianity's claims.
• Admitting to ourselves that if we had been born in another time and place, we would very likely have wholeheartedly believed something entirely different.
• Realizing the bizarreness of believing in canonicity, once you realize what was actually happening in that process.
• How the church shelters you from alternative perspectives and solid information about the origins of Christianity.

Many thanks to Erika for sharing her story with us!

episodes.title: Healing from Betrayal by Christians after Deconversion
episodes.description:
This video is about thinking through the various aspects of being betrayed by our loved ones after we deconvert from Christianity.  

I touch on:

• The bravery and beauty of the deconstruction process.
• The process of reclaiming our identities after escaping Christianity.
• The experience of realizing that our loved ones who are still stuck in a mythological worldview are treating us as traitors and will continue to do so, in increasing measure, as punishment.
• The importance of calling their behavior a betrayal, understanding the dynamics of why they feel the need to mistreat deconverts that way, and the myriad ways their betrayal plays out.
• How we can love them through it, while still setting up appropriate boundaries.
• The need to heal, forgive, and thrive regardless of whether they ever escape Christianity.

I really hope some of these insights are helpful to those on the deconstruction and deconversion journey!

episodes.title: The Resurrection accounts are FALSE and the Gospels are NOT to be trusted - Jonathan MS Pearce
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with author Jonathan MS Pearce again about the importance of understanding that the Resurrection accounts are false and that the Gospels are not to be trusted as history.

As we dove into his book, "The Resurrection: A Critical Examination of the Easter Story," we touched on many intriguing topics, including:

• The idea that the writers of the Bible are writing theology, not history.
• How Paul is our earliest source for information about Jesus, and that the evidence Paul provides is extremely poor.
• How Jesus began as an exalted prophet and slowly became legendized and mythologized with stories borrowed from other stories and mystery religions.
• The dynamic that false and even horrific ideas can seem entirely legitimate and normal to people if they are introduced early in life and reinforced consistently.
• When you expect evidence, and there is none, it is evidence that the claim is false.
• That Paul is silent about the empty tomb because it hadn't been invented yet.
• How the Gospels progressively embellish the narrative -- thus why Paul, and then later on the Gospel of Mark, have an no resurrection story.
• How Paul does not appear to have believed in a physical resurrection.
• How it is likely that Jewish authorities began arguing that Jesus' body was stolen, explaining why Matthew adds an empty tomb story.
• The fact that there are dozens of other Gospels telling very different and incompatible stories, and how church councils, over many generations, arbitrarily picked the Gospels and other books they wanted to go into the canon.
• How the characters in the New Testament don't appear to have wanted to verify extreme claims, and if the characters had been real (instead of just literary devices), they would have had little or no way to verify the claims, and the earliest audiences that read the Gospels for the first time had no way to fact check.
• Once you realize the Gospels are not historical, you realize there's no reason to hang your theology or truth claims on it anymore.
• How the wild embellishment of the Trial and Crucifixion make it easy to see that it's contrived and interpolated.
• How the Jesus character is used as a replacement for the Paschal lamb in the Gospel stories.
• How hyper-literalism keeps people from reading the Bible for what the original authors actually intended and from seeing the theological ploys and naming techniques they used.
• How Midrash, Pesher, and Mimesis techniques were used in the Gospels to retell older Old Testament and Greek and Roman epic stories to make them more valuable for the new audience.
• The dynamics around visions and hallucinations, and the strange contrast between Christians who would question people's current-day claims of visions, and yet do not question the claims of the New Testament authors in the slightest.
• The ways that resurrection mythology helps people stay in false comfort.
• And much more!

Thanks to Jonathan for his book and all the ways he helps clarify that the Gospels are mythology, not history.

episodes.title: It's Time to Crucify the Bible - Deborah Grace
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Deborah Grace, who grew up in an evangelical church environment and then got involved with the Hebrew Roots movement, before ultimately facing the discrepancies of the Bible and its origins, which led her to deconvert from Christianity.

As we talked through her story and her recent book, Crucifying the Bible, we touched on many topics, including:

• Being concerned about the validity of our earlier professions of faith, so much that we felt the need to re-confess our faith in the Jesus character and even to get re-baptized, repeatedly, because there is so much at stake.
• How our trust of our parents -- especially if they are exceptionally honest and good people -- leads us to believe that their worldview must be accurate.
• How the Christian worldview becomes pervasive and all-encompassing.
• The Christian push to outbreed the pagans through a Quiverfull mentality.
• The selective supremacy of certain people in the Bible and Christendom.
• How Christianity sets you up to never remotely question the ultimate truth of that worldview.
• The bizarre dynamic of thinking the Yahweh character is not a god of confusion, and that the holy spirit character is leading people into truth, and yet there are endless interpretations of every single verse and theological point.
• How the end times and Apocalypse/Rapture/Tribulation concepts are used to scare people into believing, and how those fear tactics often create immense trauma in people.
• The strange experience of realizing that Christianity is a cult, just as bizarre as all the other groups we previously called a "cult."
• The experience of getting pulled into the Hebrew Roots movement, as a means of experiencing being "grafted in" to Israel, to honor the eternal Levitical priesthood, and to see the Bible as more of a single cohesive message from god.
• The strange mindset of the Yahweh character, who is made to focus on what kind of clothes his people wear and what kind of food they eat, but he is silent about genocide, child rape, etc.
• How Christians treat you as a traitor, both when you switch denominations, and much more so when you claim the Yahweh and Jesus characters aren't real and that the Bible is not divine.
• The traumatic experience and true grieving process of deconstruction and deconversion, as you realize reality has nothing to do with the worldview espoused by Christianity or the Bible.
• How Christians will often mistreat or shun you if you deconvert, as they brand you a severe traitor and live out the saying, "There's no hate like Christian love," demonstrating how shallow the relationship really was since it was based on mythology.
• The urgency of exposing the discrepancies and mythology of Judaism and Christianity, especially in light of Christian nationalism.
• How Christianity causes you to "second guess" yourself constantly.
• The bizarre and disgusting dynamics of blood magic that are woven into the core of Judaism and Christianity.
• How Christianity teaches you to not trust yourself and to not see yourself as your own, but as belonging to the Yahweh and Jesus characters.
• How the Bible employs psychological and mind control tactics to ensure submission, conformity, and fear.
• How Christians refuse to share with their congregations the origins and evolution of the Yahweh character, along with his wife Asherah and father Elyon.
• The frightening power of brainwashing to totally overwhelm the thought processes of Christians.
• How terrorizing it is to Christians to admit the huge cracks in their worldview, exposing why they cannot honestly face the facts about the origins of their cult.
• The absurd arguments and wrangling Christians use to try to defend their worldview.
• The bizarre dynamics of church councils taking hundreds of years to vote on the canon, and books floating in and out of favor with the church councils.
• How the peace after deconversion is much greater than the pretend peace of Christianity.

Thanks to Deborah for sharing her story and for all the research and deep thought she put into her book.

episodes.title: I write worship songs for a large church -- and I'm an atheist
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with a guest who writes worship songs for a large church -- and is an atheist.

As we talked through his story and had , we discussed various topics, including:

• How church worship creates a placebo effect of good feelings based on the communal belief that "it's going to be ok" and that the god character is present with us during worship.
• How the church worship experience, as well as drugs, can be mistaken for a sense of the divine.
• How the church worship experience preys on the needy.
• Realizing the absurdity of the idea that the god character is helping and blessing us while simultaneously ignoring the desperate pleas of hundreds of thousands of others at the same time.
• How the Christian worldview teaches us to constantly re-examine ourselves to see if we have any unconfessed sins that we need to confess.
• Imagining what it would be like if we (who were indoctrinated into Christianity as children) had never heard of Christianity, and then suddenly heard about it as adults, and deciding how likely it would be that Christianity would sound reasonable to us.
• Learning HOW to think, as opposed to just learning WHAT to think.
• The moment you wake up and realize that you have been severely duped by religion.
• How deconversion can feel like a friend and father has died, and the loss demands a proper grieving--and yet, ironically when you need support and comfort the most, that is the moment Christians attack you the most.
• Recovering and healing from religion, including the loss of the huge amount of time in your life that you had dedicated to it.
• How professional Christians are professional charlatans, very often preying on children's innocence, gullibility, lack of exposure to alternative points of view, and lack of understanding their power to choose for themselves what they want to believe.
• The effect of cultural peer pressure to get involved in some kind of Christianity.
• The importance of describing Christianity -- in any form -- as a cult.
• The damage done by sending kids the insidious message of their wickedness in the context of the wrath of the god character.
• Realizing the irony of the concept that it's actually Christians who are in the dark, and that it's atheists who can help humanity escape that darkness.
 
Many thanks to my guest for sharing his story!

episodes.title: Stevie Noah: Christianity Gave Me Horrific Nightmares for 15 Years
episodes.description:
T/W: discussion of religious trauma, extreme nightmares

Today I spoke with Stevie Noah, who grew up in the Assemblies of God denomination and went through severe religious trauma before ultimately deconverting from Christianity.

We discussed many topics, including:

• How every religion and denomination thinks it is the right one and is most closely aligned to truth.
• How religious trauma is often passed down to the next generation.
• The extremely heavy weight of patriarchal ideas on women.
• The experience of constantly feeling bad and guilty for displeasing the god character.
• Being seen as permanently damaged goods if you lose your virginity outside of marriage.
• How many Christians are publicly shamed in church if they stray from sexual "purity."
• The many ways that the Bible blames women for sin, demeans women, and tells them to keep quiet--and the bizarre ways that progressive Christians try to downplay those verses.
• How women's periods are described in the Bible as making them unclean -- even though it's supposedly the Yahweh character who designed them that way.
• The horrors of the Biblical prescriptions for a rapist to just pay a few pieces of silver to his victim's father, and for her to become his wife forever, as well as the commands for the "men of god" to kidnap young girls and take them as child brides (or worse) after slaughtering the girl's entire family during the genocides and land theft commanded by the Yahweh character.
• How religious trauma can create long-lasting nightmares in kids who have been deeply indoctrinated, especially by messages of pending punishment, end times, and the supernatural realm.
• How the Abrahamic religions cause you to become OCD about asking for forgiveness from the god character.
• How scaring kids about hell is a form of psychological child abuse.
• The many issues with the Gospel story and worldview, including voluntarily giving up your rationality in order to embrace mythology, removing personal responsibility for sin, telling people they are wicked and worthless without a psycho god who claims to love them but threatens eternal punishment if they don't love him back.
• How church services are set up to emotionally and psychologically manipulate attendees.
• How Christianity removes people's ability to truly question the worldview they've been given, 
• The importance of honestly questioning everything.
• Realizing that there is an overwhelming amount of information about the origins of Christianity that you were never told before, and how that information exponentially speeds up the deconversion process, especially as it becomes evident that the authors of the Bible copied profusely from many other sources, such as Homer, Euripides, Virgil, Pythagoras, etc.
• Learning to reframe your life after deconversion, starting with being quiet and alone, training yourself to understand reality, deciding who you want to be apart from other people's worldviews and opinions, learning how to have peace, getting rid of guilt and self-doubt, building up your self-worth, and truly enjoying pleasure.
• The importance of healing from religious trauma, and how to get started in that process.

Thanks to Stevie for sharing her story, and for the inspiration and healing she brings through her YouTube channel!

episodes.description:

Today I spoke with Forrest Clay, who grew up in an Independent Fundamental Baptist household before eventually deconstructing his worldview and leaving fundamentalist Christianity.

As we talked through his journey, we discussed many topics, including:

• Saying the sinners prayer at a young age, and then re-confessing his faith in Jesus as his Savior repeatedly, due to the terror of hell and the concern over the earlier professions of faith being legitimate enough.
• The idea that if hell were real, then the most merciful thing people could do is kill their children before they reached the age of accountability, otherwise we risk that they might reject Christ and go to hell.
• How purity culture typically leaves young people without sufficient education about their sexuality
• How shame culture leads people to lead double lives.
• The importance of raising kids without body shame
• How church leadership being unwilling to address serious issues that arise when young people get well educated in the scientific foundation of evolution and astronomy.
• The bizarre Christian worldview regarding the horrific teachings of the Bible (genocide, land theft, slavery, child brides, stoning, etc.): that if the Yahweh character commands it, then that becomes morally acceptable.
• The dangers of remaining connected with Christianity, even progressive Christianity, due to the issues of teaching children a worldview based on mythology, as well as the easy tendency of Christianity to move toward literalism and fundamentalism.
• We ended with Clay singing his recent song, "Does God."

Thanks to Clay for his willingness to share his story and for his amazing music that challenges and inspires!

episodes.title: Gayle Jordan: There is more light, air, and space on this side of the decision to leave religion.
episodes.description:
(The interview starts at 6 minutes in).

________________________________
 
Today I spoke with Gayle Jordan, mother of 4, blogger, attorney, and the Executive Director at Recovering From Religion.  She shared her story growing up in the Southern Baptist Church and being involved in ministry until she dug into the discrepancies of the Bible and its horrible teachings, and ultimately deconverted.

As we talked through Gayle's story, we touched on many topics, including:

• Encouraging kids to relentlessly pursue the truth and to ask hard questions.
• The experience of hanging on to belief even when we have many reasons to deconvert.
• The freedom to reimagine our lives after deconversion
• How life is much more glorious after leaving belief in a deity.
• The power of indoctrination to make bad ideas sound acceptable, as it bypasses the critical thinking filter.
• The importance of giving kids the power to believe what they want to believe and to allow them to be freethinkers.
• How the threat of eternal punishment is a form extortion.
• How the Yahweh character is an extremely unforgiving, sadistic, and psychotic character.
• The typical Christian teaching that people are being tortured in eternal conscious torment and that Yahweh will never let them out of hell or stop the torture.
• The Christian cycle of having "mountaintop" experiences and then crashing down to real life and to sin, pushing people to seek to be even more committed.
• The common Christian experience of rededicating oneself to the Lord repeatedly, to be sure it is real--especially since hell is at stake.
• The ways that teachings about original sin and depravity beat people up emotionally, leave them defeated, and teach them to obsessively re-examine their thoughts and motives.
• Healing from the ways the ways the Christian worldview instill fear in people through teachings on the end times and the spirit world.
• Dissecting and analyzing the Christian worldview, and realizing how bad the thinking is.
• How the Christian ideas of heaven create a fantasy that detracts from the actual reality we do have and keeps people from enjoying their lives today.
• How teachings on the end times and about the god character creating a new heaven and earth lead Christians to treat climate change as a non-issue.
• How patriarchy and misogyny are such a fundamental part of the Judeo-Christian narrative that most believers do not even question it.
• The overwhelming damage done from the biblical teaching on sex and the church's desire to control and define people's sexuality.
• The intense ways that Christian reject and attack people who deconvert, treating them as traitors.
• Experiencing the "light, air, and space" of the deconversion experience.
• How the beauty, joy, and delight of life start when we take off the god glasses, bringing freedom from horrific and bizarre dogma, the space to be who we want to be, the opportunity to draw upon all possible solutions, and the removal of the narrow and false worldview of Christianity.
• How Christianity preys on children's best instincts and traumatizes them as the church portrays the crucifixion story and tell children they are to blame for what Jesus "had to do" to save them from their terrible wickedness.
• The ways that the Recovering From Religion organization helps provide hope, healing, and support for people who are struggling with issues of doubt and non-belief, and the great work of the Secular Therapy Project.
• The importance of fully grieving the loss of the Christian worldview after you realize it's mythology and escape the Bible prison.
• Dealing with the lingering fear of hell, anger about being duped by Christians and the church, and the fracture relationships that come as a result of deconverting.

Many thanks to Gayle for sharing her amazing journey with us, and for everything she does to help people recover from religion.

episodes.title: Derrick Day: I left Christianity because it's time to jettison mythology
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Derrick Day, a former Christian preacher who dabbled in progressive Christianity for a time before fully deconverting.

As we walked through his story, we touched on various topics, such as:

• How the horrific Christian response to the social and political issues of the last few years has helped many people see through the hypocrisy and foolishness of Christianity and the church.
• How the Bible is used for subjugation and control.
• The Biblical perspective of focusing on minute details (how to tithe, what fabrics to weave together), while ignoring gross injustices.
• The only passage in the Bible that talks directly about abortion (Numbers 5), where the Yahweh character advises a priest how to create a magic dust potion and create abortions in supposedly unfaithful women.
• How the Bible does not stand up under honest scrutiny.
• The fact that there were dozens of other gospels and epistles, and that most Christians are entirely unaware of them, unaware of how some went in and out of the canon, fail to ask the questions of why those other books were left out, and fail to be shocked at why their church leaders never mentioned them.
• The appeal yet ultimate emptiness of progressive Christianity.
• The idea that if you haven't at least flirted with the idea that there is no god, you haven't deconstructed far enough.
• How the evolution of humanity's mindset will require us to jettison religion.
• How leaving Christianity is about graduating from bad ideas in order to become the best person and embrace the most accurate worldview we can.

Thanks to Derrick for sharing some of his story today … I can't wait to connect with him again!

This video is about our need to resist the hate speech otherwise known as Christianity.  I hope you'll join me and help change our world for the better by pushing back against mythological worldviews.
--Tim

______________________________________

The Bible is hate speech, and inspires its followers to hate speech and a hateful worldview.  This is just the tip of the iceberg:

Psalm 139:21-22 ESV
Do I not hate those who hate you, O Lord? And do I not loathe those who rise up against you? I hate them with complete hatred; I count them my enemies.

But as for the cowardly, the faithless, the detestable, as for murderers, the sexually immoral, sorcerers, idolaters, and all liars, their portion will be in the lake that burns with fire and sulfur, which is the second death.

episodes.title: Tara Banks: Christianity is mythology, and I'm so glad I'm free
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Tara Banks, who grew up in a Fundamental Baptist church environment, but eventually deconverted after thinking through the philosophical issues of the Christian worldview and the origins of Christianity.

As we discussed her journey, we touched on many topics, including:

• How church teachings can cause people to have nonstop fears, and even nightmares, about dying and going to hell, being tortured, dealing with demons, or the Rapture taking place and some people being left behind.
• How the Christian worldview tries to remove a person's power and well-being through fear tactics.
• The discrepancy of the Yahweh character requiring forgiveness of his people, and yet being one of the most unforgiving literary characters ever invented.
• How Christians are effectively predators of young children, taking advantage of their ignorance, preying on their ability to be easily molded and indoctrinated, sheltering them from alternative perspectives of reality, and psychologically scarring them in various ways.
• How Christians frequently discourage questioning the bizarre stories, doctrines, and discrepancies of the Bible, insisting only on blind faith and obedience.
• How Christians ignore the reality that there are multiple canons across Christendom, and multiple versions of the books in the canons.
• How Christians try to harmonize the two creation stories in Genesis, and ignore the other mythologies of that era, such as Lilith, Enoch, etc.
• The idea that Yahweh would kill his own son, but he won't just kill Satan right from the beginning.
• How the Judeo-Christian worldview depicts women as inferior afterthoughts and ensures they have very limited power in the faith community.
• How women are seen as inherently temptresses, and men as out of control in their sexuality, women consistently to blame--rarely men--for sexual temptations and scandals.
• How Christianity convinces people that they are endlessly blameworthy  because any lack of peace or joy or commitment is entirely our fault, not god's.
• The common experience of Christians feeling the need to "get saved" or be "born again" over and over, in case it was potentially not real the first time.
• The experience of watching Christianity's claims collapse around you.
• How Christianity causes emotional damage as it tears you down and leaves you feeling constantly deficient, as you wait on a non-existent deity to transform you or reveal himself or his will to you.
• How Christians force believers to witness to others and push the narrative that "their blood is on our hands" if we don't share the Gospel.
• How the church divides and polarizes the world into "us vs. them," i.e. worldly sinners vs. Christians. 
• How Christians desensitize people from the horrific teachings of the Bible by instilling the stories in them at a very young age and trying to use the "holiness of god" as an excuse to justify genocide and other crimes.
• Being able to see the universe as much more beautiful once you remove mythological worldviews.
• The importance, after deconversion, of building a community that can support you.
• The importance of being patient with ourselves as we heal from a religious worldview and from religious trauma.

 
Many thanks to Tara for sharing her story!

Our goal is not to argue with them more, it is to ignore their ridiculous arguments and charlatanism.  We thrive best we lower the volume on those who would try to force their blood magic, scapegoating, human sacrifice death cult on us and our children.

episodes.title: Addiction & Deconversion - a conversation with Caleb Perri and Derek Lambert
episodes.description:
C/W - drug addiction

Today guest host Derek Lambert and I spoke with Caleb Perri, who grew up exposed to evangelical Christianity, but eventually deconverted while at the same time working to overcome a drug addiction.

As we went through Caleb's story, we touched on many topics, including:

• How our striving for approval from other Christians can lead to a double life as we try to be ourselves and yet look good for the church community.
• The positive and negative aspects of the idea that you need a higher power or outside source when you are struggling with an issue.
• How we tend to see arbitrary patterns and connections in life, and attribute them to god, in our effort to find meaning in life.
• How understanding science and archeology's contradictions of the Bible's details and worldview can help start the deconversion process.
• How our perspectives change when we realize that there is no deity planning our lives.
• How curiosity and amazement about the universe and science heightens after deconversion.
• The ways we empathize with people who are still religious.
• How Christianity is an addiction, as we feel good when we gain the both the judicial/salvific approval of the Yahweh and Jesus characters, as well as the daily sense of intimate connection with those characters, and then experience intense pain as we begin to deconstruct the mythology and break free from our connection to it.
• How the Bible's texts being open to endless interpretations can help us to see through the claims of Christianity.
• How the Christian worldview often tries to punish people for just being human.
• Thinking through the process of reclaiming our identity after deconversion.
• The importance of skepticism as we assess religious claims.

Many thanks to Derek for being my gracious co-host today, and to Caleb for sharing his story.

______________________________________

episodes.title: I didn’t question everything I believed UNTIL my profession no longer required me to be a Christian.
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Dr. David D'Andre, who grew up in an independent, fundamental Baptist environment, and even went into ministry and missions, until he eventually deconverted from Christianity.

As we discussed his journey, we touched on many topics, including:

• The ways that Calvinism is detrimental to our emotional and mental health.
• The idea that healing, in large part, involves the release of fear and pain, and since the Christian message by definition revolves around the fear of who we are in light of who god is, inner healing requires moving on from Christianity.
• How the Yahweh character never shows unconditional love, instead always basing his actions on fear, manipulation, and eternal punishment.
• The psychopathic nature of the requirement of perfection/righteousness, and its corollary requirement, penal substitution.
• The dynamics behind Christians blaming AIDS and natural disasters on homosexuality.
• The experience of growing up knowing we were "sinners in the hands of an angry god" and in danger of actual hellfire.
• The idea that saying the words, "I believe in Jesus" becomes a form of using magic words, in order to gain personal access to substitutionary atonement.
• Christian mixed messages over receiving all your wisdom from god--via the Bible--versus just hearing directly from god.
• The practical Christian experience of opening the Bible to a random page and expecting to receive a personal message from god for you from those verses.
• The moment we realize that it's a strong possibility that god is a figment of our imagination.
• How discarding the belief in a literal hell is often the first step toward deconversion, especially as we realize that if there is no hell, there's no real need for Christianity.
• Growing up in a church context where you're not allowed to fully admit and deal honestly with Bible discrepancies and other issues with the Christian worldview.
• Realizing how textual criticism and the documentary hypothesis affect our view of Biblical inspiration and inerrancy.
• Learning to switch our mentalities from god and the Bible being the judge of us, to us becoming the judge of the Bible and of the Yahweh character.
• Realizing there is no divine presence in the universe, and the implications.
• Seeing that Christianity taught us to categorize everyone we meet: saved vs. damned, elect vs. non-elect, insiders vs. outsiders, etc., and the relief of being able to finally see people for who they are without imposing our agenda or worldview on them.
• The damage done by the Christian message of "You are broken and incomplete, and you have a void in your life that only god can fill," and the perspective shift that occurs when you realize that there is no god, so there is no god-shaped void, and that we are not waiting for a deity to complete and redeem us.
• How breaking the hold of the biblical worldview on our lives frees our minds and gives us a chance to truly thrive.
• The dynamic of pastors and teachers withholding critical information regarding the origins of Christianity and Judaism from their congregations and students.
• How Christian doctrines can be especially harmful to those who do not have kind parents, as messages of unworthiness and badness are mixed with a lack of love.

Thanks to Dr. D'Andre for sharing his story and for his great insights!

______________________________________

and

episodes.title: Jillian Aurora: I'm not a Christian anymore, and I am UNAPOLOGETIC.
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Jillian Aurora, who grew up in an ultra-conservative, fundamentalist Christian environment until she deconstructed its core beliefs, and ultimately deconverted.

As we talked through her story, we discussed:

• Being extremely sheltered, even within the church.
• The practice of "shadowing," where children must be near their parents at all times in order to deeply condition Christian behaviors.
• The idea of women having to wear dresses, be domesticated, and put very little focus on their education beyond homemaking and child rearing.
• The idealization of ultra-young marriage of women and having many children (quiverfull).
• The very dark sides of purity culture, with its emphasis on the inherently seductive nature of womanhood.
• The idea that the more extreme you are, the more evidence you show of your commitment to Jesus.
• Going through seasons of purging worldly items from your life to demonstrate a willingness to give up anything for Jesus and to be more holy.
• How conservative Christianity burns patriarchy into your psyche via a male god, male church leadership, husband and father leadership, the husband representing the holy god and the wife representing the sinful church, women needing to keep quiet in church and being the weaker vessel, and especially in the idea of a daughter submitting to her father's ownership until he passes that ownership to her future husband.
• How people are taught to submit to authority, even bad authority, and are thus very vulnerable to abuse.
• How the combination of Christianity's loyalty programming and injunctions to constantly give selflessly often leads to extreme codependency and open the door to abuse.
• The path to reclaiming personal authority, and especially feminine authority for women escaping from a patriarchal mindset and culture.
• How the Bible is hateful, horrific, and sexist toward women.
• How the idea that the Christian worldview is intrinsically broken and flawed can be such a terrifying and threatening concept to believers, and why they cannot even begin to entertain that possibility.
• Dealing with Christians who try to explain away others' deconversions.
• Learning that your own self-worth has no prerequisites, in direct opposition to the message of the Bible.
• How a lot of adherence to Christianity stems from nothing more than social conditioning.
• Learning to trust ourselves and our own wisdom again after we realize that the god we were supposed to be trusting and listening to doesn't exist and that the supposed wisdom of the Bible is actually a terrible worldview.
• Realizing that goddess worship was once a major part of Judaism and Christianity.
• Basing personal relationships on a partnership paradigm instead of a hierarchy paradigm.

Many thanks to Jillian for sharing her story, and for her amazing work to help others heal and thrive!

______________________________________

episodes.title: Neil Godfrey: "I determined to never again rest on unquestioned assumptions."
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Neil Godfrey, the man behind the amazing Vridar blog.  Neil grew up in a liberal Methodist background, then got pulled into the Worldwide Church of God cult before he questioned Christian assumptions and examined every layer of his beliefs, and ultimately deconverted from Christianity.

After we briefly discussed his personal story, we went on to discuss various topics, including:

• The ways that churches condition people to fall in line with their thinking.
• How tithing requirements can make the givers destitute.
• How "using the Bible to interpret the Bible" ends up distorting our ability to see the Bible as a collection of different books with often opposing messages.
• The dynamic of church leaders expecting you to follow their convictions, and then after they move on or die, the next church leaders expect you to follow their different convictions.
• "Waking up" and realizing that our prayers are going to a non-existent character, that the Bible is nonsense, and that Christianity is as good as fairy tales.
• Realizing it's our faith that is propelling Christianity, not a real god.
• The ways many Christian denominations fight against evolution, despite the overwhelming scientific evidence.
• The experience of admitting to ourselves that we had fallen for significant logical fallacies when we were Christians.
• The important contributions of Earl Doherty (author, "The Jesus Puzzle: Did Christianity Begin with a Mythical Christ?" and "Jesus: Neither God Nor Man - The Case for a Mythical Jesus")
• The ways that "consensus" berates and shuns those who don't agree with them, and how their failure to address critical and relevant questions, and instead just dismiss them, leads people to more easily see the failures of the consensus and to continue on to better questions and research.
• Learning to see the Gospels as re-writes of Old Testament stories.
• How the books "The Ascension of Isaiah" and "Enoch" affected the origins of Christianity.
• How the destruction of the Temple in 70 AD was a large impetus behind the creation of early Christianity.
• The question of whether ancient Rome had any part to play in the origins of Christianity.
• Trying to understand how early Christianity, where the Jesus story was a parable, got turned into a historicized story.
• How to view Christianity and other Christians after we have deconverted.
 

Unending thanks to Neil for his studies and for sharing his fantastic insights with us as we work to understand the true origins of Christianity.

______________________________________

episodes.title: Monica Dux: As hard as I tried, god NEVER felt real to me.
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Monica Dux, a writer, social commentator, and columnist in Australia.  We discussed her experience growing up Catholic, and even wanting to be a nun, before she eventually deconverted.

We touched on many topics, including:

• Seeing the Jesus character "repackaged" after Vatican II.
• Wanting to feel god's presence, but never actually having any sense that he was real.
• Being afraid of purgatory and hell.
• The consuming ideas of confession and of purging your soul.
• Going through various motions to show piety and devotion to god, including giving things up for him, so that there will be some kind of positive response from god.
• How stricter, ritualistic versions of Catholicism and other religions are very similar to tribal animism.
• How repetition as a child creates an imprint on your mind and worldview, and the importance of stopping childhood indoctrination.
• How ex-communication and god's "get out of jail free cards" work in Catholicism.
• The strange way that the god character in the Bible seems able to be easily duped and manipulated.
• The fact that many people in the church don't actually know why they're doing what they're doing, even when the rituals and actions they do are bizarre.
• How religion is mostly about power and control.
• How trying to "feel" god when he's truly not there is like trying to fall in love with someone that you just don't love.
• How the church tries to dictate perspectives on sexuality, masturbation, pleasure, and family planning.
• How the choice to reject religion is, at the same time, a choice to embrace something positive and wonderful.
• The way the church instills in you that you are sinful and unworthy.
• How deconversion is like an unraveling of belief that takes time to walk through and recover from, as we reclaim our identity and move past religious baggage.

Thanks to Monica for sharing her fascinating story and journey!
 
_________________________________

episodes.title: Steve Hilliker: "God was supremely important in my life until I realized: HE DOESN’T EXIST"
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Steve Hilliker, the creator and host of the podcast "Voices of Deconversion."

We had an open dialogue about various topics as we talked through the highlights of his deconversion from Christianity, touching on topics such as:

• The fear-based love of Christianity.
• Believing in the Rapture, Tribulation, and 2nd coming of Jesus.
• Repeatedly rededicating his life to god to make sure it was real and that he was "definitely" saved
• The cycle of thinking you want/need god, and then sinning, so realizing you want/need god even more to resolve the sin issue, and then sinning again/more, so wanting god even more, ultimately going to more and more extremes to please him.
• The cycle of shame that is wrapped up in the pretend relationship that Christians think they have with the god character.
• How Christianity pounds into your mind that you are the problem--because the problem cannot be god, the Bible, or the Christian worldview.
• The ways that Christianity has the god character watching you and seeing inside your head, and constantly judging you.
• The idea that you are nothing without god.
• The idea that apostates are worse than those who have never heard the Gospel yet.
• The ways that early church councils decided on what was "orthodox" based on majority rule, power struggles, and infighting.
• The idea of asking god to do whatever it takes--deprive us of good things, of our dreams, etc.--to make us holy.
• The experience of constantly hoping to "hear" from god and never hearing from him--and doubling down on our efforts to hear from him.
• The idea that god can only "use" you if he "breaks" you first.
• The Christian mentality of quiverfull, being fruitful and multiplying, and of outbreeding the pagans.
• The idea of god "coming into your story" when you are at your weakest/lowest point--and what it does to people when they feel like god never showed up in those dark times of life.
• The way that Bible discrepancies as well as varying interpretations of Biblical doctrines, evolution, etc., can help start the deconstruction process.
• How people can slowly get fed up with believing in an illogical fantasy world.
• The fact that there have been many stories of dying and rising gods, and that Christianity doesn't look at all like the original, but a story that emerged out of other worldviews and stories/holy books.
• How learning about the formation of the Bible / canonicity helps advance deconstruction.
• The emotions of falling in love with the god/Jesus characters and then realizing they have never been real.
• The ways that Christian apologists are extreme charlatans.
• How Christians ignore comparative mythology and the history of the Levant around the several hundred years around the time that Christianity formed.
• Facing the moral atrocities of the Old Testament and the Yahweh character, and admitting that the Yahweh character is a tyrant.
• Being "unequally yoked," where a Christian is married to someone who is no longer a believer.
• Reclaiming your identity after deconversion, especially regarding your moral compass and your strengths.
• How to begin healing from religious trauma, especially embracing reality when you've been sold a fantasy.
• Why the Christian delusion is so toxic for our world.
 

Thanks to Steve for his Voices of Deconversion podcast, and all the ways he helps the deconstructing and deconverting community.

______________________________________

episodes.title: Betsy Wecker: "Jesus Camp" was my childhood in a nutshell.
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Betsy Wecker, who grew up in an Assemblies of God Church but eventually deconverted after the stories and ideology of the Christian cult slowly fell apart.

As we walked through her story, we touched on many points, including:

• Feeling lied to by Christianity and the church, and being left wondering what's actually real.
• Dealing with resentment and anger over the deception that occurred.
• How Christianity demonizes the "self" and self-love.
• Unpacking the idea that we should love god/Jesus more than our family.
• How Christian teachings lead people to be afraid of being left behind in the Rapture and of demonic activity.
• Going on cringy mission trips as teenagers, and the constant pursuit of the "mountaintop experience."
• Repeatedly expressing faith in Jesus out of fear that it was not real the first time.
• How Christianity uses hell as a very powerful motivator and realizing, as Christians, that most of the people who have ever lived are in hell or headed there.
• How learning more about the history of Christianity, world religions in general, and evolution helps to deconstruct Christianity.
• How existential crises cause deconstruction to pick up speed.
• How deconversion is, for some people, a gradual letting go, instead of a specific moment or day.
• Admitting the ridiculousness and arrogance of thinking we had all the answers when we were Christians.
• Realizing Christianity is a bizarre blood magic human sacrifice death cult.
• The idea of how questioning god or discrepancies was never encouraged, and Christians are instead asked to just believe and trust.
• Deconstructing the disturbing idea of how "blessed" Christians are, especially in America, while kids elsewhere are starving to death or dying of disease by the thousands each day, as if we have some kind of special favor from Yahweh while millions endure horrible suffering.
• Realizing that the Yahweh character is psychopathic and narcissistic in the ways he acts and in his nonstop demand to be worshipped.
• How purity culture / shame culture leaves you feeling cut off from your own body.
• How virginity culture leaves those who have lost their virginity feeling like "damaged goods."
• How purity culture treats women to be responsible for men's thoughts, and to avoid being a temptation and stumbling block to men.
• Escaping the darkness of Christianity and the subsequent peace and thriving that occurs when we deconvert from Christianity.
 
Many thanks to Betsy for sharing her story and for her openness in dealing with difficult topics.

______________________________________

episodes.title: Von & Howard Hanshaw: "We preached the Gospel to thousands, and then we realized it was mythology."
episodes.description:
C/W + T/W: Childhood abuse, rape

_____________________________________

Today I spoke with Von Hanshaw and Howard Hanshaw, brothers who were pastors, evangelists, authors, and involved in many ministries before they investigated the claims and origins of Christianity and the Bible in depth, and eventually deconverted.

After talking through their background and introduction to ministry, we discussed:

• The heavy influence of Jimmy Swaggart in their lives, due to their ignorance and the emotionalism of that branch of Christianity.
• Feeling the call early in life to a preaching ministry.
• The way that the church uses fear tactics to keep people in the cult of Christianity.
• Realizing that Christianity was a lie, and that despite being sincere, Christians are sincerely wrong in proclaiming the Bible and Christianity as true.
• Grieving the loss of time lost to Christianity, and dealing with the shame of preaching Jesus and the Bible during our time in the cult.
• The way brainwashing into Christianity includes trauma bonding and Stockholm syndrome toward the psychopathic Yahweh character.
• The unfairness of the exclusivity of the Christian gospel, in light of most people on the planet never ever even hearing about Jesus.
• Realizing when you're not alone in your skepticism, and that there are actually many other who are also seriously examining the claims of Christianity.
• The ways Christians hope everyone else will question their own worldviews, but Christians won't seriously question their own because they "know" they alone have the truth.
• The ways that the characters of Christianity are based on characters in older mythologies.
• The fact that the Bible is fallible, errant, and was heavily influenced by religious and political leaders, and by scribes.
• The fact that Christianity is a blood magic death cult focused on human sacrifice and scapegoating.
• The ways that Christians treat those who deconvert as traitors, and respond with attacks or shunning.
• How the Christian teaching on scapegoating through Jesus is just a form of not dealing with personal responsibility.
 
Thanks to Von and Howard for sharing their amazing story!

**Also, my apologies for messing up their last name at the beginning of the interview.

episodes.title: Sherrie D'Souza: "I escaped from the Jehovah's Witnesses cult"
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Sherrie D'Souza, one of the board members at Recovering from Religion, and one of the founders of the first support group in Sydney, Australia.

We talked through her story, touching on topics including:

• Being deeply indoctrinated and sheltered from an early age.
• The beliefs of the Jehovah's Witnesses regarding Armageddon and the coming Kingdom of God.
• The craftiness of the ways the JW church shifts it story of when Jehovah will return.
• The extremely patriarchal mentality of JWs.
• The apocalyptic perspective, especially in light of the book of Revelation, that pervades the JW worldview.
• The path of being a Kingdom Publisher, and eventually a Pioneer, where a JW does lots of door-to-door preaching.
• The guilt trip of non-believer's blood being "on your hands" if you fail to witness.
• Paranoia over Satan and demonic activity or influence.
• The overwhelming control that the JW leadership has over its members.
• The dynamic of resisting higher education that is prevalent in the JW church.
• The punishments, including disfellowship and shunning, that the JW church uses to punish people who question the faith.
• The extreme quantity of sexual abuse cases in the JW church, and the horrific ways the JW church has covered it up for years.
• The experience of "realizing you're an apostate" once deconversion occurs, and the sympathy you develop for those who have already deconverted before you but who received little or no sympathy from you or others.
• Dealing with the ways that believers write off those who have deconverted and treat them as traitors who are disloyal to Jehovah.
• Starting to rethink our identities after deconversion, and finding out who we are apart from mythology.
• Recovering from religion and the complexities of religious trauma.
• How indoctrination of children is a form of psychological child abuse.
• The importance of getting support through the process of becoming skeptical and deconstructing religion.
 
Many thanks to Sherrie for sharing her amazing story!

episodes.title: Christ Church Rampant: Why Mythology and Patriarchy are a VERY bad mix
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Kevin McGill about the extreme patriarchy, abuses, and overall dynamics at Christ Church, a cult led by Doug Wilson, located in Moscow, Idaho.

We touched on many topics including:

• The importance of religious freedom.
• Why it's so important to speak up if someone is using theology to cause active harm, especially to the vulnerable.
• How bad religion can be worse than no religion.
• The ways that Christ Church (CC) is a cult and Doug Wilson (DW) is a cult leader.
• The dangers of the extreme patriarchy and misogyny exhibited by CC and DW.
• The issue of marital rape that naturally arises from the teachings of a cult like CC.
• The danger of having structures of leadership that protect the power of men, at the expense of women, especially in cases where abuse is happening.
• The danger of cults, especially those which believe that a literal kingdom led by the Jesus character is coming, and that Christians are obligated to be involved in establishing that kingdom.
• The nature of toxic masculinity, and why it is so critical that we make it clear that no one should be submissive to an abuser.
• The nature of the emotional and spiritual abuse done by church leaders in the name of god.
• The need to have courageous empathy instead of sweeping issues under the rug.
• The tension between believing in redemption and forgiveness for people who have committed grievous and abusive acts, and yet protecting those who have been harmed.
• The dangers and horrors of brainwashing and indoctrinating children into a cult worldview.
• The need to speak up in the fight against toxic worldviews and highly controlling cultic groups.
• How to begin to heal from spiritual abuse and thrive again, while respecting that forgiveness takes time and must be accompanied by appropriate boundaries for the abuser.
• How solidarity and courage can bring down corrupt structures.

Separately, I added about 30 minutes of solo commentary at the end, from the perspective of atheism and the reality that Christianity is mythology.

Many thanks to Kevin for his courage, his desire to speak truth, and his willingness to stand up against abusive cults.
