episodes.title: Cheryl Marella: "My worth doesn't come from the pretend god of the Bible."
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with TV anchor and radio personality Cheryl Marella, who grew up exposed to Catholicism first, then Protestantism and being "born again," before she began her deconstruction and eventual deconversion from Christianity.

We covered many topics, including:

• Seeing her parents get "born again" and how other family members got pressured to do the same.
• Experiencing a barrage of Christian events that were designed to indoctrinate.
• Growing up under a strict and fierce preacher.
• Being told that god intends for you to suffer a lot as part of his master plan.
• How transforming our minds away from religion helps us to thrive.
• How patriarchy, especially from religion, creates a stifling and toxic environment, but is accepted, even by women, due to extensive brainwashing.
• How a lot of faith is based on fear of punishment and hell.
• Grappling with the experience of sincerely wanting god to feel real to you, but never actually feeling his presence or feeling like the teachings make any significant difference to your life experience.
• Realizing during deconstruction that we don't agree with the Bible's bizarre morality anymore.
• Working through how Christianity denigrates people's self-worth and teaches us we are broken without the psychotic and bloodthirsty Yahweh character.
• Healing from the injunction to submit -- to the Bible, to the mythological Yahweh character, to church leadership, and (for women) to men.
• The dynamic of Christians feeling like they should have a platform and a strong voice, but that others who disagree with them should have their platform diminished or silenced.
• Dealing with anger after we deconvert, as we realize others who were steeped in mythology were dominating our lives and decisions for many years.
• Realizing that sexuality and pleasure are beautiful and healthy parts of life, especially as we remove shame and "dirtiness" from our worldviews.
• Grappling with the reality that years of brainwashing cannot be undone quickly, and searching for the many roots of religious ideas that are deep in our psyches.
• Learning to own the process of reclaiming our identity and the life skill of loving ourselves just as we are, apart from the god character and the Bible's false messages.
• Dealing with the (often) total lack of compassion from Christians.
• Learning to live in the present once you realize the afterlife is made up as part of mythology.
• Undo the damage of the teaching that we need to distrust ourselves, and instead trust the Yahweh character, with his capricious, bizarre, psychopathic, narcissistic, bloodthirsty nature.
• Deconstructing the teachings of the eternal, infinite, conscious torture of hell over finite sins.
• How Christians think they are on the right path and everyone else is fringe, even though they are extremely fringe, compared to reality.
• How to begin healing from religious trauma.
• How dealing with friends who are still stuck in the Bible prison feels like a nonstop battle.
• The importance of pursuing the truth, regardless of where it takes us.
 
Many thanks to Cheryl for sharing her story, and for the many ways she reminds us to get empowered, educated, inspired, to love ourselves, and to awaken as many people as possible of the importance of self-improvement.

episodes.title: HARMONIC ATHEIST - John Lundwall: How to tackle life's deep questions, in light of mythology
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with author, teacher, and astronomer Dr. John Lundwall, who does an amazing job unraveling the epistemology of oral cultures and the creation of ancient myths.

We had an informal dialogue on several topics, including:

• His time growing up in Mormonism and his recent departure from the Mormon faith.
• How ancient cultures created and passed on their mythologies.
• How human beings think, with and without writing.
• How every culture reinterprets their ancient stories--repeatedly--especially when they change from an oral to a literate society.
• The fact that oral societies did not have a word for religion, and how the concept evolved into the "oaths and ordinances of the cult of the state."
• How the horrors of the OT are political action using religion as a justification.
• How oral societies have a completely different epistemology than a literate society.
• How the base medium of oral societies is their cosmology - their observations of the sun, moon, planets, eclipses, and constellations.
• Why people feel betrayed when they realize their metaphysics does not correspond to reality, and how that dynamic creates an existential crisis.
• How ancient Israel's polytheism and henotheism was a result of their being an oral culture, and their literacy turned them to monotheism as it helped them codify their religion.
• How keeping an open mind requires us to accept ambiguity.

Many thanks to Dr. Lundwall for his amazing contributions in the area of astrotheology, epistemology, and comparative mythology.

episodes.title: Pablo Chaverri: How the church uses lies, fear, and guilt to control and manipulate
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Pablo Chaverri, who was raised Catholic, and even being groomed to become a priest, until he thought deeply about the background, content, and implications of the Christian faith, and ultimately deconverted from Christianity.

We talked about:

• How culture and social cognition shape our worldview and beliefs.
• How church leaders manipulate poor people through the demand of a tithe to the church in order to be blessed.
• The idea that when things go well in your life, it's because of god's blessing, but when things go badly, it's due to your lack of faith or because of demonic activity.
• How Catholic teachings on hell instill fear in children.
• The Catholic church's obsession with making young people ashamed over masturbation.
• The Catholic church's extreme and criminal abuse of children.
• How the Catholic church instills fear in believers with the fear of dying without unconfessed in.
• The psychological damage of forcing people to constantly search their hearts for secret/unconscious sins.
• How the Catholic church teaches followers that sex is mostly for procreation instead of for pleasure and enjoyment.
• How Christianity effectively teaches you to see god as a safety net and a magic charm.
• The ways that Christianity is a form of mental control, where the god character knows everything and can read your mind, and he requires you to think and act correctly, with full sincerity and no doubt, or he will be angry at you.
• The ways that even smart people can drop their critical thinking and start basing their thoughts on magic and superstition.
• The ways that Christians want to "feel" more than they want to think and analyze.
• Dealing with our intense desire for their to be hope beyond our physical life.
• How Christianity and its make-believe afterlife doctrine effectively keeps people from truly grieving when someone's death, because we are not truly grieving their one life, we are grieving as if it is temporary and we are going to see them again.
• The bizarreness of the teaching that the slaughter of an innocent person can resolve another person's guilt.
• How Christianity is a blood magic death cult.
• How Christianity is a cult of suffering.
• How skepticism and critical thinking, without any fear, is far better than faith.
• How Christianity uses guilt to manipulate people.
• The deeply disturbing psychological abuse that Christianity inflicts on children.
• The ways Christians act like they have hurt feelings, instead of choosing to embrace critical thinking, when the inconsistencies and contradictions of their worldview are exposed.
• How Christianity trains people in the habit of believing lies.
 
Thanks to Pablo for sharing his thoughts on all these topics, and for his great insights!  Keep it up!

episodes.title: Sasha Sagan: “For small creatures such as we, the vastness is bearable only through love.”
episodes.description:
Today I was honored to speak with author, television producer, and filmmaker Sasha Sagan.  

We briefly discussed several of her family stories, and then went on to chat about:

• The amazing gift parents can give to their children of letting them make their own faith choices.
• How traditions need to mutate in order to survive.
• How we use rituals to understand our world and process change.
• The role that the fear of the unknown and of things out of our control plays in shaping our worldview.
• How her parents had a similar influence on her, as well on as the "Eleanor Arroway" character that they created for their book "Contact."
• Working through our tendency to want things to keep going eternally in order for them to be beautiful, meaningful, and reassuring to us.
• How to create a positive culture about our mortality.
• The ways that religions censor information from believers that would otherwise keep them from deconverting.
• The idea that anything that's true can stand up to scrutiny.
• The importance of always being willing to follow new information and evidence.
• How we as humans look for--and create--patterns, and what we do with those patterns to make sense of our experience.
• The fact that we all are capable of deceiving ourselves.
• The importance of encouraging children to ask hard questions and pursue critical thinking as they discover the world--and being ok with not having all the answers.
• How the feeling of belonging can keep people in a faith community, even if they don't really believe the doctrines being taught.
• The dynamics of how those who have deconverted can be an existential threat to their prior religion.
• Learning to celebrate and enjoy sexuality and to relinquish religious shame.

Many thanks to Sasha for her book, her stories and insights, her family's invaluable impact on our world, as well as her positive impact on the secular and atheist communities!

episodes.title: HARMONIC ATHEIST - Jonathan MS Pearce: The Resurrection: A Critical Examination of the Easter Story
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with author Jonathan M.S. Pearce about his new book "The Resurrection: A Critical Examination of the Easter Story."

As we dove into his book, we touched on many aspects of the story of the resurrection of Jesus, including:

• The elitist side of Christian apologetics, where apologists say that only if you study hard enough can you find the truth of how the atonement truly works.
• The competing theories of atonement, including penal substitution.
• Blood magic, Yom Kippur, and the Pascal lamb.
• The moral culpability of the god character, who supposedly created the world with divine foreknowledge, yet his creation is a big mess theologically.
• How god is burning most humans just to go to hell (or be annihilated).
• The dynamic that stunningly extraordinary and exceptional claims require stunningly extraordinary and exceptional evidence.
• The special pleading and begging that Christians do regarding the claims of the Gospels regarding the Resurrection, especially in light of prior probability, such as the way that Christians reject the claims of other similar Greco-Roman mystery cults while still claiming Christian claims are legitimate.
• How the Gospels are written in unknown places, at unknown times, by unknown authors--none of whom were eyewitnesses--with ex-post-facto agendas, making claims to people who, at the time, did not verify the claims, and had no way of verifying them.
• How the "historical methods" used by the Gospels is exceptionally poor.
• The fact that the NT writers had an agenda.
• Realizing that Christians cannot imagine that the Resurrection might be simply "made up," even though the evidence overwhelmingly points that way.
• Terror management: how Christians cannot rationally debate or analyze the claims and details of the NT, because they cannot handle the implications, which threaten their hope of an afterlife and their overall worldview.
• Why we need to accept explanations that are most probable versus those that make claims which have no evidence and fall apart logically.
• How childhood indoctrination sets us up to analyze the world based on what we're taught, versus what is probable, and how we can do it with other religions, but not our own.
• How we are programmed to believe our elders.
• The dangers of taking ideas "on faith," which amounts to belief without evidence.
• How Christians claim that their evidence is much better than it really is.
• How every single Gospel claim is problematic and easily challenged.
• Realizing that while we were stuck in Christianity we were blind to its bizarreness, such as the doctrine of transubstantiation, where we "eat the flesh and drink the blood" of our demigod.
• How our dread of death and fears of mortality drive us to "need" the story of the resurrection to be true.
• How the Bible's god character creates a façade of being a stabilizing and protective psychological function that "fills the void."
• The reality that absence of evidence for extraordinary claims DOES mean evidence of absence, if evidence never appears.
• The fact that Paul provides almost no details about the resurrection, and that the Gospels introduce later embellishments to the early versions of the Resurrection story.
• How the dynamics of apocalypticism and messianism could have mixed with the disappointment, grief, anger, and guilt of early Christians in order for them to come up with the Resurrection mythology.
• How the Resurrection is "theology with an agenda," but not history.
• The fact that we believe because of indoctrination and societal pressure, not because we've truly studied the evidence.
• Rebuilding our identities and worldview, and learning to celebrate life, after we realize that the resurrection stories are mythological.
• And much more!

Thanks to Jonathan for his amazing insights and for helping us to see that the stories of Christianity are not history.

episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Jennifer Fernandez, who shared her story growing up in a conservative, fundamentalist Christian environment before going through the long and painful process of deconstructing and leaving Christianity.

Throughout the interview, we touched on:

• Enduring the personal oppressive holiness culture of Calvary Chapel.
• Saying the "sinners prayer" repeatedly to be sure she was saved.
• Fear of being "left behind" if the Rapture occurred and she was not saved.
• Fear over demonic influences.
• The dynamics of Christian homeschooling, including sheltering and protecting kids from worldly ideas, especially evolution.
• How living in an area where most everyone is a Christian makes it easier to ignore the moral problems of the god character allowing others to burn in hell forever.
• Constantly second guessing ourselves as Christians.
• Shame and guilt over struggling to "remain pure."
• Being exposed to the cultish teachings of Bill Gothard.
• The mentality behind the quiverfull movement and the desire to "outbreed the pagans."
• The pressure to speak in tongues.
• How Christian authority figures create security, while at the same time instilling a fear of listening to anyone else.
• Guilt over not going to church anymore, and the anxiety and shame over leaving the faith.
• Fear over the early steps of deconstruction and where the hard questions might be leading.
• No longer believing that a loving god could send people to burn in hell for all eternity.
• Going through deconstruction in isolation, without any support or other people to talk to about it.
• Dealing with the issue of homosexuality as a conservative evangelical Christian.
• Beginning to question the Bible's inerrancy.
• How the Bible's message is unclear and confusing.
• Realizing the neurological dynamics happening inside the brains of religious believers.
• How deconverting can shake us up as we realize the implications, but also frees us and gives us peace.
• The identity crisis that deconversion presents to us, as we realize that our identity was caught up in a pretend god and our focus was wrapped up in a mythological worldview.
• The role of good therapy in healing from religious trauma and reclaiming our identity after deconversion.
• Adjusting to realizing there's probably no afterlife.
 
Thanks to Jennifer for sharing her story, and for the many insights she has been sharing with the community, especially regarding deconversion, purity culture, Christian homeschooling, and deconstructing while being focused on motherhood and family.  You are a huge encouragement, Jennifer!

episodes.title: HARMONIC ATHEIST - Keith Giles: Deconstructing Bad Theology in the Church
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Keith Giles, an author, blogger, podcaster, and teacher who focuses on the dynamics of deconstruction.

We talked through his story growing up Southern Baptist and eventually becoming a pastor, when he started to analyze his beliefs and reassess his worldview.  We touched on various topics, such as:

• God's wrath, penal substitution, eternal conscious torment, universal salvation, and the nature of the Gospel.
• The history of canonicity, including the colorful and shaky history of how the canon came to be, and how there are various canons, even today.
• The fact that many church fathers included books in the canon that many of us have never read or heard of, such as: the Didache, the Shepherd of Hermes, the Book of Baruch, Jubilees, the Letter of Jeremiah, and Enoch.  They also did not include all the books that were later added to the canon.
• How to overcome the fear of asking hard questions and analyzing the faith we were taught as children.
• Dealing with ostracization and loss of community when Christian family and friends realize you are deconstructing.
• Respecting others who don't agree with where we "land" during our deconstruction, i.e., people who remain in theism in some way vs. those who see no evidence for any gods.
• The toxicity that can occur in certain theological constructs, and how to deal with loved ones who are still proponents of teachings we are strongly opposed to.
• The pagan parallels and source stories that were used to create the Jesus character, such as Dionysius, Homer's epics, Pythagoras, the Zodiac (in the Gospel of Mark), Josephus, Plutarch, etc.
• Realizing that each of us is probably not done changing our perspectives and worldview, even if we've already changed a lot, and how that realization helps us to be more patient and gracious with others.

Many thanks to Keith for the great questions he's always bringing to the table, the graciousness he shows to people who disagree with him, and his compassion for people who are deconstructing and reclaiming their identities as they reshape their worldviews and heal from religious trauma.

episodes.title: Ralph Ellis: Why are so many famous biblical characters MISSING from the historical record?
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Ralph Ellis, a historian and author who has spent more than three decades searching for secular similarities and parallels between the disciplines of history and theology. 

We briefly discussed his background, and then dove into many topics, including:

• How the Hebrews were actually the Hyksos, who did exit Egypt and conquer Canaan.
• How the Garden of Eden was based on the Egyptian garden of Aten, and the fascinating history of Pharaoh Akhenaten and Queen Nefertiti, who were major players in the move toward monotheism, as they worshipped Aten, the sun disc.
• The fact that neither the characters of Jesus and Paul are not attested in the historical record, and what that implies regarding the major cover-up of their true identities, including the kingdom of Edessa.
• How the Gospels and Acts represent historical events and people, but 40 years later than Christians are taught.
• The theological and academic blindness that keeps people from seeing alternatives to what they've been taught, and how the issue is not just what people DON'T know, but what they WON'T know.

Many thanks to Ralph for the many ways he sheds light on important issues and shares insightful historical connections.  His work inspires me more than ever to dig into history.

episodes.title: HARMONIC ATHEIST - Will Thorpe: An apostate examines the bible and the claims of Christians
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Will Thorpe, who was a Christian for 20 years before his deconversion and the launch of his platform, Heretical Theology.

We touched on various topics and parts of his story, including:

• Growing up in a Methodist environment.
• Attending and being a counselor at Abstinence Camp,
• Hearing god's voice and knowing his will, especially regarding going into ministry.
• Working through marriage where one spouse deconverts a while before the other.
• Going through a deconstruction himself later.
• Experiencing the early part of deconstruction with the expectation that "god" is going to fill in the gaps and resolve the issues, such that the end expectation was of a stronger Christian faith--not a deconversion.
• Helping the church to understand that there are parts of their theology that are fundamentally dangerous to humanity.
• Seeing the sexist side of church up-close.
• Knowing the Bible inside and out, and yet not believing anymore.
• Hearing the perspectives of atheists and textual critics, which fueled the deconstruction process.
• Acknowledging that there are good things that the church does on the surface, but that doesn't rescue it from all the evil that it does.
• Learning to love your spouse for who they really are, not for their faith and theology, or lack thereof.
• Exemplifying the importance of "unequally yoked" spouses loving and truly listening to each other.
• Experiencing how the "light bulb" comes on in our minds when we allow the possibility that the Bible is full of errors.
• Realizing that elaborate Christian rationalizations and harmonizations don't actually work.
• Facing the conundrum of whether we have satisfactory answers to the discrepancies and issues of the Bible, or whether the alternative is more likely.
• Seeing the ridiculousness of how hard Christians try to ignore the pagan parallels of Jesus to the earlier Greco-Roman mystery cults.
• Noticing that the Christian worldview creates a susceptibility to conspiracy theories.
• Dealing with the cognitive dissonance of Christians who try to merge the Bible with science.
• Realizing how ignorant we were when we were Christians, and how much we lacked truth and reasoning when we were stuck in it.
• Seeing how Christian views of sexuality try to make us guilty of thought crimes.

Thanks to Will for all he does on the Heretical Theology platform, especially the ways he helps people to heal and thrive after deconversion.

episodes.title: HARMONIC ATHEIST - Matthew Distefano: "I can't worship that god any longer."
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Matthew Distefano, a hip-hop artist, author, podcaster at the "Heretic Happy Hour" and "All Set Free," and a regular contributor for the blog "Unfundamentalist Christians."

We chatted briefly about his deconversion from Christianity, touching on many topics, including:

• The fear of being left behind during the Rapture and of committing the unpardonable sin.
• Contemplating the implications and dynamics of hell/eternal conscious torment.
• Struggling with defining god as "good" if he forces eternal hell on sinners, including the horrors of election, where god picks some of his children to eternal glory and some to eternal punishment.
• The experiential absurdities of Christian beliefs.
• How people craft their theology based on false assumptions.
• Realizing that other people's theologies have no power over us.
• Deciding that you can't let ideas that you find harmful go unaddressed.
• The grief cycle and raw emotions of deconstruction.
• Working through the shunning process that occurs when you leave your prior faith.
• Why some people "look behind the curtain," and others simply refuse to.
• Admitting that you can't just choose to believe something that you find unbelievable.
• How you can't go back, and "unsee what you've seen," once you've truly deconstructed.
• The dynamics of Christians disowning their loved ones who deconstruct/deconvert, and not digging into the reasons they left.
• Understanding Girard's mimetic theory about why ancient cultures were ritualistic and sacrificial.
• How Protestant Christianity does not teach the history of the development of Christianity.
• How understanding the "pagan" parallels and non-Biblical sources of the Bible stories helps us to deconstruct and take more of a historian's perspective.
• Learning to live in the moment to live out your humanness, regardless of your beliefs.


Many thanks to Matthew for sharing his story and perspectives with us today, and for all that he does for the community!

episodes.title: HARMONIC ATHEIST - Jessica Zeno: Walking away from the bizarre and abusive teachings of Christianity
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Jessica Zeno, who shared her story of growing in a household of "born again" Christians until she researched the origins of Christianity and thought through its philosophical implications.

As we discussed her journey, we touched on:

• Dealing with the frightening fire-and-brimstone threat of hell as children.
• Learning to loathe ourselves and see ourselves as worthless due to the theology we are taught in church, and how that leaves people feeling never "good enough."
• How the book of Revelation is used to instill fear.
• How seeing the "double life" of pastors and church leaders helps to shake our faith.
• The details of Jesus' genealogy and birth containing discrepancies--thus the story falling apart from the beginning.
• Being accused of demon possession and even kicked out of churches because of becoming skeptical of the Christian story.
• Going through a form of Stockholm syndrome regarding Christianity.
• The ways that the Christian experience robs us of the ability to have an identity and to know who we really are, in and of ourselves, apart from Christianity.
• How Christianity makes people co-dependent on a character who doesn't even exist.
• How Judaism and Christianity borrowed ancient Egyptian and Greek stories to create much of the Biblical narrative.
• How the Yahweh character is originally part of a Canaanite pantheon of gods.
• The disillusionment the occurs as we realize that the Bible's stories are mythological.
• Facing the horrific teachings (genocide, slavery, land theft, child brides, forced dust water abortions, etc.) of the Bible honestly and head-on. 
• Realizing that childhood indoctrination into Christianity is psychological child abuse.
• How the Bible severely distorts what real love is about, where disobedience or a lack of faith results in torture.
• Discovering that if the god character were real, we would realize he had made huge mistakes by making Satan, putting a temptation in the garden, and drowning everyone in the flood.
• The myriad ways that the Bible is misogynistic, and how surprising it is that Christian women defend a book that treats women so poorly.
• How Christianity is a form of emotional manipulation that uses fear and intimidation to try to control people.
• Enjoying freedom from Christian mythology and its bizarre teachings.
• Healing and becoming emotionally strong and secure after deconversion.
• Learning to tune out the Christian message and listen to ourselves.

Thanks to Jessica for sharing her story and heart with us today.  You were an inspiration on many levels!

____________________________________

episodes.title: HARMONIC ATHEIST - Ben Urban: Breaking down toxic paradigms
episodes.description:
Today I Interviewed Ben Urban, who grew up exposed to cultural Christianity, but eventually made it his own faith and became a Christian.  After going to seminary in preparation for ministry, he got exposed to the darker sides of Christianity, and his deconstruction began.

As we unpacked his story, we talked about:

• Feeling called to go to seminary and become a pastor
• Being exposed to Southern Baptist theology and ideology, especially their focus on hell and their fight against homosexuality.
• The absurdity of God choosing some people for heaven and letting the rest go to hell.
• How spending time in the Bible made it more clear that something with that worldview is wrong.
• Realizing that Christianity is a cult.
• Rethinking the teaching on hell.
• Starting to question everything.
• The closed-mindedness of conservative evangelical Christianity.
• How education should teach you how to think, not what to think.
• Realizing that the Bible is not inerrant.
• How Christians are into fringe ideas like blood magic.
• The bizarreness of the Bible's teaching about how to create potions made of dust water to cause a forced abortion, and about dashing babies heads against rocks.
• How Christianity borrowed heavily from the book of Enoch and syncretized from Zoroastrianism and other religions.
• How Christianity arbitrarily picked certain parts of its mythology to declare "orthodox."
• The dynamics of spiritual humanism.
• The beauty of teaching our children to explore the world and existence without threatening them with eternal punishment if they don't agree with our worldview.
• The emotional fallout that sometimes accompanies deconstruction.
• Recovering our identity after breaking down toxic paradigms.
• The importance of thinking for ourselves.
• How amazing community is when it is inclusive.
• Becoming a catalyst for others to have the bravery to escape religion.

Thanks to Ben for sharing his story and for what he does every day to inspire and challenge the community!

episodes.title: HARMONIC ATHEIST - Janice Selbie: Healing and Thriving after Divorcing Religion
episodes.description:
**Apologies for the audio issues at points in the interview.

______________________________________

Today I spoke with Janice Selbie, a registered professional counsellor and religious recovery consultant.  She hosts workshops called Divorcing Religion, as well as the Conference On Religious Trauma.

As we talked through her story together, touching on these aspects of her story and of the resulting insights:

• Growing up and seeing other family members walk away from Christianity and determining to stay faithful to the Lord.
• The dynamics of multi-generational brainwashing.
• Legalistic Bible teachings regarding women being submissive to men and modestly dressed, and to fit in the roles assigned by the church.
• Being exposed to the Holdeman Mennonite community.
• How the ability to strictly obey the rules of church can lead to pride and a sense of being close to the Lord.
• The anti-feminist perspectives of Christianity.
• The negative ways that women are influenced by viewing their husbands as their god-given leader, and that god would speak to the men to give guidance for the family.
• How community bubbles , especially conservative Christianity, create fundamentalist echo chambers.
• How homeschooling plays into the Christian goal of protecting children from "the world."
• How seeds of doubt and discontent get sown.
• How child getting a life-threatening diagnosis affects our view of god.
• How negative life situations, disillusionment, and mourning the loss of our dreams can help plant seeds of doubt.
• The strange experience of realizing that stepping away from Christianity is healthier than being in it.
• The difference that support groups make to the deconversion process.
• Realizing, after deconversion, that Christianity is truly a cult.
• Moving past deconversion to being able to assist others with the healing process.
• The pain, trauma, and isolation that occurs after the disillusion of our Christian beliefs and Christian identity.
• The losses that occur from walking away from the faith ideologies of our families and communities.
• How to build a secular life that is healthy, happy, and fulfilling.
• Balancing freedom and responsibility after we deconvert.
• How to deal with Christians who remain insensitive and who cannot understand the grieving process of those who deconvert.
• The importance of having someone to talk through the post-deconversion season.
• How to address triggers that come to deconverted Christians from Christians who have not deconverted yet.
• How religion causes us to give up our autonomy and agency.
• The importance of protecting our mental health.
• The tendency to leave fundamental Christianity but not leave a fundamentalism mindset, where we feel the need to "make others pay" when they don't think just like us.
• The importance of those of us who have already deconverted to help those who are being disenfranchised.
• How tragedy works to shake people free from their cognitive dissonance and to give people permission and courage to doubt.
• The importance of graciousness as we realize that other people are trying very hard to protect their fragile belief system and to protect their worldview at all costs.
• How, to a fundamentalist, any cause can seem like a holy cause, if we're desperate enough
• The importance of focusing our energy mostly on helping those who are deconverting, instead of on fighting with fundamentalists.
• How indoctrinating children into Christianity is a form of psychological abuse, and how Christian doctrines prey on children's best instincts.
• The importance of stopping the group religious delusions of Christianity that have saturated in our culture.
• How Christianity preys on the vulnerable and becomes a replacement addiction for their other addictions.
• The importance of honoring our grief, and of learning to rebuild ourselves and reclaim our identity after deconversion.
• Getting the right tools to thrive in the next chapter of life after deconversion.
 

Many thanks to Janice for sharing her story, as well as for her amazing work as she helps the community at large, as well as individuals, in the deconstruction and healing journey.  I look forward to speaking with Janice again and hearing more of her heart in these crucial arenas.
 

______________________________________

Today I spoke with Neil Bernstein, a.k.a. "Neil the 604 Atheist."

We had a casual chat about various topics, including:

• His childhood, growing up in a moderately Jewish home.
• The path of questioning former beliefs. 
• Giving up on the idea of an all-powerful deity.
• The bizarre morality and atrocities of the Bible.
• The fact of evolution.
• The realization that this life is "it" and that we won't be reunited with people in some kind of afterlife.

• How recent American politics is giving people more reasons to escape the Christian worldview.
• The dynamics of religious shunning.

• How to deal graciously with family and friends that are still stuck in theism.
• How future technologies and scientific discoveries could help eliminate religion.
• The need to empower more atheists to create a platform and use their voices to make a difference.


Many thanks to Neil for sharing some of his story with me today.  I applaud him very highly for the tremendous efforts he puts into helping those who are deconstructing, and to the atheist community as a whole.

episodes.title: HARMONIC ATHEIST - Summer Biby: "I Studied My Way Out of Christianity"
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Summer Biby, a mother of four and fellow YouTuber who grew up in Pentecostal Christianity but eventually deconverted after diving into the philosophical and historical issues of the Bible and the Christian worldview.

We discussed many aspects of Summer's story, from upbringing through deconversion, touching on many topics along the way, including:

• The reality distortions propagated by Pentecostalism.
• The negative influence of King James Only-ism.
• The very shaky ground of canonicity and church "history".
• Growing up fearful of dying with unconfessed sin that could "condemn us to hell."
• The cracks in the theological structures we Christians grew up with.
• The teaching on depravity that is behind our need for the "gospel."
• How Christian parents sow in their kids' hearts the untruth that they are intrinsically broken.
• How Christianity creates feelings of failure in believers, and then preys on those feelings.
• How Christianity teaches people to interpret internal dialogue and intuition as the Holy Spirit talking to us.
• Realizing that we have nothing to be "saved" from.
• The horror of the god character who creates people knowing they will be tortured forever in hell.
• The bizarreness of clear teachings in the Bible that say God has favorites, i.e., people he has picked and loved, and others he has not picked and therefore hated.
• The origins of the Yahweh character and the strangeness of his capricious jealousy.
• Being sheltered from reading non-Christian books during childhood.
• How Christianity borrowed from many other religions during its creation and evolution.
• The bizarreness of blood magic and of why it was acceptable to believe in "drinking his blood."
• How we see other gods as strange but ours as normal.
• The realization that "if others are indoctrinated, maybe I got indoctrinated too."
• How charismatic Christianity preys on people's desire to feel something special from god
• How Christianity preys on the needy
• How difficult it is to leave the community that you were deeply plugged into in Christianity.
• The negative effects of the purity culture and shame culture.
• The Christian dynamic of telling women they are responsible to diminish their curves and demeanor to not distract and tempt men.
• How deconversion hits us in waves as we realize the ways that theism has defined many parts of our worldview, and how we get to realize reality is entirely different than our old Christian construct.
• How Christians cherry pick topics in the Bible to obey and not obey, based on what is culturally acceptable.
• Realizing that religion is just the story of humans trying to figure out who god is--if there were a god--and not actually the story of any real god.
• How the church uses scare tactics, such as fear of god "cursing" us, to get people to fall in line with their authority.
• Losing the fear of the pretend deity.
• How to study our way out of faith.
• The powerlessness of the Bible and of the Christian message.
• Learning to stop seeing people as projects to fix and "save."
• How the synoptic problem of the gospels helps us see that the Bible has errors in it.
• How Christianity tries to teach its adherents to use circular reasoning.
• Being ok with not knowing all the answers.
• How deconversion from Christianity helps us to live in the moment and appreciate our lives more.
• How deconverting is like waking up from a bad dream.
• The need for slow and thorough healing from religious trauma and deception.
• The general dynamic of recovering from a religious worldview, and rebuilding from the ground up.


Thanks to Summer for her great contributions on her Youtube channel, and for sharing her heart in these matters during our interview today.  I look forward to doing  a follow-up interview with her.

episodes.title: Harmonic Atheist - Dr. Steve Mason: Josephus on Jesus & the Testimonium Flavianum
episodes.description:
Today I was honored to speak with Dr. Steve Mason, professor emeritus of Ancient Mediterranean Religions and Cultures at the University of Groningen.

We analyzed the Jewish historian Josephus' Testimonium Flavianum, starting with an introduction, touching on a few interpolation possibilities, and then going line by line through the Testimonium to understand what is and is not being said there, and how it fits into the larger context of the rest of Josephus' writings.  Throughout our conversation, Dr. Mason provides valuable insights about what conclusions may be warranted and which are assumptions, providing valuable guidance for how to stay on track as students of history.

Many thanks to Dr. Mason for his lifelong contributions toward Josephus studies, and for his presentation here today.  I am looking forward to digging deeper into these subjects soon!

episodes.title: I examined my old beliefs in a new light - Dr. Valerie Tarico
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Dr. Valerie Tarico, who is a psychologist, freelance advocate, social commentator, writer, and former evangelical promoting freethought and working to undermine the corrosive power of biblical literalism.  She is the author of "Trusting Doubt: A Former Evangelical Looks at Old Beliefs in a New Light," as well as two other books.

We talked briefly about her background, and then moved through various topics, including:

• How the Christian experience eventually feels like you're holding your beliefs together with "duct tape and bailing wire."
• How Christians try to gaslight those who deconvert by saying they hadn't actually been Christians or weren't truly committed to Jesus.
• The distastefulness, abusiveness, and self-serving ideas that stem from the belief that suffering is from god and should be seen as a good thing
• The common experience Christians have of repeatedly asking Jesus to save them, just to be sure it was real.
• How the ideas of personal failure, helplessness, self-recrimination, and judgment get bound up in the Gospel message of "divine love."
• How Christian theology triggers people who struggle with post-traumatic stress from their time brainwashed by Christian theology.
• How teaching kids about demons is like teaching them that there are monsters in the closet.
• How teaching kids about the end times/rapture concepts often instills in them a fear that they will be "left behind" in this world.
• Dealing with the fear of "hell."
• The leaps of logic and tweaking of reality that are part of the Christian worldview, which ultimately help us see its bizarreness.
• Dealing with our imperfect human processing and flaws in our ability to discern what is true.
• The real-world contingencies that govern our well-being.
• Confirmatory thinking and cognitive dissonance.
• The cultishness of Christianity.
• How compassion for others and anger over theodicy were core factors in her deconversion.
• The inexcusable cruelties of the Bible's Yahweh character.
• How to not "miss having a god" once we realize that the story is fabricated and mythological.
• How to help others work through religious indoctrination and trauma.
• The horrific idea that Christians in heaven will be blissfully indifferent to the torture happening in "hell."


Thanks to Dr. Tarico for her strong voice in these subjects, and for the ways she passionately makes a difference in our culture, as well as in the experience of individuals who are working through their deconversion and the process of creating of a healthy worldview.

episodes.title: HARMONIC ATHEIST - Interview with Bill Zuersher: Seeing Through Christianity
episodes.description:
Today I was honored to speak with Bill Zuersher, author of the book "Seeing Through Christianity: A Critique of Beliefs and Evidence," and one of the people who had a profound influence on my deconversion from Christianity.

Bill's passion stems from his observation of the ways that American culture has drifted to allow Christianity to occupy a prominent and privileged position in the public square--versus maintaining a strong separation of Church and State.  That dynamic motivated Bill to speak up and make a difference, primary by exposing the true origins of Judaism and Christianity, which are unknown to many.

We touched on his unique experience growing up in a Christian home with a Lutheran father and a Christian Scientist mother, and went on to talk through many topics Bill is passionate about, such as:

• Addressing the deep philosophical questions of life
• The ways that mythology has been institutionalized
• How to help people widen the lens of how they see the information regarding the origins of Christianity
• How the Bible's authors wrote stories after an event occurred and then claimed to have written a prophecy that got fulfilled
• The evolution of the Yahweh character
• The idea that "The smarter you are, the more clever the excuses you can make for the things you already believe"
• The power of worldview, and of what we unwittingly accept as axiomatic.
• How there were so many legends added to the Jesus story from the beginning that it's hard to tell which parts of the story have any basis in history
• How many other stories of other gods and mystery religions of that time were very similar to Christianity
• The evolution of Judaism and Christianity
• The apostle Paul's role in creating Christianity
• Presuppositionalism and the transcendental argument for god

Many thanks to Bill for his life-changing effect on my life, and for his impact in providing critical information about the pagan origins and mythological content of the Christian worldview.

___________________________________

episodes.title: Christianity deprives us of the ability to thrive - Sara Martin
episodes.description:
Today I was delighted to speak with Sara Martin, a musician and fellow Youtuber.  We discussed her journey growing up as a Christian, heavily exposed to Gospel messages and calls to ministry, attending a Christian college and going on mission trips, but eventually deconstructing her faith and deconverting from Christianity.

Throughout our discussion, we touched on:

• The general Christian goal of getting to heaven, and before that, living a life with god at the center, and fulfilling his plans for our lives.
• The Christian focus on being intentional and on fire for Christ, to not live an average life for God, and to make an impact for the kingdom of god.
• Struggling with self-esteem, even while knowing god loves us
• The perpetual guilt of not measuring up, not praying enough, etc.
• How Christianity becomes part of your identity, to the point that it is painful to disconnect from it when you eventually realize it's mythology, and deconvert.
• The psychology of Christian ideas.
• The ways that Christian college and missions trips can lead to deconversion, as they create disillusionment over the Christian worldview’s poor answers to life’s questions.
• The dynamic of Christians convincing themselves that they are sensing God's strength in situations that were really difficult, that god’s work was evident in their lives ("that was a god thing"), and how that causes Christians to look for “god moments,” and “god signs,” such as seeing god in rainbows, special cloud formations, life situations.
• How Christians assure themselves that they feel their god's peace and presence.
• How Christians think that their god is opening doors, but how that perspective falls apart badly as life situations don’t work out well at all.
• How it "wears you out" to live with the cognitive dissonance of Christianity, and how critical it is to prioritize our own mental well-being over that cognitive dissonance.
• Walking through deconstruction alone, not having safe places to talk about it and to ask honest questions about faith.
• The guilt and fear people grapple with over losing their faith, not wanting to be a heretic.
• How Christian faith falls apart.
• What it’s like to finally allowing ourselves to admit Christianity’s not real, to go "over the edge" and admit you no longer believe.
• Grappling with the idea that god has a plan for people's lives, even in contexts where entire generations faced genocide and extreme poverty.
• The ways that the purity culture shames people and drowns them in legalism and guilt.
• The unhealthiness of the Christian view of sexuality, the dangers of the ultra-modesty culture, how the desire for sexual pleasure is normal and appropriate, and how sex before marriage is not “sinful.”
• How Christianity deprives us of the ability to thrive.
• The hypocritical Christian message of god loves us, he hates us, and thus “I love myself, I hate myself.”
• Giving ourselves the right to say when something sounds wrong and no longer accepting pat answers.
• Pursuing the truth, wherever it leads us.
• The importance of living an authentic life.
• The final steps of deconversion.
• Walking away from Christianity and our "relationship" with Jesus.
• How Christianity is about blood magic and scapegoating.
• Why it makes no sense that "the soul that sins must die" versus just being forgiven.
• How bizarre the Bible is in light of its messages of genocide, slavery, misogyny, the psychopathic deity character, etc.
• How deconversion brings more peace than being a Christian.
• After deconversion, being able for the first time to see people for who they really are.
 
Thanks to Sara for sharing her story here today, and in more detail on her channel.  I look forward to continuing the discussion in the future.

episodes.title: HARMONIC ATHEIST - David LeBlanc - Walking away from the deeply flawed claims of Christianity
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with David LeBlanc about his story of walking away from Christianity when he realized that its fundamental claims are deeply flawed.

We discussed his deconstruction journey, starting with growing up Catholic, then moving into Protestantism via a Calvinistic church, then Calvary Chapel, and lastly into Messianic Judaism, before deconverting.

We dove into many parts of his story, focusing on topics related to deconstruction, such as: 

• The hypocrisy of the Catholic church.
• The ludicrous nature of the doctrines of blood magic and the Trinity.
• The discrepancies in the Bible.
• The quasi-intellectual side of Christianity.
• How religious groups see many critical questions as “off limits,” and why it’s important to ask the hard questions, despite push-back.
• The unspoken social construct in religious circles that followers must accept the narrative, even when it doesn't make sense.
• How increasingly extreme religious beliefs drive people to get involved in ministry + how imitation of Jesus and a call to be ultra-committed to him pulls people to more extremist lifestyles as proof of discipleship.
• The Christian call to “Come under authority,” “Suffer for Christ and the Gospel,” and “To not seek your own glory.”
• How Christianity is a performance-based narrative, despite the surface message of grace.
• How Christians will often oppose stories about magic and mythology, while concurrently embracing a book that is full of magic and mythology.
• The triumphalist view of Christians that their interpretation of Jewish writings was more accurate than Jewish interpretations.
• How the original Jesus movement leaders took Old Testament narratives and deceptively wrote the Jesus story to try to make it look like he had selectively fulfilled certain prophecies.
• The Christian distortions around Jesus being the Messiah.
• The arrogance of the mentality that "We're right and everyone else is wrong."
• How Christianity is a cult.

Thanks to David for sharing his story, including some of the more painful parts of it.  I appreciate your vulnerability.

______________________________

episodes.title: HARMONIC ATHEIST - Tiffani Cappello: How to Recognize and Reject Toxic Beliefs
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Tiffani Cappello, who shared her involvement with the Independent Fundamental Baptist Church, where instead of focusing on love, acceptance, reasoning, and logic, the primary messages were of self-denigration, worthlessness, and of how people are bad and broken.  

We walked through her story, up through her eventual deconversion from Christianity, followed by her work to help others heal from religious trauma.

Tiffani has become a Women's Empowerment Coach, Clinical Hypnotherapist, and a Rapid Transformational Therapist.  She runs the Transformed Women Academy, where she helps women address trauma and negative patterns, remove toxic stress, find happiness, and become empowered to do self-directed healing. 

Tiffani runs the Transformed Women Academy, where she helps women address trauma and negative patterns, remove toxic stress, find happiness, and become empowered to do self-directed healing.  Tiffani also helps oversee two FB groups: Transformed Women, and Former Fundamentalists.

We talked through:

 • The ramifications of telling people they are sinful and worthless, and that you're so bad that god has to kill his own son
 • Guilt and shame + judgmentalism in Christianity
 • Perfectionism
 • The danger of religious power without accountability
 • Hell: infinite punishment for finite crimes + the issue of those who die without having heard of Jesus
 • Cognitive dissonance
 • Positive psychology - what do people who are happy believe?
 • Core principles of psychological and emotional health
 • The abusiveness of the Christian worldview
 • The psychological effect of forcing yourself to believe that god is love, even though he does very unloving and abusive things.
 • The idea that if god says he requires blood, and he is in charge, why he doesn't also have the power to change that requirement.
 • Our ability to be deceived
 • Learning to question the narrative
 • How Christianity makes the world seem unsafe to children
 • The lack of peace that so many of us had as Christians, which we try to explain away.
 • Childhood psychological abuse
 • Healing from religious trauma
 • What toxic vs. healthy spiritualty looks like
 • Why Christianity is mythology


Thanks to Tiffani for sharing her story and insights.  Her heart to help those healing from religious trauma, and her desire to make a positive difference in our culture, shine through.

_______________________________________

episodes.title: HARMONIC ATHEIST - Andrew Jasko: Reclaiming our identity after religious indoctrination
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Andrew Jasko, a seminary-educated minister who ultimately left his religious faith and community.  He is now focused on helping others heal from religious trauma.

Andrew shared his background growing up in the Assemblies of God church and being groomed to become a minister and missionary.  He eventually questioned the content and philosophical implications of the Christian worldview and belief system, and deconverted.

Throughout our discussion, we touched on:

 • The traumatic, bedrock fear of the unending torture of hell as the motivation behind Christianity.
 • How to unwind the indoctrination and fears.
 • The premise of human beings fundamentally wicked.
 • The "identity theft" that occurs through religion and how it's difficult to see the psychopathic nature of the Yahweh character of the Old Testament when your identity is wrapped up in him, and the side effect of how those beliefs degrade our humanity.
 • The victim mentality and disempowered position that comes from seeing your identity, acceptance, safety, and power as coming from an outside source, through belief and obedience.
 • The danger of seeking solutions from a religious system, and of always concluding that the issue is ourselves, not our religious beliefs.
 • The idea that the Bible is a flawless communication from god, that you have to obey everything in it, and that you can't scrutinize and judge the god character.
 • Seeing sexuality as a curse where you are constantly trying to fight your urges.
 • Being programmed for severe repression on many levels.
 • The baseline of purity in thoughts and desires, especially in the area of sexuality, and the resulting guilt and shame trauma.
 • The Yahweh character being able to see every thought in our heads.
 • How religion enslaves us.
 • Outsourcing our power vs. standing in our own sovereignty.
 • The rude awakening of deconversion.
 • Committing ourselves to dealing directly with the bad ideas
 • Cultivating a non-judgmental, empathic awareness.
 • The psychology of believers, especially regarding the cognitive dissonance of Christianity.
 • How to approach theists who are stuck in an apologetics mindset.
 • Having grace with ourselves through the healing process, so that we truly give ourselves the time, freedom, and patience to heal.
 • Integrating all aspects of ourselves.
 • The role of religious trauma counseling, as well as meditation.
 • Non-dual humanism.


Thanks to Andrew for the many ways he helps others heal and reclaim their identity after religious indoctrination.

__________________________________

episodes.title: Harmonic Atheist - Tammie Willis - Escaping the Independent Fundamental Baptist Church Cult
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Tammie Willis, who shared her story of growing up in the Independent Fundamental Baptist Church cult.  She described the ways that the church psychologically abuses people, especially children, as it tries to indoctrinate them into the mythology of Christianity.

We discussed the negative results of the purity culture movement, and touched on the ways that threatening kids with hell and instilling in them a fear of the end times, i.e., being "left behind," creates an extremely toxic environment.  We zoomed out a bit as well to talk about the larger context of how the church blinds people people from critical information and alternative perspectives, and ultimately impairs people's ability to think critically and keeps them from questioning the Judeo-Christian narrative.

We moved on to discuss how ongoing experiences with Christians can trigger those of us who have escaped, and how we should deal with those situations and emotions, as well as the broader issue of healing from religious trauma.

We ended by talking about the beauty of life without religion, about the joy of embracing reality, and about how to reframe the narrative of our lives once we are free from the Christian cult environment.

Thanks to Tammie for her vulnerability and power in sharing her story and helping others to think through these critical issues, as they reclaim their life and identity.

**This video was taken before Christmas, but due to my backlog in processing videos, I am posting it later than anticipated.

episodes.description:

Kevin shared how becoming educated about the psychological dynamics of mind control and fabricated authority helped him understand the power of religion, and why it's so hard for many to escape Christianity, especially when it starts in the context of childhood indoctrination.

We finished by talking about the topic of astrotheology that both Kevin and I are very interested in, as we uncover how the Bible is full of stories that are based on an understanding of the sun, moon, constellations, solstices, and equinoxes.

episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Dr. Marlene Winell, the author of the book "Leaving the Fold - A Guide for Former Fundamentalists and Others Leaving their Religion."

We discussed Dr. Winell's story of growing up in a Christian family, and her journey through deconversion.  We walked through the ways her personal background and professional experience provided a backdrop for her to speak to and help others walk through the dynamics of healing from religious trauma.

We touched on how people learn to move past toxic religious ideas and theology as they process the feelings of deconversion and heal from the scars.  We talked through how we learn to trust ourselves and acknowledge that we aren't bad just because we don't subscribe to the mythology of Christianity.

We ended by talking about the ways that childhood indoctrination into Christianity is abusive, especially as it creates a trapped feeling in children, where they are forced to believe and follow certain rules, despite the profound damage it does and the cognitive dissonance it requires.

Thank you, Dr. Winell, for sharing some of your story as well as your passion and skill for walking people out of the darkness of religion, and into the resulting healing, peace, personal growth, and thriving that occurs.  I can't wait to speak with you again!

Today I spoke with Tyler, who shared his journey out of Christianity.  We walked through his childhood and young adulthood, which were passionately focused on the Bible, the Gospel, ministry, and missions.

Tyler shared how his time with New Tribes Mission / Ethnos 360 created an environment in which various classes, experiences, and theological issues led him to deconstruct his faith, and to eventually--and joyfully--leave Christianity behind.

As Leslie investigated the claims of the Bible and Christianity in depth, his Christian beliefs and worldview dissolved as he realized it was mythology, and full of discrepancies, errors, and ridiculous claims.  We talked through the bravery and sometimes immense upheaval that is part of the deconversion process, and how painful it is to see others who still believe the Bible is true and that god is real.

Thanks to Bill for his insights and wisdom.  I can't wait to dive deeper into how the writers of the Gospel of Mark wove the zodiac through the narrative.

episodes.title: Harmonic Atheist - Interview with David Rich
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with David Rich, author of books such as "Myths of the Tribe" and "Scribes of the Tribe."

David and I took some time to discuss his early exit from Christianity.  He recognized as a very young man that the Christian worldview is full of fraudulent, misleading claims, that it is psychologically abusive, and that it prevents people from seeing reality, and instead provides a social construct bubble that is difficult to leave.  We discussed how myths can hamper reason and incite violence.

In his book "Myths of the Tribe," David promotes a rational analysis of all problems in the light of objective scientific evidence, a system of ethics that allows complete individual liberty constrained only by the principle of harming no one else, taking personal responsibility for one’s own welfare and actions, and the absence of government control over the pursuit of happiness.  In his book "Scribes of the Tribe," David shares insights from great thinkers throughout the ages.

Thanks to David for his writing and speaking, and for his efforts for the atheist community.

episodes.title: Harmonic Atheist - The deconversion story of Hannah Timson
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Hannah Timson, the former President at Humanist Students UK.

Hannah joined me previously for a discussion with Mike Lawrence regarding the subject of the abusiveness of childhood indoctrination, but today we talked through Hannah's deconversion story.

We focused on the early cracks in the foundation of her Christian beliefs, the issues and crucial questions that came to the forefront as she worked through whether or not the Bible stories were real or mythological, and the implications.  We discussed her final steps toward deconversion, her exit from Christianity, and what it looks like to live a life free from a pretend deity and worldview, and from the horrific and bizarre teachings of the Bible and Christianity.

episodes.title: Harmonic Atheist - Interview with Dr. Justin Sledge of Esoterica
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Dr. Justin Sledge of the Youtube channel Esoterica, which explores "the arcane side of history, philosophy, and religion."

We discussed the Book of Enoch, the influence of the Greco-Roman/Mystery cults on Christianity, 
the Essenes, the Gnostics, ancient cosmology/aeons, the Zodiac, angelology, the Archons and Metatron, Jewish mystical visions, Kabbalah, and the overall context of the Jesus Movement and its origins, in a 1st century Jewish perspective.

We also spent some time discussing the Christ-Myth theory, and how likely it was that there was an actual man at the start of Christianity, or whether it was part of the mystical visions mythology, with Jesus being euhemerized later as the Gospels began to be written, based on rewrites of Greek epic works.

Thanks to Dr. Sledge for his time, expertise, and balanced perspectives on all these topics.  I love his channel--please subscribe and support him!  His amazing work is relevant and crucial to the Mythicist community.

episodes.title: Harmonic Atheist - Interview with Maria Gernand: Deconstruction and Healing from Religious Trauma
episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Maria Gernand about her deconstruction and the process of healing from religious trauma.

Maria shared her story of growing up in Guatemala in a Baptist church, how Jesus was the love of her life, and how she felt drawn to be a missionary to those who had never heard the Gospel.

Over the years, as she looked deeper into the Bible and Christianity, it slowly became clear that its truth claims were not real.  We walked through the ways we both had tried to defend, excuse, and reconcile the bizarre, cultish beliefs of Christianity, instead of seeing it as it is: the blood magic death cult focused on human sacrifice, scapegoating, and hell.

We talked about the Bible's message of humanity's sinfulness, about constantly trying to please a pretend god, and about how some people may be intellectually ready to let go of religious ideas, but still not emotionally ready.  We also touched on the residual effects of having previously been a Christian, and how we have to give ourselves the patience and grace to learn how to embrace reality, love others, redeem our time, and live our lives without Christian mythology.

We discussed how to support others wherever they are in their journey, and giving people space and sensitivity to think through these issues and investigate for themselves the origins of the Bible and Christianity.

We wrapped up talking about the dangers of psychological abuse of childhood indoctrination into Christianity, and about the importance of raising kids without a mythological worldview and a fear of a mythological hell.

Many thanks for Maria for her openness and vulnerability in our interview, and for the other subjects she covers on her own channel.


__________________________

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCEU4E6IRIfgIu4IVG4QvLNQ

episodes.description:
Today I was honored to speak with Mike Lawrence, author of the book "70".  Mike is a researcher focused on the historicity and reliability of the Bible, especially the Gospel narratives.   He is also an activist, focused on trying to expose and stop the damage done by compulsory childhood religious indoctrination.

We discussed the historicity--or lack thereof--for Jesus, and what was going on at that time in history, especially the Temple destruction, that caused various Jewish sects to need to come up with an alternative way to deal with sin that still focused on blood magic atonement.


Our discussion was fascinating, and we touched on many topics, including astrotheology, religious brainwashing, and ending with some counsel for Christians who are on the verge of deconverting, who are realizing and admitting to themselves that it is mythology.


Thanks to Mike for his strong voice in these discussions.  He has been an inspiration to me, and I deeply appreciate his work and his clarity of thought as he presents many years' worth of research.

episodes.title: Harmonic Atheist - Dr. Steve Mason addresses Jesus Mythicism
episodes.description:
Today I was honored again to speak with Dr. Steve Mason, Distinguished Professor of Ancient Mediterranean Religions and Cultures at the University of Groningen.

Dr. Mason and I addressed several aspects of Jesus Mythicism, which I deeply appreciated.  We touched on the absence of historical information about Jesus in the letters of Paul, and whether Paul is anticipating the first, or second, coming of Jesus, in 1 Thessalonians 4:13-17.

We praised the voices in the Mythicist-Historicist conversation that are bringing valuable and insightful information to the forefront.  We also agreed that we all need to focus on mutual respect as we find points where we disagree, or areas where each of us chooses to focus our research. 

Ultimately, we agree that whether there was "a guy" at the start of Christianity, it is heavily built up with legend and mythology that needs to be studied and understood, in its proper context, in order to understand the origins of Christianity.

We also discussed Josephus, but saved a discussion on the Testimonium Flavinium for another time.  During today's conversation about Josephus, we focused on:

--James the brother of Jesus
--The ways that the author of the Gospel of Luke knew and used two of Josephus' books: Jewish War, and Jewish Antiquities.

Dr. Mason's expertise and insights regarding the Bible, Josephus, Jesus, and the cultures of that time are enlightening, and his desire to bring balance to these discussions shines through.  He always does an excellent job at explaining the role of a historian when investigating early Christianity. 

Thanks again to Dr. Mason for his time.  I excitedly look forward to a discussion on the Testimonium Flavinium in the future!

______________________________________


Dr. Mason's books may be purchased here:
https://www.amazon.com/Steve-Mason/e/B01HVVIDJK

https://www.rug.nl/staff/s.mason/

episodes.description:
Today I spoke with Dr. Michael Kochenash, an American New Testament scholar and a postdoctoral research fellow in Christian studies at Hunan University, China.  

His research explores the meaning of early Christian and early Jewish narratives—especially the canonical book of Acts, but also the Gospel of Luke, the Gospel of Judas, Joseph and Aseneth, the book of Judith, and the Protevangelium of James in their ancient Mediterranean contexts.

Dr. Kochenash and I discussed his faith journey, his experience teaching in an evangelical university, mimesis in the Bible, and his upcoming book, "Roman Self-Representation and the Lukan Kingdom of God."

Thank you, Dr. Kochenash, for sharing your thoughts on all these subjects.  I look forward to digging deeper into mimesis with you in the future!

episodes.description:
I had a blast speaking with Derreck Bennett as he shared an overview of his deconversion story, his recovery from alcoholism, and his work in comparative religion and Jesus mythicism.

Throughout the discussion, we touched on many topics, ending with a few suggestions for people who are realizing that Christianity is mythology, and want to dig deeper into the origins of the Bible and Christianity.

I am looking forward to bouncing ideas off Derreck in the future and hearing more about his work and writing.  Many thanks to him for taking the time with me today for this introductory video.

episodes.title: Harmonic Atheist - Interview with Lindsey Articolo
episodes.description:
In today's interview, I spoke with Lindsey Articolo, a friend who grew up as a Christian.  She is working through what she believes as she studies various topics related to the Bible.

In our discussion, Lindsey shared some of her story about growing up in a conservative Christian environment, gradually being open to new ideas that challenged her faith in various ways, and learning more about the origins the canon of the Bible and of Christianity.

We went down a few rabbit trails, but kept the focus coming back to becoming increasingly better educated in all these subjects.  We chatted about what it means to be on a path of rationality vs. blind acceptance of what we were taught as children.

We will check back in from time to time, by video interviews, with updates on our journeys.

episodes.title: Harmonic Atheist - Interview with Derek Lambert of MythVision
episodes.description:
I had a blast speaking with Derek Lambert, of MythVision, as he shared an overview of his deconversion story.  

Throughout the discussion, we skimmed through a few concepts related to mythology, the psychology of faith, the amazing experience of escaping from the Bible/Christianity prison and seeing reality for the first time, and being proactive in getting information out to people who don't really know the truth about how Christianity formed.  

Looking forward to taking it to the next level soon in our future talks.  Many thanks to Derek, both for the video and for his behind-the-scenes support. 

Please visit Derek's MythVision channel at: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCWVCimOe67LOfyi9PjUeGgA

episodes.title: Harmonic Atheist - Interview with David Fitzgerald
episodes.description:
My very first interview! David Fitzgerald graciously gave his time to discuss various topics related to deconversion from Christianity, atheism, and mythicism.  We touched on the parallels, astrotheology, and numerology found in the Bible, as well as my desire to get more involved in the atheist and mythicist causes. He has been one of my heroes, so I was honored to talk directly with him, and to receive his encouragement for my journey thus far, and for my forthcoming efforts in all these areas.


Mentioned in the video:

Bill Zuersher, Seeing Through Christianity
